column2: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP)-- Manufacturers of plastic articles streamed before the Senate Small Business Committee today to press their claim for the raw materials they said they must have to stay in business.

MOSCOW, Jan. 23 (AP)--The United States, France and Britain delivered notes to the Soviet Union this evening that opened a new cycle in nearly three months of discussion on whether there would be another four-power foreign ministers' council.

The "revised" Chinese Communist terms for a settlement in Korea, as reported indirectly to the United Nations by the Indian delegate, Sir Benegal Rau, express a willingness to agree to "a cease-fire for a limited time-period" as a preliminary to negotiations by a seven-nation group ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP)-- Representative Howard H. Buffett, Republican of Nebraska, raised the question today whether the proposed new defense housing bill would be used to expand what he called the Government's "socialized housing program."

CHICAGO, Jan 23--Grain prices were unsettled on the Board of Trade today. Removal of hedges against export sales caused an early upturn in wheat and corn but selling pressure developed and the markets reacted quickly with considerable profit-taking as the ...

ALBANY, Jan. 23--As the trucking industry girded to fight against imposition of new taxes on trucks, Senator George T. Manning, chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Highway and Canal Use, said today that any new tax imposed would apply at first only to the heavier motor freight carriers.

LAWSON ROBERTSON was born in Scotland but he was to become a track coach on six American Olympic teams, the acknowl edged, respected and beloved dean of his profession. Robbie died the other day after a long and distinguished career, mast of it at the University of Pennsylvania. However, the one thing which had the most profound influence on him was the fabulous Irish-American A.C.

DETROIT, Jan. 23--Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., served notice today that his union was planning a campaign to win a guaranteed annual wage for its 1,250,000 members.
ALBANY, Jan. 23--The Senate unanimously confirmed today Governor Dewey's nomination of Emil N. Baar of Brooklyn as a Supreme Court justice for the Second Judicial District.
A weekly pay rise of $4.80 for 120,000 city employes earning less than $7,500 a year does not do justice to their needs and does not constitute an adequate solution.

Provided they do not block their own progress, fur manufacturers should experience a good year, it was said last night by Adolph Lieblich, president of the Associated Fur Manufacturers, Inc. He spoke at the organization's thirtyninth annual meeting in the Statler Hotel.

PUSAN, Korea, Jan. 23--Pressure is being applied on South Korean officials by United States economic experts here to speed the enforcement of land reform laws as concrete proof to the Korean people that they have nothing to gain from Communist promises of land redistribution.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 23 (AP) --Gen. Bob Neyland today received a life-time contract to continue as head football coach of Tennessee.
The New York Yacht Club will begin the Newport to Annapolis ocean race on June 17 and its annual cruise from a new location, Fishers Island, on Aug. 6, according to sailing plans made public ...

Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., in a suit filed yesterday in Federal Court, charged that a former employe gave confidential information regarding its color television system to Allen B. Du Mont Laboratories, Inc., in breach of trust.

William W. Remington contradicted in Federal Court yesterday his former wife's testimony that he had told her he was a member of the Communist party and that she had made him promise to remain a Communist as a condition of their marriage.

Charles Munch will share the podium with Serge Koussevitzky at the Boston Symphony Orchestra's 1951. Berkshire Festival, which will run from July 7 to Aug. 12. As in the past, it will be held at Tanglewood, the estate near Lenox, Mass., that has been the festival's home since 1937.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--The House passed unanimously and sent to the Senate today a bill designed to recapture excessive profits on defense orders by authorizing the renegotiation of Government contracts. Action was by a roll-call vote of 377 to 0.
BOSTON, Jan. 23--John E. Burton, chairman of the New York State Power Authority, asserted here today that his state would discourage any effort to federalize its natural resources.

Governor Dewey paid tribute to the 259th Anti-Aircraft Artillery Gun Battalion, which was federalized yesterday in a ceremony in their armory in Fourteenth Street. He called for preparedness because "the Communists have no intentions of letting up on us."

CHICAGO, Jan. 23--Mounting problems of the construction industry in the face of sharp cutbacks in civilian home building and uncertainties over supplies under defense restrictions were outlined here at today's sessions of the annual convention of the National Association of Home Builders.

Luke Vincent Lockwood, lawyer, author and antiquarian, who was president of the Municipal Art Commission of New York, from 1944 until his resignation in 1947, died-yesterday at his home on Lake Avenue, Greenwich, Conn., after a long illness. He would have been 79 years old on Feb. 1.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--Pleas from the Director of the Budget and the Secretaries of the Treasury and Commerce that President Truman receive the blanket war powers he requests to reorganize Federal departments and agencies appeared to fall on deaf ears today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--Maj. Gen. Floyd Parks, chief of Army information, tonight acknowledged authorship of a confidential message to Army commands on rules governing public utterances of officers but denied any intent to "gag" military personnel, as had ...
Charles Nessler, originator of the permanent wave process, died Monday of a heart attack at his home in Harrington Park, N.J. His age was 78. He also invented false eyelashes.

Following the action taken by the National Collegiate Athletic Association in dropping Sanity Code control of financial aid to athletes at its convention in Dallas earlier this month, the Eastern College Athletic Conference yesterday reaffirmed its own ...

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 23--For a fortunate few in the crowd of 14,910 at Hialeah today, the fourth race was the main event. In fact, it will go into some memory books as the race of the year. In that sixfurlong number, a $5,000 claimer, a gallant steed named Sir Walter R. won at $190.40 and a filly named Queen Zac placed at $113.20.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 23 (AP) --The National Association of State Racing Commissioners was warned today that Congress probably would attempt to impose a Federal tax on pari-mutuel racing in its efforts to raise funds to meet the expanded emergency budget.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 23-- Miss Gwynneth Clifton Hamilton was married here this evening to Robert Arthur Collett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur B. Collett of Evanston, Ill., in the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick E. Hamilton. The Rev. Osborne Budd performed the ceremony.
Trading in cotton futures on the Exchange here was moderately active yesterday, and closing prices were near the best levels of the day, 2 to 40 points net higher than on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--Loans totaling $50,000,000 to the Union of South Africa for electric power and transport facilities were announced today by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 23--The newest indication of the growing international interests in decorative arts for the home is an exposition that opened here this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, today appointed Clark Tibbitts as chairman of the agency's committee on aging and geriatrics, which will en deavor to gear the skills of older persons to the nation's mobilization program.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP)-- Senator Herbert R. O'Conor said today that American aid funds had been used by some Western European nations to send materials useful in war to nations behind the Iron Curtain.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 23--Foreign Minister Moshe Sharett informed the Knesset (Parliament) today that the signature of a pact with the United States for Point Four aid was imminent.

An investment syndicate headed by Shields Co. will offer today a new issue of $15,300,000 of public electric revenue bonds of the South Carolina Public Service Authority at prices ranging from one to yield 1.50 per cent to a dollar price of 101 for 2.70 per cent bonds due in 1993. The bonds are exempt from Federal income taxes.
The eleven Democratic legislators from Queens have decided to oppose the setting up at this time of a tax-exempt Long Island Transit Authority to run the Long Island Rail Road.

MANILA, Jan. 23--United States Government officials and neutral observers here are assuming an attitude of "cautious" optimism toward the recently renewed Philippine military campaign against the Communist-led Hukbalahap rebellion.

BOSTON, Jan. 23--The scrapping of 1,000 Liberty ships built during World War II, and now laid up, and the building of 300 highspeed cargo vessels were urged today by the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C.I.O.

After a three-week absence, Coach Adolph Rupp has guided his Kentucky Wildcats back to the top of the national basketball rankings, but the Bluegrass lads got a stiff argument from Long Island University.

Leaders of professional athletic teams here and throughout the country were quick to rally yesterday behind the statement of Secretary of Defense George C. Marshall that athletes who fail to pass selective service physicals may be drafted for non-combat jobs.

The trial of Harry Gross ended abruptly yesterday in the Brooklyn Court of Special Sessions when the gambler pleaded guilty to a sixty-six-count criminal information charging him with bookmaking and conspiracy to violate the gambling laws.

The Museum of Modern Art will open to the public today its exhibition, "Abstract Painting and Sculpture in America," comprising a survey of characteristic directions in the field since the Armory Show of 1913.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Jan. 23--The Netherlands Government announced tonight the dismissal of Gen. Hendrik J. Kruls as chief of the Army General Staff.
Totally and permanently disabled workers in the men's and boys' clothing industry will now be covered by pensions on an industrywide basis.

The city's program for imposing a wide variety of new taxes to finance $30,000,000 a year in wage bonuses for city employes and an expected $87,800,000 rise in the 1951-52 budget got a cool reception here and in Albany yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--The Administration was putting finishing touches tonight on a broad program of price, wage and production controls that it will apply to the economy in the all-out defense production program.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--The split between the United States and most of the rest of the Atlantic nations over Far Eastern policy has reached a critical point in the last few days.

Lawrence Vita, president of Vita Automatic Windows, Inc., yesterday announced the election of five new directors. They are Raymond C. Shepherd, former vice president of the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn; John Oakley, president ...

The first thing to examine, in considering the amended reply of the Chinese Communists to the cease-fire proposal of the Truce Commission, is whether it brings nearer a settlement of the Korean conflict that vindicates the intervention of the United Nations.

The drive by Federal and local authorities on narcotics sellers in this city was praised yesterday as a "paralyzing body blow" to the illicit commerce as twelve suspects were arraigned in Felony Court.

"King Richard II," opening at 8:15 this evening at the City Center, is the third and final fortnightly offering in the bargainpriced series of the New York City Theatre Company's six-week winter season. It will be the second of the Bard's works on the boards, the other one being the reprieved "King Lear."
HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 23-- Joe Adonis and four of his gambling associates in New Jersey and New York were among seven men indicted today by the special Bergen County grand jury on gambling.

Agreement has been reached one an employer-financed welfare plan providing $100,000,000 of group life insurance and hospital disability benefits for the 40,000 members of the National Maritime Union, C.I.O.

The stock market ran into one of those snags yesterday that did little to give a hint as to the immediate outlook. Prices, except in a few instances, were held within limited bounds although losses incurred in the morning shrank under afternoon buying.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--Secretary of Defense George C. Marshall told the House Armed Services Committee today that in his opinion the Korean situation would not have occurred had Congress passed the Universal Military Training Bill in 1948.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--The Senate unanimously called on the United Nations today to reject Communist China's demand for membership and instead to denounce that regime as an aggressor in Korea.
Playwrights, theatrical producers, actors and actresses were among the 500 persons who attended a funeral service yesterday for Dwight Deere Wiman, New York producer for the last twentyfive years.

ON THE CENTRAL KOREAN FRONT, Jan. 23--The series of engagements around Wonju in the central mountains of Korea have proved the superiority of the now battle-seasoned American troops to the reconstituted North Korean Communist forces, observers here believe.

ALBANY, Jan. 23--Several important revisions in Governor Dewey's defense emergency bill were in prospect as the result of criticism voiced today by representatives of local governments at a three-hour conference with Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP)-- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation reported today its program for achieving a $5,000,000 annual saving in operating costs will go into "full effect" on March 1.

Plans for the erection of a new lower Manhattan building to house concerns in the shipping business were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of four old warehouses at 162 Maiden Lane, 71 to 74 South Street and 35 Depeyster Street by the Hudson Releasing Corporation to New Jersey interests.
Now that the tour of the horizon, as the French put it, is nearly over, Americans might pause to think of the tremendous responsibility they placed upon General Eisenhower's shoulders.
Top officials in the American Nurses Association took a unanimous stand yesterday against the proposed Equal Rights Amendment, which has been before every Congress for twenty-seven years.

A plot of about three acres at Stiles Street and Linden Avenue in Linden, N.J., has been sold by the United New Jersey Railroad and Canal Company to Howard and Lettia Sober of Lansing, Mich., in a transaction negotiated by the James H. Burns Company, broker.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23--Identical telegrams asserting that the meat and livestock industry was "greatly disturbed by the gravity of the situation confronting us and the threat of a program of controls" were sent tonight to Charles E. Wilson, director of the Office of ...

A proposed innovation in the presentation of evidence in the Government's anti--trust suit against certain investment banking houses moved Federal Judge Harold R. Medina yesterday to tell the lawyers that he has reached the point where he cannot sleep nights because of his preoccupation with the many issues of the trial.
Henry Curtis Blackiston, former American managing director of Furness, Withy Co., Ltd., British steamship owners and operators, died yesterday at his home in Hampton, Va., after a long illness.
Dr. Hermann Borchardt, philosopher and author, died of a heart attack yesterday morning at his home, 110 Morningside Drive. He was 62 years old.

Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Franz Pick, now living in Berlin, formerly of Dresden, Germany, have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Erika Elizabeth Maria, to John Hudson Hall Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hall of Nunataks, Hartsdale, N.Y., and the Manor House, Morris, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--President Truman created a Commission on Internal Security and Individual Rights today and directed it to tackle in a nonpartisan way the bitter controversy over loyalty and the related problems of treason, espionage and sabotage.

Engineers for leading public utility companies in New York and other American cities appeared confident here yesterday that they could continue to give near-normal service even if this nation were attacked with atomic weapons.

A departmental trial was ordered yesterday for Patrolman William A. Tierney of the West Forty-seventh Street station on charges that he had maltreated a 21-year-old youth while arresting him on New Year's night for disorderly conduct.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--The ranking Republican of the Senate Committee on Appropriations, Senator Styles Bridges of New Hampshire, called on President Truman today to take back his record budget and submit a "realistic" one in its place.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--In another move to reduce the turnover of Army personnel, foreign service tours of all soldiers were extended today for another six months. Indefinite extension of Far East duty was continued.

For the, second consecutive day, wool prices advanced the daily permissible limit of 10 cents a pound in the futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange. The limit advance ranged "across the board," including all active deliveries in both wool tops and grease wool.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 23-- The American Federation of Labor today urged Congress to adopt a new "and workable price control law which will permit effective stabilization of the cost of living."

SAIGON, Indo-China, Jan. 23-- The big part that United States supplies had played in last week's successful French-Vietnamese defense against the all-out Vietminh attack in Tongking was emphasized here today at a press conference by Gen. de Lattre de Tassigny, French Commander in Chief in Indo-China.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 23--Asian and Arab states tonight outlined a "middle road" plan for calling a preliminary conference to try to work out the basis of a Korean cease-fire and "clarify" Communist China's counter-proposals to the United Nations.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 23--Something of a diplomatic mystery developed today about messages passing to and from the Chinese Communist Government in Peiping.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 24-- Tank-led United Nations forces yesterday thrust five miles north of the battered city of Wonju in the central mountains of Korea, scoring their deepest penetration back toward the Thirty-eighth Parallel since the fall of the Republican capital of Seoul.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 24 (AP) --Eighth Army communique 145, issued today at 10:15 A.M. (8:15 P.M. Tuesday, Eastern standard time):

How the color found in a pleasing drapery print may be the basis for the entire room's color scheme is emphasized in four model room settings now on display at James McCreery Co. The conventional furniture pieces from Drexel's ...
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 23 (AP)--Miss Marge Lindsay of Decatur, Ill., covered the Miami Country Club course is 72 strokes, four under ...

A surprise raid resulted yesterday in the arrest of five men on charges that they had raised $13,000 by fraudulently representing that the money would help build a youth center in Israel, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 23--Mayor Impellitteri's proposals for increased state aid and local taxing powers for New York City met a cool reception from Republicans and Democrats in the Legislature today.

A fifty-year-old veteran of the sea, the Israeli-flag, vessel Atzmaut, member of the khost fleet of ships that ferried immigrants into Palestine during the struggle for independence, has been sold for scrap, it was learned yesterday.

In his talk here before the New York Board of Trade we believe that Secretary of the Treasury Snyder was invading the domain of the Federal Reserve System when he undertook to states what the rates on Government securities were going to be in the years immediately ahead.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 23--A detailed blueprint for Protestant unity, designed to bring together into one church nine denominations and one association of churches, was made public here today at the opening session of a two-day conference on church union.
Remington Rand, Inc., established new sales records for the last quarter of 1950 and increased profits by $3,839,868 in the nine months ended on Dec. 31, it was reported yesterday.

Stepping up its drive for recruits, the City Office of Civil Defense announced yesterday that beginning Friday it would distribute 500,000 copies of a thirty-fourpage booklet emphasizing the need for volunteers, describing their duties and listing enrollment offices.

Top state and city officials are expected to testify before the Senate Crime Investigating Committee when it begins inquiring into charges made in the 1950 election campaign of an alliance in this city between crime and politics.

Top state and city officials are expected to testify before the Senate Crime Investigating Committee when it begins inquiring into charges made in the 1950 election campaign of an alliance in this city between crime and politics.
BILOXI, Miss., Jan. 23--Immediate announcement by the Government of a defense stockpiling program for cotton was urged here today at the annual meeting of the National Cotton Council.

One of the largest personal collections of jewels to be brought into this country in recent years by an alien visitor arrived in New York Monday aboard the liner Brazil, it was learned yesterday. The jewels were not insured.

With consumer income showing a net increase of more than $11,000,000,000 for the first six months of 1951, the spring season will be the largest in history for retailers, according to Edward Schwarz, vice president and general manager of Amos Parrish Co., Inc., ...

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 23 --Progress toward rearmament of Western Germany, considered a "matter of urgency" by the Western foreign ministers at Brussels a month ago, has been negligible, though officials of the United States High Commissioner's office ...

ALBANY, Jan. 23--The State Conservation Department reported today that the work of clearing storm-felled timber from 240,000 acres of Adirondack forest preserve would get under way within a week in an effort to reduce fire hazards quickly there.
Preparing a lunch that's as attractive as it is economical is no problem for 10-year-old Janet Bonomo, first-prive winner in the Children's Aid Society's annual Nourishing Meals contest.

ALBANY, Jan. 23--Resolutions calling for a legislative veto of the rent control plan proposed by State Rent Administrator Joseph D. McGoldrick were submitted to the Legislature today by the two Democratic leaders and Senator William Bianchi, Republican ...

The supply of concentrates needed badly by primary slab zinc producers and makers of zinc pigments is 133,000 tons short of the 980,000 tons required to maintain the present rate of production, according to a report issued yesterday by the American Zinc Institute.

Both good and bad news came out of the Brooklyn Dodgers' offices yesterday. On the bright side was the signing of Roy Campanella, league's leading catcher, to a 1951 contract that will bring him more than $18,000.

Peg Fischer, in her spring collection yesterday at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel, gave ample proof of her knowledge of creating pretty hats. A youthful pointed crown, called Balinese, gave distinction to pillboxes, sleek deep-fitting caps, jaunty cloches and a bumper breton of snowy white faced with navy velvet.

The United States, Britain and France have sent identical new notes to Moscow in which they continue to insist that discussions at a new conference of the Foreign Ministers of the four Powers should not be limited to Germany but should embrace other outstanding problems now causing ...
As the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies swings into the closing ten days of its 1950-51 campaign New Yorkers of all faiths might well think for a moment what this great ...

LONDON, Jan. 23--Britain will go so far and no farther in condemning Communist Chinese aggression in Korea, Prime Minister Attlee told a troubled Commons today when it met after a long Christmas holiday.
A serious shortage of engineers, technicians and some types of skilled labor faces the aircraft manufacturing industry of the United States as it swings into the rearmament effort.

Directors of the Erie Railroad at a meeting here yesterday authorized the purchase of 500 gondola cars and 500 box cars, expected to cost about $6,400,000. The company also reported for 1950 a net income ...

Normal advertising schedules should be continued through the emergency, whether or not advertisers are engaged in Government work and out of their normal market. This advice was contained yesterday in an analysis of the tax and legislative situation in Washington sent to its members by the Association of National Advertisers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23--The Senate voted today to cite for contempt eight men who refused to answer questions put to them by its Crime Investigating Committee at hearings in the last several weeks. The cited witnesses were:
A large audience--one of the season's largest--assembled last night in Town Hall to listen to an evening of chamber music by Beethoven. The Albenerl Trio was

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24-- Ninety-eight members of the Senate and House joined today in sponsorship of bills designed to force an increase in the strength of the Marine Corps to at least 400,000 men and give it direct representation on the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

A retired deputy chief inspector in the Police Department returned yesterday to the holdover grand I jury in Brooklyn an unanswered financial questionnaire and then sought to withdraw the waiver of immunity he had signed at an earlier appearance before the panel.

L.C. Smith Corona Typewriters, Inc., yesterday introduced at a New York branch meeting in the Governor Clinton Hotel, what it claims is an entirely new kind of standard carriage typewriter. Limited quantity deliveries will begin next month and the machine is priced at $157.50, according to F. A. DeManche, branch manager.

ALBANY, Jan. 24--Democratic legislative leaders today called for extensive revisions of the state's unemployment insurance and workmen's compensation laws that would involve raising the benefits paid under both systems to reflect the increased cost of living.

TOKYO, Thursday, Jan.25-- United Nations forces yesterday scored their deepest penetration back toward the Thirty-eighth Parallel--the old boundary between the Korean Republic and the Communist north--fighting their way into Hoengsong, thirtythree airline miles below the border in central Korea.

Announcement by President Truman that he is appointing a commission to investigate the twin problems of protecting internal security and of safeguarding individual freedom comes not a, day too soon. In fact, our only crit

William W. Remington told a Federal Court jury yesterday that he never gave Elizabeth T.Bentley, former Soviet spy courier, any secret or classified information, and that he never knew her as anything but a researcher for newspaper men.

LONDON, Jan. 24--A letter protesting against the critical meat shortage in Britain as a result of the deadlock in British-Argentine trade negotiations was sent by London butchers today to Prime Minister Attlee.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24--A five-hour conference on a wage increase for eastern Pennsylvania's 75,000 hard-coal miners broke up here this afternoon with John L. Lewis and the operators 20 cents apart as to the amount of the proposed daily increase.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--The House of Representatives passed today by 390 to 0 a bill to provide free insurance of $10,000 for all persons on active duty in the armed services.

Planning for the expansion of its present facilities, Joseph H. Gray, Inc., Pontiac automobile agent, has purchased a vacant interior plot 35 by 105 feet on the east side of Long Beach Avenue, 213.50 feet north of Pine Street, in Freeport, L.I, from Dr. Jules M. Nova. The

There were moments yesterday when Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, saw only four Schofield children in front of his desk. But George, the fifth member of the family, had a good reason for slipping from view.
PARIS, Jan. 24--Approval by the French Cabinet today of a policy of conciliation in the international situation was evidenced by three major developments:

LONDON, Jan. 24-The stock markets here were unsettled today by the divergence of view between the United States and Britain on the question of Communist China and the further official warning of threatened fuel crisis. Although there was little selling, prices tended to weaken in most sections.
The Italians will enter the whaling field next year with a new factory ship, one of the largest in the world, it was learned yesterday.
Eleonora Mendelssohn, actress and great-granddaughter of Felix Mendelssohn, the composer, was found dead yesterday morning in her third-floor apartment at 173 East Seventy-third Street.

Private placement financing last year rose to a new high peak of $3,391,279,908, according to a tabulation just published by the Investment Dealers' Digest. The total of the private deals involved 830 transactions, according to the count taken by the trade publication, or at the rate of sixteen a week. There are, of course, many

The forces which have brought interest rates on bank loans to a higher level are likely to continue their upward pressure, S. Sloan Colt, president of Bankers Trust Company, told stockholders yesterday. Speaking at the annual meeting, Mr. Colt explained that higher

TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 24--The question of Near East defense Will be on the agenda of a regional conference of United States diplomatic chiefs in Istanbul next month. About the same time, Gen. Sir Brian Robertson, British Middle East army commander, will pay what is officially described as a "courtesy visit" to Israel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--Dr. Donald Horton, a Chicago, sociologist speaking for the National Association of Educational Broadcasters, declared today before the Federal Communications Commission that New York City was not well served by its video stations.

A diamond cutter from Brooklyn was arrested at Logan International Airport in Boston yesterday, charged with attempting to smuggle $50,000 to $60,000 worth of gold out of this country, as Federal officials in New York pushed their investigation into international diamond smuggling.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 24--The fifth choice was the right choice in the $10,090 Palm Beach Handicap at Hialeah today. That one was the Cross Bell Ranch's American Glory, with Ken Church in the saddle, and he hustled up from fourth place in the stretch for a two-length decision, a $17.90 mutuel and a $7,295 increase in his earnings.
The country's 12,000 labor arbitrators, umpires of industrial disputes, received yesterday a code of ethics for the conduct of their activities.
For more than five consecutive years world consumption of wool has exceeded world production. Blankets that cost the Navy $7 each in the recent war now bring $12.50.
United Nations members were warned by Warren R. Austin yesterday that each was risking future aggression unless all adopted the United States motion to brand Communist China an aggressor in Korea.

Animal experiments that have led to the discovery of a fundamental mechanism controlling resistance to infantile paralysis are described in the current issue of The Proceedings of the Society for Experimental Biology and Medicine by Dr.Gregory Shwartzman of Mount Sinai Hospital.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 24--A jury of seven women and five men today decided in favor of Vivien Kellems, Stonington industrialist, and her brother, David, in their suit against John J.Fitzpatrick, Connecticut Internal Revenue Collector, for the return of $6,133.80 seized from them in 1949.

THE modern "wildcatter" is something of a study in contradictions and might very well be termed a lazy man with ambition. For he will spend a lot of time in research and experiment in order to obtain a rifle that will kill a woodchuck at 300 yards rather than at 150.

Mr. Deeds originally went to town and Mr. Smith went to Washington, as American moviegoers who saw the two pictures in the Thirties will recall Now Mr. Deeds and Mr. Smith have both gone to Russia and both come to a sorry end. In America Mr. Deeds
"Fashions with the functional, uncluttered character of modern architecture" -- this quotation Bonnie Cashin considers the best explanation of her designs.

ALBANY, Jan. 24--The trucking industry protested before a joint legislative committee today that it could not afford the $20,000,000 to $30,000,000 that would be imposed upon it by a proposed weight-distance tax.
The cotton futures market closed 45 points lower to 2 points higher, with the weakness most pronounced in the old-crop months, as trading on the New York Cotton Exchange increased in volume.

The Department of Welfare announced yesterday that the way had been cleared for the possible reinstatement of some of its employes dismissed for "failure to cooperate" with the department's civilian defense program.
Seventy-six teams in sixteen relay races were listed by Meet Director Fred Schmertz in completing groupings for the forty-fourth annual Millrose A. A. Games at Madison Square Garden Saturday night.

Three five-story and four fourstory buildings at 1326-36 Avenue of the Americas and 54-56 West Fifty-fourth Street, the southeast corner, have been sold by the Missionary Society of St. Paul the Apostle to Frederick Brown. They

Effective next Thursday, all men enlisting in the Air Force from the First Army area, except those with prior service, will be sent to the newly opened Sampson Air Base at Geneva, N.Y., for basic training, it was announced yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 24----Consideration was given today to a request by Air France for a permit from the Mexican Government to establish service between this capital and Paris. The request was heard in the conference of the legal committee of the International Civil Aviation Organization, an agency of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--The new President's Commission on Internal Security and Individual Rights, which is to be headed by Fleet Admiral Nimitz, can contribute much or little to the sound solution of a perplexing national problem. The quantity and qual

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 17:
A $2,258,349 Federal income tax lien was filed yesterday against Frank Erickson, the gambler, for the years 1937 through 1946.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 24 (AP)--The Racing Commission and Jockey Club of New York State received the controversial Jockey Don Meade issue from the Florida State Racing Commission today.

Plans are being perfected for a Valentine tea dance to be given by the Thrift Shop Committee of the Women's Auxiliary of the Union settlement on Feb.9 in the Roof Garden of the Pierre for the benefit of the organization. Mrs. Richard P. Connette and Mrs.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 24--A convocation on church union, called by the representatives of nine denominations and one church association, adjourned here today faced with the thorny problem of incorporating two separate plans for Protestant unity into a single blueprint that would be acceptable to most churchgoers.
The political crisis in the Netherlands has its importance for all of us, since it concerns the Atlantic rearmament program and Southeast Asia.

Establishment of a central registration bureau at 2000 Park Avenue, where all persons killed, injured, made homeless or otherwise affected by an enemy attack will be listed, was announced yesterday by the Office of Civil Defense.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Jan. 124--Julius H. Amberg, an attorney who was prominent in state and Federal affairs, died last night in Butterworth Hospital, where he had been a patient for a week. His age was 60.

WASHINGTON, Jan.24--In a matter of hours after taking the oath of office as Economic Stabilization Administrator, Eric Johnston cleared the way today for the imposition this week of wage and price controls.

By going back to his first success in this country, Maurice Evans has given the City Center its finest and most stirring production. The play is Shakespeare's "Richard II," which Mr. Evans first acted in New York in 1937. He opened in it for a two weeks' engagement last evening.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 24 (AP)--Onesided victories by a pair of tested campaigners--Marjorie Lindsay of Decatur, Ill., and Polly Riley of Fort Worth, Tex.--highlighted today's opening round of match play in the Helen Lee Doherty women's amateur golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--Wage scales of union workers in the construction industry rose almost 7 per cent in 1950. The average increase in the last quarter of the year was 1.8 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--The chief Republican spokesman on taxes in the House, Representative Daniel A. Reed of New York, called on Congress today to postpone consideration of further tax increases until House and Senate Apprapriations Committees had acted on President Truman's budget.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP)-- The excitement over drafting 4-F athletes into the armed services simmered today down to the indication athletes would get the same treatment as everyone else. Furthermore, a spokesman for the Surgeon General's office said it was that way in World War II.

Seeking to prevent the disruption of orderly distribution, the nation's wholesale dry goods merchants yesterday called for Governmental regulations that would assure delivery to them of a proportionate share of manufacturers' goods.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--Representative Adolph J. Sabath, Democrat of Illinois, moved today to strip again from the House Committee on Rules the powers to block Administration legislation that were restored to it earlier this month.
The great American city family --all 34,000,000 of them, in effect --for the next four months will be under the spotlight as a spending unit.
Art for therapy's sake is brightening the sedentary lives of patients on the new orthopaedic floor at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center on 168th Street west of Broadway.

A voluntary plan of recapitalization of the Brown Company, manufacturer of pulp and paper products, has been approved by the directors for early submission to stockholders, it was announced yesterday.

In the third breakaway in seven weeks from voluntarily established stabilization formulas, prices for iron and steel scrap metal advanced $2 a ton at Pittsburgh yesterday, setting a high record of $50 a ton for this important steelmaking material.
A meeting will be held here today to accelerate plans to establish a New York city crime commission because of black markets feared from impending price controls.
TORONTO, Jan. 24--American methods of social case work, group work and community organization are the best means yet devised by any country to prepare social workers for their job of helping people,

LONDON, Jan. 24--Michael of Lachasse received deserved applause from overseas buyers and press representatives today at his first collection as a member of the Incorporated. Society of London Fashion Designers.
Joseph W. Duffield, formerly a district sales representative at the New York office of General Electric Company, Schenectady, has been appointed Eastern regional sales manager for the tube division.
The first requisite for the establishment of peace is the restoration of the military strength of the anti-Communist world, Lewis W. Douglas declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP)---- The House passed a bill today giving statutory authority for establishing a Tactical Air Command with prime responsibility for the air support of ground troops.

Gil Hodges, the National League's best first baseman, had a brief conference with Emil J. (Buzzie) Bavasi, Dodger vice president in charge of signing players, yesterday, but left without picking up a pen.

Restraining influences were again at work yesterday on the stock market. Cautiousness continued to rule and prices eased as a result of mild profit taking. Losses of fractions predominated and the composite average fell 0.75 point, although in several strong spots gains ranged from 1 to 2 points.
Reflecting the increase in the permissible production of Texas crude oil output last week reached a new peak of 6,051,350 barrels daily, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

With produce costlier this January than in other years because of bad weather in growing sections, the local marketing office of the New York State Extension Service advises consumers to compare the cost of fresh fruits and vegetables with those for the frozen and canned.
ALBANY, Jan. 24--Governor Dewey attacked tonight as "a plan that would place New York in a straitjacket" a proposal that all highway-use revenues be constitutionally earmarked for highway purposes.

The greatly accelerated expansion plans of steel companies in the last three months will raise the total annual steel capacity of the United States to a record high of 117,500,000 tons at the end of 1952.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan.24-- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru came out strongly tonight against the United States resolution in the United Nations Political Committee to name Communist China an aggressor in Korea.

Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of New York University for the last eighteen years, was honored last night by 1,000 of the university's alumni, faculty members and administra tive staff at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The chancellor, who went on terminal leave on Jan. 1, will retire on July 1.
LONDON, Jan. 24--A 25-yearold New Yorker, who for two months tried unsuccessfully to enter Communist countries in Europe, sailed for the United States today "disgusted with communism."
Coming from behind in the second half, the New York Knickerbockers defeated Tri-Cities, 95-85, at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night.
Prices fell in virtually all commodity futures markets yesterday, following reports from Washington indicating an imminent price ceiling order "across the board" for all goods and materials.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Jan. 24 -Dr. Luther Lee Bernard, widely known sociologist, died at his home here today after an illness of several months. He was 69 years old.

Two new films will open in Broadway houses this morning. At the Capitol, the attraction will be 'The Enforcer," a melodrama, starring Humphrey Bogart and produced by United States Pictures for Warner Brothers release.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 24-- A new deal to provide financial resuscitation for the United Artists Distributing Company has reached final stages, it was learned today. The owners of the company, Mary

Saginaw, Mich., sold yesterday $7,700,000 of sewage disposal bonds due on Jan. 1, 1952, to 1981, to a banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., on a bid of 100,003 for l s, 1 s and 1 s, for an interest cost of 1.47055 per cent. The bonds were reoffered

Because many Americans preach one kind of democracy but practice another, the leadership of the United States among freedomloving peoples, particularly in Asia, is seriously endangered, Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, director of the United Nations Trusteeship Department, declared last night.

EIGHTH ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Korea, Jan. 24--A heavily armed network of police and military sentry posts, plus round the clock vigilante action, is holding almost 20,000 Communist guerrillas in rigid check in South Korea and disrupting their plans for an all-out strike.

Vigorous prosecution of antitrust law violators, whose activities, may revive black markets in the current emergency, was promised yesterday by H. Graham Morison, new chief of the anti-trust division of the Department of Justice.

EVER since the first football rule was invented, the amalgamated order of football coaches has been busy searching for loop holes in the code. It became a game of sorts. The coaches would poke away until a breach was found in the dikes and the rules makers would furiously toss in a sandbag to fill it up. Another hole would be found. In would go another sandbag.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24-Liquidation became general in the grain markets on the Board of Trade here today, following statements that price controls would be placed into operation tomorrow or on Friday with meat definitely to come under the price act. Commission houses sold freely and found support less in evidence than it had recently been.
WASHINGTON, Jan.24--Secretary of State Dean Acheson indicated today that the United States was moving with great selfrestraint to avoid widening the free world's division over the Far Eastern crisis.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24--Despite a strong plea from Raymond M. Foley, Administrator of the Housing and Home Finance Agency, for support of the so-called Defense Housing Act, the National Association of Home Builders today went on record in opposition to this measure in its present form and asked for sweeping changes, before it is approved by Congress.

Dr. Joseph John Reilly, an author and a member of the English Department at Hunter College for twenty-five years, died Tuesday night in his sleep at his home, 34-20 Eighty-fifth Street, Jackson Heights, Queens. He was 70 years old.

An investigation of reports that two small red Fire Department automobiles normally used to accommodate visiting chiefs actually were used freely by Gerard W. Purcell, indicted secretary of the Uniformed Firemen's Association, was ordered yesterday by Fire Commissioner George P. Monaghan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. (AP)---- Two examiners for the Interstate Commerce Commission today recommended revision of minimum charges on both railroad and motor carrier freight services, designed to increase revenues for both types of transportation.
MINNEAPOLIS. Jan. 24 (UP)-- Wes Fesler, who quit Ohio State last month and "gave up" football, today took the job of coaching Minnesota's Golden Gophers.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 24--The United States used mild but sober language today to tell members of the United Nations that their own security against future attacks depended on determination to face aggression whenever it occurred.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--The United States, Britain and France have proposed to the Soviet Union that representatives of the four governments meet in Paris to list the issues now threatening world peace that should be discussed at a possible future session of the Big Four foreign ministers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--The Senate Rules Committee voted today to recommend an $85,000 fund for a Judiciary subcommittee that will be a counterpart of the House Committee on Un-American Activities. The fund would cover operations until Jan. 31, 1952.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--Recent sales of gold by the Bank of France at premium dollar prices have drawn an informal but vigorous protest from the United States Treasury to French officials.

WASHINGTON, Jan.24--Ralph W.McDonald, representing the National Educational Association, testified before the Senate Preparedness subcommittee today that the Administration's plan to draft men at 18 for twentyseven months of service and training would "represent a serious blow to the future strength of the nation."
The voluntary plan through which the tanker industry proposes to contribute the tanker capacity necessary for national defense became effective yesterday.

The first test of a 113-station state-wide emergency radio network, to function in event of an atomic bomb attack, was carried out last night by Col. Lawrance Wilkinson, chairman of the State Civil Defense Commission.

NYACK, N.Y., Jan. 24--Hundreds of telegrams to National Mobilization Director Charles E. Wilson were sent from the Tappan Zee area today asking that materials for the proposed Thru way bridge be withheld because a crossing at a narrower place in the Hudson River would be more beneficial to defense.

Some sensational charges of underworld influence on politics and support of candidates were bandied around in the 1950 campaign in this city, which was generally conceded to have been one of the dirtiest of recent memory.
Unless they receive a "satisfactory" wage offer by tomorrow afternoon at 5 o'clock, 3,000 city school custodial workers threatened to strike after that hour.

Robert E. McNeill Jr. has been elected a director of Alexander Smith Sons Carpet Company, it was announced yesterday by William F.C. Ewing, president and chairman. Mr. McNeill is president and trustee of Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company and a director of the National Surety Corporation and the National Surety Marine Insurance Corporation.

A 46-year-old Newburgh (N.Y.) mathematics teacher was sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard to seven years' imprisonment for embezzling $19,931 from the Newburgh Teacher's Federal Credit Union.

A charge before the City Planning Commission at City Hall yesterday that a "will-o'-the-wisp corporation" had just bought up all the land slated to be condemned for a $22,000,000 low-rent housing project in the Bronx brought an immediate pledge of inquiry yesterday from the City Housing Authority.

The Council of the Living Theatre announced yesterday that it will collaborate with a group of motion-picture exhibitors to produce a $1,000,000 feature-length film, the earnings from which will be employed as a fund for financial aid to various branches of the theatres.

There is a possibility that, if the city gets all or most of the $50,000,000 increased state aid for which it is asking, the $250 wage bonus for 120,000 city employes will be raised about July 1 to $350, Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson said yesterday.

The text of the new Western notes to Moscow, published elsewhere in this newspaper, makes plain again what the Western Powers have long since demonstrated by word and deed--namely, that they are always willing to discuss with the Soviet Government all problems likely to threaten world peace.

Margaret Ann Fick of Arlington, Va., a cheerful, chubby, 9-yearold blonde, who is condemned to a wheelchair with both legs crippled by infantile paralysis, cut a white ribbon yesterday afternoon across the main corridor of the new Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation.
LONDON, Jan.24--An urbane but serious talk between Prime Minister Attlee and Walter S. Gifford, the new United States Ambassador, took place today at 10 Downing Street.

Economic controls, direct or indirect, will fail unless backed by strong fiscal and credit measures, Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, warned yesterday. Mr. Sproul spoke at the annual midwinter conference of the New York State Savings and Loan League in the bank's auditorium at 33 Liberty Street.

WINTSON-SALEM, N.C., Jan. 24--Mr. and Mrs. Timothy C. Shea of Woodside, Queens, will receive a rather bulky package one of these days. In it will be two clocks--a 1911 model that doesn't run and a 1951 model that does.

Despite an expected record output this year, American manufacturers foresee substantially reduced net profits, according to a survey of 178 manufacturing executives by the National Industrial Conference Board, released yesterday. Two kinds of reasons for their viewpoint were given--"the certainties" and "the uncertainties."
David F. Driscoll of 214 Clerk Street, Jersey City, former business manager of the Brooklyn Dodgers baseball team, died yesterday at Jersey City Medical Center after a long illness. His age was 77.

FRANKFORT,Germany, Jan. 24 --The United States Twelfth Air Force, comprising all the American air units in Germany and Austria, was reactivated today. This marked another step in the realignment of Western Allied fighting forces in Europe into a coordinated defense system capable of rapid expansion.

BOSTON, Jan. 24-The Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C.I.O., called today for the immediate reopening of all contracts in the seventy-six yards where it has locals to negotiate for a uniform wage level.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--A railroad wage dispute, now almost two years old, was snagged today on one of the most difficult of all, issues. The railroads contend they have an agreement with the four operating unions. The union leaders say they have not.

At the insistence of sanitation officials, the Department of Traffic has decided to ask the Board of Estimate next month for funds to extend the alternate-side-of-thestreet parking program to West Manhattan between Ninetieth and 110th Streets.

PARIS, Jan.24--With the aid of the strongest security forces mobilized in Paris since the liberation, the Government successfully met a major Communist challenge to its authority this evening by quelling a mass demonstration against Gen.Dwight D.Eisenhower called in defiance of an official ban.
Paul Reynaud, chairman of the economic commission of the European Consultative Assembly, arrived here yesterday, expressing certain misgivings about the United States' policy in the Far East.
MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 24--The American Federation of Labor laid the basis today for a "full-speedahead" political campaign in the 1952 elections.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 24--Secretary General Trygve Lie said today that Paris was "out" as a possible site for the 1951 session of the General Assembly. Plans are therefore being made to hold the session here, where erection of the new Assembly building is due to begin next month.

The operating costs of the Long Island Rail Road, already running at a deficit, are expected to increase between $2,000,000 and $2,800,000 a year as a result of pending wage increases, it was made known yesterday.

ALBANY, Jan. 24--A bill that would permit life insurance companies incorporated in New York and fraternal benefit--societies to invest up to 5 per cent of their assets in common stocks of American companies registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission was introduced today by Assemblyman Archibald Douglas Jr., Manhattan Republican.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--The Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today that it is considering a revision of Form S-1, which is one of the forms for registration of securities under the Securities Act of 1933.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24--Bright bumpers, nickel-plated hubcaps and the glistening trimmings that enhance the appearance of modern automobiles fell victims today to the "austerity" required by defense production.

ALBANY, Jan. 24--Mayor Impellitteri registered with the legislature today his formal opposition to proposals that four more Supreme Court justices be added to the First District bench in Manhattan and the Bronx.

Greater optimism pervaded the major advertising agencies in New York yesterday, following publication of the report of the Advertising Federation of America to the effect that, tax-wise, the position of advertising was assured in Washington.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Jan. 24--The two-and-one-halfyear-old coalition Cabinet offered its resignation today, after Foreign Minister Dirk U. Stikker, repudiated by his party in Parliament, had turned in his portfolio.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24----A continuous retail panel, covering 1,500 families, enables The Pittsburgh Press to furnish retail advertisers with "bench mark measurements" as to their success or failure in providing families with the merchandise they require, Earl J. Gaines, its advertising director, said today.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Jan. 24 (AP)-- "We need have no fear" that segregation in the state's public schools will be abolished, Gov. James F'. Byrnes declared today.
PARIS, Jan. 24--The steady development of exports and a decrease in the over-all deficit were features of France's foreign trade for 1950 as revealed in customs figures made available today.

DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 24--Mr. and Mrs. Roger Mayham Rowe of Butlers Island have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Adele, to Carlton Mills Badger of New York and Greenwich, son of Mr. and Mrs.Paul B. Badger of Nantucket, Mass.
All controls believed necessary to prevent shipment of strategic goods to Communist countries are now complete, a meeting of exporters was told yesterday.

ALBANY, Jan. 24--Contracts were awarded in 1950 for the construction or reconstruction of 579 miles of state highways at a cost of $91,999,000, according to a tabulation completed today by the Public Works Department.

The United States Sec 4: of the International Society for Contemporary Music waited until last night to give its first concert of the season, but it was worth the delay.
The Consumers Power Company's revenues of $114,350,814 last year were the largest in the history of the 41-year-old Michigan utility system.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan turned the spotlight on organizational finances of still another city department yesterday when he subpoenaed the books of four labor unions representing workers in the Department of Sanitation.

Appropriations totaling $172,805 were made yesterday by the Board of Estimate to remove Park Department trees felled by the storm of last Nov. 25 and to repair streets in the Bronx and Brooklyn damaged by falling trees.

FLORIDA sailfishing, which slacked off during the inter national contest, has improved considerably during the past few days and the contestants in the Silver Sailfish Derby of the Palm Beaches have tallied 216 fish during the first twelve days of the twenty-five-day event.

The New York City Ballet will open a season of four weeks at the City Center on Feb. 13, with two new works scheduled to be added to the repertoire. George Balanchine, artistic director of the company, has choreographed them both.
The City Council must decide today whether it is making law for New York City, or whether a determined clique within the police force has taken over that authority.

The four-story dwelling on lot 47 by 21 feet at 180 Lexington Avenue, northwest corner of Thirty-first Street, was sold by the estate of Gustave J. Staats to an investing client of Charles Liboff, attorney.

PARIS, Jan, 25--For the first time in modern peacetime history, France has granted supreme authority on all military matters to one general. A decree promulgated today gave to Gen. Pierre Alphonse Juin, Resident General in Morocco, sweeping powers to command and reorganize the military establishment.

Wagner's "Das Rheingold," absent from the repertoire last season, was revived yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House, where it launched the "Ring" cycle sponsored by the Metropolitan Opera Guild.

IOWA CITY, Iowa. Jan. 25 (AP) --Two University of Iowa varsity basketball guards were barred from intercollegiate competition today for delivering parlay cards to Davenport Iowa, last week.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP)-- Secretary of Defense George C. Marshall said tonight that "we must take our chances in the world" until the draft program began producing 50,000 trained men a month.
The Dayton Rubber Company, in its fiscal year ended last Oct. 31, scored new high-records in sales and profits, sharply reversing the previous year's trend, when a loss of $83,106 was sustained.
Two of the country's "Big Three" carpet mills yesterday touched off what is expected to become an industry-wide price revolt against carpet wool suppliers all over the world.

John Twomey, national outdoor 1,500-meter champion from the Illinois A.C., was named yesterday as the fifth starter in the Wanamaker Mile at tomorrow's Millrose Games in Madison Square Garden when John Joe Sarry, Villanova's Irish sophomore, requested that he be switched to the twomile.

United States Attorney Frank J. Parker announced last night that Leiser Weitman, 31-year-old Austrian, held for seeking to bring $280,000 worth of diamonds into the country, had also secreted in his body another batch of gems valued at $320,000.

LONDON, Jan. 25--A British veteran of World War II who is still on the reserve list and soon may be called into service again, recently wrote to his Member of Parliament protesting against the prospect of another period of military service.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--Dr. Kenneth H. Baker, director of research of the National Association of Broadcasters, asserted before the Federal Communications Commission today that educational broadcasting had been "a dismal failure" in realizing "full potentialities of the medium."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--The New England Power Company, Boston, filed a registration today with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $12,000,000 of firstmortgage bonds, Series D, due Feb. 1, 1981, to be offered for public sale at competitive bidding.

The possibility that Suez Canal tolls may be reduced, saving American ship operators thousands of dollars annually, was disclosed yesterday by Rear Admiral Edmond J. Moran in a report to directors of the National Federation of American Shipping.

William H. Harrison, Defense Production Administrator, said last night that complete allocation of critical materials would be needed by summer to balance the requirements of military production and the civilian economy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--An investigation into the influx of Federal employes into nondefense agencies of the Government and the, planning of a "hard-boiled" program for putting workers into places where they are most needed were projected in the Senate today.

Little skiing is in store for metropolitan enthusiasts this weekend unless they search out trails and slopes in more distant points of New York State, Vermont, New Hampshire and the Laurentians of Eastern Canada.

Despite encouraging economic progress made by Italy, the rate of expansion in work opportunities has been insufficient to reduce a more or less constant unemployment total of 1,800,000, Albert E. Pappano, United States consul in Rome, reported in an interview yesterday.

Tomorrow night will see the departure of "An Enemy of the People" from the Broadhurst. Originally slated to close last week, Arthur Miller's modernized treatment of the Ibsen play earned a reprieve because of a jump in receipts--nearly twice what it was the preceding week.

If war production limits the amount of yardage for dresses and suits, as in the last war, women will look to accessories to add costume interest, Dorothy L. Wallis, president of the Fashion Group, Inc., predicted yesterday. She spoke at a luncheon meeting and accessory show in the Astor Hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25 (AP)-- Philco Corporation, a leading producer of radio, television and electronic equipment, said today its recent research "has made great progress along the lines of conserving scarce materials."
MOSCOW, Jan. 25 (UP)--Dr. Sergei Ivanovitch Vavilov, president of the Academy of Sciences of the U.S.S.R. and one of this country's top physicists, died today at the age of 60.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 25 (AP)-- Ben Hogan, the United States open champion, came back to competitive golf after a six-month lay-off today and promptly paced the 125-man field in the first round of the $10,000 Phoenix Open.

The Foreign Policy Association has just published an estimate that there are sixty million refugees in the world today. This is big news but not new news, although the exact figure has continually to be brought down to date.

Virtually all commodity futures markets tumbled sharply on the exchanges here yesterday following the issuance in Washington of a price rollback order in hides.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, the new Supreme Commander for Europe's defense, is returning from his European tour of inquiry with six major reports to the leaders and people of the United States.

VIENNA, Jan. 25--Because Czechoslovakia failed to supply the Soviet Union with machinery that she had contracted to deliver in 1950, the Soviet Union has embargoed grain shipments on which its satellite had depended to feed her people.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--An amateur show, the cast of which would add up to any press agent's wildest dream, was offered tonight at Constitution Hall as the Women's National Press Club presented the V.I.P. Original Amateur Hour on radio and stage.

Exterior and interior improvements are offered in the eleven body styles of the 1951 line announced yesterday by De Soto division of the Chrysler Corporation. Engine power has been increased and several safety factors have been added with mechanical advances that make for riding comfort.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--During the week ended Jan. 24, member bank reserve balances decreased $327,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UP)-- Owner George Preston Marshall of the Washington Redskins bowed to both his customers and players today and reappointed Herman Ball as head coach for the 1951 National Football League season.

Reaction to high meat prices is mixed. Varying reports derive from retailers and wholesalers, though all agreed that the obvious has not yet occurred: Demand for fish, moderately priced in comparison to fileat, shows virtually no upswing.
Almost every one of the 1951 trends in contemporary furniture design is represented in a group of model rooms opening today at Abraham Straus.

ALBANY, Jan. 25--Negotiations are under way between employer and labor groups for a revision of the State's Unemployment Insurance Law to provide larger benefits to unemployed wage-earners and permit greater tax credits to employers.
