The original painting of the Armed Forces March of Dimes poster of 1951 was presented to the Army, Navy and Air Force yesterday at a ceremony in the Federal Building at 90 Church Street.

A $25,000,000 building program, consisting of thirty-one separate projects now under way or planned by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, was announced yesterday by Msgr. Walter P. Kellenberg, chancellor of the archdiocese. Among the projects are churches, hospitals, schools, convents and children's homes.

New credit commitments by business interests continued to expand last week, with New York banks advancing an additional $22,000,000 to bring commercial loans outstanding to a new high of $6,383,000,000.

TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 26--John Foster Dulles, with his mission of Army and State Department personnel, arrived here last night for a series of conferences with Japanese leaders and Gen. Douglas MacArthur, looking to the formulation of a draft peace treaty for Japan.
TOKYO, Friday, Jan. 26 (AP)-- Eighth Army communique 149, issued at 10:30 A.M., Friday (8:30 P.M., Thursday, Eastern standard time):

The twelve Arab and Asiatic nations which have sponsored a resolution on Korea in the General Assembly must be credited with sincerity of purpose, but the plan which they have offered is so humiliating in its approach and so loaded with grave danger that it should not be permitted to speak for the United Nations.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 25--The United States said today that it stood by its position that the recognition of Peiping as the Government of China in the United Nations could not be subject to the veto in the Security Council.

BOSTON, Jan. 25--The Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C.I.O., accused the Navy today of creating "acute labor unrest" and of accentuating the steel shortage by a policy of keeping repair and conversion contracts in its own yards.
Diversity is the keynote of two one-man painting shows and one group exhibition which opened this week.
The Hercules Powder Company last year shared in the upward trend of business with sales at the end of 1950 running 57 per cent higher than a year earlier and earnings at a new high record.
Charles Spencer Hart of 52 Gramercy Park North, advertising executive, author and former Grand Exalted Ruler of the Elks, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital. His age was 63.
Arthur W. Wallander, Civil Defense director, urged all individuals and firms in the food industry yesterday to cooperate in defense plans to keep food rolling into the city after an enemy attack.
William W. Remington stepped from a Federal Court witness box at the close of his first full day under cross-examination yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--The Wage Stabilization Board balked today at ordering a general wage freeze and there was some doubt that the long-awaited price-wage order would be ready tomorrow.

The recent restoration of historic St. Paul's Chapel, on Broadway between Fulton and Vesey Streets, was commemorated yesterday at a special service that also marked St. Paul's day. The original edifice, "the oldest building in Manhattan," was built by Trinity Church and opened Oct. 30, 1766.
Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein obtained a consent judgment yesterday from Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente enjoining Stewarts Credit Company, Inc., 1 Nevins Street, Brooklyn,...
CHICAGO, Jan. 25 (UP)--The White Sox' left-field problem, Gus Zernial, came to terms on his 1951 contract with General Manager Frank Lane today to become the twenty-fifth player on the 1951 roster.

Private financing totaling $115,000,000 in mortgage bonds and bank loans has been arranged for the expansion of aluminum production by Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, it was learned yesterday in investment banking circles here.

TOKYO, Friday. Jan. 26--United Nations naval forces moved in yesterday on the west coast of Korea to shell Inchon, seaport of the former Korean Republican capital at Seoul, while on the ground tank and infantry patrols again ranged...

LONDON, Jan. 25 (AP)--Influenza appears to be waning in several nations of Western Europe, but it is flaring up in Poland and Czechoslovakia and reaching epidemic proportions in Spain, a survey showed today. Britain still seems to be the hardest hit.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--President Truman asserted today that he believed in "calling an aggressor an aggressor" and that this country was solidly behind him in so stigmatizing Communist China.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 25 (AP)--Violators of thoroughbred racing regulations hereafter must return to the scene of their offenses for reinstatement before they can apply for a license elsewhere.

Again, as so often in the past, Gen. Douglas MacArthur celebrates a birth day today surrounded by war maps and battle reports. It is his seventy-first, and perhaps the most significant birthday of his life.
TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 25 (AP)-- Waning American and British prestige in this oil-rich country was bolstered today by an overwhelming parliamentary vote of confidence in Premier Gen. Ali...

DON GEHRMANN beat Fred Wilt by the approximate margin of a thin red whisker in the Wanamaker Mile a year ago. The job was accomplished in four minutes, nine and three-tenths seconds but Gehrmann had to wait ten months, one week and four days before he was sure of it.
Two Giants and three Yankees turned in their signed contracts yesterday, with Dave Koslo, the Polo Grounders' stocky southpaw pitcher, the headliner of the day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--A price rollback, second in the brief history of the Office of Price Stabilization, was ordered today on cattle hides. It carried prices back to the highest levels that prevailed in November and was said to amount to a reduction of 15 per cent or more from present quotations for domestic cattle hides, kips and calf skins.

THE island of Manoa, now called Terraqueous, is not to be found on any map of the Indian Ocean. Like the island of Bali H'ai in "South Pacific" it is a dream island, an island of the mind. And like all proper dream islands Terraqueous is a haven of serenity and beauty. Its skies are bluer, its verdure greener, its nubile native girls more innocently alluring than those...

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 25 (AP)-- School children of this city, exultant since last Tuesday over the strike of janitors that has closed down all the public schools, had a rather quixotic come-uppance today.

The Columbia Broadcasting System dismissed yesterday a girl office employe who refused to sign a loyalty statement explaining whether she had belonged to an organization designated as subversive. The name of the employe was not made public by the network.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--Republican House and Senate leaders beat back today a proposed party reorganization plan which they regarded as an effort to curtail the activities of their independent campaign committees.

BOSTON, Jan. 25--A threemonth study at Boston University on the effect of three antihistaminic drugs in the treatment of the common cold, has failed to reveal "any effect of the drugs in the dosage used that differed significantly" from a placebo of milk...

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 25--Premier Marshal Tito told Representative John F. Kennedy, Massachusetts Democrat, tonight that Yugoslavia would adopt the same attitude as other members of the United Nations in the event of attack against Western Europe and would honor her commitments under the Charter.
The Federal Home Loan Bank of New York in 1950 enjoyed the best twelve months in its eighteen-year history.
New procedures for improving the cooperation of industry and government in setting up workable food standards were suggested yesterday at the food, drug and cosmetics section of the seventyfourth...
John Foster Dulles arrived in Tokyo yesterday on "a mission of peace." That mission, of course, is to lay the groundwork for a long-overdue peace treaty or its equivalent.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 25--The West German trade unions won today what may turn out to be the greatest victory in the history of the German labor movement when they reached an agreement with industrial leaders on a proposed "co-determination" law.

Patrolman William A. Tierney of the West Forty-seventh Street station pleaded not guilty yesterday before Aaron Frank, Third Deputy Police Commissioner, to Police Department charges arising out of his alleged beating of a young man he arrested in Times Square on New Year's night.

CAIRO, Jan. 25--Overriding United States objections, the executive committee of the Universal Postal Union, a specialized agency of the United Nations now in session here, voted today to seat a delegation from Communist China and to exclude a Nationalist Chinese delegation.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 25--Changed conditions because of the death of Michael B.U. Dewar in England last December form the basis of a motion filed in United States District Court today by the Timken Roller Bearing Company of Canton ...
CHICAGO, Jan. 25--Grain prices fluctuated in an extremely nervous manner on the Board of Trade here today, breaking sharply early only to rally strongly in the late trading.
OTTAWA, Jan. 25 (AP)--Finance Minister Douglas Abbott said today in an interview that no decision has been taken on a suggestion that Canada allow the free sale of industrial gold in world markets.

Lush assignments for forty-five able-bodied firemen were ended yesterday when Commissioner George P. Monaghan removed them from the Divisions of Fire Prevention and Combustibles and ordered them back to fire fighting.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, Assistant Secretary of Defense, assured the House Armed Services Committee today that the Selective Service files of nearly 800,000 men 19 through 25 years old, now classified 4-F, were being reviewed with...

Members of the Citizens Committee on Children of New York City, leaders in local and national work for and with youngsters meeting at Sherry's, 300 Park Avenue yesterday, adopted a sixpoint program aimed at protecting children's interests during the uncertain times ahead.

The one-story taxpayer containing nine stores on a plot 125 by 100 feet at 147-01 to 147-17 Union Turnpike in the Kew Gardens Manor section of Queens has been sold by Barney Liechtung to an investing customer of A.G. Walker Associates, brokers in the transaction. Jack Schwartz was attorney for the buyer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--Senate and House Armed Services Committee leaders said today that the military services planned to speed construction and expansion of both domestic and overseas training facilities and bases and that defense planners had made some important changes in their major projects.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 25 (AP)-- The Senate Crime Investigating Committee heard testimony today that New Orleans gamblers tried to scribe a churchman by offer of a new Sunday school building.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--Marriner S. Eccles, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, advised Congress today that over-all price control was "unnecessary and should not be, imposed on the economy."

Paul Reynaud, chairman of the economic commission of the Consultative Assembly of the Council for Europe, advised the American people last night: "Ask more of Europe, if you wish, but do not abandon it."

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 (AP)--The Chicago Black Hawks dropped their sixth straight and ran their string of games without victory to nineteen in a row tonight as they lost to the New York Rangers, 2--1, before a crowd of 6,112, smallest to attend a National Hockey League contest here in sixteen years.

CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Jan. 25--Millions of gallons of water cascaded over the top of New York's Croton Dam here today for the first time since June, 1949. Water in the chain of Croton reservoirs to the northeast finally was at a peak again of 103,000,000,000 gallons.
DOVER, N.J., Jan. 25--Five persons were killed and four others injured today when a flash fire swept a small powder-blending building at the Picatinny Arsenal.
LONDON, Jan. 25--The condition of Britain's Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin, who is suffering from pneumonia, was described today as serious but not critical.

A plan for making the Long Island Rail Road virtually accident-proof within eighteen months, submitted by the railroad's new trustee, William H. Draper Jr., will come up for a hearing before Federal Judge Harold Kennedy in the Brooklyn Federal Building at 10:30 this morning.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25--Emergency mortgage restrictions now covering only residential building work, are going to be extended quickly to embrace commercial construction, members of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America were informed today at the opening of their annual mid-winter conference here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today its consumers' price index had risen 1.6 per cent between Nov. 15 and Dec. 15, the greatest peacentage increase during any month in more than three years.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 25--The American Federation of Labor today agreed with the Administration that proposed defense expenditures would require $16,000,000,000 to be raised in the next year through additional taxation, and offered a program for raising such revenue.
MOSCOW, Jan. 25 (AP)--Izvestia, organ of the Soviet Government, accused Britain today of making use of the situation arising out of "failure of American policy in the Far East" for her own ends.
Whether her taste was luxurious or turned to the practical as well as pretty, almost any prospective bride could find a wedding gown to please her in yesterday's showing at Bonwit Teller.

As the city's preparations for civil defense progress there are bound to be questions in need of answers. The questions will no doubt run the gamut from what to do in the event of attack to where is the nearest registration point for Civil Defense duty.

Paddy Young, 22-year-old Greenwich Village, middleweight, will face Kid Gavilan, the welterweight division's No. 1 challenger, at Madison Square Garden tonight. The bout is listed for ten rounds with Gavilan rated a 5-to-7 favorite.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--President Truman completed today the personnel of his new Commission on Internal Security and Individual Rights, and told his news conference that its creation was nonpolitical and had nothing to do with investigative plans in Congress.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 25 --Mary Robbs, 25-year-old Negro soprano, who studied voice in New York and paid her expenses by sewing labels on sweaters in a garment factory, was selected today to appear as a soloist with the Chattanooga Symphony Orchestra in a "Pops" concert to be held in March.

Dwight Deere Wiman, Broadway theatrical producer who died last Saturday in Columbia Memorial Hospital, Hudson, N.Y., left a gross estate of more than $3,000,000, it was disclosed yesterday when his will was filed for probate here.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 25--Sir Benegal N. Rau of India said today that the reported lull in the Korean fighting "may not be without significance" and urged that advantage be taken of it to start preliminary peace talks.

Benny Saltsman, 56-year-old Bronx house painter, whose son was killed in action in Belgium during the last war while serving with the United States Army, was ordered deported yesterday because of membership he held in the Communist party fifteen years ago.

The Boston Metropolitan District sold yesterday $14,720,000 of bonds due in 1952 to 1981 to a banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., on a bid of 100,757 for 1 per cent interest, an interest cost of 1.459 per cent. The next best bid, submitted by Kuhn, Loeb Co., designated an interest cost of 1,462 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP)--A maritime hearing revealed today that Denmark had notified the State Department that approval of a pool agreement between United States and Chilean shipping lines would seriously harm Danish economy.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 25--In the House of Assembly today Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan intervened in a debate on his Government's policies to define this country's position in the present international crisis.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 25 --Paul C. French, executive director of Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe (C.A.R.E.) announced tonight that his organization would distribute $35,000,000 worth of American food free of charge in Yugoslavia within the next six months.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP)-- Rear Admiral Tom B. Hill, who has been director of the Navy's Atomic Energy Division, was named depuay director of Joint Task Force 3 today. This force is responsible for atomic weapons projects in the central Pacific.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 25 (AP)--Miss Polly Riley of Fort Worth, Tex., set the pace in the second round of the Helen Lee Doherty amateur golf tourney today by defeating Miss Betty MacKinnon of Dallas, 4 and 3. Miss Riley matched women's par for the 6,068-yard Miami Country Club course.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25--Leaders of the National Association of Home Builders today expressed confidence that the Government's restricted goal of 850,000 new housing units during 1951 would be attained despite shortages and defense demands.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25--A warning to be on the alert for "opportunists" who may seek to exploit consumers and the Government in time of emergency was issued to the Federal Trade Commission staff today by Chairman James M. Mead.
Eleven champion sweet potato growers from South Carolina--10 to 18 years old--journeyed to the Bronx Zoo yesterday to see for the first time a group of small monkeys and antelopes

Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore defended yesterday the proposed state civilian defense bill as the mere reinstitution of provisions that were lifted for the most part from other emergency acts of other war periods.

"Conditional approval" was given yesterday by the Federal Maritime Board to the application of the American President Lines for authority to continue its unsubsidized service from United States North Atlantic and Pacific Coast ports to destinations in the Straits...

For those who would like a room with a view and haven't one, some designs today in fabrics and wallpapers may help to create this impression. A few paraphrase scenes close at hand while others suggest more remote times and places. The New York Times Studio

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--The Government froze wages, salaries and other compensation of employer today for the second time in less than nine years. The rates of the freeze are those paid yesterday and those rates may not be increased without Government approval.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. (AP)-- Senator Margaret Chase Smith, Republican of Maine, lost her seat on a key Senate investigating subcommittee today, and she is reported to have protested strongly that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, "bumped" her out of the post.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--The Department of Defense reported to the House Armed Services Committee today that the Soviet Union's military forces did not get many more combat units per 100,000 men than the United States...

One hundred employes of the Aetna Marine Corporation, accompanied by their wives and members of their families, will go over the American Export liner. Independence today with the critical eyes of the expert.

CAMDEN, N.J., Jan. 26-- A 28-year-old marine engineer from Bombay, charged with illegal entry into this country, pleaded today in United States District Court not to be returned to "a Communistridden India" so that he could join our Army to combat the communism that is "wrecking" his land.

United States Attorney Frank J. Parker said yesterday he was convinced that Leiser Weitman and Mrs. Eta Hoffman, accused of smuggling $1,400,000 worth of high-quality diamonds into this country, were key figures in an international smuggling syndicate exchanging American gold bullion for valuable gems.

Reactions in the business community to the temporary pricefreezing order in Washington were calm last night. Little hope was held out that any price reductions at wholesale or retail were in prospect as a direct result.

ARTHUR KOESTLER wrote a memorable portrait of the legendary young R.A.F. fighter pilot, Richard Hillary, for Horizon in 1943 and called it "The Birth of a Myth," because he felt that "writing about a dead friend is writing against time, a chase after a receding image; catch him, hold him, before he becomes petrified into a myth. Already the fatal,...

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 26 (AP)--A slender sharpshooter from Cleveland, Miss Claire Doran, shot nearperfect golf over the windswept Miami Country Club course today to defeat Miss Marjorie Lindsay of Decatur, Ill., 2 and 1, in the first upset of the Helen Lee Doherty amateur tournament.
Since Dec. 18 our Government has had before it a request for 2,000,000 tons of grain to relieve a threatened famine in India.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--Secretary of State Dean Acheson assured Congressional leaders today that no "formal agreements" or new policies were likely to result from President Truman's forthcoming conversations with Premier Rene Pleven of France.

A request for 500 additional firemen to supplement the Fire Department's existing uniformed force of 10,512 men was made by Fire Commissioner George P. Monaghan yesterday at departmental budget hearings in the Municipal Building. The hearings were held before Assistant Budget Director Abraham D. Beame.
A new and sterner code of morality is gradually being established within the Police and Fire Departments under Commissioners Murphy and Monaghan.
OTTAWA, Jan. 26--Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower arrived here today on the last lap of his twelve-country tour. He said he had been "encouraged" by what he had seen in Europe.

LAKE SUCCESS, Jan. 26--Asian and Arab states, faced with charges that their plan for "clarification" talks with Communist China gave Peiping a blank check, were reported today ready to revise their resolution by providing that a Korean cease-fire must come first in the negotiations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--A Senate committee in charge of executive department matters voted unanimously today to deny to President Truman the blanket war powers he requested for reorganizing the Government to fit the defense pattern.

Preliminary study of drug and other materials requirements essential to basic public health will be made in the next several weeks as a fiist step in setting up necessary allocations, Oscar R. Ewing, chief, of the Federal Security, Agency, told a business group luncheon here yesterday.

Dinner was served in thirty-one languages early this week at an international party at the New York City Mission Society's De Witt Memorial Church, 280 Rivington Street. For the occasion, sponsored by the Dorcas Society, a women's organization of the church, each member produced her family's favorite dish.
A $5,000,000 pier rehabilitation program designed to reduce ship layovers and integrate rail and truck traffic was disclosed last night by William Zeckendorf, 45year-old real estate executive.

William W. Remington testified in Federal Court yesterday that a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent told him in 1947 that "20 to 25 per cent" of the Government employes in Washington were Communists.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UP)-- Federal District Judge James A. Kirkland said today that he would rule next week on whether a witness before a Congressional committee could refuse to answer questions on the ground of possible self-incrimination.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 26 (AP)--The Government has asked the Federal Court here to upset a jury verdict that held that Vivien Kellems had not wilfully violated the withholding-tax law.

BONN, Germany, Jan. 26--Promising the Germans that their participation in a European army could not be considered provocative by the Soviet Union, the French High Commissioner's Office began today to woo the Germans into foregoing the idea of a national army in favor of membership in a European force.
Most commodity futures moved over a fairly wide range in nervous trading on the Exchanges here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--The Republican National Committee today put new steam behind the drive to ratify, in the next thirty days, a constitutional amendment that would bar a third term for any President but would not keep President Truman from running again in 1952.
The present proposal for universal military service and training beginning at the age of 18, which is now before Congress, may need some modifications in detail.

The annual winter furniture market in the New York Furniture Exchange entered its closing stages yesterday with total business placed far heavier than was anticipated by most of the 500 exhibitors prior to the opening on Monday. The event closes at noon today.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 26 (AP)-- The Ryder Cup matches between top professional golfers of the United States and Great Britain will be played in this country "sometime in the fall," P.G.A. president Joe Novak announced here today.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange became somewhat irregular yesterday and closed 15 points higher to 3 points lower. The trade generally was awaiting announcement of the methods to be used in imposing price and wage controls.

John P. Crane, president of the Uniformed Firemen's Association, offered yesterday to testify before the grand jury which on Monday indicted a fellow officer in the association, but only if he were permitted to do so under a "limited" waiver of immunity.
CARSON CITY, Nev., Jan. 26 (AP)--The first explosion has occurred at the Atomic Energy Commission's new testing grounds in Nevada, Gov. Charles Russell disclosed today.

In St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church yesterday afternoon, Miss Thereza Muniz, daughter of Ambassador Joao Carlos Muniz, permanent representative of Brazil to the United Nations, and Mrs. Muniz of 1115 Fifth Avenue, was married to Marquis de Belmonte de la Vega Real, son of Marquesa de Belmonte of Madrid, and the late Marquis de Belmonte.

A skyscraper office structure is planned for The Sun Building's site at 280 Broadway, which has been bought by a syndicate headed by Charles F. Noyes, chairman of the Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., and Robert W. Dowling, president of the City Investing Company, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--The White House disclosed today that there had been an increase in the number of threatening letters addressed to President Truman.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, Assistant Secretary of Defense agreed today to give the House Armed Services Committee on Monday the Administration's justification for exempting about 900,000 married nonveterans from 19 to 26 in favor of seeking to draft men at 18.

The Federal Government moved to curb inflation by ordering a freeze of wages and prices. Wages were ordered frozen at the levels prevailing at midnight last Thursday and prices at the highest points reached between Dec. 19 and Thursday midnight.

MONTREAL, Jan. 26 (AP)-- R.M. Fowler, president of the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association, said today that the subject of newsprint supplies and prices is not one on which United States publishers can always form a "detached and dispassionate judgment."
Public education is increasingly under attack and the challenge must be met "fairly and honestly," Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, declared yesterday. Speaking to 200...

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 26 (AP) --Long Island University's basketball team kept its undefeated record intact tonight by beating the University of San Francisco, 58--52, before a crowd of 6,884, at the Cow Palace.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 26--La Prensa, one of the two newspapers eft here free of Government influence was silenced today. What the Government failed to do through a newsprint squeeze, limiting the number of pages, the...
Six young American musicians have been engaged to make their first appearances with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony during its 1951-52 season, the society announced yesterday.
In winning an equal voice in the management of the Ruhr coal, steel and iron industries, the West German trade unions hay a obtained a position for labor that has no exact parallel anywhere else.
ALBANY, Jan. 26--The New York Public Service Commission lost its court fight today to prevent commuter fare increases on the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad from going into effect Feb. 1.
FRANCONIA, N.H., Jan. 26-- This pioneer ski center was excited today as cross-country and slalom racers began to arrive for the New Hampshire state classic title, as well as the invitation Franconia
The lifting of pressure enabled the stock market to stage a sharp reversal of form yesterday and, despite an easing in the pace of trading, prices advanced an average of 1.31 points.

Marine Corps Recruiting headquarters at 346 Broadway administered the oath yesterday to the largest group of enlistees-- ninety-four men and eleven women--it had inducted on any one day since World War II. The recruits were sent to Parris Island, S.C., for basic training.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26--An 11,000-pound anchor, dropped by a Sun Oil Company tanker, split open today a branch of a TexasNew York natural gas pipeline running under the Delaware River at Marcus Hook, twelve miles south of here.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 26--Here in a country inn forty-five miles from Manhattan's civil defense centers, boys and girls from every city high-school are plugging away at studies to fit them for any emergency or, if none occurs, for the services to veterans and children which is the goal of the Junior Red Cross.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26-- Thomas B. McCabe, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, warned here tonight that this nation's way of life as well as the defense program depends on the maintenance of a sound economy and a sound dollar.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 26--Winner of horse-of-the-day honors at Hialeah today was a 4-year-old Devil Diver colt named Call Over, who led all the way in the six-furlong sprint that headed the program.
Voluntary rationing is being considered by big hardware distributors here to conserve supplies of scarce items which cannot be readily replaced, it was learned yesterday.

The beginning of price stabilization under the new temporary freeze order should act to restore consumer confidence, and thereby stimulate continuance of the normally high volume of retail advertising built up in recent years, trade observers believed yesterday.
CHICAGO, Jan. 26--Action of the grain markets here today was highly nervous, reflecting uncertainty regarding the Korean situation and the Pending price freeze.
Available bank credit will have to be redistributed among borrowers in keeping with "the vital objectives of the defense economy," the American Bankers Association...

TRIPOLI, Libya, Jan. 26 (AP)-- Adrian Pelt, United Nations Commissioner in Libya, today proposed a compromise Constitution for this newly independent state. He asked a meeting of the United Nations Council for Libya whether he should formally submit his plan to the National Assembly.

ALBANY, Jan. 26--Governor Dewey declared today that he did not care whether the Federal Government developed the power potential of the St. Lawrence River, just so long as Washington abides by a 1933 Federal-state accord and turns the power over to the state at cost.

PARIS, Jan. 26--Patou millinery shows a collection very much in the new forward movement. Whether the hat is a sailor with rounded crown and tiny brim, a beret or a mushroom, this theme of shading the brow is carried out in shape as well as trimming.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Jan. 26--The Rev. Dr. G. Clifford Cress, former associate secretary of the Ministers and Missionaries Benefit Board of the Northern Baptist Convention, died today in the Claremont Nursing Home here after a long illness. He was 77 years old.

TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 27 (UP) --Premier Shigeru Yoshida, on the eve of talks begun today by Gen. Douglas MacArthur and John Foster Dulles for the United States that are expected to lead to a peace treaty for Japan, warned the nation that remilitarization might, lead to aggression abroad and a military dictatorship at home.
CHICAGO, Jan. 26--The American Meat Institute issued the following statement tonight on the Government's price freeze order as it affects certain meat items:
Governor Dewey's defense emergency bill received full support from speakers at an all-day meeting of the Federation of Women's Republican Clubs of New York State yesterday at the Astor Hotel.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 26-- Elizabeth Taylor was named today by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to star with Stewart Granger and Ava Gardner in the studio's remake of Rafael Sabatini's novel of the French revolution, "Scaramouche," which will go before the cameras next month.

Mel Ott, the piano-legged kid who joined the New York Giants before his sixteenth birthday and never played an inning in the minor leagues, and Jimmy Foxx, American League star, have been elected to baseball's Hall of Fame at Coonerstown, N.Y.

With John Garfield as its star, "Peer Gynt," Paul Green's American version of the Ibsen play, will open tomorrow evening at the Anta Playhouse, 245 West Fiftysecond Street. The opening night curtain is announced to rise at 7:45 o'clock.
The thirty-fourth annual championship show of the Empire Cat Club opened yesterday at the McAlpin Hotel with two major divisions of cats, the long hair and the short hair, competing for honors.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 26--Only 600 persons were present tonight in the Mineola High School Auditorium, capable of seating 1,000, for the public hearing on the preliminary draft of the Governor's Long Island Rail Road Commission report.

Wider participation by church laymen and youth in the progress of the Young Men's Christian Association was predicted yesterday by Frank M. Totton, president of the association in this city, at the close of a campaign for current expenses amounting to $444,524.

An amendment its opponents charged would destroy the force of the measure requiring policemen to wait thirty days for retirement after filing applications was adopted yesterday by the City Council by a vote of 15 to 10.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--Eric Johnston, Economic Stabilization Administrator, advised Congress today that price and wage controls would be "temporary" if the public cooperated and if specified steps were taken to curb inflationary forces at the roots.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (UP)-- Government stabilizers announced their price-wage freeze tonight at a rough and tumble news conference that outdid Hollywood's wildest conceptions of newspapering.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP)-- The Federation of Musicians, headed by James C. Petrillo, won a 2 to 1 ruling from the National Labor Relations Board today in a case involving the "anti-featherbedding" clause of the Taft-Hartley Law.

The Fortuna Holding Corporation has purchased the eleven-story loft building at 4951 West Twenty-fourth Street from Hattie Sinske and others. The purchasers plan to occupy the entire building, which, with the land is assessed at $155,000.

The Federal Maritime Administration yesterday announced tanker freight rates that will apply for all tanker charters made pursuant to the voluntary plan of the industry for the contribution of liquid carrier tonnage for requirements under the Defense Production Act of 1950.

THE ancient wilderness craft of tracking, which has been on the decline since the Indian traded in his moccasins for a pair of elevator shoes, is going to be revived out in Michigan this winter when state trappers begin their fox research program.

Two North Atlantic steamship conferences were permanently enjoined yesterday from reinstituting the exclusive patronage contract rate system which, in effect, set up a dual system of ocean freight rates.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26--Blanket orders freezing both wages and prices as of midnight Thursday were invoked by the Government tonight to curb inflation.
Corsets as the foundation of the fashion silhouette or as health protectors is the theme of a brilliant exhibition that will open to the public today at the Brooklyn Museum.

The New York Telephone Company asked yesterday for another state-wide rate increase, which it said would average 7 to 8 per cent and total $44,000,000 a year. The increase would be effective on March 1. Last May the company received an 11 per cent increase amounting to $48,500,000.
LONDON, Jan. 26--Britain's meat ration was cut by 20 per cent today. This means that within two months the ration for Britons will have been reduced by 60 per cent.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 26 (AP)-- Ben Hogan withdrew from the $10,000 Phoenix open golf tournament today because of an attack of intestinal influenza, and Chick Harbert took the lead with his second sub-par round and a 36hole score of 133.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP)-- Congress heard today that the Government soon might restriot the use of aluminum in consumer goods. Operators of small companies promptly protested that such a move would bankrupt them and eventually hurt the defense program.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 29-- The purchase of two new story properties, "Before I Pronounce Sentence," a melodrama by Berne Giler, and "Carib Gold," a period adventure yarn by Ellery H. Clark, was announced today by Paramount.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Jan. 29--Dr. Kurt Schumacher, leader of the Socialists, at present one of the most powerful voices in Germany, completely rejected today the Pleven plan for an internationalized European army.
No top official in the utility industry appears willing to challenge the Federal Government's contention that "the reserve margin of electric power has practically disappeared."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29--The State Department, in a retaliatory move, directed members of the Hungarian diplomatic staff here to stay within an eighteen-mile radius of the White House, unless they received permission to go outside that area.

Three years ago, Sigi Weissenberg, Israeli pianist, made his local debut in Carnegie Hall as soloist with the New York Philharmonic Symphony as a Leventritt winner. Last night at the same auditorium, he gave his fourth New York recital. It means he has been in big spots for a young man of 21.
The paradoxes and complications of Western politics could not be dramatized better than they were yesterday by the announcement of Britain's new and bigger program for rearmament.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29--The Federal Communications Commission today announced that it would conduct public hearings on the question of television programming as it affects the public interest. No date was set for the sessions.

Men's wear retailers, seeking to obtain an adequate supply of staple merchandise for spring and summer, are ordering well ahead, according to manufacturers' representatives at a display by the Men's Apparel Club in the New Yorker Hotel.

A further move to augment the nation's steel-making capacity, already running at the record rate of nearly 105,000,000 tons annually, was disclosed yesterday with the announcement of plans for a new $100,000,000 mill along the Detroit River.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 29 (AP)--Ken Henry of Chicago, 22-year-old sophomore at Northern Teachers College, Dekalb, Ill., outsped a field of thirty-one skaters today in the opening battle for places on the 1952 Olympic speedskating team.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29--President Truman will go to Philadel-- phia on Saturday to dedicate a chapel to the four heroic chaplains who locked arms after giving away their life preservers and died on the torpedoed troop transport Dorchester on Feb. 3, 1943.
William W. Remington said under cross-examination in Federal Court yesterday that he had "slapped" his former wife in June, 1947, in a disagreement over their son.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29--Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security Administrator, announced grants today totaling more than $2,000,000 for ACTH and cortisone research in seventeen states in "a program unique in the history of medical research."
Traveling on Green Bus Company lines in south Queens became an irritating experience for 56,000 commuters yesterday when most of the 300 bus drivers refused to fill transfer ticket machines.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29--Officials of the Economic Stabilization Agency failed today to clarify the effects of Friday's wage-price freeze, which appeared to have bewildered many consumers and workers.
TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 29 (AP)-- Jerry Dillon's free throw with twelve seconds left gave Arizona an uphill 62--61 victory over Long Island University's tourling basketball team tonight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29--In a second repudiation of innovations installed by the last Congress, the system of consolidating all major Federal appropriations into a single bill as a move for economy and a balanced budget was scrapped today by a 31-18 vote of the House committee in charge.

George D. Widener's Battlefield, last year's juvenile champion, and Joseph J. Colando's Uncle Miltie, chosen as the top horse by Handicapper John B. Campbell, in his Experimental Free Handicap, head the list of 3-year-olds nominated for the eighty-third Belmont Stakes.
TRENTON, N. J., Jan. 29--Administration measures to increase the maximum unemployment and disability benefits in New Jersey from $26 to $30 a week were received today in the State Senate here.

The last of a series of ice storms that had harassed the metropolitan area since Saturday moved out to sea last night after coating roads and highways with a fresh glaze.

The Pakistan Government has pledged $25,000 annually for the next ten years to Columbia University for the establishment of a center of Pakistan studies here.

Jerry Coleman, rated the best second-baseman the Yankees have had since the days of the late Tony Lazzeri, yesterday came to terms with General Manager George M. Weiss on his 1951 contract, and, it was announced, will formally sign the document at noon today in the club's Fifth Avenue headquarters.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Jan. 29-- Presumably because of his Zionist background in Czarist Russia, the Soviet Union has rejected the nomination of Zalman Shazar as Israeli Minister to Moscow.

Much of today's aluminum and wrought-iron furniture has lost its metal look. Some has been finished with hand-glazed enamel, other pieces have a black satin enamel finish and one group is made to simulate rattan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29--High Air Force officials have reported to headquarters here from Lackland Air Force Base at San Antonio, that there have been no undue sicknesses or hardships at the crowded recruit training center, as recently charged.

New trends in hospital care, accelerated by the defense emergency, are taking place in New York. Originally prompted by excessive overcrowding in the municipal hospitals, they are proving efficient and beneficial to the city's needy ill.

The new format for the nation's economy under the defense-mobilization program drew a hearty response yesterday from the stock market. Prices were bid up briskly under the leadership of the steel, oil and automotive divisions, which had some sizable gains.

Promotion of Valentine's Day as a gift day when "she" gives "him" something to wear will be started on a nationwide basis this week in stores and through national advertising.

Federal civil defense funds should be made available to aid the city's construction program for hospitals, arterial highways and parking garages, Mayor Impellitteri said yesterday.

The Jeep Patrol on the West Side Elevated Highway helped 7,145 motorists in 1950. According to Robert F. Wagner Jr., Borough President of Manhattan, the number of drivers needing assistance on this highway has steadily declined in the last three years.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 29 (AP)-- Pitcher Bob Feller today regained his old place as the Cleveland Indian earning the most wampum.

Dr. A.J. Cronin, for two decades a popular novelist, is nearing completion of the dramatization of his recent book, "The Spanish Gardener." Eddie bowling is interested in sponsoring the play, which may be produced here next season.
THERE can be no disputing the election of James Emory Foxx into the Hall of Fame. He belongs. Only Babe Ruth hit more home runs than Double X and not even the Babe could pole-axe a ball farther.

United Nations forces gained three miles in their drive toward Seoul and were believed to have reached the outposts of the main Chinese Communist defenses. Heavy air attacks helped the ground forces overcome stubborn enemy resistance. [1:8; map P.2.]

The Armco Steel Corporation is planning a common stoct issue of 884,000 shares with rights to be issued to present stockholders on the basis of one for each five shares held.

Junior's piggy bank stood yesterday as the symbol of America's strongest anti-inflation weapon and its best bet for continued economic well-being.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 29 (AP)--Walter Geist, president of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company, died tonight in a hospital, to which he had been taken Saturday suffering from a heart ailment. He was 56 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP)-- The National Labor Relations Board today asked the Federal Court of Appeals in Chicago to enforce its order requiring the International Typographical Union, A.F.L., to stop insisting on variations of the outlawed closed shop.

Asset value of Atlas Corporation's common stock, indicated on Dec. 31, last year, amounted to $33.12 a share, compared with $30.12 at the end of 1949, Floyd B. Odlum, president, reported to stockholders yesterday.

HAVANA, Jan. 30--Harold C. Halstead of Morichs Bay, New York, sailing Chuckle, today won the first race of the Cuba Cup series in the twentieth international Star Class regatta. His time was 2 hours 15 minutes 29 seconds and he gained eight points. Thomas Barnes was the crew.

Columbia University and eight other schools in this area withdrew their sponsorship of Shanks Village yesterday, thus leaving the thriving "student city" of 1,430 veterans and their families entirely in the hands of the Federal Government.

"Papa" Dikran Kelekian, one of the greatest authorities on Near Eastern art, crashed to his death at 7 o'clock yesterday morning. The police said he jumped or fell from his suite on the twenty-third floor of the Hotel St. Moritz to a second-floor extension under his east-facing windows.
The Department of Hospitals will ask more than $100,000,000 for its 1951 budget, an increase of $20,000,000 over last year's appropriation, Mayor Impellitteri indicated last night.

First steps have been taken by leading companies in the warehouse aluminum products industry to organize a national trade association to cooperate with Government agencies on problems of aluminum products distribution.

The radiant smile of little Joya Moore, 1951 poster girl for the March of Dimes, was symbolic of the mood of guests at the March of Dimes Fashion Show yesterday. The presentation was made in the ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Getulio Vargas, who is being inaugurated as President of Brazil today, is a towering and controversial figure. The one certainty about the immediate future is that things are going to hum in Brazil.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, Assistant Secretary of Defense, completing nearly three weeks of testimony at the Capitol, told the House Armed Services Committee today that drafting men over 25 would not be "profitable or economical" at present.
Efforts by the Theatre Guild to do "The Little Blue Light," written by Edmund Wilson, novelist and book critic, have come to naught.

ALBANY, Jan. 30--Over solid Democratic opposition, the Assembly approved today a proposed amendment to the State Constitution to place the state's credit behind $500,000,000 in bonds for the cross-state Thruway. The vote was 82 to 58.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30--Dissension in the three-sided Wage Stabilization Board blocked the issuance of policy orders again today.

MORRISVILLE, Pa., Jan. 30-- One of the big land owners in the rich farming region outside this small town--a resident of only a few months--will turn up his soil soon after March 1, beating the neighbors by three or four weeks.

ALBANY, Jan. 30--Governor Dewey submitted to the Legislature today a record high and payas-you-go budget for the fiscal year starting April 1. It proposed specific appropriations for a total of $938,940,759, an increase of $68,653,561 over the final total for the current year.

The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest producer of steel, reported yesterday net income of $215,337,655 for last year, the highest since 1917, and announced that its directors had voted dividends of 75 cents a share on the common stock and $1.75 on the preferred stock, for a total of $25,887,237.

Patrolman William A. Tierney of the West Forty-seventh Street station, charged with beating a prisoner, was indicted yesterday by a New York County grand jury. The true bill included four counts of felonious assault in the second degree, and one of third-degree assault. Tierney was suspended immediately from police duty, and released in bail of $1,000.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 30 (AP)-- Ken Henry of Chicago virtually clinched a place on the 1952 United States Olympic speed-skating team today by dominating the trial races for the second straight day.

LONDON, Jan. 30--Prime Minister Attlee made an addendum today to his defense speech. He apologized in the House of Commons for the oversight through which a passage had been omitted from his statement yesterday in which he said that Britain would spend 4,700,000,000 on rearmament over the next three years.

THOSE who hold to the theory that this is the slack season fore hunting might get a change of heart if they would hunt up a man with a foxhound, for reports from several near-by states indicate that the reds and grays are providing good sport.

Joseph Palmer Knapp, former chairman of the board of the Crowell-Collier Publishing Company, died last night at his residence, River House, Fifty-second Street and the East River. He was 86 years old.

Despite big new war orders, the regular output of some builders hardware manufacturing plants may exceed production levels of 1950, according to a canvass of manufacturers and distributors here yesterday.

Andrew W. Mulrain, Sanitation Commissioner, announced yesterday that line organizations in his department had been ordered to limit ticket sales for their social functions to relatives and fellow employes only.

The latest addition to the furniture-in-a-package fad is a collection of pieces that can be put together without the aid of nails, screws or glue. National advertising during December took a slight drop from the record high reached in November, but was 27 per cent heavier than in December, 1949, according to the trade publication, Printers' Ink.
ALBANY, Jan. 30--Labor leaders were sounded out at the Capitol today on a Dewey administration proposal aimed at reducing strikes in the state's defense industries during the national emergency.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 31-- United Nations forces hammered out small gains yesterday in their limited offensive along a fifty-mile front in western Korea against the stiffest resistance met since the attack began last week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--The Office of Price Stabilization today freed from price controls all goods and services "peculiar to military needs." The exemption, which was the first to be issued since the price freeze of last week, runs until April 1.

Joseph, president of the E-J Electric Installation Company, 235 East Forty-second Street, electrical construction engineering firm, and an electrical engineer, died of a heart attack on Wednesday in Santa Barbara, Calif., where he was on a vacation. No matter how it is played, Mordaunt Shairp's "The Green Bay Tree" is a thoroughly absorbing drama. Every dog has its day, and yesterday Colette, a six-year-old French poodle, was the center of attraction in Surrogate's Court, where she howled and not without reason, for on the decision of William T. Collins depended her life.

The long-promised "get tough" policy of the Bureau of Smoke Control against chronic violators of the anti-smoke ordinance went into effect yesterday with an announcement that five court summonses had been served on offenders.

A former official of the old War Production Board testified at William V. Remington's perjury trial yesterday that the garbage-intorubber formula, which the defendant is accused of turning over to a Russian agent, was "secret" and under "long and serious consideration" by the World War II agency.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1--A report that the National Production Authority "feels reasonably confident that, given time, many of the shortages which now prevail will be alleviated through expansion of production" was given today before the annual spring management conference.

MOSCOW, Feb. 1--The Soviet press took the line today that Prime Minister Attlee and Premier Pleven had now harnessed Britain and France more firmly than ever to a United States program of preparation for an aggressive war and that both leaders had placed their nations on the path of militarization and a rearmament race.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--Congress registered two sharply differing reactions to the two meetings with General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 1-- Trygve Lie will begin three more years as Secretary General of the United Nations tomorrow--and will find out soon whether the Soviet bloc will carry out its threat to boycott him.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--John L. Lewis has called on his miners to contribute $20 apiece from their newly won wage increase "to build up financial bulwarks to ward off onslaughts from our adversaries."

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Feb. 1-- Charles B. King, whose pioneer automobile in Detroit contributed to an industrial revolution that changed the habits of millions of Americans, will be 83 years old tomorrow. An inveterate craftsman and designer, he tinkered on new inventions today at his fabulous estate. "Dolfincour," on Long Island Sound here and made no concessions to age.

Real estate groups announced yesterday they had filed a petition with the Public Service Commission, asking for a temporary electric rate reduction of $10,000,000 a year. They said it would represent a 5 per cent cut across the board for the 2,000,000 customers of the Consolidated Edison Company throughout the city.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--Miss Frieda B. Hennock, member of the Federal Communications Commission, advocated before the Women's National Democratic Club today the same sort of conservation policy on the television spectrum as has been applied to national parks and forests.

Sharp increases in the number of rental-housing units which may be offered to Manhattan tenants at moderate rentals are in prospect under proposed changes in the Multiple Dwelling Lam designed to foster the creation of additional apartments through alterations in older houses.

TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 2--John Foster Dulles "invited" Japan today to share in collective protection against a possible direct aggression.
A strike by 250 employee of three bus lines operating between Queens and South Shore points in Nassau County forced 40,000 commuters to find alternate routes yesterday.
OTTAWA, Feb. 1--Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent told the House of Commons this afternoon that Canada would not have selective service now although the situation and need might change.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--The Army today asked the Selective Service system to send 80,000 men into training camps in April. This raised to 530,000 the total of draftees already put into service or scheduled since the draft was revived last summer.

Still surging upward, New York bank loans to business advanced $52,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, after a rise of $22,000,000 in the previous week. The latest increase makes the total expansion since the first of the year $130,000,000, and brings the total of such loans outstanding to $6,435,000,000, a new high.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 1--The General Assembly adopted this morning a United States resolution holding that Communist China had committed aggression in Korea. The vote was 44 in favor, 7 against and 9 abstentions.

Industry's principal challenge in the defense program is the need to continue expansion of plant resources, William H. Harrison, National Production Administrator, declared yesterday. The problem facing industry, he said, is whether it has the courage and determination to set aside enough materials to build up its plant capacity for 1952 and 1953.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (UP)-- Retail food prices increased another 1.1 per cent in the first two weeks in January, bringing them to a record high of 220.5 per cent above the pre-war 1935-39 average, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics asserted today.

ALBANY, Feb. 1--The Legislature received today a bill with bipartisan backing that would give the State Commission Against Discrimination broad powers to bar religious or racial discrimination in theatres, resorts, hotels, certain schools and other places of public accommodation.

Many of the new tugs and towboats coming off the ways this year will ply the inland waterways of this area without experienced crews to man them, the American Waterways Operators, Inc., was warned yesterday.

A collection of contemporary furniture from across the seas, just arrived at Altman's, has an unexpected freshness. The group comes from factories organized as the Scottish Furniture Manufacturers, Ltd.

Present and future medical research projects of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America will constitute a memorial to Dr. Robert L. Dickinson, who was senior vice president of the organization and devoted much of his career to research in human reproduction.

The look of cushioned softness, a popular trend in current Paris millinery presentations, ran throughout the twenty-fire original Legroux spring models shown yesterday at Saks Fifth Avenue. The French imports may be ordered here to be made in Paris.

Imported steel for future delivery is being jeopardized by recent price control orders and first steps are being taken by importers to obtain relief. Total tonnage of imported steel affected by the price ceiling exceeds 1,000,000 tons annually, according to estimates.
HOUSTON, Tex., Feb. 1--The Sheffield Steel Corporation is planning plant expansion here costing in excess of $71,000,000, provided it can arrange Government financing.
Headed by Tyrus Raymond Cobb, regarded by many as the greatest all-around ballplayer, members of baseball's Hall of Fame reached the city yesterday by rail and plane from all sectors of the nation.

ALBANY, Feb. 1--Proposals to force a major reorganization of the Board of Regents and the State Education Department, which the board supervises, are under consideration by a special legislative commission that has studied the state's educational system for the last three years.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 1-- Valuable deposits of ores bearing fissionable materials including uranium, thorium, beryl and monazite have been discovered in India, according to a report of the Atomic Energy Commission released today.

ALBANY, Feb. 1--Figures on the state's income from alcoholic beverage taxes, released by the State Tax Commission today, showed that drinkers in the state were consuming more liquor and wine and less beer.

BERLIN, Feb. 1--By a vote of 114 to 8, with four abstentions, all three political parties represented in the West Berlin House of Deputies accepted today a Government program submitted by Mayor Ernst Reuter on the basis of a "great coalition."

HICKSVILLE, L.I., Feb. 2-- The Long Island Lighting Company has obtained from the Oyster Bay Town Board a change of zoning on a twenty-acre plot on Old Country Road between this community and Plainfield to permit the immediate construction of a non-manufacturing unit that will cost $4,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--President Truman today authorized the Defense and Commerce Departments to streamline procedures for granting the huge contracts necessary to carry out the mobilization program. He invoked the War Powers Act of 1941 and the amendment of it passed on Jan. 12.

MADRID, Feb. 2--The organization of Western Europe for its oven defense, backed by the United States, has encouraged Spaniards of every type of political opinion, except the well-hidden Communists. But there is a wide divergence on the role that Spain can be expected to play.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--The White House denounced the railroad strike today, using an unusual technique to do it.

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 2 (AP)-- The first four of seven Martinsville Negroes condemned for the attack on a white woman were electrocuted here today, and a clamor for clemency continued for three others who are to die Monday.

BUFFALO, Feb. 2 (AP)--Walter W. Schneckenburger, who was associated with many banks in New York State during a career spanning nearly half a century, died in a hospital today at the age of 68 after a long illness.

A report that President Truman soon would request that Congress give 2,000,000 tons of grain to India without regard for political considerations was hailed yesterday by the National Lutheran Council as evidence of a truly democratic spirit.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan today announced greatly increased acreage aims for five main food and fiber crops in order to attain "the highest feasibly level of production" for defense.

There was a subsiding yesterday of the bullish flurry in the Governmont bond market which was set off Thursday by the implications of the Washington conference of President Truman and members of the Federal Reserve System's Open Market Committee.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 2--Trinity Protestant Episcopal Cathedral was the scene here this afternoon of the marriage of Miss Helen Chisholm Halle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Murphy Halle, to John Holmes Foster son of Mrs. Joseph Foster and the late Mr. Foster.

The prizewinning kitchen plan in a recent contest sponsored jointly by the National Association of Home Builders and Architectural Forum magazine demonstrates how maximum efficiency may be obtained in a minimum of space. Elliott Magaziner, who played at Times Hall last night, is a talented, young American violinist. It is evident that he has worked hard and seriously. PARIS, Feb. 2--Paquin, Carven and Maggy Rouff devote a considerable portion of their collections to handsome spring tailormades, each group outstanding in its way.

The Army Nurse Corps was fifty years old yesterday. "None of you looks 50," someone said as a joke to three Army nurses at a birthday party given for the corps by the management of the Vanderbilt Hotel.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 2-- Eight ambitious undergraduates. determined to fill a need for "a direct medium of discussion of the internal workings of the college," gave Princeton on June 14, 1876, its first and only successful newspaper when they published the first edition of The Princetonian.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 2 (AP)--An offer by the Alleghany Corporation and associates to the Missouri Pacific Railroad to pay off the $20,000,000 debt of the New Orleans, Texas Mexico Railway Company has been rejected by Guy A. Thompson, Mopac trustee.

A dozen roses in a water repellent, cellophane covered box is a method of marketing with which some wholesalers and growers have been experimenting since 1944. WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--A trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board held today that 106 individual seamen had been illegally discriminated against under Pacific Coast maritime contracts. BONN, Germany, Feb. 2--German members of the Allied-German Military Committee, which ended its first series of meetings today, have expressed strong opposition to the Allied concept of limiting West German units to the size of regimental combat teams.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--Two Roman Catholic organizations struck back today at Protestant charges that the "political ambitions" of the Vatican were in conflict with the "ideals of American democracy." They asserted that such allegations were "unsubstantiated and misleading attacks."

Sale of the Puget Sound Power and Light Company's properties to the City of Seattle, Wash., moved closer to accomplishment yesterday with announcement that a public hearing on the proposal would be held probably next week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2--Thomas K. Finletter, Secretary of the Air Force, has accepted an invitation from the Government of Turkey to observe that country's defense activities under the United States military aid program.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4--Demands for a cutback in the $71,600,000,000 Federal budget for the 1952 fiscal year, with nondefense items a major target, mounted today as Congress prepared to start work on a huge tax bill for putting the mobilization effort on a pay-as-you-go basis.

Air Force and Navy reserve airmen in fifty-four transports, fighters and bombers roared 243 miles at low altitudes yesterday across three states to drop simulated supplies to imaginary friendly troops beleaguered in Central New Jersey by a hypothetical enemy.
NEWARK, Feb. 4 (AP)--The state-seized Public Service Transportation companies tomorrow will renew a plea for a temporary fare increase.

Wallace C. Speers, chairman of the Laymen's Movement for a Christian World, yesterday outlined a program for the practical application of Christianity to the search for "a true democracy that is neither reactionary nor radical."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP)-- Senator H. Alexander Smith, Republican of New Jersey, expects to introduce legislation this week to authorize sending about 2,000,000 tons of grain to India. Mr. Smith said yesterday that fourteen Senators and fourteen House members had agreed to become co-sponsors of the bill.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 4--One of the largest lease blocks ever put together in the history of the oil business, more than 2,000,000 acres, have been completed in North Dakota by Union Oil Company of California.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 4-- Premier David Ben-Gurion appealed today to the Israeli Manufacturers Association for an end to the lockout that had closed the country's 260 metal factories during the week-end.
Instead of a series of concerts featuring "live" and new music at Columbia University's annual Festival of Contemporary Music, the forthcoming festival--the seventh --will be put on records.

BOSTON, Feb. 4--Dorothy Speare, who combined careers as an author and an opera singer, died here early this morning in a hospital after a brief illness. Since 1949 she had been an Associate Professor of Creative Writing at Boston University, and she had taught classes until a month ago.

Baseball's current "off-season" went out in a wild blaze last night as 1,400 guests, including fourteen members of the diamond's Hall of Fame, attended the twenty-eighth annual dinner of the New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers Association of America in the grand ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4--The United States can meet its present national defense objectives and still increase its living standard if the Government pursues "a realistic program of economic mobilization," according to a committee of economists of the Twentieth Century Fund.

With the opening of the spring term this month, the majority of American colleges and universities are planning an accelerated emergency program. The traditional four-year college course once again will be telescoped into three years or less on many campuses.

At the direction of Cardinal Spellman, congregational prayers for Josef Cardinal Mindszenty, imprisoned Roman Catholic Primate of Hungary, and for other bishops and priests who have "suffered similarly in both Europe and Asia" were offered yesterday at all masses in St. Patrick's Cathedral together with supplications for Divine forgiveness of "their enemies."
CLEVELAND, Feb. 4 (UP)--The Standard Oil Company of Ohio said today that it will "simply not go along" with a Government order to cut down on the quality of its products.

Thirty-nine Protestant ministers, Jewish rabbis and other religious leaders from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut asked the State Board of Regents yesterday not to revoke the license of the controversial Italian film, "The Miracle."

ALBANY, Feb. 4--State Democratic leaders are scheduled to make their first attempt this week to block approval of new rent control regulations permitting increases up to 15 per cent. They are expected to begin their attempt at tomorrow night's session of the Assembly.
Charles D. Marsh has resigned as vice president in charge of operations of Federated Department Stores, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UP)-- Julius D. Madaras of Longview, Tex., Hungarian-born inventor, said today he has developed a new way to make steel that is cheaper, quicker and cleaner than existing methods.

Unless new tax measures are adopted, the contemplated cash outlays under the President's programs for fiscal 1952 would require that the Treasury borrow some $12,700,000,000 from the public, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York points out in its Monthly Review, published today.

Gil Dodds, who three years ago set a Boston record of 4:08.1 in his mumps-ridden indoor farewell, was an interested bystander last Saturday when Don Gehrmann lowered that mark to 4:07.9 in the Hunter Mile at the Boston Athletic Association games.
TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 4 (AP)-- Lloyd Mangrum of Chicago played his poorest golf in many weeks today but it was good enough to win first prize money of $2,000 in the $10,000 Tucson Open golf tournament.
Concern over truancy in the public schools of New York, which is expected to increase because of the defense emergency, was voiced yesterday by authorities on education and child care.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4--The United States has started a series of informal discussions with Britain, France, Yugoslavia, Turkey and other countries on the Cominform's increased political and military pressure against Yugoslavia.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4--Members of the Subversive Activities Control Board, headed by Seth W. Richardson, who have been awaiting confirmation by the Senate since Congress convened on Jan. 3, were restored to the payroll late last week and received pay for January. They had been off the roster since the end of 1950.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Feb. 4-- Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. F. Donald Arrowsmith of the engagement of their daughter, Adele Ellis, to William B. McIlvaine 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. McIlvaine Jr. of Lake Forest, Ill. The wedding is expected to take place in June.
LONDON, Feb. 3 (UP)--Soviet gold was reported today to have suddenly appeared on European markets for the first time since the war.

LONDON, Feb. 4--From a nation of beef eaters the British people reluctantly are being turned into a nation of vegetable eaters. Ten years of rationing and shortages have wrought a radical change in the Briton's diet, and the change is by no means over yet.

ZURICH, Feb. 4--Concern over the rapid shrinkage of copper stocks brought the Swiss Federal Government to a decision to grant the Belgian Government a credit of 150,000,000 Swiss francs at only 2 per cent interest, repayable in seventeen monthly installments through the European Payments Union.
Volunteers for the medical emergency division of civil defense may enlist in any one of forty-two job categories, Grover Whalen, coordinator of recruiting and public information, said yesterday.
Rail transport bogged down further in most parts of the nation yesterday as "sick" switchmen carried their work stoppage for shorter hours and more pay through its sixth day.
This week's art calendar includes retrospective exhibitions by three important French twentiethcentury artists.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 4 (AP) --An aroused Alabama Legislature has started a sweeping investigation of the wholesale release of criminals from prison in the last months of the recent Folsom administration.

PARIS, Feb. 4--Fears have developed here of a coal shortage during the year, it is learned in Government circles. Needs for 1951 have been estimated at 73,000,000 tons. LONDON, Feb. 4--The City's initial reactions to Prime Minister Attlee's announcement of a new defense program have been comparatively slight if the movements in the stock markets are any criterion.

The bond market remained depressed because of the conviction gaining that the period of high interest rates has started.

One of the best cake bakers we know (our own home economist of THE NEW YORK TIMES) almost exhausted her supply of adjectives when it came to describing a new coconut square created by Schrafft's. ROME, Feb. 4--The Communists called off today a general strike, scheduled for tomorrow in the Province of Reggio Emilia, that they hoped would prove their dominance over that part of Italy. Last week two deputies from that region, Valdo Magnani and Aldo Cucchi, resigned from the Communist party.

Bishop Herbert Welch, 88-yearold senior Bishop of the Methodist Church, returned from "retirement" yesterday morning to preach at Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue at Sixtieth Street.

The first in a series of three lieder recitals was sung yesterday afternoon in Town Hall by Erna Berger, Metropolitan Opera soprano. Baseball Commissioner A.B. Chandler again appealed for fair play last night and asked indirectly what the club owners had against him.

A program which furnished an interesting perspective of the progress of John Haussermann as a composer was presented last night in Times Hall. It listed certain of the principal compositions which he has completed between the years of 1935 and 1950.

LONDON, Feb. 4--Strike leaders among Britain's dock workers, alleged by union officials to be Communists or fellow travelers, were busy today with plans to paralyze all the country's major ports. If successful, they might seriously interfere with Britain's rearmament and export industries.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 4--The steel industry almost knocked itself out last week by again making more than 2,000,000 tons of steel in a single week. Operations were at a rate of 101.5 per cent, up half a point from the week before.

A 25-year-old medical student died yesterday after a 45-minute struggle with policemen who tried to rescue him from an excavation into which he had backed his car. The cause of death was undetermined last night.

More than 5,000 auto accessory buyers attended the opening yesterday of the twenty-fourth annual exposition of the Automotive Accessories Manufacturers of America at Grand Central Palace.

PARIS, Feb. 5--Balmain is introducing duralumin hoops for day as well as evening. As his teenage frocks have box or accordionpleated skirts, the light metal framework at the base of petticoats gives them a bell flare.

THE lumber salvage and fire hazard elimination programs about to be carried on in those sections of the state forest badly hit by the November hurricane undoubtedly will be one of the most carefully supervised projects ever conducted in the big woods.
MELBOURNE, Tuesday, Feb. 6 (Reuters)--The United States will meet Japan in the first round of the North American Zone 1951 Davis Cup competition. The draw was made here this morning.

LONG MEADOW, Mass., Feb. 5 --The engagement of Miss Joan Lettis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Robert Lettis of Long Meadow and Cooperstown, N.Y., to Robert Johnston 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Johnston Jr. of Cooperstown, has been announced by her parents.

The management of the Paris Theatre, where the controversial film, "The Miracle," is being shown, complained yesterday to Fire Commissioner George P. Monaghan that it had been "singled out" and haled into court on charges of having violated the fire regulations. Mr. Monaghan denied any discrimination.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UP)-- Gen. J. Lawton Collins, Army Chief of Staff, said today that the United States would have atomic artillery shells in the "not-too-distant future" and guided missiles with atomic warheads in a few years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--The Senate Small Business Committee called today for establishment as quickly as possible of a Controlled Materials Program to save thousands of small manufacturers from extinction.

WITH UNITED NATIONS TASK FORCE, at Anyang, Korea, Feb. 5 --This spearhead of United States tanks and infantry warily entered Anyang today, the last city on the direct route to Seoul, and found only a phantom town flattened almost into rubble.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--The Senate Banking and Currency Committee took a hand today in the long-standing Treasury-Federal Reserve Board dispute over the Administration's "easy money" financing of the public debt.

The Chesapeake Ohio Railway reported yesterday for 1950 a net income, after year-end adjustments, of $33,947,000, equal to $4.25 a common share.
Armored spearheads probed enemy positions northwest and west of Anyang and encountered a tank trap and booby-trapped mine fields. Obstacles were successfully eliminated.

The nation's banks may have to replace 25 per cent of an estimated total of 410,000 workers during the next year because of the impact of defense mobilization on the labor supply, 1,800 trust officers were warned here yesterday at a meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., Feb. 5 (UP) --Illinois, relying on quick-opening pass plays and a fast break, defeated Purdue tonight, 85--76, to remain in the thick of the race for the Bid Ten basketball crown.

TRENTON, Feb. 5--Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll presented his proposed budget for the next fiscal year to the New Jersey Legislature today with items for department operations, state grants, capital improvements and deficiencies totaling $180,624,055. The governor recommended no new taxes.
The Corning Glass Works will open in May or June in Corning, N.Y., a new "Glass Center" that will contain the "world's most comprehensive facilities for research and education in glass."

Republic Steel Corporation, third largest company in the domestic steel industry, last year shattered all previous records with new peaks in earnings, sales, payrolls and dividend disbursements, according to the 1950 report made public yesterday.
An investment of $1,000,000 in future good citizenship for New York City is being asked of New Yorkers this year by the Police Athletic League.
ALBANY, Feb. 5--Governor Dewey clashed today with organized labor over revision of the merit-rating provisions in the unemployment insurance law.
