HONG KONG, Feb. 5--The "Year of the Tiger" gave way to the "Year of the Golden Rabbit" tonight as the Chinese population of Hong Kong welcomed the lunar New Year with the traditional bombardment of firecrackers, the clatter of mah-jongg pieces and the start of a night of protracted family feasting.

The presidents and deans of twenty-nine women's colleges in the New England and Middle Atlantic states suggested yesterday that the Government consider the possibility of a voluntary registration of women for special duties in the present national emergency.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UP)-- James V. Hunt, central figure in the Senate's stormy five per center inquiry, was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of accepting fees for helping business men get Government contracts while he was on the Federal payroll.
A group of Boy Scouts went to Bellevue Hospital last night and pushed the patients around. The boys have been doing that every Monday night for three weeks and intend to go on until May.
ALBANY, Feb. 5--The Republican majority in the Assembly blocked tonight Democratic efforts to force the McGoldrick rent proposals to the floor.

DEDHAM, Mass., Feb. 5--Miss Molly Hall Frothingham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Lord Frothingham of Dedham, was married to Harrison Koons Caner 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Caner of Philadelphia, this afternoon in St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church here.

The controversial garbage-intorubber formula, which the Government contends William W. Remington gave to a Soviet agent, was "fairly common gossip" and "a big joke" around the War Production Board, a defense rebutial witness testified yesterday at Remington's perjury trial.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--Secretary of Agriculture Charles F. Brannan today authorized production programs for long staple cotton and castor beans for oil, two commodities critically needed in the country's preparedness drive.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UP)-- The Government said today it expects all petroleum refiners--including Standard Oil Co. of Ohioto obey a forthcoming order cutting gasoline octane ratings.
The Port of New York Authority has under immediate consideration a plan to rent its Union Motor Truck Terminal in Newark to the Air Force for four years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--The American Research and Development Corporation of Boston sought today the registration of 106,420 shares of its common stock of $1 par value, with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Net earnings of the International Shoe Company in its fiscal year ended last November increased $3,275,348 to $10,957,707, the annual report to stockholders disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Director of Selective Service, told the House Armed Services Committee today that a regulation was being written to make eligible for the draft married childless nonveterans between 19 and 26 and other nonveterans with no more than one dependent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, spelled out today a "quickie" tax program entailing the highest rates in history on individual and corporation incomes and on a number of consumer goods, such as automobiles and home appliances.

Hampered by railroad transportation tie-ups, steel operations this week will be reduced to 96.7 per cent of rated capacity from the 101.3 per cent of the previous week, according to yesterday's report of the American Iron and Steel Institute.
LAWRENCE, Kan., Feb. 5(AP)-- Oklahoma A. and M., the nation's No. 2 basketball team, scored its nineteenth victory against one defeat in beating the University of Kansas Jayhawks, 46--41, tonight.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 5--Hedley Woodhouse, the jockey with the push-and-kick riding style that he calls "scuffling," rode his seventh feature-race winner of the Hialeah meeting today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--A State Department spokesman said today that the United States would regard any effort to help Yugoslavia resist pressures from Moscow as "obviously in the interest of the United States."

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 5--More than 17,000 miners were idle in Australia today, disregarding warnings by the Commonwealth Government. Their refusal to work has deprived industry of 75,000 tons of coal.

An elaborate electronic telephone device for foiling police wiretapping and raids was seized yesterday in two simultaneous detective visitations to alleged bookmakers' offices in Queens and the Bronx.

TRENTON, Feb. 5--The New Jersey Assembly approved a revision of the state's traffic regulations today. Breath tests for sobriety would be included in the new code.
The Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York is engaged in an extensive "social research" study of the effectiveness of its parish work throughout Manhattan.
The Soviet military budget for 1950 provided for a real increase of 10 to 20 per cent over 1949 in resources allocated to the armed forces, figures that have just become available indicate.

Armed with literature on Permanent Personal Registration and a line of "sales talk" to match, the League of Women Voters started a city-wide doorbell-ringing, houseto-house canvass yesterday for signatures to Support "P.P.R."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--The Senate was asked today to call on President Truman to remove James W. Johnson as Collector of Internal Revenue for the Third District of New York, one of the largest in the country.

The prospects of an early peace treaty with Japan have brightened considerably as a result of the mission to Tokyo headed by Mr. Dulles.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--The Federal Trade Commission moved today to halt deceptive trade practices in the installment sale and financing of motor vehicles.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--Republicans in the nation's capital, honoring Abraham Lincoln at a box supper, raked the Truman Administration policies at home and abroad tonight as they appealed for support in 1952 to turn the Democrats out of power.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 5 (AP)-- The 1951 Ryder Cup matches between the top ten professional golfers of the United States and Great Britain were awarded today to Pinehurst, N.C. for Nov. 2 and 4. Saturday, Nov. 3 will be skipped to avoid conflict with the North ...
A thousand-dollar bill in New York on a Sunday afternoon is nothing but a pretty engraving of Grover Cleveland.

"Jotham Valley," a musical play presented by MRA, Inc., an affillate of the Oxford group, sponsoring moral rearmament, will open at 8:30 this evening for a fortnight's engagement at the Fortyeighth Street Theatre.
JERSEY CITY, Feb. 5--A class for children suffering from the glandular deficiency commonly called "mongolism" opened today at Public School 11, Bergen Square, here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--The Senate Banking Committee today authorized a subcommittee to continue its investigation of favoritism and political influence allegedly used in obtaining loans from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. The charges were made in a report last Friday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5--The Truman Administration was accused today of having permitted the French to ignore a Congressional warning against alleged harassment of United States traders in French-controlled Morocco.

Lloyd Paul Stryker, one of the leading criminal lawyers in New York, is slated for appointment as a Federal District Judge for the Southern District, which includes Manhattan, the Bronx, and a number of Hudson River Valley counties.
TRENTON, Feb. 5--Only one juror was seated today at the opening of the second trial of six men accused of having murdered William Horner, 72 years old, a shopkeeper here, three years ago.

With housefurnishings, food, rent and fuel all at or near record highs, the homemaker, with her family's aid, would be well advised to set up a budget system or revise her present one to make her bookkeeping easier.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Feb. 5-- Former Emperor Bao Dai, Chief of State of Vietnam, outlined his ideas for social, political and economic progress in a lunar New Year radio address to the nation here tonight.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 6-- United Nations armored columns with the heaviest concentration of tanks yet used by the United Nations in the Korean war punched through the Communist lines in strong probing attacks yesterday.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 7--Chinese Communist troops on the western Korean front pulled back five and one-half miles to new defense positions in the hills six miles below the Han River and the old Korean Republican capital of Seoul as United Nations armored task forces for the second day yesterday probed deeply into enemy advance positions below the city's southern outskirts.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--The Mink Traders Association, Inc., of New York and its seventy members were charged today in a Federal Trade Commission complaint with "conspiracy to suppress competition" in the purchase, manufacture and sale of mink fur products.

The debate on the nationalization of steel, which opens in the House of Commons today, is on a Conservative motion calling upon the Labor Government to reverse its decision on this highly controversial measure. The Labor party was returned to power by so narrow a margin at last year's election that most observers supposed it would postpone action on the bill until another election either revoked or strengthened its mandate.
LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 6--The Soviet Union called on the United Nations today to "condemn" the United States officially as guilty of a series of air attacks against the territory of Communist China.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Feb. 6-- With the fifth and mightiest of its atomic blasts in eleven days, the Atomic Energy Commission today concluded its first series of test explosions in this area. The commission reported that the tests had "saved invaluable time in the national atomic energy development program."

Natural crude rubber futures upon reopening for trading on the Commodity Exchange yesterday, advanced the permissible limit of 400 points, or 4 cents a pound, taking the near-by March delivery to 71 cents a pound, bid.
The Long Beach and Santa Monica school districts of Los Angeles County, Calif., sold bond issues yesterday amounting to $16,190,000.
To the accompaniment of a twenty-piece Navy band, the new American Export liner Independence will be welcomed today as the 200th unit of the post-war merchant marine naval reserve.

"Jotham Valley," the musical play that opened at the Fortyeighth Street last evening, presents a theatregoing problem. As a Broadway show, it is considerably below professional standards, and most of its comic interludes are embarrassing.
ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 6 (UP)-- Jockey Ray York suffered a fractured collarbone today when he was thrown by the horse, On The Spot, at the start of the sixth race at Santa Anita.

WOODBRIDGE, N. J., Feb. 6-- Survivors and eyewitnesses of the derailment here tonight of a Pennsylvania commuter train depicted swaying and bouncing cars traveling at a "pretty good speed" just before they toppled over one another to imprison screaming passengers among twisted wreckage. One passenger set the speed at fifty to sixty miles an hour.

PERRY, N. Y., Feb. 6 (AP)--Senate elections subcommittee investigators interviewed former Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley today for the second time concerning his "debt of honor" and other questions raised by the widely publicized Hanley letter.

PARIS, Wednesday, Feb. 7-- While not declining to discuss other questions, the Soviet Union in its note on the four-power conference, as it was published in Paris today, once more placed the emphasis entirely upon Germany, as though its demilitarization was the principal issue.

The case of William W. Remington, former Commerce Department employe who is charged with having lied in denying under oath that he ever was a member of the Communist party, will go to the jury in Federal court late this afternoon.

PARIS, Feb. 6--A large British surplus and a still larger Western German deficit are the outstanding characteristics of the European Payments Union balance sheet, which now has been calculated to the end of last December.
MONTREAL, Feb. 6 (Canadian Press)--Decline in the extent of the switchmen's strike in the United States eased tonight the box-car shortage which has seriously affected the movement of newsprint.
Importers who have been complaining about delays by customs authorities in processing imports are themselves partly to blame for the present cargo congestion on New York's piers.

Former Chief of Detectives William T. Whalen brought an action in Supreme Court yesterday to compel the Police Pension Fund to pay him an annual pension of $7,012, retroactive to Oct. 16, the date of his retirement.
A subpoena for James Leary, lawyer who has long been regarded as behind-the-scenes Republican boss of Saratoga County, has been issued by the Senate Crime Investigating Committee.

Signing of Infielders Rudy Rufer and Jack Lohrke and Catcher Sal Yvars left only nine of the thirtynine players in the roster still to be brought into the Giants' fold, Secretary Eddie Brannick announced yesterday.

William H. Draper Jr., trustee of the Long Island Rail Road, gave his approval yesterday to the Long Island Rail Road Commission's plan for a state transit authority to operate the road.
WEIRTON, W. Va., Feb. 6 (AP)-- One of the nation's largest tinplate producers today claimed to have perfected a tinplating process it says will make big savings of defense-strategic tin supplies.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--Three wounded Army veterans of Korea today were presented with the first Korean service ribbons by Army Chief of Staff Gen. J. Lawton Collins and Secretary of the Army Frank Pace Jr.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 6 --The revision of war crimes sentences, which United States authorities said they had hoped would end once and for all the West German agitation in this field has not resulted in the desired effect, it was clear today, one week after the announcements by United States High Commissioner John J. McCloy and Gen. Thomas J. Handy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--The Department of Justice today won its fight to handle civil as well as criminal cases arising out of violations of the nation's price ceilings, according to a spokesman for Eric Johnston, economic stabilization administrator.

HONG KONG, Feb. 6--With security crackdowns and revolutionary land reform going hand in hand, widespread social ferment is now reported to be taking place in the rural districts of Communist China's "new liberated areas."

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 6 --The United States High Commission has "heard" that Dr. Vladimir Clementis, Communist Foreign Minister of Czechoslovakia from 1948 to 1950, may be in Western Germany. A spokesman added: "If this is the case, we have had nothing to do with bringing him here."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP)-- John L. Graves, chairman of the Treasury's Committee on Practice, said today it had turned down an application by Paul Dillon of St. Louis, an attorney, for permanent authorization to represent clients in dealings with the Treasury and its agencies, including the Internal Revenue Bureau.

Trainless commuters crowded some New Jersey highways with family cars and buses yesterday, but there was far less congestion and confusion than had descended on Westchester, where commuter trains had stopped running a day earlier.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 6 (AP)--Miss Edean Anderson, Helena, Mont., amateur, fired a 1 over women's par 73 today to take the medal in the qualifying round of the twenty-seventh annual women's amateur Palm Beach golf championship.

Apparently observers of the utility industry, including 3,000,000 stockholders, will continue confused about the so-called threat of Government-owned power facilities. The basis for this confusion was the odd coincidence on last Thursday of conflicting statements from the same source.

A 67-year-old burglar said to have stolen several million dollars in jewelry in thirty-five years of crime was arrested on the East Side yesterday, his pockets bulging with $10,000 in loot.

ALBANY, Feb. 6--A Seaburytype investigation into underworld influence in New York City politics and the general administration of municipal government in New York was proposed today by two Republican legislators from Manhattan, with the reported backing of Governor Dewey.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--The railroads and four operating unions were still locked in dispute tonight, and management estimated that the traffic jam resulting from the "sick" strike of switchmen showed little improvement, considering the country as a whole.

Striking railroad switchmen went back to their jobs in the East yesterday, permitting partial resumption of passenger and commuter service, but many other points in the nation were still locked in the grip of the walkout.

The Public Service Commission issued an order yesterday in which rate increases asked by the New York Telephone Company were blocked pending investigation. The commission directed that hearings be held throughout the state beginning March 1, the date on which the company had sought to make higher rates effective.

Stanley Lock, young American pianist, devoted about half of his Town Hall program last night to contemporary composers. Of the seven on his list, in fact, four were people who are active in musical affairs today. These four were, in the order of their appearance, Marcelle De Manziarly, Arthur Berger, Jacques de Menasce and Virgil Thomson.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--The Securities and Exchange Commission today announced the registration by the General American Oil Company of Dallas, Tex., of 90,748 shares of common stock of $5 par value.

LONDON, Feb. 6--Prime Minister Attlee said today that the British Government was watching and, "in appropriate cases," controlling the exportation of strategic materials to Communist countries.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--Seeking to avert another twist in the inflationary spiral, the House of Representatives passed today a bill permitting holders of Series E defense bonds, which start maturing May 1, to hold them for another ten years on attractive terms.
Assistant District Attorney Julius Helfand, who is directing Brooklyn's gambling inquiry, was reported yesterday in Florida on "business and pleasure."

WOODBRIDGE, N.J., Wednesday, Feb. 7--Seventy-four persons were killed and 330 injured here yesterday when a Pennsylvania Railroad train jammed with rushhour commuters jumped from a temporary track section, strewing the wreckage of eight cars along the side of a steep embankment.

ALBANY, Feb. 6--The Assembly passed unanimously today three bills designed to strengthen the state's civil defense program. They provide for a modernized State Guard, interstate military cooperation, and increased defense expenditure limits for communities.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--George J. Schoeneman, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, gave notice today that the Government hereafter would audit all returns of taxpayers earning $25,000 or more as part of an enforcement program expected to collect about $2,000,000,000 annually in unpaid taxes.
If it would require another defeat to knock Kentucky from the top of the national college basketball rankings, then the Wildcats probably can relax and make themselves at home.
Stockholders of the Singer Manufacturing Company at a special meeting yesterday approved a split of the common stock on the basis of five shares of $20 par stock for each share of $100 par held.

General wage increases ranging from $3 to $5.50 weekly were awarded yesterday by an arbitration board to editorial and general office employes of The Associated Press who earn less than $145 weekly.

Maurice Wilk, who was heard at Carnegie Hall last night, is a serious and musicianly violinist, but the merits he has been developing as an ensemble player counted against him as a solo recitalist in so large an auditorium.

TY COBB unceremoniously bumped into the bottom of the column yesterday just as he was about to take off with some comments on the art of base-stealing. The Georgia Peach always did need running room. Not only was he the greatest of all hitters with an incredible lifetime average of .367 but he was the greatest of all base stealers with a record total of 892, including a one-season high of ninety-six thefts.

MADRID, Jan. 27--It is clear that United States policy toward Spain is founded upon the hope that some day Spanish manpower and the nation's raw materials, industrial ability and geographic position may be incorporated into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

PARIS, Feb. 6--Truly in the tradition of grand couture, Balenciaga shows beautiful clothes, among which the quiet elegance of little pongee frocks is as much to be appreciated as sumptuous, gowns for great occasions.

Loaded to her Plimsoll mark with 9,200 tons of Philippine sugar, the freighter Arimasan Maru put into a Brooklyn pier early yesterday-- the first Japanese cargo ship to enter New York Harbor since Pearl Harbor.

The Easy Washing Machine Company, one of the country's largest producers of electric washers, halted temporarily yesterday production of a portable washer. Paul Nelligan, president, said the move was compelled by a combination of materials shortages and a military contract to produce fuses.

Plans for a veterans' cooperative housing development in Whitestone, Queens, were disclosed yesterday with the announcement of the purchase by Realty Associates, Inc., of the Cresthaven Country Club and Whitestone Swimming Pool properties.

The annual report of the Industrial Rayon Corporation yesterday showed a new high record in sales and a net income of $11,744,610 for 1950, compared with $9,577,455 the year before.

TOKYO, Feb. 6 (AP)--Eighth Army communique 172, issued at 8 P.M. Tuesday (6 A.M. Tuesday, Eastern standard time): United Nations forces advanced 2,000 to 3,000 yards all along the western front today as Task Forces Bartlett and Dolving probed enemy positions for the second consecutive day.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Feb. 6-- Six persons, one of them a Rutherford policeman, were indicted today by the Bergen County Special Grand Jury for conspiring to make book.

A $250,000-a-year loan shark ring, which specialized in supplying ready cash to bookmakers and included among its clientele Harry Gross, major figure in the Brooklyn gambling investigation, was named yesterday in a twenty-seven count criminal information.

AS a result of recent columns on the assorted varmint rifles, a lot of inquiries have come in on the available telescope sights for combined target and varmint shooting, so we made a field check on several scopes that fall in this category.

While the five atomic explosions at the gunnery range near Las Vegas are of necessity shrouded in official mystery, certain facts, known to scientists but unfamiliar to the public, make it possible to arrive at reasonable conclusions about them.
It is essential for the security of the nation that our soldiers be well informed and know why they are in uniform, Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared yesterday.

Marymount College has purchased the Charles C. Brace estate in Tarrytown, N.Y., which covers fourteen acres adjoining the Marymount campus on Nepperhan Avenue, overlooking the Hudson River and the Tarrytown Lakes.

In its latest report to the President, the Economic Cooperation Administration supports General Eisenhower's view that Europeans today increasingly recognize the urgent need of rearmament and are ready to proceed with it as quickly as possible. They are able to embark on such an enterprise only because their economies have been strengthened through the Marshall Plan.

Tatiana du Plessix, leading millinery designer for Saks Fifth Avenue, dipped into the sea for the major decorative motif in her spring and summer hats, shown yesterday. Sea shells dainty as spring flowers, starfish brown as amber, and white shells crisp as quills provide decoration for hats of many shapes and sizes.

The recently completed onestory taxpayer at the northwest corner of Boston Post Road and East 213th Street, the Bronx, has been sold by Land Properties, Inc., to Mildred Grossman. The building, on a plot about 110 by 150 feet, contains eleven stores.

Communists are attempting to "split the English-speaking people," Lady Astor, former member of the British Parliament, warned yesterday. "If the Communists could separate us they'd destroy us," she commented.

A plea for tolerance of the views of our neighbor nations within the United Nations, coupled with a defense of the American demand for the branding of Communist China as an aggressor, was made here last night by Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama, a member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--Senator A. Willis Robertson, Democrat of Virginia, closed the door today on any public inquiry into differences between the Treasury and Federal Reserve Board over the Administration's "easy money" policy of financing the public debt.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Feb. 6-- Edward J. Quintal, vice president and controller of the Chase National Bank at his retirement four years ago, died here this morning in Mountainside Hospital. Mr. Quintal, who lived in Glen Ridge, was 72 years old.

LONDON, Feb. 6--The stock markets here were disturbed today by renewed feelings of doubt that the Government would survive tomorrow's Parliamentary vote on steel nationalization. The undertone, however, remained firm.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 6--Even though he hadn't raced since October at Jamaica, Circle M Farm's Foxey Lad was bet into 9-to-5 favoritism in the sprint for 3-yearolds that topped the program at sunny, breezy Hialeah today. Foxey Lad made the grade.

Leonard Truex, Ohio State's rising star, and Alf Holmberg, Tennessee's Swedish sophomore, yesterday were named as the fifth and sixth starters in the Baxter Mile at the New York Athletic Club games. They will race against Don Gehrmann, Fred Wilt, Ingvar . . .

Teak and ebony woods, imitation mother of pearl, Pakkawood, Lucite and other plastics are some of the materials used as handles for new stainless steel flatware that is decorative as well as functional.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6--Grain markets developed a heavy undertone on the Board of Trade today. Much of the business in wheat was of a commercial character with removal of hedges against export sales, placed at 1,500,000 bushels,

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 6 (AP) --Clear signs developed today that organized opposition would be thrown in the Connecticut General Assembly against the proposal to establish a steel mill in the New London area.

The projected increase in corporation taxes and the impact of excess-profits taxation will bring about a doubling of the number of existing pension plans for employes, G. Warfield Hobbs, vice president of the City Bank Farmers Trust
Intensified merchandising of securities brought a record profit of $12,544,090 last year to Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane, the largest brokerage house in the world.

Construction of the new BeekmanDowntown Hospital at the intersection of Beekman, William and Spruce Streets is now under way. The promptness of its completion will depend largely on the flow of contributions from generous donors to provide $4,500,000 to make the new institution a reality. With the great need for adequate hospital facilities in the down- . . .

TORRINGTON, Conn., Feb. 6-- Announcement has been made by Mrs. John S. Wiggins of the engagement of her daughter, Beth, to Harold Frederick Ellis, son of Mrs. Harold B. Ellis of New Haven, and the late Mr. Ellis.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--Twelve outstanding Eagle Scouts, representing the country's 2,750,000 Boy Scouts and their leaders, gave President Truman today a report on their activities last year and submitted a plan for their role in civil defense. He told them they had done "great things for this republic of ours" and urged them to continue their good work.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--Plans to "draft" experienced staffs of Chambers of Commerce throughout the country to break up the hiring by smaller businesses of "contact" and "influence" men to obtain defense production orders in Washington are under consideration by the Department of Defense.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP)--A spokesman for the aluminum smelting industry yesterday accused three Government agencies of helping keep scrap aluminum off the open market. He said this "vicious" practice tends to increase prices.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 6-- Governors of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms at their meeting here today sent Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder a telegram criticizing his latest proposal to increase the capital-gains tax.

TRENTON, Feb. 6--Technical mistrial abruptly halted the William Horner murder case today, when Mercer County Prosecutor Mario H. Volpe underwent an emergency operation for appendicitis in St. Francis Hospital. Superior Court Judge Ralph J. Smalley advanced trial date to March 5.

At Lake Success a special committee consisting of delegates of fifteen nations has been at work for some time on a new draft of a convention on "Freedom of Information." The United States has been ably represented on this committee by Carroll Binder of The Minneapolis Star and Tribune. Mr. Binder has made a valiant attempt to

MADRID, Feb. 6--With their original nominee turned down because of his notoriously anti-British views, the Spanish are reported to have proposed as their Ambassador to London Miguel Primo de Rivera, son of the late dictator of Spain and brother of the founder of the Falange party. The British have not yet acted on this proposal, if it has been made.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 6-- Ann Sheridan today won damages of $55,162 in her suit against R.K.O.-Radio Pictures arising out of the studio's failure to star her in "Carriage Entrance." A Federal jury of six men and six women decided that the sum represented

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 6--The United Nations' new text for a global treaty on information--rejected yesterday for opposite reasons by both the United States and the Soviet Union--today received the qualified approval of other member states.

Government subsidies to speed up defense production were urged yesterday by former Senator James M. Mead, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission. The areas in which such subsidies would be helpful, he said, would be high cost mining operations and purchase of raw materials from abroad.

For the first time in more than a week the stock market showed signs yesterday of tiring of its sustained advance. While prices recovered somewhat from early selling, the rebound was not formidable and the leadership on the recovery not of a nature to spur a resumption of buying.
WOODBRIDGE, N.J., Feb. 6-- George W.C. McCarter, widely known Newark lawyer, was among those killed in the wreck here today.

WOODBRIDGE, N.J., Feb. 6-- The floodlights of the Woodbridge Volunteer Fire Department and other fire units lit up a tragic scene of death and confusion here tonight. At 11 P.M. rescue workers had not yet completed the task of bringing the dead and injured from the twisted passenger cars of The Broker, Pennsylvania Rail

A timetable for the little-known and all-important chemical mechanism by which the body counters threatening disease germs in the blood stream was presented yesterday at the seventh annual meeting of the American Academy of Allergy at the Statler Hotel.

Last night's accident at Woodbridge, N.J., was the first great railroad wreck of the new year. In 1950 there were five major, rail accidents including the two on the Long Island Rail Road which took 111 lives. The first of these occurred on Feb. 17 near Rockville Centre, L.I., in a head-on collision between two passenger trains.
Franklin Pangborn, who for many years has been active as a character player in Hollywood, will return to the New York stage in the musical, "Make a Wish," which is scheduled to open here on April 5.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 6 (AP)--George Rhoden, Morgan State's national 400-meter champion, set a new meet record while gaining his third 600-yard victory of the indoor track season tonight in the fifth annual 175th Regiment-South Atlantic Association games.

JOPLIN, Mo., Feb. 6--Charles Evard (Gabby) Street, former manager of the St. Louis Cardinals and St. Louis Browns, who was one of baseball's top catchers, died today at St. Joseph's Hospital. He was 67 years old.

Eighteen field offices of the United States Department of Commerce have been authorized by the National Production Authority to act directly on special hardship applications for commercial construction work, John F. McKier

Frank Vincent DuMond, painter and instructor for fifty-nine years at the Art Students League, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street, died early yesterday morning at his residence in the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park. The league's oldest teacher in age and term of service, he was 86.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6--Opposition to drafting men at 18 years old has reached such a pitch in Congress that Administration observers believed today Congress would finally pass a compromise manpower bill fixing the minimum age for induction at 18 and probably attaching a prohibition against sending inductees to combat areas before they reach 19.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6--Government witnesses in the contempt of court case against the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen testified today that the "sickness" of switchmen in their wildcat strike of Dec. 1315 was prearranged by local officers of the brotherhood.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UP)-- Federal agents seized 1,176 unfit or mislabeled food shipments and 223 consignments of dangerous or otherwise improper drugs during 1950, the Food and Drug Administration reported today.

Proposals for creation of an international board for combined allocation of essential raw materials among democratic nations were announced yesterday by officials of the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce.

LONDON, Feb. 6 (AP)--The British Professional Golfers Association today insisted that the 1951 Ryder Cup match at Pinehurst, N.C., be played on consecutive days. American authorities had suggested that the match be played on Friday, Nov. 2, and Sunday, Nov. 4.

UNTIL today only two of Francis MacManus' numerous books had been published in this country, a historical novel about eighteenth century Ireland and a biography of Boccaccio. Both were good, but they caused no great stir on this side of the Atlantic. That one of the finest living Irish writers should be almost unknown here, even among American lovers of . . .

Young, husky Vincent S. La Rosa, vice president of V. La Rosa Sons, third generation in a family that started in 1914 what is now the largest macaroni manufacturing company in the United States, donned yesterday a starched chef's hat and cooked a Lenten dish before food writers lunching at Patio Bruno, 24 West Fifty-fifth Street.

With highway fatalities after dark rated at four times as many as the daylight toll in proportion to traffic volume in this state, safety organizations are urging that adequate testing of ability to drive at night be included in examinations for drivers' licenses.

Business concerns will be asked to give the American Red Cross substantially more this year than they gave last year, David Sarnoff, national chairman of the agency's forthcoming drive, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb.7 (AP)Senator Homer E. Capehart, Republican of Indiana, said today the full Senate Banking Committee should decide whether to investigate a dispute over Government financial policy.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 (UP)--Jake La Motta, world middleweight champion, arrived today to wait for his title bout with Sugar Ray Robinson next Wednesday night. Robinson is due tomorrow, when both boxers will report at Illinois Athletic Commission headquarters for physical examinations.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- A Senate investigating subcommittee today supported a denial by Joseph E. Casey, Washington lawyer, that he had received any fees in connection with Reconstruction ....
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 -- E.A. Roberts, president of the Fidelity Mutual Life Insurance Company, reported today that the company increased its insurance in force by 14.6 per cent or $70,188,447 last...

MADISON, Wis., Feb. 7 (UP)-A state "Taft for President" club was incorporated with the Secretary of State today. It also will campaign for the election of Wisconsin delegates to the 1952 National Republican convention who would be pledged to support Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio for the nomination.

Popular Photography Magazine announced yesterday the 1950 annual awards of the Press Photog-- raphers Association of New York. Mayor Impellitteri headed the panel of judges, which was composed of laymen instead of the customary experts, and will present the awards at the opening on...

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--President Truman called the entire House Public Works Committee to the White House today and urged them in an hour-long meeting to on legislation authorizing the St. Lawrence Seaway and power project.

WASHINGTON, Feb.7(UP) -- Senator A. Willis Robertson, Democrat of Virginia, said today the Treasury and Federal Reserve Board were going to try again to settle their dispute over the interest rate on Government bonds.
WASHINGTON, Conn., Feb. 7 -Harold L. Bache, senior partner of Bache Co. of New York, has accepted the chairmanship of the Second Century Development Program of The Gunnery to raise $350,000, Henry B.

An analysis of veterans' benefits made by the National Industrial Conference Board shows that World War II veterans "may ultimately receive close to $1,000,000,000,000 under the hundreds of Federal laws granting privileges, services and money to them."

Jean Thorp gave her second piano recital in this city last night at Town Hall, playing Scarlatti, a Schubert Impromptu, the BachBusoni Chaconne, pieces by Chopin, Scriabin and Rachmaninoff, and the first book of Debussy's Preludes.

Donald R. Heath, United States Minister to the states of Indo-China, has given what is at once a reassurance and a warning in respect to this critical East Asiatic position. He denies the Communist propaganda that our assistance in defense of the region serves merely to perpetuate a colonial rule.
There were more births and fewer deaths last month than the January average for the last three years, the Department of Health announced yesterday in its monthly report.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Feb. 7 (UP)Pedro Albizu Campos, head of the anti-American Nationalist party, went on trial today on charges of attempted murder in connection with the abortive Nationalist uprising here last fall.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 7--The International Confederation of Free Trade Unions charged today that trade union rights were being suppressed in three Eastern European countries. It said that this conformed to a pattern set by the Soviet Union that included use of "corrective labor" battalions.

Plans for the erection of a new building for its own occupancy were announced yesterday by Schuster's Express Company which has purchased a vacant plot 75 by 100 feet at 434-38 West Thirty-sixth Street,...

Frank J. Sampson, executive assistant to Mayor Impellitteri, received a subpoena at City Hall yesterday and then testified before a New York County grand jury looking into a charge that $27,000 in bribes had been paid by firemen seeking promotions.
ALBANY, Feb. 7 (AP)--The Disabled American Veterans will hold their New York State convention in Albany June 7-9.

A centralized administration of the public schools of eight communities in the North Westchester area was proposed yesterday by experts from Columbia Unversity's Teachers College as they completed a four-month survey.

Net income of the National Steel Corporation in 1950 amounted to $57,814,974, equal to $7.85 each on the 7,361,850 shares of capital stock outstanding, according to the preliminary statement, issued yesterday.

WOODBRIDGE, N. J., Feb. 7-- Charges of excessive speed and absence of a caution signal at the Pennsylvania Railroad's temporary spur here, where a fast commuter train carried eighty-three persons to their death last night, were focal points of investigation today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--Maj. Gen. John H. Church, until recently commander of the Twenty-fourth Division in Korea, confidently declared today that there was no likelihood the United Nations forces would be driven from Korea.

For almost two weeks one of the most respected voices of opinion in the Western Hemisphere has been forcibly silent. For almost two weeks La Prensa, whose name has been synonymous throughout the world for independence of political belief and for sober maturity of judgment, has failed to appear on the streets of Buenos Aires.
Dr William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, yesterday warned district superintendents, principals and other school heads to be on the look-out for narcotics addiction among pupils.

ALBANY, Feb. 7 (AP)--Dr. Cortez F. Enloe Jr. of Manhasset was appointed today as special consultant to the State Department of Health on medical supplies for civil defense. Dr. Enloe, who is a consultant to the Council on National Emergency Medical Service of the American Medical Association, will serve without compensation.
Richard J. Compton, former head of Compton Advertising, Inc., 630 Fifth Avenue, died on Tuesday in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif., where he had resided since 1948. He was 59 years old.
Dr. Claude R. Flory, Professor of English at Florida State University, will speak tomorrow at the winter meeting of the New YorkNew Jersey Florida State University Alumni Club.

PARIS, Feb. 7--Except for the Communists, all members of the French National Assembly voted approval today of Premier Rene Pleven's agreements for a common policy with the United States. The vote was 401 to 182.

SALEM, Mass., Feb. 7-Eugene O'Neill, the playwright, who was admitted Monday to Salem Hospital, is suffering from a fractured right knee, Dr. Frederick B. Mayo, his personal physician, said today. Dr. Mayo said that he had received permission from his patient to describe the injury. The playwright injured the knee when he fell last week-end in the yard of his home in neighburing Marblehead, Mass.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7-Top defense planners believe they can so expand American productivity that a $50,000,000,000 defense program can be superimposed on a continuing $275,000,000,000 civilian economy within the next two years.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 (AP)-Fairbanks, Morse Co. announced today receipt of an order for ten ingle-unit, 2,400 horsepower, diesel electric passenger locomotives for the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company.

The nation's gasoline stocks last week increased an additional 3,439,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end supplies were 129,700,000 barrels, compared with 126,261,000 a week earlier and 127,437,000 a year ago.
An attempt by left-wing groups to sabotage by ridicule the civil defense preparations in Nassau County was charged yesterday by Vincent Wilder, civil defense director at Merrick, L. I.

Plans for the alteration of the four-story building at 72-74 St. Marks Place into a residence club for boys at a cost of $201,000 were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings by...

Richard B. Loomis, secretary of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, will speak on "Lincoln, the Man" at the Lincoln Day dinner of the Kings County Republican Committee at the Towers Hotel next Monday evening, John R. Crews, chairman, announced yesterday. Representative Joseph W. Martin, minority leader of the House, will deliver the principal address.

LONDON, Feb.7 (AP)--Fifty-nine of the original seventy-three entries remained in the Grand National steeplechase scheduled for Aintree, Liverpool, on April 7 after the first acceptance stage today. The second and final acceptance for the four-mile 856yard race is March 20.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Feb.7(AP) -The secretary of the National Livestock Producers Association said last night his industry needs "more production, not more regulations." P. O. Wilson contended at a Clark County Livestock Producers Association meeting that the Federal plan to control meat supplies and prices won't work.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UP)-- Edwin T. Gibson of New York, executive vice president of the General Foods Corporation, was named Deputy Administrator of the Defense Production Administration in charge of staff services today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb.7(AP)Standard Oil Company of California announced plans for a $10,000,000 benzene plant at its El Segundo refinery in Southern California with an annual production capacity of 13,000,000 gallons. The plant, which is expected to be in operation by the middle of 1952, also has been designed for daily manufacture of 3,200 barrels of toluene, urgently needed for aviation gasoline.
Albert J. Fitzgerald, president of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, yesterday asked Attorney General J. Howard McGrath to dismiss contempt cases against seven member's...

An offer yesterday afternoon of an 11.5 per cent wage increase to the 17,000 workers in eight Bethlehem Steel Company shipyards on the East Coast was rejected last night by the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C. I. O.

GUATEMALA, Feb. 7 (UP)-The Foreign Ministry announced today that it had agreed to the appointment of Rudolf E. Schoenfeld as United States Ambassador to Guatemala. Mr. Schoenfeld will succeed Richard C. Patterson Jr., whom the Guatemala Government charged last year with meddling in domestic politics.

Austin J, Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority, will address a luncheon meeting of the Municipal Forum next Wednesday at the Lawyers Club. "The Port of New York Authority Today and Tomorrow" will be his topic.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 7 (AP)-- Argentina announced today the acceptance of Ellsworth Bunker of New York, chairman of the board of the National Sugar Refining Company, as United States Ambassador. President Truman sent Mr. Bunker's nomination to the United States Senate on Monday.
William W. Remington, former Commerce Department employe, was found guilty of perjury last night by a Federal Court jury of seven women and five men.

LONDON, Feb.7-The reinvestment demand from steel shareholders slackened again on the stock markets today pending the result of the Parliamentary vote on steel nationalization. As a result the leading industrialists weakened under profit-taking.

RICHMOND Va., Feb. 7 (AP)-- Two cars of the Seaboard Air Line Railroad's Silver Star were derailed here early today but caused only brief delay of the New Yorkbound passenger train. There were no injuries A railroad spokesman said the cause of the derailment, which occurred shortly after the train had left Main Street station, was not determined immediately.

The Chesapeake and Ohio Railway announced yesterday that it has placed orders for 4,900 freight cars to be delivered in 1952. This is in addition to the 6,000 freight cars already on order which are to be delivered in the fall of this year and the spring of 1952.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 7-- Fred Christ dribbled in from the left corner with 13 seconds to play and drove in for a lay up to give Fordham a thrilling 64-62 overtime basketball victory over Yale tonight.

NEWARK, Feb. 7--The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company estimated today that 150,000 telephone calls were made between 6 P. M. and midnight last night in connection with the wreck of the Pennsylvania train at Woodbridge.
Gregor Piatigorsky, the 'cellist, had not played in New York for three seasons when he gave his recital, with the assistance of Ralph Berkowitz, pianist, last night in Carnegie Hall.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--The House approved a three-year extension of the reciprocal trade program today, but only after the Republicans, splitting the Democratic majority, rewrote it piecemeal to their own liking.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--The National Mediation Board marked time tonight while waiting for the "Big Four" rail unions to offer data that might be used to obtain settlement of the long-standing railroad dispute.
Elmer Rice's new comedy, "Not for Children," co-starring Betty Field and Elliott Nugent, has postponed its Broadway debut at the Coronet Theatre from tonight to Tuesday evening, Feb. 13.

Pan American World Airways, Inc., reported yesterday that it had flown 331,652,000 passenger-miles and 14,483,617 plane-miles in the fourth quarter of 1950. This compares with 391,837,000 passengermiles and 14,417,500 plane-miles in the preceding quarter and with 272,414,000 passenger-miles and 15,662,250 plane-miles in the fourth quarter of 1949.

In fairly active trading amounting to 490 tons rubber futures on the Commodity Exchange continued higher yesterday. Final prices in this strategic commodity were 250 to 325 points higher, taking the nearby March delivery to 74.25 cents a pound.

The season of Lent this year, which began yesterday with Ash Wednesday services in all Roman Catholic and many Protestant churches, will be a time for sacrificial giving as well as repentance among 12,800,000 communicants in twenty-four Protestant and Eastern Orthodox denominations.

Wilbur K. Jordan, president of Radcliffe College; Mrs. Leonard W. Cronkhite, its vice president, and Mrs. Mildred McAfee Horton, vice president of the National Council of Churches of Christ in America, mill sspeak at a luncheon forum to be given by the Radcliffe Club of New York at Louis Sherry's on Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP)-- Announced United States combat casualties in Korea reached 47,388 today, an increase of 574 in a week.
EASTVILLE, Va., Feb. 7 (AP)-- A Marine transport plane crashed in a rain and wind storm near this Virginia Eastern Shore commuunity today, killing all nine men aboard.

Coward Shoe, Inc., will open its new store at 383 Main Street, Hackensack, on Feb. 17, it was announced yesterday by Irving D. Brown, general manager and vice president. This is the first suburban venture for the company. The store will carry a complete selection of shoes for boys and girls of all ages.

Construction of a large petrochemical and cellulose acetate plant in the Edmonton area of Alberta, Canada, will be started soon by the Celanese Corporation of America, it was announced yesterday A new Celanese affiliate, known as Canadian Chemical Company, Ltd., has been formed in Alberta to build and operate the plant on a site already selected.

Mrs. Donald C. Webster gave a luncheon yesterday at Chez Cardinal, 14 East Fifty-second Street, for Mrs. Frederick Harris and Mrs. George M. Hardin of Philadelphia. With Mrs. William Stockhausen of Garden City, L. I., there for luncheon was Mrs. Nielson Olcott.

THE conversational winds were still eddying through hotel corridors yesterday, the last wispy evidence of the mass descent of the baseball men on our village over the previous week-end. If a fellow's hearing was sharp enough, he could distinguish fragments and maybe even piece them together. Shall we try?

Abraham H. Goodman of 708 Empire Boulevard, Brooklyn, Deputy Industrial Commissioner and Counsel of the State Labor Department, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital, after an illness of several months. His age was 63.
Within recent weeks our soldiets, sailors, marines and airmen...

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--The Czechoslovak Government in exile, as embodied in the Council of Free Czechoslovakia, has been seriously disrupted by an internal dispute, and its former leader, Dr. Peter Zenkl, has set up a rival organization of exiles under the title National Committee of Free Czechoslovakia.

ROME, Feb. 7--Negotiations between the United States and Italian Governments to get the Italian rearmament program going entered their final stage with the arrival in Rome of a definitive offer from Washington of financial assistance during the next two years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7-President Truman and former President Herbert Hoover joined forces today in a bipartisan drive to win Congressional approval of a large United States grant of food to avert starvation in India.

GREAT NECK, L. I., Feb. 7-- The engagement of Miss Jean Foley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Foley, to Dr. John McCormick, son of Mrs. John McCormick of New Rochelle, N. Y., and the late Mr. McCormick, has been announced by her parents. The wedding has been planned for June.
BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Feb. 7Tin fluoride has been shown to be 50 per cent more effective in preventing tooth decay than the widely used sodium fluoride, two Indiana University researchers said today.
PARIS, Feb. 7 (AP)--The French Cabinet today approved Manuel Aguirre de Carcer as Spanish Ambassador to France.
BOSTON, Feb. 7--Former Mayor Malcolm E. Nichols of Boston died today of a heart attack in his home at the age of 73.

Mr. McCarter, 63 years old, was one of the leading lawyers of New Jersey as well as a member of a long-established and wealthy family. His father, the late Robert McCarter, was Attorney General of the state and his uncle, Thomas N. McCarter, is the retired head of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey.

While ACTH and cortisone have been proved dramatically effective in relieving severe attacks of asthma and other dangerous allergic manifestations, physicians were cautioned here yesterday to avoid the use of the hormones when possible in the routine management of allergy.

STOCKHOLM, Feb. 7 (Reuters) -- The American Bates hockey team, on a tour of Europe before the world amateur championship, lost, 3-2, to the Hammarby Hockey Club tonight. The Swedes got an early first-period goal. Each team tallied twice in the middle period.
MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 7 (UP)-- Striking janitors refused today to go along with a school board plan to reopen Minneapolis public schools.

BOSTON, Feb. 7--William Stevenson Smith, assistant curator of Egyptian art at the Boston Museum of Fine Arts, has been appointed director of the new American Research Center in Cairo, Egypt, for 1951. Mr. Smith, who holds a Fullbright fellowship, is a lecturer in Egyptian art at Harvard Unversity. For ten years he was a member of the HarvardMuseum of Fine Arts Expedition.

ONEONTA, N. Y., Feb. 7 (AP)-- The Hofstra basketball team beat Hartwick, 67-64, tonight. With less than three minutes remaining, the count was 60--60. Captain Matt Ernau put Hofstra ahead to stay with a field goal and a foul. Hofstra led, 32--29, at the half. Hofstra's Percy Johnson topped the scorers with 15 points.

The National Music Council has announced that it has offered its facilities to the Government for the use of musical activities in the armed forces and in communities throughout the nation "for the stimulation of our people in the National Emergency."

The Baldwin High alumni, including many team-mates of Frank Zachman, basketball, football and baseball star killed in the Long Island Rail Road wreck Thanksgiving Eve, will meet a Mepham High alumni basketball team in a benefit game on the latter's court in Bellmore Saturday night. Proceeds will go to Zachman's wife and children.

The Cribside Social Service Committee of the Babies' Hospital will have its sewing classes during the lenten season as usual, meeting on Thursday mornings, beginning today, at the home of the various members.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP)-A Civil Aeronautics Board hearing opened today on a proposal to abolish airline passenger "common fares" between all West Coast cities and the East.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7-- Federal Judge Michael L. Igoe overruled today motions of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen to dismiss Government charges of criminal and civil contempt against the brotherhood resulting from the "sick" strike of switchmen last Dec. 13-15.
TOKYO, Feb. 7 (UP)--Some 148,000 miners in Japan's four major coal mining companies went on strike today for higher wages.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 7--The new text for a United Nations treaty on information was distributed for comment to member states after a fifteen-nation committee had wound up its threeweek drafting session today.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 7(UP)--The City Council President, the City Controller and five other men were indicted today in Pittsburgh's "free work" investigation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--Amendments to the Defense Production Act to give defense authorities greater control over rising prices will be asked tomorrow of Congress.

Mrs. Helen Hamilton Woods, director of the public liaison division of the office of information of the European Cooperation Administration will be the guest speaker at luncheon meeting of the New York Financial advertisers at the Lawyers Club, Thursday, Feb. 15. Mrs. Woods will discuss the workings of the Marshall Plan and European Cooperation Administration in the reconstruction of Western Europe.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Feb. 7(AP) -United States B-26 bombers given the French, bombed and machine-gunned targets in North Indo-China yesterday in their first Indo-China war mission. French pilots have been training with the planes for a month.
Many parties will be given at the Animal Kingdom Ball for the benefit of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals tonight in the Embassy Ballroom of the Ambassador.

The Horn Hardart Company has leased a store in the fiftythree-story Lincoln Building at 60 East Forty-second Street for a retail bake shop. The store, containing about 2,000 square feet of floor space, was leased from the Saltei Management Corporation through Tankoos Co., brokers.

We congratulate the three Council members who changed their minds on the police retirement bill and thus reestablished the good name of the City Council. These members are Edward A. Cunningham, Arthur A. Low and Maurice J. McCarthy Jr., all Democrats.
FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 7 --The German people were advised tonight by Chancellor Konrad Adenauer to reject Russian promises of neutrality, demilitarization and withdrawal of occupation forces.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 7--Dr. Vladimir Clementis, former Czechoslovak Foreign Minister, is probably "on his way out of Czechoslovakia," one well-informed American said today, while all efforts to check the whereabouts of the former Communist official through official United States and Allied channels drew a blank.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 7 (AP)-- The National Football League squabble over Conference alignment and schedules was settled today by Commissioner Bert Bell despite objections by some owners.
WASHINGTON, Feb.7 (AP)-The Government today called upon commercial growers to plant considerably larger acreages of vegetables this year for expected greater needs under the defense program.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--A $2,750,092,000 program of naval construction and reconversion involving 464 vessels, including a 57,000ton carrier able to launch atomic bomb-delivering planes, was approved unanimously today by a Senate Armed Services subcommittee.

Prison sentences up to twenty years for narcotics sellers and intensified treatment for addicts as "public health menaces" were urged in an interim report on the problem of narcotics control, issued yesterday by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan.

The emphasis on femininity expressed in snugly molded bodices, slim waists and skirts either gracefully full or draped to one side pervaded both day and evening designs in Jay Thorpe's showing of Ceil Chapman fashions yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The increase of about 3 per cent in 1950 honey production partly explains why it is priced lower than a year ago. But despite plentiful supplies and decreased cost, consumption remains at the same level as in 1949.

The first suburban store of I.J. Fox, Inc., fur retailer and manufacturer, will be opened tomorrow in Jamaica, Queens. The one-storyand-basement building, finished in modern style with an all-glass facade, is on 165th Street, just north of Jamaica Avenue, in one of the busiest shopping centers in the metropolitan area.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7-Secretary of State Dean Acheson declared today that the basic trouble in the world at this time was caused by the vast build-up of armaments in the Soviet Union and its satellite governments.
All forms of charges by advertising agencies are frozen by the Federal Wage-Price order, according to an analysis by Printers Ink yesterday.

Ralph C. Coxhead, founder and chairman of the board of the Ralph C. Coxhead Corporation of Newark, manufacturers of the VariTyper machine, died Tuesday night while on vacation ih Palm Beach, Fla. His age was 58. He resided at 10 Gracie Square.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 7-- Arthur B. Krim and Robert S. Benjamin have concluded their deal to take over the management of the United Artists Distributing Company and to obtain new financing for the organization from the Walter Heller Company of Chicago.
HOBOKEN, N. J., Feb. 7-- Degrees in mechanical engineering were conferred on 110 graduates by Stevens Institute of Technology tonight. Thirty-six graduate students received Master of Science degrees.
CINCINNATI, Feb. 7 (AP)-- Major league club owners were called today to meet in Miami Beach, Fla., on March 12 to select a commissioner of baseball.

A total of $59,765 was awarded by the Buick Motors division of the General Motors Corporation last year to 851 employes for suggestions to improve operating efficiency, safety and quality of product. This was announced yesterday by Ivan L. Wiles, Buick general manager and vice president of General Motors. Employes made a total of 4,539 suggestions during the year.

So that tenants of small apartments may entertain large groups of people in an atmosphere that seems like home, an unusual suite has been opened in Sutton Terrace, a new apartment house at 450 East Sixty-third Street.

The Citizens' Committee on Children of New York City, Inc., in letters to members of the State Senate, charged yesterday that the Board of Education's Bureau of Attendance was "tragically inadequate" to cope with the problem of truancy in this city.

A banking syndicate headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane will put on the market today a new issue of $15,000,000 of Carolina Power and Light Company first-mortgage 2 7/8 per cent bonds due on Feb.1. 1981, at 101.125 to yield about 2.82 per cent. The underwriters bought the bonds on Tuesday at competitive sale at a bid of 100.613.

The market for Treasury securities is still taking a wait-and-see attitude about the "fixed pattern of interest rates for the mobilization period" being the sure thing that Treasury Secretary Snyder has been assuming.

ALBANY, Feb. 7-Republican leaders of the Legislature have agreed to fix the date of the fall primary this year for late in August. This represents a concession by up-state Republicans to the wishes of the party's New York City delegation.

Merck Co., Inc., manufacturing chemist, made a new high record in sales and earnings last year. Plant limitations and raw material shortages prevented meeting demands for many products and the year ended with a backlog of unfilled orders, the annual report declared yesterday.

Two Soviet resolutions calling the United States an aggressor were voted down yesterday by the Political Committee of the United Nations. The first charge of American aggression against Communist China was dismissed with a vote of forty-nine against, five for, and three abstentions--Yugoslavia, Burma and Indonesia.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--Vice President Alben Barkley received today the 1950 Histadrut Humanitarian Award, a bronze plaque, at a presentation ceremony in his offices. Histadrut is the General Federation of Jewish Workers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--President Truman told a delegation of Methodist ministers from Illinois today that he was "working with everything that I have to mobilize all the moral forces we have in the world for the welfare of the world as a whole."

N. Gosta Arnheim, Swedish Industrialist and business man, has established an import company under his own name at 40 Depot Plaza, White Plains. He will deal in imports from Sweden exclusively. Any plan for wool subsidies must take into consideration finished goods owned by both jobbers and clothing manufacturers, it was suggested yesterday. This opinion was expressed in comments on a proposed Government plan for subsidizing raw wool stocks in the hands of mills and wool dealers.

Inventories of metal products imported from Western Europe and Great Britain have started to improve substantially with the arrival in greater quantity of goods ordered last summer, it was reported here yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 7--A dinner was given tonight for United Nations Secretary General Trygve Lie by his immediate subordinates to mark completion of his five-year term in office and its extension for another three years. It took place at the Hotel WaldorfAstoria in New York with about eighty persons present.

WOODBRIDGE, N. J., Feb. 7 --The City Council chamber in the Municipal Building here presented a pathetic scene today as relatives of the dead and injured in the Pennsylvania Railroad wreck came in to identify clothing and personal possessions of their kin.

After a brief ownership, the Trans-New York Corporation, operators, sold the thirty-family apartment building at 850-858 Longwood Avenue, the Bronx to Sadie Oresky, through the Vyn Realty Corporation, broker. The building also contains ten stores.

NEWARK, Feb. 7-The chairmanship of the American Brotherhood Week for the New Jersey Region of the National Conference of Christians and Jews has been accepted by Dr. Evald B, Lawson, president of Opsala College, East Orange, N. J. The week will be observed this year from Feb. 18 through Feb. 25.
DETROIT, Feb. 7 (AP)--The Detroit Red Wings ran up the highest scoring total of the National Hockey League season as they trounced the Chicago Slack Hawks, 11 to 3, tonight before 10,182 fans.
Congressional consideration of the nation's manpower problem was still clouded yesterday by attempts to avert the inevitable and evade the unavoidable.

BONN, Feb.7(AP)-- West Germany raised its monthly produc-' tion of rolled steel products by nearly 70,000 tons in January, the government reported today. It said 745,097 tons of rolled steel products were turned out in January, 1951, as compared with 675,795 in December.
Henry S. Woodbridge has been elected a vice president of the American Optical Company and director of its business development and business research department, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb.7 (UP)The Cooperative League of the U.S.A. said last night that adoption of Secretary of Treasury John W. Snyder's plan to make all coops liable for taxes would affect fewer than 5,000 such organizations.
Mrs. Eric L. F. Archdeacon of Rippling Waters, Tuxedo Park, N. Y., gave a luncheon yesterday in the Sert Room of the WaldorfAstoria.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP)--The foot and mouth livestock disease has been virtually eradicated in Mexico, Senator Allen J. Ellender, Democrat of Louisiana, chairman of the Senate Agricultural Committee, reported today.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Feb. 7 (Reuters)--England, with her three star batsmen out, her captain a doubtful starter because of a road accident, and still needing 389 runs to win, was in bad shape today at the end of the fifth day of the fourth cricket test against Australia.

John P. Riley, director of development for the city Housing Authority, will be appointed today by the Board of Education to the new position of Coordinator of School Construction. The post, which was created by the board yesterday at a special meeting, will pay $22,500 a year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Herbert P. Ramsey of the engagement of their daughter, Barbara, to A. Ogden Pierrot Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Pierrot of Washington, and Bluemont, Va. The wedding will take place in June.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--A Government-assistance educational program, designed to overcome shortages in physicians, dentists, nurses and allied personnel, was approved unanimously today by the Senate Committee on Labor and Public Welfare.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UP)-- The House Appropriations Committee patched up its internal quarrels today and prepared to begin work on President Truman's $71,600,000,000 budget.

The Edison Pioneers, a group of early associates of the late Thomas A. Edison, will celebrate on Saturday the 104th anniversary of the inventor's birth and the sixtieth of his invention of the motion picture camera.

The National Asphalt Research Center has been established by the Franklin Institute Laboratories for Research and Development, Philadelphia. More than twenty corporations, representing oil, roofing, molded products, sealing compounds and allied industries, are sponsoring the new organization.

Edith Eisler, Vienna-born violinist, made her New York debut last night at Times Hall. Her program included works by two men she studied with in England before coming to this country, Max Rostal's edition of a little-known Concerto in G minor by Tartini and a Gigue by Berthold Goldschmidt.
A shabby tale of political influence, favoritism and mismanagement has been told by a Senate subcommittee investigating recent operations of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

Some 300,000 tons of raw steel production have been lost during the railroad switchmen's strike, an authoritative steel observer estimated yesterday. But before the strike is ended its effect on steel production is expected to be considerably greater.

Stanley Stolarski was seized by the police only two hours after he opened a new office yesterday. Assistant Chief Inspector James R. Kennedy, who led four other policemen on the raid, said the arrest spoiled Stolarski's elaborate plans for a bookmaking blind and an alarm system.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP)-The Economic Stabilization Agency today advised the Latin American coffee-producing countries it will soon issue-an order setting import prices at the highest point at which a substantial amount of coffee was bought during the base period Dec. 19 to Jan. 25.

Y., Feb. 7--The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization reported from Paris today that it had assigned a technical assistance mission to help Indonesia lower her illiteracy rate and to aid in transforming thousands of demobilized Indonesian soldiers to teachers.

Public power, as represented by the $20,000,000 Electric Power Board of Chattanooga, saved its 65,146 customers $8,300,777 in electricity costs last year, according to the report for 1950 issued yesterday by this largest municipal customer of the Tennessee Valley Authority.

After receiving three emergency calls for supplies of whole blood ahd plasma within the week, the Red Cross appealed yesterday for more donors to help it meet its quotas.

Clarence K. Streit, promoter of a federal union of the democratic nations, sailed on the French liner Liberte at noon yesterday for his first visit to Europe since 1938. A reorganization of the foreign offices of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., was announced yesterday by Leo Martinuzzi, vice president of the offices. MEMPHIS, Feb. 7--His country, his city and his fellow-citizens today honored the late Pvt. Edward O. Cleaborn, Negro hero of Korea.

TOKYO, Feb. 7--The United States peace-treaty mission will suggest a brief and simple treaty with Japan. The suggested terms will not force the Japanse to comply with occupation reforms, but will be within the framework of the Potsdam agreement of 1945.

During the past two years, this office has been seeking a solution to the grave and increasing problem of drug addiction-particularly among adolescents-and the problem of narcotics control in general.

Dr. Henry W. Cave, president of the American College of Surgeons, was honored last night by the Harlem Surgical Society for having initiated a successful movement for the admission to the college of qualified Negro surgeons.

MONTREAL, Feb. 7 (Canadian Press) --The Seafarers International Union of North America (Canadian District) met today with Canadian shipowners and officials of the Shipping Federation of Canada to demand a monthly wage increase of $45 across the board.

Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic state chairman, in announcing yesterday that the Democratic party would support the Mitchell-Roman resolution, declared the party supported any move designed to uncover crime and corruption in public life.

HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 7--Columbia's unbeaten basketball team scored enough in two surges to gain its fourteenth victory of the season and easily beat Dartmouth, 59--43, on the Indians' court tonight. It was the seventh Eastern League triumph for the Lions, whose winning streak over two campaigns now stands at twentythree.

LONDON, Feb. 7--The Conservatives lost tonight what was probably their last chance to keep the British steel industry from nationalization. By a majority of ten--308 to 288--the Labor Government survived a vote of censure for insisting on taking over...

KINGS POINT, L. I., Feb. 7-- The Fairfield University basketball team halted Kings Point, 70 to 53, tonight. The Connecticut quintet held a 24-23 lead at halftime. Jim Homa and Joe Kehoe of Fairfield and Jim Malloy of the Mariners shared scoring honors with 13 points each.

The Terriers of St. Francis gained their eleventh basketball triumph against eight setbacks last night, defeating the New York State Maritime College, 75-48, on the Fort Schuyler court. The setback was the sailors' third in twelve games.

BOSTON, Feb. 7--Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, urged tonight the passage of the Defense Department's universal military service and training bill to meet a national danger "clearly of military nature."

AMHERST, Mass., Feb. 7--Otto C. Glaser, an early molecular biologist, who was professor emeritus of biology at Amherst College, died today in the Northhampton (Mass.) Hospital of a heart attack. His age was 70.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP)-- Federal investigation of the train wreck at Woodbridge, N. J., yesterday to determine possible sabotage was proposed today by Representative Edith Nourse Rogers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--The successes of Government attorneys in the courts bring kudos to individuals and power to officials, but less often do they produce a flow of money into the Treasury.

More ground was lost yesterday by the stock market as caution became more pervasive. It was not that the complexion of the news on the international scene or the domestic economic front had been materially altered, but traders on the New York Stock Exchange saw warning signals in view of the recent sustained advance.
One of the country's top life insurance executives charged yesterday that the Federal Reserve Board was now a "captive" of the United States Treasury.

MONTICELLO,N. Y., Feb. 7 (AP) -Two parole commissioners were injured when their automobile skidded on an icy road near Thompsonville today. Commissioner Louis F. Costuma of New York City suffered head lacerations and Commissioner Reginald B.Taylor of Buffalo was bruised. John C. Karl, the driver, was bruised slightly.
MIAMI, Feb. (UP)--Joe Louis brushed aside another stumbling block on his comeback trail tonight with a unanimous ten-round decision over willing but wild Omelio Agramonte of Cuba.
Helen Keller, who will sail next Thursday on her first trip to Africa, looks forward to "feeling the roll of drums" and would like especially "to see a zebra."

PATERSON, N.J., Feb.7-What is believed to be the country's first comprehensive program to mobilize the industrial resources of an entire city in the defense program was announced today by the Paterson Industrial Commission.

State and municipal financing during January totaled $169,409,290, compared with $248,175,717 for January, 1950, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. The revised total for December of last year is $170,556,841.

ARLINGTON, Mass., Feb. 7-- Mrs. Frank X. White has announced the engagement of her daughter, Ellen Patricia, to John M. Harrington Jr., son of Colonel Harrington, U. S. A. R., retired, and Mrs. Harrington of West Roxbury.
OLYMPIA, Wash., Feb. 7 (UP)-- A bill was introduced in the State Legislature today increasing from $25 to $75 the amount a person must steal before his crime changes from petty to grand larceny.

Holding sixteen accused sellers or users of narcotics in high bail, Magistrate Joseph Martinis in Bronx Court yesterday advocated a revision of the law covering this traffic and also further investigation to reach a solution.

WASHINGTON, Feb.7(UP)The Federal Power Commission said today that the natural gas and electric power industry had made "vast strides" toward developing adequate supplies of energy for the defense program.

A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Melvin H. Safran of Metuchen, N. J., on Saturday in LeRoy Sanitarium, this city. Mrs. Safran is the former Miss Nan Sander, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Monroe H. Sander of 1125 Park Avenue. The child will be named Charles, for his paternal grandfather.

WILLIAM FAULKNER'S first book since he won the Nobel Prize is "Notes on a Horse Thief."* It is at once a brilliantly told story of a manhunt and a subtly woven allegory on man's fate. The style is as intricate as the play of lights and shadows in a painting by Velasquez, you might say, giving a rest, for the moment, to the customary comparison with a Bach fugue.
FITCHBURG, Mass., Feb. 7 (AP) --The Tri-City Dairymen's Cooperative, Inc., will start selling milk in gallon jugs Monday in an experiment "to reduce high milk prices."

NAPLES, Italy, Feb. 7 (UP)-- Naples University scientists have received X-ray photographs that may identify a body in Monte Cassino Monastery as that of St. Benedict who died 1,400 years ago, well informed sources said today.
Naval air and surface attacks on both coasts of Korea continued with sustained intensity yesterday.
R. Smith Schenk yesterday was elected president of the Sun Tube Corporation to succeed R. R. Leonard, who has resigned for health reasons.
Because it is one of the few foods actually lower in price than a year ago at this time, honey deserves to play a more important part than it does in family meal planning.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 7 (AP)--A 10 per cent electric power curtailment for industrial and domestic use in the Transvaal and part of the Free State was announced today.
