MADRID, Jan. 27--The two dominant influences contributing support to Generalissimo Francisco Franco's totalitarian regime in Spain are the army and the church. The Falange party, as such, is a less important, less organized and less certain force.
YONKERS, Feb. 7 (AP)--Yonkers Raceway announced today a change in date for the $25,000 Gotham trot from Oct. 11 to Oct. 18.

A new conference between the Western Powers and Soviet Russia appears today to be more likely. This is the consequence of Moscow's latest note, opening the door for Soviet acceptance of the main Western condition for such a meeting.

"The Man Who Cheated Himself," which arrives at the Palace, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Lee J. Cobb, John Dall and Jane Wyatt head the cast of the melodrama, which is being presented by Twentieth Century-Fox. Felix E. Feist directed and Jack M. Warner produced from a script...
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UP)-- The Navy announced new assignments today for four admirals.

Benjamin Abrams, president, predicted at yesterday's annual meeting of stockholders that sales in the present fiscal year will reach the $74,188,297 volume transacted in the last fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, but profits will be pared by...

Sale of two memberships on the New York Stock Exchange for $60,000 each was announced yesterday. This is $5,000 over the last previous sale and brings the sale price to the highest level since July, 1945, when a membership was sold at the same price.

ALBANY, Feb. 7--Progress toward drafting a new state unemployment insurance law that would reward employers with stable employment records has been stalled by a split between the legislative committee handling the bill and the State Advisory Council on Unemployment Insurance.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 7(AP)-- Miss Anne Dietrich of Cynwyd, Pa., today defeated Mrs. Jack Carrott of Greenwich, Conn., for the women's Atlantic Coast squash racquets championship. With the match tied at the end of four games, Miss Dietrich yielded an early 9-3 advantage in the final game, but rallied to win, 15-11.

An exhibition of books by Negro authors was opened yesterday at Brooklyn College, marking the annual observance of Negro History Week, which begins Sunday. The exhibit will be open to the public for two weeks.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 7 (AP) Miss Edean Anderson of Helena, Mont., the medalist, scored a 2 and 1 victory over Miss Evelyn Odom of Miami today in the first round of the twenty-seventh annual women's amateur Palm Beach golf championship.

ROME, Feb. 7--Three more key members of the Italian Communist party resigned today, and it was reported that an urgent appeal had been sent to Palmiro Togliatti, the party leader, to return from Moscow and prevent a threatened stampede.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, Feb. 7 (AP)--More than 7,000 pieces of property used by United States forces in the United States zone of Germany have been returned to the Germans, United States Army authorities said today.

After a season's absence from the repertoire, Wagner's "Siegfried" was revived yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House as the third event in the "Ring" cycle sponsored by the Metropolitan Opera Guild. The music drama received an excellent, carefully detailed performance:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--Eric Johnston, Economic Stabilization Administrator, set up a labor-management advisory committee today to help him on stabilization problems.

Edward J. Dimock, a member of the board of governors of the American Bar Association, has been recommended for appointment as a Federal Judge for the Southern District of New York to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Murray Hulbert.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7-F. Joseph Donohue, who only recently was appointed chief of enforcement in the Office of Price Stabilization, will leave that job and tomorrow will be nominated by President Truman to be a Commissioner of the District of Columbia.

Charles Henry Tenney of Springfield, Mass., chairman of the boards of seven utility companies, who had been a leader in the development of utilities in New England since the beginning of the century, died yesterday in the Springfield Hospital after a brief illness.

PARIS, Feb. 7--Lieut. Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's Chief of Staff, arrived here late today "to stay" and to hasten the development of Shape (Supreme Headquarters of the Allied Powers in Europe) from a silhouette into actuanty.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7- A repentant Louisiana Sheriff promised the Senate Crime Investigating Committee today that he would close all the gambling places in his jurisdiction as soon as he got home.
LONDON, Feb. 7--Gian-Carlo Menotti's dramatic opera, "The Consul," opened tonight with distinct success before a distinguished audience at the Cambridge Theatre.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 7--A kind of small-scale guerrilla war between the Jews and Arabs has broken out on the Israeli-Jordan border in and around Jerusalem, coinciding with a breakdown in the work of the United Nations Mixed Armistice Commission.
ALBANY, Feb. 7 (AP)--The police stopped the showing of the Italian film, "Bitter Rice," half an hour after it began an engagement at the Ritz Theatre today.

Purchase of 2,500 shares of its 5 per cent non-cumulative preferred $100 par value stock during January was announced yesterday by the Atlantic, Gulf and West Indies Steamship Lines. The company paid $237,074 for the stock, and holds in treasury for retirement 11,605 preferred shares.

Committee 1 (Political and Security)--By 49 to 5, with three abstentions, rejected Soviet proposal calling on Assembly to request Security Council to halt "United States aggression against China" and defeated another Soviet motion by 50 to 5,...

The four-stony business building at 157 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Necaro Company, in the settlement of an estate, to the Brooklyn Heights Realty Company, wholly owned subsidiary of Realty Associates, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UP)-- The Civil Defense Administration announced plans today for a nation-wide fire-fighting organization to protect forest lands against possible enemy attack. It said a national committee already had been set up to work with state forestry organizations and the Agriculture and Interior Departments.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7--The puzzlement and wonder of many television viewers over the faultless delivery of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower last Friday when he reported on his recent tour of Europe was explained today by the radio section of the Department of Defense.
PARIS, Feb. 7--Christian Dior in a much applauded collection introduces a new "new look" in skirts of moderate or tempered fullness, namely half fullness.
The American Gas Association's thirty-third annual convention will be held from Oct. 15 through Oct. 17, at the Kiel Auditorium and various hotels in St. Louis, Mo., it was announced yesterday.

MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, Feb. 7 (AP)--Mrs. Baba Madden Lewis of Newtonville, Mass., advanced today to the semi-finals of the Caribbean tennis championship with a startling 6-3, 6-4 victory over Barbara Scofield of San Francisco, ranked No. 7 in the United States. Mrs. Lewis is rated fifteenth.

A step to "thaw" the Jan. 25 "wage freeze" and make it a wagestabilization measure permitting increases within the pattern of the employer's commitments and past practices was taken yesterday by the Wage Stabilization Board.

Eight college graduates, who had been accepted by the Marine Corps for officer training, were sworn in yesterday at recruiting headquarters, 346 Broadway. They were directed to report to Parris Island, S. C., on April 23 to join the first class for officer candidates that the corps has held since World War II.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 7(AP)The Chilean Government indicated today it was willing to consider lowering the taxes of the United States copper mining companies in Chile and give them greater facilities for increasing the return on their investments in order to stimulate production.
Cook County, Ill., announced yesterday that an issue of $18,400,000 of the county's tax anticipation warrants would be put up for sale at competitive bidding on Feb. 20.
Two more policemen who have been called by the Brooklyn grand jury investigating gambling have retired from the force, it was announced yesterday.

A seventy-acre tract in western Alabama has been purchased by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation for the construction of a plant to manufacture light bulbs, it was announced yesterday. The site is one mile south of Reform. a Pickers County community, and thirty-four miles northwest of Tuscaloosa. The land is bounded on the west by Alabama State Highway 17.

A luncheon was given yesterday by Lady Sparks in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. Francis E. Corbett. Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Baldwin gave a luncheon there for Mr. and Mrs. C. Chauncey Gray of Cambridge, Mass., and Mrs. Ernest L. Heebner was a guest of Mrs. William P. Roth.

CHICAGO, Feb.7-The grain markets were on the upgrade on the Board of Trade here today, headed by old-crop deliveries of wheat and soybeans, all deliveries of the latter closing at the top with new seasonal peaks.

A bill to repeal New Mexico's "fair trade" aw was defeated yesterday in the lower house of the State Legislature in session at, Santa Fe, according to private information reaching a trade organization here.

ALBANY, Feb. 7 (AP)--Governor Dewey today appointed De Forest C.. Pitt, 44 years old, of Hoosick Falls as Rensselaer County judge. The Senate immediately confirmed the appointment. Judge Pitt succeeds Herbert D. Hamm, former county judge who was appointed by Mr. Dewey to the State Supreme Court last week.

BOSTON, Feb. 7 (AP)--Playing wide open and checking closely, the Boston Bruins and New York Rangers battled to a 2-2 tie tonight before 6,602, the smallest crowd of the local National Hockey League season.
Assistant District Attorney Lewis Joseph came to the defense of a defendant yesterday in Brooklyn Felony Court and won for her--a 23-year-old war bride--a dismissal of a Sullivan Law violation.
Strong winds with gusts up to fifty-seven miles an hour howled through the city yesterday as the mercury hovered below freezing.

DALLAS, Tex., Feb. 8--More than a thousand spectators at two performances witnessed a demonstration of trading on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, in the Adolphus Hotel roof garden here today.
TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 9 (AP)-- Eighth Army communique 177, issued at 10:15 A.M., Friday (8:15 P.M., Thursday, Eastern standard time):

The preliminary annual report of the Hytron Radio and Electronics Corporation and wholly owned subsidiaries disclosed yesterday that earnings rose 520 per cent over 1949 on a sales increase of 156 per cent.
TRENTON, Feb. 8--Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll sought a legal opinion today whether Representative Edward J. Hart or State Senator Edward J. O'Mara, both of Jersey City, is the Democratic state chairman.

The Pennsylvania Railroad was sharply criticized on two counts yesterday by Alex Eber, assistant prosecutor of Middlesex County, N.J., and chief investigator into the wreck of the commuter train, the Broker, in Woodbridge last Tuesday night.
NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 8 (AP)-- The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company today reported a $4,705,189 increase in earnings in 1950 over 1949, yielding a 4.8 per cent return on the company's investment.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--The Federal Trade Commission in the 1949-1950 fiscal year, issued 125 formal complaints alleging law violations and reopened two cases, the annual report said today.
John Hughes of the Towers Hotel, Brooklyn, former assistant to the president of the United States Steel Corporation, died yesterday at St. Peters Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 85 years old on Feb. 1.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--The Army broke the back of the tenday "sick" strike of railroad switchmen on orders from President Truman today.
Plans for a campaign to fight an increase in the city's sales tax from 2 to 3 per cent took definite shape yesterday.

Mention of the Woodbridge (N.J.) railroad wreck and testimonials to the "courage" of the Hills, Schiffs, Morgans and others who built and financed the nation's railroads got into the trial record of the Government's antitrust suit against certain investment banking houses in Federal court here yesterday.
The public pays more for newspapers than far all other types of reading matter combined, and payments for newspapers in the United States and Canada come to $1,036,000,000 annually.

ALBANY, Feb. 8--Governor Dewey signed a bill today to increase the monetary jurisdiction of the New York City Municipal Court from $2,000 to $3,000. It will take effect only if a constitutional amendment increasing the jurisdiction of the City Court from $3,000 to $6,000 is approved.
HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 8--Spirits were high in this college town as five inches of new snow today provided a real winter setting for the forty-first Dartmouth carnival, which starts tomorrow.
At the opening of the Senate debate on the question of sending additional troops to Europe, Senator Smith of New Jersey has made a proposal which should help to resolve this whole issue.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 8--Dr. Grace Browning, who was to have left yesterday for Italy to act as consultant on organization and training in that country's schools of social work, died last night here. Her age was 46.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 8 (AP)-- Fritz Thyssen, once Germany's richest industrialist, who was financial sponsor of Adolf Hitler's rise to power, died here today of a heart attack at the age of 77.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 8--A United Nations initiative to get the Israeli-Jordanian mixed armistice commission working again and relieve the tension on the border in and around Jerusalem failed today.

Dr. Hanson K. Corning of 1107 Fifth Avenue, for many years Professor of Anatomy and a member of the medical faculty at the University of Basle, Switzerland, died in his home on Wednesday at the age of 90.
BOSTON, Feb. 8 (AP)--Slugger Ted Williams has signed his 1951 Red Sox contract and, from all apparent signs, continues as baseball's highest paid performer.
The Office of Price Stabilization for the New York and New Jersey area scored victories yesterday against the rising cost of living.

Georg Bech, Danish Consul General in New York for thirty years, retiring in 1946, died on Wednesday in his home near Birkerod, Denmark. His age was 75. Long dean of the foreign Consuls General here, he made his home at his retirement at 1165 Park Avenue.

One way to prevent such tragedies as that which brought death to eightythree persons and injuries to 400 more on the Perth Amboy-Woodbridge branch of the Pennsylvania Railroad last Tuesday night is to find out what caused them.

The need for adequate planning in the development of new defense areas was stressed yesterday by C. McKim Norton, president of the Philadelphia-New York Chapter of the American Institute of Planners. He was one of the speakers at a luncheon meeting of the New York Chapter, American Institute of Architects, at the Architectural League Building, 115 East Fortieth Street.

A NORMAL snowfall makes things a bit difficult for upland game, but a snowfall with an icy crust results in a large loss through starvation and excessive predation, and this situation is confronting game in several near-by areas.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--President Truman today ridiculed a Senate subcommittee's report on political influence in the lending activities of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and accused Senator J. William Fulbright of leaving town to avoid discussing the charges with him.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 8-- Howard Duff will play the leading role in "The Cave," a photoplay by Elizabeth Wilson of Arizona in the 1880's, which is scheduled to go before the Technicolor cameras in two weeks at Universal-International. The studio has assigned William Castle to direct the film and Leonard Goldstein to produce.

MADRID, Jan. 27--Spain, since the loss of her once enormous overseas empire, has always been a poor country regardless of the political regime established in Madrid. The tragedy of the nation is that it is poorer today than ever before.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP)-- Newton B. Drury, Director of the National Park Service, confirmed today published reports that Secretary of the Interior Oscar L. Chapman had asked him to resign as of Jan. 15.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 8--The over-all level of building for 1951 can be expected to exceed the average of all previous post-war years and compare favorably with all but last year's unprecedented volume.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--President Truman said today that he dared Congress to cut the budget, which calls for $71,500,000,000 expenditures in the fiscal year to begin July 1.

TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 9--United Nations forces thrust ahead for more than two miles yesterday against weakening resistance, fighting to trap and destroy the Chinese and North Korean Communists pocketed south of the wide Han River below the old Korean capital at Seoul.

In an atmosphere of high tension and to an accompaniment of shouted objections, the Board of Education dismissed by unanimous vote yesterday eight teachers who had refused to tell the Superintendent of Schools whether they were Communist party members.

SOUTH LONDONDERRY, Vt., Feb. 8--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edward G. Janeway of Middletown Farm, formerly of Oyster Bay, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Priscilla, to Thomas K. Sherwood 3d, son of Dr. Thomas K. Sherwood of Wellesley Hills, Mass., and the late Mrs. Sherwood.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8 (AP)-- The Philadelphia Eagles made a fast switch of football coaches today, replacing Earle (Greasy) Neale with Alvin (Bo) McMillin.

Despite the recent price freeze, shoppers this week-end will find that many perishables have increased considerably in cost since last Friday. Meats generally are 2 to 8 cents a pound higher. Several vegetables have advanced as much as 6 cents a pound. Prices of poultry and some citrus fruits also are up.

WHEN Greg Rice was fumbling along on his way to become America's greatest distance runner there was one fellow he just could not beat, Mel Trutt of Indiana. The bustling little Notre Dame ace would set a blazing pace and then succumb to Truttt's blistering last-lap sprint. Seven times they met. Seven times Trutt won. It was getting to be a habit.

Plans for the erection of another apartment house in the rapidly expanding Murray Hill section were announced yesterday in connection with the purchase by Nathan Wilson of 36-38 Park Avenue and 38 East Thirty-sixth Street, the southwest corner, in a deal negotiated by the Herman A. Acker Corporation, brokers.
The forty-first anniversary of the Boy Scouts of America was celebrated yesterday at a luncheon of the Greater New York Councils.

Direct military production in the Soviet Union in 1950 was at a substantially higher level than originally contemplated by the Fourth Five-Year Plan, which ended last year, analysis of the latest economic report issued by the Soviet Government indicates.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP)--The Government today ordered paper mills to reserve 5 to 10 per cent of paper production for possible purchase by its agencies.

Col. Candler Cobb, New York City Director of Selective Service, announced yesterday that young men being graduated from high school or college within the next month might apply for a thirtyday postponement of their thirtytion in order to enlist in the branch of their choice.

The manner in which Florence and Hans Knoll have arranged furnishings against the backgrounds in their new showroom for decorators, which opens today at 575 Madison Avenue, might almost serve as a textbook of contemporary decor.

A program of art for science's sake was opened yesterday at the National Hospital for Speech Disorders, 61 Irving Place, as eleven adult stutterers put brush to canvas to help themselves and hospital personnel obtain a greater understanding of the cause and cure of their speech impediments.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 8 (AP) --The resignation of William J. Bingham, Harvard director of athletics for the past twenty-five years, was announced tonight by Provost Paul H. Buck.

LONDON, Feb. 8--The Labor Government won another victory tonight. The scanty supply of meat was the issue. Party discipline held in the House of Commons and Prime Minister Attlee weathered the storm by a majority of eight-- 306 to 298.

So many important paintings having been garnered into museums, old master exhibitions are increasingly rare. For this reason, and because it contains some delightful and curious things from Renaissance and Baroque periods, the current painting show at the Koetser Gallery is well worth a visit.
"Ti-Coq" (Li'l Rooster), the play by Gratien Gelinas, better known to French-Canadian theatregoers as Fridolin, will open this evening at 8 o'clock at the Broadhurst Theatre.

Former President Herbert Hoover's timely intervention seems to have quieted some members of Congress who held that starving people whose Governments differ with our Government should be permitted to go on starving.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--Two labor organizations bitterly assailed the Government's economic policies today.

While preparing for total war it would be "criminal" for this nation to neglect its schools, Dr. William F. Russell, president of Teachers College, Columbia University, warned yesterday.
Prices of commodity futures were in a general decline here yesterday, except coffee, which scored gains of 20 to 39 points.
Long Island University, rebounding from the four successive de feats it suffered on the road, handed Seton Hall's quintet a 79-67 trimming at Madison Square Garden last night.

The Brooklyn Museum, which in the last few years has notably increased its educational services to a large public, and in the last fiscal year showed an 11 per cent increase in attendance over 19481949, now finds its entire program endangered unless the public and the city come to its aid with additional funds.

NORWALK, Conn., Feb. 8--The engagement of Miss Nancy Garwood Adams to Bruce Maclean Shields, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin B. Shields of Pittsburgh, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Harold E. Adams. The wedding has been planned for June.
A bankrupt non-scheduled airline and its vice president were accused yesterday by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan of mulcting 300 travelers of $15,000 paid for worthless tickets.

If full production is maintained, the cotton textile industry should be able to fill civilian as well as military needs this year, according to W. Ray Bell, president of The Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York.
LONDON, Feb. 8--For the first time in his reign of fourteen years King George VI received a rise in pay today, amounting to about 10 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--Former President Herbert Hoover declared in a letter made public today that Federal savings in excess of $5,000,000,000 a year could be made if Congress and the President followed through on Government reform.

The final program of the Brahms cycle which Bruno Walter is now completing with the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, and which will be repeated this afternoon, was given last night in Carnegie Hall, with the collaboration of Myra Hess, pianist, in the performance of the B flat concerto.

Miss Elyn Kahn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Kahn of 1125 Park Avenue, was married to Arthur I. Grayson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Grayson of Brooklyn, last evening in the Roof of the Pierre by the Rev. Dr. Sidney Tedesche.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James J. Devine of 965 Fifth Avenue and East Hampton, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Catherine Anne, to Neil Anderson McConnell, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. David H. McConnell of New York. The wedding will take place in the spring.

In observance of Lincoln's Birthday, all security and commodity markets throughout the nation will be closed on Monday, Feb. 12. Various livestock reports, however, will be issued by the Department of Agriculture on that day. Canadian grain and security exchanges as well as the London financial markets will be open as usual.

THE island of Flores, about which Alfred Lewis has written in his first novel, "Home Is an Island," is somewhat less enchant ing than the Terraqueous of Rumer Godden's idyllic fantasy, "A Breath of Air." The reason is that there really is such a place as Flores and most of us have heard of it--long ago when we were children.
The repeated reports that Burma has agreed to turn over a substantial part of the northern border area to the Chinese Communists are disturbing.

The Board of Estimate appropriated yesterday an additional $1,181,000 for the Department of Marine and Aviation, thus assuring the construction of a new Pier 57, North River, to replace the structure burned out nearly two and a half years ago. The replacement is scheduled for completion by the end of next year.

ALBANY, Feb. 8--Four new bills completing Mayor Impellitteri's program for getting New York City more state aid were submitted to the Legislature today. They are expected to furnish a basis for negotiations looking toward a solution of the city's financial problems for next year.

It is a pleasure to see a collection such as that shown at Lord Taylor's in the Bird Cage yesterday. It was designed by Jacques Fath for Joseph Halpert, and is his American collection. These clothes, about two dozen models, are outstanding for their grace of movement.

The two-day reversal of prices on the stock market was halted yesterday and the list recovered under the sponsorship of individual issues. Spurring the advance was the determination of the Army, technical operators of the railroads, to end the tie-up caused by the switchmen.

A $60,000,000 thirty-year 2 per cent debenture offering to the public by the Borden Company was announced yesterday. Also, the Pacific Gas and Electric Company disclosed a plan for early offering of 1,419,562 common shares to stockholders.

News from Albany that New York City is to be the subject of a new "Seabury type" inquiry into official and political corruption perhaps causes less excitement than it might because our appetite for investigation, sensational disclosure and political bombshells has been somewhat sated.

Representatives of police line organizations, headed by John E. Carton, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, staged a preliminary skirmish at the Board of Estimate meeting yesterday against the bills requiring policemen to wait thirty days, after retirement, for their pensions.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 8--Eleven persons were killed in an explosion at the Minnesota Mining Mfg. Co. here at 8:20 A.M., today. More than sixty were injured, a score seriously. A six-story concrete and steel building was severely damaged.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 8 (AP) --Miss Betty Mackinnon of Mount Pleasant, Tex., defeated the medalist, Miss Edean Anderson of Helena, Mont., 1 up in the quarter finals of the twenty-seventh annual Palm Beach women's golf championship today.

Proposals for temporary specialized price-control regulations on imports to relieve some of the "squeeze" on importers under the general freeze were approved yesterday at a membership meeting of the National Council of American Importers. More than 250 members attended the session at the Astor Hotel.
PARIS, Feb. 8--The protectorate of Tunisia will receive an increased measure of self-rule in preparation for full autonomy within the French Union under the terms of an agreement published today.

"The unbounded avarice of many persons," which sent beef soaring to three and one half cents a pound and woolen stockings to seven cents a pair (at modern rates of exchange for shillings and pence), was dealt with in the good old days just as it is now.

William W. Remington, former Government economist, was sentenced to prison for five years and fined $2,000 yesterday in Federal Court. The 33-year-old defendant, who was convicted of... perjury Wednesday night by a jury of seven women and five men, received the maximum sentence. He was found guilty after ...

John P. Crane, president of the Uniformed Firemen's Association, testified yesterday without a waiver of immunity before the grand jury that is studying the financial records of the Fire Department and its line organizations.

WITH THE EIGHTH ARMY, East of Suwon, Korea, Feb. 8-- United States Army infantry outfits that are discarding Negro segregation practices in Korea are discovering that removal of the color line among fighting troops is ...
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--Republican members of the House Appropriations Committee charged on the floor today that Representative Clarence Cannon of Missouri, chairman of the group, and other ...
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 8--Cain Hoy Stable's Battle Morn, at 2 to 5, gave Sam E. Wilson Jr.'s Royal Mustang nine pounds and took a three-and-a-half length beating from him at Hialeah today.

Thousands of striking railroad switchmen reported back to work yesterday in response to the Army's work-or-be-discharged ultimatum, virtually ending the tenday walkout that had crippled transportation and industry.

PARIS, Feb. 8--First audiences this week have been applauding Claude Dauphin in "Mister Roberts" and the Paris critics have been writing pleasant things about the "amazing decor," "the spirited dialogue" and the excellent acting in the Paris version of the Thomas Heggen and Joshua Logan Broadway success.
R.L. Hockley, vice president and a director of the Davison Chemical Corporation, has been elected a director of the Safe Deposit and Trust Company of Baltimore.

Wrangling between opposing counsel caused United States Commissioner Edward W. McDonald to adjourn abruptly yesterday a hearing for three Puerto Ricans charged with conspiracy to assassinate President Truman.

Addiction to narcotics among teen-agers here has reached such alarming proportions as to demand creation of a local public institution to give the cure to youthful "dope fiends," the Welfare Council of New York City declared yesterday.
MADRID, Feb. 8--Jose Felix de Lequerica, newly named Spanish Ambassador to the United States, stirred up lively speculation here today through the news that he was en route to Madrid from Washington.

SAN ANTONIO, Feb. 8 (UP)-- Lionel Hebert, playing in his third tournament as a pro, led a parcracking field through the first round of the $10,000 Texas open golf tournament today with a sizzling five-under-par 66.

With the pace of credit expansion more than double that of the previous reporting period, bank loans to business in this locality moved again to a new high record for the week ended Wednesday, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 8 --Dr. Charles E. Birch, who started as a horse-and-buggy medical practitioner here sixty years ago and still uses a goose-neck wall telephone of the Gay Nineties era beside his desk, retired today on his eighty-eighth birthday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 8--Nasrollah Entezam of Iran, president of the General Assembly, is expected to announce tomorrow the selection of a third person to complete his Committee of Good Offices that is to make a new effort to end the Korean war.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--Highly secret measures have been taken to guarantee the protection of the, nation's supply of atomic weapons from sabotage and related dangers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--President Truman said today that he got the impression at a recent meeting with the Federal Open Market Committee that a majority of its members had agreed to support the Government bond market and hold interest rates at the low level recently announced by John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--A cutback in automobile production ranging from 25 to 40 per cent loomed here tonight following a meeting of officials of the National Production Authority with representatives of the automotive industry.

WITH SPECIAL TASK FORCE, north of Anyang, Korea, Feb. 8-- The command came forward today to "let 'er go," and twenty seconds later the lead tank of this armored column sent a shell screaming into Seoul, to open the first barrage of this offensive against the former Korean capital.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 8 --The Soviet Union does not want war, a prominent Eastern European Communist said today, and the United States, if it accepts this, has opportunity to sell excess industrial and agricultural production in India, Communist China ...
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP)-- Fritz von Opel, member of one of Germany's foremost industrial families lost another round today in his fight to regain stock control of two American companies.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8--The Army's work-or-be-discharged ultimatum to striking switchmen led Federal Judge Michael L. Igoe to release from his court room defendants in the contempt-of-court hearing of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen today.
Leaders of the New York Heart Association had luncheon in their overcoats yesterday in the waiting room of Pier 61, North River.

The recent atomic tests in Nevada are an added evidence of the importance attached by our strategists to atomic weapons as a major part of the formula for victory in any general war we might have to fight.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday that a proposed legislative inquiry of underworld influence in New York City politics "will not interfere with my investigation now or at any time in the future."
Two hundred Red Cross volunteer workers, headed by Colby M. Chester, New York Chapter chairman, were sworn in yesterday by Arthur W. Wallander, civil defense director, as civil defense aides.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, Republican leader in the Senate, accused President Truman today of trying to create "a dictatorship in Foreign policy" on the issue of sending American troops to Europe.

The combination of United Nations victories in Korea and colder weather has resulted in a marked increase in luxury cruise bookings in the last two weeks, according to A.L. Simmons, head of Simmons Tours and president of the American Society of Travel Agents.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8--Dr. Arthur S. Flemming, president of Ohio Wesleyean University, took charge of the nation's manpower program today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8--All deliveries of corn and soybeans and March, May and September wheat and March and May oats sold today at new high prices for the crop year to date before reacting under liberal profit-taking sales induced in part by the Army order to switchmen to return to work.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--Civil Defense authorities here were inclined today not to view too seriously published reports that a model civil defense law issued by the Government "could conceivably empower Governors to seize newspapers and radio stations in wartime."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--A report of Senate investigators cited evidence today that bad labormanagement relations existed in the Bell Telephone System and appeared to be getting worse.

One unexpected by-product of General Eisenhower's survey of Western Europe is to raise questions about three countries he did not visit. It is not by accident that Secretary of Air Thomas K. Finletter is on his way to Ankara to discuss with the Turkish Government the problems that the Supreme Commander took up with the members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

The stock market extended the rally yesterday, although some difficulty was encountered in the last hour and early peak gains of 2 points were halved by the close. The list encountered considerable difficulty in holding its own and profit taking near the close emphasized the divergent trends now operating.

DETROIT, Feb. 9--The Senate Crime Investigating Committee, convinced by testimony it heard in Detroit that public enemies had won "a foothold" in certain key industries here, wound up its hearings today.

What causes a rich cheese cake to shrink after baking is a problem this column examines this morning. The question has been submitted more times than we can count since a recipe for this cake first appeared in this column more than four years ago.

Two firemen rescued two 19months-old cousins yesterday from the top floor of a three-story frame dwelling in the Hill section of Brooklyn during a two-alarm blaze. The infants had been harnessed in their crib and left alone while their grandmother, who cares for them, went shopping.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 9-- William Edmondson, primitive sculptor whose work was exhibited in New York and Paris more than a decade ago, died at his home here on Wednesday after an illness of several months.

Ernest Hutcheson, noted pianist and teacher and president emeritus of the Juilliard School of Music, died early yesterday morning, after a brief illness, in his home at 1107 Fifth Avenue. He was 79 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--The Federal Security Agency today announced a reorganization of the Office of Education, designed to promote efficiency. Operating divisions under the plan will be reduced from eight to three. Each of these will be headed by an assistant commissioner.
A five-alarm fire severely damaged a five-story warehouse at 160 East 126th Street last night and forced twenty families in near-by tenements to spend the night in the 126th Street police station

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--Senator William Benton, Democrat of Connecticut, urged today that the Voice of America be made a "voice of peace and freedom for the free world" and declared that the State Department and Congress had failed to make it so.

Maintenance of American exports to Latin American countries during mobilization was urged yesterday by S.R. Williams, vice president in charge of foreign business of Worthington Pump and Machinery Corporation.
Americans taking part in the current foreign policy debate were warned last night by a Canadian Government official against pressing the threat of isolationism too far.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--George B. Christian Jr., secretary to President Harding, died today of a heart ailment at his home. He was 78 years old.

LONDON, Feb. 9--The range and retaliatory power of the United States Air Force will soon be increased throughout the strategic Middle East by the new AngloAmerican air agreement now in its final stages. Under this agreement the United States will modernize some Royal Air Force bases in the Middle East.
ATLANTA, Feb. 9--Alan Kemper, State Welfare Director reported here today thirty-one cases of abuse of Georgia's old-age pension funds. The cases, he said, were a sample of many in which persons ...

Operations of Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., in the three months ended on Dec. 31, first quarter of its 1951 fiscal year, resulted in a net profit of $1,562,074 after taxes at the current 47 per cent rate. This is equivalent to 51 cents a share on 2,790,704 shares of common ...
New York's big insurance companies asked permission yesterday to invest some of their surplus millions in common stocks and loans to small business--investments now forbidden by law.
The combination of flippancy and arrogance with which President Truman greeted the Fulbright report criticizing the Reconstruction Finance Corporation does not do him credit.
Dr. W.E.B. Du Bois, Negro anthropologist and educator who will be 83 years old on Feb. 23, voiced "a deep sense of shock" at the indictments returned in Washington.

An indictment charging the Pennsylvania Railroad with criminal negligence as a result of the wreck that cost eighty-three lives in Woodbridge, N.J., Tuesday will be sought Monday by Alex Eber, assistant prosecutor of Middlesex County.

Foreign money arbitrageurs say that the recent transactions in gold prove that while the "price system" may be losing out in the capitalist West, it still has influential friends in Communist Russia. By selling gold abroad on the free market at a substantial premium ...

There may be a new twist, if not a new result, to tonight's seventh meeting between Don Gehrmann and Fred Wilt in the classic Baxter Mile at the New York Athletic Club games, which touch off a four-Saturday sequence of track and field fireworks at Madison Square Garden.

The new building to house the $1,200,000 annual Painting Industry Insurance and Pension Fund was officially opened yesterday by Mayor Impellitteri in a former firehouse at 355 West Twenty-fifth Street.

LONDON, Feb. 9--Misgivings in the British Labor party about the rearmament of Germany and the arms race between East and West crystallized tonight in the form of two motions offered in the House of Commons by persistent critics of the Labor Government's policy.
Replying to critics of his previous statement on foreign policy, Ex-President Hoover has outlined a ten-point program for safeguarding both the United States and the free world.

High winds and seas combined yesterday to provide one of the busiest days this winter for the Coast Guard. Reports of large and small ships in distress or in need of assistance kept coming in from widely separated points.
HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 9--Dartmouth went to the fore today in the opening half of its forty-first annual winter carnival held under the best conditions in many years.

An expertimental radar installation to guide ocean vessels and smaller craft during poor navigational conditions in New York Harbor will be set up on Staten Island next month under the auspices of the Port of New York Authority.

ALBANY, Feb. 9--The Legislature is being asked by Nassau County legislators to by-pass regulations of the Village of Cove Neck, L.I., to permit converting Sagamore Hill, home of the late President Theodore Roosevelt into a historic shrine.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 9--Hialeah should have traffic cops on the turns for the $25,000 added McLennan Handicap tomorrow. Twenty-three horses are listed to compete in the mile-and-a-furlong race and there's bound to be jamming, even though there'll probably be some scratches from the two-gate line-up. The number of entries set a post-war record for a major stake here.

TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 10-- United Nations tank-led troops today captured Yongdungpo, industrial suburb on the western edge of Seoul, and a Twenty-fifth Division patrol entered the Korean capital itself.
L.D. Rigdon, formerly manager of the headquarters manufacturing division of Westinghouse Electric Corporation, Pittsburgh, has been named assistant to the vice president in charge of manufacturing.
TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 10 (AP)-- Eighth Army communique 179, issued at 10:15 A.M., Saturday (8:15 P.M., Friday, Eastern standard time):

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 9 --Completing a study of the effects that newspaper and magazine columns concerning love and etiquette have on teen-agers, the Mental Hygiene Association of Westchester County reported today that most adolescents read the columnists' advice but hold it in low regard.
The nation's economy began slowly yesterday to shake off the effects of the ten-day "sick" strike of railroad switchmen, who returned to their jobs in almost full strength.

The New York Curb Exchange's second paid president, Francis Adams Truslow, will resign from that $40,000-a-year post, effective April 1, to "undertake work for the United States Government," it was learned yesterday. His successor will be Edward T. McCormick, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Negotiations are under way for the acquisition of the Stern Bros. department store here by the Allied Stores Corporation, it was learned yesterday. Details concerning the purchase of control are not available, since the transaction has not yet been consummated.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--The Government acted today to circumvent development of black markets in meat during the defense emergency. The Office of Price Stabilization placed the... slaughtering of livestock under rigid licensing and quota controls.

Seven three-story buildings and one two-story building occupying a plot 134 by 102 feet at 287-99 Eighth Avenue and 300-04 West Twenty-fifth Street, the southwest corner, were purchased by Arthur J. Abramson from the National City Bank and Edith Hunter Beebe and Bradford J. Norman, trustee of the estate of George H. Norman.

Merger of the National Safety Bank Trust Company into the Chemical Bank Trust Company has been approved by the directors of both banks and by the State Superintendent of Banks and will be put up to stockholders of the two institutions on March 15.

WE are all book collectors now, from Frederick B. Adams Jr., the mandarin of the Morgan Library, to the righteous serv ants of the law, who are in truth making this an age of anxiety, as Auden would say, or an age of longing, as Koestler will say, for the horseloving bookmakers of the town.

The United Service Organizations was welcomed back to "active duty" yesterday by Lieut. Gen. Willis D. Crittenberger, commanding general of the First Army, as "a good soldier returning to the service of his country in a time of need."

MADRID, Jan. 27--On Jan. 15 delegates of the non-Communist underground opposition in Spain voted to advise the Western powers that any Spanish cooperation in the defense of Western Europe must be preceded by a political evolution toward a normal constitutional regime in Spain.
A panorama of American time-telling from the colonial period through today was presented last night at an exhibition of sixtysix clocks contained in the James Arthur Collection of Clocks and

Miss Dorothy Bloom lost her legal fight yesterday to escape a ninety-day workhouse sentence for failure to make repairs to an oldlaw tenement. Miss Bloom and her sister Pearl were termed two years ago "the meanest landlords in town."

SAIGON, Indo-China, Feb. 9-- The French are rapidly turning the Tongking port of Haiphong and its environs into a beachhead redoubt of great strength. New airfields are being built, and the area is being ringed with a system of permanent new fortifications and entrenchments as part of a large-scale program of defense construction.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9--A sharp break in soybeans as the result of reports that a ceiling price of around $3.33 would be announced for that commodity either late today or tomorrow, or below the current market level, resulted in unsettling the grain markets on the Board of Trade here today.

LONDON, Feb. 9--After a week much disturbed by political uncertainties, the stock markets closed quiet today. Prices moved narrowly and irregularly, although the undertone in nearly all the markets remained firm.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--A basic wage formula that would permit cost-of-living adjustments for all workers temporarily has been proposed by public members of the nine-man Wage Stabilization Board.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 9 (UP) --A high Washington official said flatly today that Ohio Gov. Frank J. Lausche will be the next commissioner of baseball.

ACCORDING to a survey made by wildlife management students at the University of Michigan it doesn't take much to fool a duck, which may come as something of a jolt to wildfowlers who spend hours touching up one decoy to insure a realistic appearance.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--The new Subversive Activities Control Act was found today to be barring from the United States not only long lists of war brides and other relatives of American citizens but alien sheepherders as well.

Although the Borden Cheese Company contended yesterday that it had thoroughly checked food establishments here to halt the sale of its Liederkranz Brand cheese spread, the Health Department reported last night it had found fifty-five jars of the product in eighteen retail stores.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9--Federal Judge Michael L. Igoe found the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen guilty of civil and criminal contempt of court today in the "sick" strike of switchmen last Dec. 13-15 and fined the brotherhood $25,000.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9--The four-day mystery surrounding the early morning attempt of Paul Harvey, a Chicago radio news broadcaster, to break into the Argonne National (Atomic) Laboratory in near by DuPage County was partly cleared up today.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 9 (Reuters)--The Government Information Office denied here tonight that Vladimir Clementis, former Czechoslovak Foreign Minister, was in Yugoslavia.

Net income of the New York Telephone Company, largest operating unit in the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, was $46,501,955 in 1950, compared with $28,802,685 in 1949, the company announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UP)-- The Government will go before a Federal grand jury here next week to seek indictments, possibly for perjury, in connection with recent Congressional hearings on Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, Assistant Secretary of Defense.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 9 (AP) --An all-Texas final in the Palm Beach women's golf tournament was assured today when Miss Polly Riley of Fort Worth and Miss Betty Mackinnon of Mount Pleasant won semi-final matches by identical 3-and-2 scores.

LANCASTER, Mass., Feb. 9-- The engagement of Miss Cornelia Van Rensselaer Thayer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Duncan Forbes Thayer, to Samuel Adams 2d, son of Mrs. Walter E. Robb Jr. of Boston, and the late Charles True Adams of Chicago, has been announced by her parents.

Relief for wholesale salesmen from the mandatory wage freeze under Stabilization Regulation One of Jan. 26 has been assured, it was reported yesterday by Louis A. Capaldo, president of the National Council of Salesmen's Organizations.

Railroads operating commuter services between New York and suburban points have made arrangements, where necessary, for ticket, refunds, or extensions, to passengers who were affected by the "sick" strike of switchmen.

With a V-8, Firepower, 180 horsepower engine of new design and Hydraguide power steering mechanism offered on some models, the 1951 Chrysler line was presented yesterday by the Chrysler Corporation. The cars will go on display today at the ...
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--Canadian Breweries, Ltd., of Toronto filed a registration for 61,220 common shares of no par value with the Securities and Exchange Commission today.

The Federal Court of Appeals yesterday continued William W. Remington in $5,000 bail temporarily and reserved decision on a defense motion to readmit him to bail pending the determination of his appeal.
Herbert Hoover put forward last night a ten-point "peace" program for the United States.

Four men who operated a meat cutters' school for war veterans in Brooklyn were indicted by the Brooklyn Federal Grand Jury yesterday for allegedly mulcting the Veterans Administration of a sum that may reach $800,000.

Test exercises for thousands of aircraft spotters of the civil defense Aircraft Warning Service will be held today and tomorrow along the eastern seaboard under the supervision of the Eastern Air Defense Force.

General Electric Company may have to reduce refrigerator production at its Erie, Pa., plant 4,500 units weekly by April 1 and 7,500 weekly by May 1, Robert C. Reed, assistant works manager, said yesterday. He said growing shortages of essential materials will probably force the cutbacks.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Feb. 9 --Concern that rapid defense mobilization would jeopardize the proposed multi-billion dollar development in the Missouri River Valley to the detriment of the country's food and fiber supply was expressed today at a meeting of the Missouri Basin Inter-Agency Committee.

LANSING, Mich., Feb. 9--Firemen late today were still pouring tons of water onto the State Office Building some thirty hours after a small blaze began eating its way through top floors of the structure, causing a loss now estimated at between $4,000,000 and $5,000,000.

The Childs Company is proposing a recapitalization plan designed to remove dividend arrears on 36,647 shares of preferred stock which will total $11 a share on March 31, John J. Bergen, board chairman, and Charles Crouch, president, announced yesterday. A special meeting of stockholders has been called for March 15.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--Considerable misunderstanding among rank and file switchmen over the import of the Army's "work or be fired" order resulted in many inquiries today from field officers to heads of the "Big Four" railroad brotherhoods here.

For seating extra guests at parties, television viewing or for rooms where space is scarce, stools today are designed to occupy as little room as possible. Some serve a double purpose. One group converts into a day bed with a handy low table; another, with the beach in mind, is portable and has space for magazines and miscellany.

The American Woolen Company, Inc., increased last year its net income to $5,309,630 after taxes and all charges from the $2,194,451 earned in 1949, according to the fifty-second annual report, issued yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--Charles F. Brannan, Secretary of Agriculture, denied today that farm prices were disproportionately high or that farmers were a favored group in the price situation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP)-- The House Un-American Activities Committee, lining up a new series of investigations, decided tentatively today to question the Hollywood actor, Edward G. Robinson, committee members said. Some predicted that another all-out Hollywood inquiry would follow.
Jesse James, that progenitor of Damon Runyon's romantic bandits, rode again last night as the Equity Community Theatre began its second season at the De Witt Clinton High School in the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--The Interstate Commerce Commission today ordered the Railway Express Agency to cancel tariffs that would have increased minimum express charges on fresh or frozen fish and other seafoods from Atlantic and Gulf of Mexico ports to points in the East, the South and the West and between those points.

The two-story taxpayer on a plot 100 by 100 feet at the southwest corner of Broadway and Thirty-fifth Street in Astoria, Queens, has been purchased by Milton Wurman and others from Seymour S. Siegel for cash above mortgages of $112,000. Thomas G. Sarris was the broker.

NASHUA, N.H., Feb. 9--The shoe industry can supply all present military demands and still produce enough footwear for civilian needs, Ward Melville, president of the Melville Shoe Corporation, asserted today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9--Sales of gift wares are running about double those of a year ago at the gift shows in the Merchandise Mart and Loop hotels, manufacturers said today. They said this is not indicative of scare buying, but of forward buying by stores to protect themselves against probable shortages.

About a year ago Dr. Jansen, the Superintendent of Schools, asked eight public school teachers whether they were or had been members of the Communist party. They refused to answer or were evasive and they have now been dismissed from the school system by unanimous vote of the Board of Education.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 9 --Spokesmen for the Federal Government, asserted today that France and Britain wished to delay German rearmament while the United States still believed in the urgency of a German contribution to the defense of Europe.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--The food-for-India program, which President Truman expects to submit to Congress early next week, ran into some tough Congressional questioning today.

VIENNA, Feb. 9--In today's meeting of the Allied Council, the Russians stuck to their contention that Austria had no constitution and therefore could not elect a new President without obtaining the Council's unanimous approval for a constitutional law to that effect.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--The National Committee for Liberation of Slovakia appealed today for United States support of its underground forces inside Slovakia, said to number 20,000 and to be in a position to "disintegrate" the Communist regime.

PARIS, Feb. 9--Castillo of Lanvin presented a collection in the grand manner, applauded throughout by fashion critics. Manipulating fabric with a master hand, he does not mar his silhouettes with trimming or even a useless button.
The theft of $22,300 worth of jewelry from the Sherry-Netherland Hotel suite of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas O'Hara was reported yesterday to the police of the East Fifty-first Street station.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9--The executive committee of the Association of American Medical Colleges heard both principals in the feud over medical policies of the Veterans Administration today, then announced it was keeping a "watchful eye" on the situation.

EIGHTH ARMY HEADQUARTERS, in Korea, Saturday, Feb. 10 --As the strategy of the Eighth Army command continued to pay off with successes of almost monotonous regularity daily, enemy casualties grew today to very great numbers.

Exhibitions by six strongly individualistic painters invite consideration this week. Those who like to keep in touch with contemporary Italian work should not miss Vedova's paintings at the Viviano Gallery.
Winter unwrapped its coldest day of the year for New Yorkers yesterday, with a low temperature of 11 degrees at 5:35 A. M., and the Weather Bureau prediction was for more of the same today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--The Senate Preparedness subcommittee voted today to report to its parent body, the Armed Services Committee, a bill to lower the draft age to 18, with certain limitations.

For some time word has been coming down from Canada about the volatile acting of Fridolin in his own drama entitled, "Ti-Coq." Both Fridolin and Ti-Coq stopped by at the Broadhurst last evening to visit a few New Yorkers and most of the Canadians in town.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 9--Mrs. Adelaide Sinclair of Canada, a welfare leader and wartime director of the Canadian Women's Royal Naval Service, was elected by United Nations officials today to head the new executive board of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund.

The good news about the switchmen's strike is that it is ending. The bad news is that it is not ending in an atmosphere of goodwill. The Government and the public are aggrieved--and have a right to be--at a walkout taken in bad faith and with cynical disregard of the nation's critical needs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--The Commerce and Industry Association of New York asked Congress today for a 5 per cent manufacturers' sales tax on all products except food instead of selective increases in existing excise taxes and higher levies on corporation income.
In a penetrating annual report, Ordway Tead, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, reaches the conclusion that the four city colleges should be unified under the head of a single educator.

A marine in a California naval hospital recovering from battle wounds apologized to Columbia University yesterday for being late to school--four months late. He explained he had been "pretty busy" in Korea.

Publication of a series of inexpensive, brightly illustrated story books written for parents about children, to explain to adults how young people feel about some of the problems of growing up, has been proposed by Mrs. Lucy Sprague Mitchell, author and cofounder of the Bank Street College of Education.

ALBANY, Feb. 9--Dr. James H. Lade, director of the State Health Department's Office of Medical Defense, said today plans had been completed for 263 upstate blood donor stations that could have 20,000 pints of blood on the way to the scene of a disaster by the sixth hour after an attack.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 9-- The independent Marine Firemen's Union, at a conference of port agents and delegates here today, called upon the rank and file members of the National Union of Marine Cooks and Stewards to throw out their present leadership.

Along with studies of the effects of prejudice on children of minority groups, research is needed also into its effects on the youngsters who hold prejudices, Dr. Kenneth B. Clark, a founder and associate director of the Northside Center for Child Development, 31 West 110th Street, said yesterday.

A four-step plan by which Standard Gas Electric Company together with its affiliate, the Philadelphia Company, proposes to comply with Section II of the Public Utility Holding Company Act has been filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Standard stockholders were informed yesterday by E.O. Boshell, chairman and president.

Another investigation of the Paris Theatre, which became involved in a controversy with city authorities shortly after it began to show the film "The Miracle," was opened yesterday by the Fire Department.

Peaking of deliveries of military orders in wool goods during the second and the beginning of the third quarter of this year will leave little goods for civilian customers, it was learned yesterday. The bulk of fall deliveries to men's, women's, and children's clothing manufacturers are generally made in this period.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 9--The Newsdealers Union, which has kept the independent daily La Prensa from publishing for a fortnight, today warned La Nacion, the only independent organ now circulating in Argentina, that it, too, might have the chance of becoming a "martyr."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--For the twelfth consecutive week the weekly wholesale price index again advanced to another record high. The advance of 0.7 per cent in the week ended Feb. 6 brought the index to 5.5 per cent above Dec. 5 and 16 per cent above that in the May 24-June 24, 1950, period.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9--The Senate's Democratic leaders on foreign and military policy decided today to hold open hearings on the issue of sending American troops to Europe and how much hand Congress should have in that decision.

Back from Australia and his stunning triumph in the national tennis championship there, Richard Savitt went on record yesterday as giving the United States an even chance of winning back the Davis Cup this year.

Plunging and tossing like a rudderless ship, Rex Layne, Lewiston, Utah, heavyweight, somehow or other managed to gain a decision over Cesar Brion, from the Argentine, in ten dull rounds of fighting at Madison Square Garden last night. And if there is any consolation in a moral victory, Brion has it.
Prices of coffee, sugar and rubber futures in the markets here declined yesterday, but cocoa futures had moderate gains.

Eddy Duchin, the pianist and orchestra leader, died at 7:10 o'clock last evening at Memorial Hospital of leukemia. Mr. Duchin, whose full name was Edwin Frank Duchin, was 41 years old. He had been under treatment for several months.

Aaron Rosand, who made a good impression at his debut recital two years ago, practically duplicated it when he played again in Town Hall last night. The Indiana-born violinist is a reliable, musicianly performer.

Three teachers have resigned rather than answer questions about Communist party membership, Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, reported yesterday after the Board of Education had dismissed eight others who had refused to answer similar queries.
The Louis O. Coxe and R.H. Chapman play, "Billy Budd," based on Herman Melville's sea novel of the same name, opens tonight at the Biltmore Theatre. The curtain is announced to rise at 8:30.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 9--Britain has taken the lead in diplomatic consultations aimed at finding a formula to break the three-yearold deadlock between India and Pakistan over the princely state of Kashmir.

A 1951-1952 city budget at least $50,000,000 higher than the current record budget of $1,254,431,504 was indicated yesterday as scheduled departmental hearings before Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson drew to a close.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP)-- Senate crime investigators said today they might ask Congress to set up a permanent commission to expose big-time criminals whose operations criss-cross state lines.

On the eve of Lincoln's Birthday exiles from ten countries in Eastern Europe met at Independence Hall, in Philadelphia, to issue a Declaration of Liberation.

The extent to which residents of New York State benefited in a year from the health, education and social security programs of the Federal Security Agency was outlined yesterday by Joseph B. O'Connor, regional director of the agency, whose headquarters are in this city.

Artur Rubinstein's affinity for Chopin is well known and so there was a capacity audience of 2,800 at Carnegie Hall last night when the Polish pianist followed his precedent of last season and devoted the first of his current New York recitals to the music of that master.

Takeo Okubo, wiry and energetic director of the Maritime Safety Agency of Japan, is on his way home after a whirlwind inspection and study of safety and other maritime activities of the United States Coast Guard.

Christians with the "perverted notion" that God shows favoritism to "those who love Him" are victims of an illusion, the Rev. Albert L. Neibacher said in his sermon yesterday at St. Luke's Lutheran Church, 308 West Forty-sixth Street.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 11--Prime Minister Willem Drees said last week the emergency program being drawn up to cope with the proposed large defense expenditures and the gap in the payments balance would have to form the basis of any new Cabinet.

Nobody bothered to publish Herman Melville's grim story of "Billy Budd" until thirty years after his death. It was easy to evade the malign implications of the sea yarn by stuffing it into a pigeonhole. But it is going to be hard to avoid thinking about it now.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb.11--With Edward G. Miller Jr., United States Assistant Secretary of State, scheduled to arrive here in the course of the Pan-American Olympic Games beginning Feb. 25, and with Argentina facing the Inter-American foreign ministers' meeting March 26, the closing of the independent newspaper La Prensa has reawakened sharp criticism of the Peron regime throughout the Western Hemisphere and in several European capitals.
TRIESTE, Feb. 11 (AP)--ProTito Yugoslavs who now live on the Italian side of the frontier and in Trieste are making sport shoes for the women of America.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 11 (AP)--Seven golfers left here tonight by plane for Mexico City to play in the Mexican National Open, six of them in defiance of an order from the P.G.A. tournament committee.

COLUMBIA, Pa., Feb. 11--A critical water shortage has developed here as the result of the Susquehanna River's freezing solid from shore to shore for eight miles. Emergency decrees were imposed today to protect the community's 12,000 residents against drought and fire hazards.
Three dogs imported by Tom Gately of Wilton, Conn., were among those that glittered in the Associated Terrier Clubs show at the 212th A.A.A. Group Armory yesterday.
A New York City teacher training pamphlet put out by the Board of Education was attacked yesterday by Roman Catholic educators as "atheistic" and critical of the philosophy of their church.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11--The United States was described in authoritative, quarters today as seeking a Hemisphere-wide export control policy to check the flow of critical materials to the Soviet Union and its satellites.

As a result of a sharp drop in enrollment, 20,000 to 25,000 faculty members of American colleges and universities either will be dismissed from their jobs this year or will not be replaced when they leave for military or Government service or war jobs.

Assemblyman John R. Brook of Manhattan remarked in Albany, as he introduced a revised bill for Permanent Personal Registration of voters, that this issue had been before the Legislature since 1926 and he hoped it would be "resolved once and for all at the present session." We fervently hope so, too.
The story of the four Godfrey brothers which recently appeared in this newspaper moved thousands.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UP)-- Senator Pat MeCarran, Democrat of Nevada, said today that the Senate Internal Security subcommittee, of which he is chairman, would investigate "fully" all matters involved in the records of the Institute of Pacific Relations. The Senator, in Reno, was interviewed by telephone.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 11-- George C. McGhee, Assistant Secretary of State for Near East and African Affairs, arrived here today for a conference of United States diplomatic representatives accredited to countries in this area that is to begin in Istanbul Wednesday.

LONDON, Feb. 11--While the Western powers have been weighing the Soviet satellites' threat to Yugloslavia and considering what assistance they might give to the Belgrade Government, Marshal Tito himself has not yet asked for any arms or a security guarantee according to official information here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UP)-- The Wage Stabilization Board, under mounting pressure to relax the freeze on collective bargaining contracts, will meet Tuesday to consider a compromise formula for permitting general pay increases.
LANSING, Mich., Feb. 11.(AP)-- A 19-year-old father took full blame today for the $4,000,000 fire that ruined the upper floors of the State Office Building here.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. 11 (UP)--Doug Ford, a newcomer to pro ranks, and the veteran E.J. (Dutch) Harrison tied today at 265 for top honors in the $10,000 Texas Open golf tournament. They will meet tomorrow in an 18-hole play-off for the title.

Governor Dewey split sharply yesterday with other national leaders of the Republican party by declaring that American military leaders must establish joint airsea-ground defenses abroad without the necessity for Congressional approval of such commitments.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 11 (UP)-- Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, Iran's 31-year-old "King of Kings," weds the young daughter of a tribal leader tomorrow.

Action to bring the Schuman Plan into official existence--with some decisions on actual implementation possibly left for settlement as the need arises--is expected in a matter of weeks, according to word reaching a major business and foreign trade group here last week.
The Marionette Theatre of the Park Department will begin a tour of educational and recreational agencies in Queens tomorrow. The theatre will present twenty-eight performances of "Pinocchio."

School children, college students, civil service employes and workers in banks and institutions north of the Mason-Dixon line will have a holiday today in observance of Lincoln's Birthday. Celebrations of a semi-private nature will be held in the South.

An expert on family finances offered a timely hint yesterday: Outwit the inflation by re-examining your routine expenses and curtailing them all you can. Do not let them pick your pocket, all but unobserved, of money for "those extra things that keep up going, that give us a lift, in times like these."

Preaching the first in a series of Lenten sermons on the general theme "Marriage" Msgr. Fulton J. Sheen declared yesterday that "the greatest fallacy of the modern world is that it takes only two to make love."
An inventory of every type of equipment that would be needed to dig the city out from the rubble of an atomic bomb attack--equipment ranging from picks and shovels to giant cranes--is well under way.

A list of ten clubs and canteens now open to men and women in the armed forces was issued yesterday by the United Services Organizations.

The 1951 Nash Healey, a twopassenger sports car capable of a speed of 125 miles an hour, was announced yesterday by Nash motors division, Nash-Kevinator Corporation. The car will sell for $3,750 to $4,000 in this city, exclusive of sales and excise taxes and retail delivery charges.
NASSAU, Bahamas, Feb. 14 (AP)--The 72-foot ketch Ticonderoga led the fleet of seventeen yachts across the finish line in the 184-mile Miami-to-Nassau race tonight.

Winter was tossed right out of the minds of several hundred women who attended Martin's spring fashion parade in Brooklyn yesterday. The store officially started its new fashion season with a fresh, feminine look in colors, fabrics and silhouettes.

Though neither so abundant nor so low in cost as a year ago, eggs nevertheless are readily available this month, of top quality and reasonably priced.

Gene Hermanski, the regular left fielder, an outstanding candidate for Gene's job and a pitcher signed yesterday to raise to thirtyseven the number of Dodgers under contract. Only Preacher Roe, Billy Cox and Eddie Miksis remain unsigned.

The shift in emphasis of the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund from Europe to Asia and the Middle East is strikingly illustrated by the change in membership of the Fund's executive board. Instead of two representatives from Asia and fourteen from Europe on the twenty-six-nation body, there are now eight from each of the two areas.

TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 15-- A hard-fighting allied division today claimed victory "as of this moment" over elements of nine Chinese Communist divisions that tried to break through the central Korean front.
A husband and wife in whose home the plot to assassinate President Truman was hatched, according to the Government's charges, were arraigned yesterday in Federal court.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP)-- American manufacturers of jeweled watches asked today that tariffs on imported watches and movements having up to seventeen jewels be raised to the 1930 rates.

Within a few days home cooks will be offered, for a small sum, the first recipe booklet devoted exclusively to cake mixes. In "Betty Crocker's Cake Mix Magic," General Mills presents more than 120 formulas utilizing its three mixes not only in cakes but also in puddings and cookies.

An intensive campaign to curb the reckless tactics and other shortcomings of motorists was opened yesterday in Manhattan. This latest effort to cut down traffic accidents included tests for drivers and street safety exhibits at the Port Authority Bus Terminal, Eighth Avenue and Forty-first Street; at Grand Central Terminal and at the Baltimore Ohio bus depot at 122 East Forty-second Street.

Albert Budlow has been appointed national manager of the tobacco division of Eversharp, Inc. He formerly was a field director and merchandising expert for the National Association of Tobacco Distributors.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--The question of the way in which Federal funds for education are apportioned was raised forcefully today in the annual report of the Office of Education.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 14-- A conference of United States chiefs of diplomatic missions in the Near and Middle East began here today under the presidency of George C. McGhee, Assistant Secretary of State. It is scheduled to last one week, with morning and afternoon sessions--all in the strictest secrecy.

Price trends in commodity futures on the local exchanges yesterday were mixed. Coffee and cocoa advanced, world sugar futures declined and domestic sugar, cottonseed oil and soybean oil contracts held firm in the near-by deliveries.

Guaranty Trust Company of New York has been appointed paying agent for $17,500,000 Southern Natural Gas Company 2 7/8 per cent first mortgage pipe line sinking fund bonds, dated Dec. 1, 1950, and due in 1970; also New York paying agent of Village of Kenmore, N.Y., 1 per cent public (serial) improvement bonds, dated Feb. 1, 1951.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--The market value of the nation's output of goods and services, or the "gross national product," advanced to $280,000,000,000 in 1950, an increase of $24,000,000,000 over 1949, the Department of Commerce reported today.

LONDON, Thursday, Feb. 15-- A shotgun wedding took place last midnight in Britain between private enterprise and public ownership. The rich and unwilling bride was the iron and steel industry which was obliged to say "I do" to the new Iron and Steel Corporation established by Act of Parliament and this country's Socialist Government.

SAVANNAH, Feb. 14--Attorney General J. Howard McGrath announced tonight that he would move soon to bolster investigations into Communist conspiracies and inter-state gambling rings by asking Congress for authority to grant immunity from prosecution to witnesses essential to grand jury and Congressional committee inquiries.

IT is a poor year indeed when fewer than fifty books are published on various types of fishing, and usually the assortment covers bluegills to giant tuna. But this season finds two volumes in print which have long been needed by anglers who want to know where to go, what to do aad what to expect.

BRISTOL, England, Feb. 14--In this war-blitzed "city of a thousand spires" a small 41-year-old railway clerk has become overnight one of the most discussed political figures in Britain. He is Harold Lawrance, an avowed pacifist, a conscientious objector in World War II and the official Labor party candidate in tomorrow's Parliamentary by-election for West Bristol.
