A "surprise" witness testified to the Middlesex County grand jury in New Brunswick, N.J., yesterday that the tender of a Pennsylvania Railroad commuter train that crashed in Woodbridge on Feb. 6 was not in proper condition just before the fatal run.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14--One hundred eighteen of the 199 Republican members of the House of Representatives demanded today that the United States concentrate its military efforts on defending the Western Hemisphere.

The motor vessel Dona Aurora of the De La Rama Steamship Company, Inc., the second of three new vessels built in Japan for the line, is due here today on her maiden voyage from Manila. The 504-foot freighter will be berthed at Pier 33, Atlantic Basin, Brooklyn, this afternoon.

Princeton prevailed over the elements and the best opposition that Pennsylvania and Columbia could muster to register a conclusive triumph in the thirteenth Polar Bear meet on Columbia's South Field board track yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 14--A revision of New York's unemployment insurance law designed to save employmers $100,000,000 a year in payroll taxes and increase benefits to the unemployed received the approval of a special legislative committee today.

The Welfare Council of the City of New York expects to strengthen its program for coordinating health and welfare work here under te new administration of Raymond M. Hilliard, who has been appointed executive director.

Cardinal Spellman added an appeal for local charity to his recent solicitation for aid for the needy persons abroad at the opening yesterday of the 1951 campaign for Catholic Charities in the archdiocese of New York.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 14-- President Truman was urged today "in the interest of a wellrounded national transportation industry" to give representation on the Interstate Commerce Commission to water transportation.

Members of the Miami Fashion Council showing spring and summer lines at the New Yorker Hotel leave booked substantial orders in the last three days. The Southern fashions for women and children are being exhibited by twenty-six of the council's fiftytwo members and will be shown through Friday of this week.

The presses of THE NEW YORK TIMES were shut down for thirty-five minutes last night when members of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union refused to remove papers from the pressroom. Several other newspapers in the city also were delayed in making deliveries as a result of the labor dispute.

ALBANY, Feb. 14--The Senate passed by a vote of 42 to 13 and sent to the Governor today bills increasing the minimum liability insurance required of taxi cab owners, effective July 1. Governor Dewey is expected to sign them.

There is every reason of logic and common interest for close cooperation between France and Italy. The two countries are linked not only by geography but by old bonds of history and culture. They form a natural and complementary trading area. They have similar political problems.

Officials of the Paris Theatre, 4 West Fifty-eighth Street, testifying under oath yesterday at a hearing before Chief Fire Marshal Martin Scott in the Municipal Building, admitted having made payments of $20 a month beginning in September, 1948, to firemen sent to inspect the movie house. LONDON, Feb. 14--A woman Labor M.P., who until recently was a stanch supporter of the Labor Government's food policies, has joined the housewives' revolt against food shortages and the high cost of living in Britain.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 14--Chancellor Konrad Adenauer appealed today to John J. The stock market reverted to the downside yesterday although a creeping recovery in the late trading minimized the extreme inroads. The rails again were the principal targets for selling while the key industrial units failed to chart a definite course. Prices were pretty thoroughly scrambled at the close with the combined averages off 0.81 point.

Dr. and Mrs. DuBois S. Morris of 515 Park Avenue, New York, took place here this afternoon in Christ Protestant Episcopal Church.

Arturo Toscanini has canceled his final two concerts with the N.B.C. Symphony Orchestra because his injured left knee, which has been under treatment for months, has not healed entirely. Opening at 9 P.M. tomorrow with a preview, to which admission will be $15 a couple, the show contains thirty-five works by the great Flemish master. From Wednesday admission will be 60 cents.

WASHINGTON, Feb.18--Joe R. Hanley has given Senate investigators an affidavit stating that, in agreeing to run as Republican candidate for the Senate in New York last fall, he received no money, property or anything else of value as a consideration.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP)-- The Truman Administration appeared today to have enlisted a majority within two key Senate committees against limiting the number of troops for Europe.
BERLIN, Feb. 18--Editorial comment in the Sunday editions of West Berlin newspapers on Premier Stalin's interview in Pravda was unanimously adverse.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--The Voice of America, broadcasting around the clock, is proclaiming that Premier Stalin has been forced into taking over from his "puppets and stooges to propagandize the world with the fake charges and claims of the Kremlin."

ALBANY, Feb. 18--A proposal to set up special "watchdog" grand juries in all counties of New York City, except Richmond, for the express purpose of investigating political or governmental misconduct is to be submitted to the Legislature tomorrow night.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Feb. 18 --A few miles east of this resort community and upthrust sharply from an otherwise prairie-like landscape is a knoll, reached by a winding macadam road. To one driving through the sparsely populated countryside below, the hill presents but two distinguishing features; a salt-box type house and a slender but towering antenna.

VIENNA, Feb. 18--The Austrian Government has been asked by United States authorities here to explain why it was considered necessary two years ago to reorganize the cellulose plant whose shares are now being quoted on the Vienna stock exchange at seven times their par value.

In a rough and tumble battle which produced twenty-eight penalties for a new Eastern Hockey League record, the New York Rovers beat the Boston Olympics, 6--3, before 5,399 onlookers at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

For lack of facilities, Bridge House, the city's center for treatment of alcoholics, had to refuse its services to 468 applicants last year. The demand for investment funds by private business in 1951 will be significantly below the peak level of 1950, the bond department of the Bankers Trust Company predicts in its annual review, United States Government Securities and the Money Market, published today.

TAEGU, Korea, Feb. 18--A series of drastic measures, including tax increases, stiffer methods of collecting taxes and the floating of new war bond issues, will be introduced soon in South Korea by the Government to keep the country afloat economically.

Dr. Carleton Simon of 152 West Fifty-eighth Street, criminologist and psychiatrist, whose name was familiar to newspaper readers in the Nineteen Twenties when he was a Special Deputy Police Commissioner in charge of the narcotics bureau, died yesterday in New York Hospital after a month's illness. He would have been 80 years old on Feb. 28.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP)-- Greater opportunities for profits brought a 50,000 net increase in American business firms in 1950 to put the total number over the 4,000,000 mark, the Department of Commerce reported tonight.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 18--A broad denunciation of "guilt by association" as undemocratic and unAmerican was delivered at Hendricks Chapel of Syracuse University today in a guest sermon by Prof. Kirtley Mather of the faculty of Harvard University.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 18--International bottlenecks in metal and fuel mining and manufacturing will be shattered on a broad scale as the largest exploration and development programs in history get under way this year. LONDON, Feb. 18--A cautious warning against an attack on Yugoslavia by the Soviet satellites in Eastern Europe was delivered by the British Government last Thursday, but it was scarcely noticed in the excitement of a debate and vote on the Government's defense policy in the House of Commons.

In its first major policy decision under the leadership of its new chairman, Delos W. Rentzel, the Civil Aeronautics Board has indicated a revision in its whole attitude toward the airline route pattern of the United States. This decision came as a result of the denial of another transcontinental route on the basis of six applications for certificates of service comprising the area, roughly, from Miami to Los Angeles.

The Baby Sitters Association, a non-profit group organized at City College last term to help students seeking work as baby sitters, has grown so rapidly it now has a staff of thirteen, an office, a telephone number and calls for at least fifty students each Saturday night.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 18--United States Ambassador to South Africa John G. Erhardt was found dead in bed this noon at his official residence in suburban Wynberg. He was 61 years old. Appointed to the post last May, Mr. Erhardt arrived in South Africa in September.

Difficulty in obtaining materials for completion of the new American Export Lines express liner Constitution has delayed the ship for nearly two months. She is a sister ship of the 26,000-ton luxury liner Independence, which is now on her first Mediterranean voyage.

The management of the Pennsylvania Railroad, charging that unfair regulation and taxation had caused the bankruptcy of the Long Island Rail Road, announced yesterday that it would seek to reestablish private operation of the line.
UJINA is the port for the city of Hiroshima, fourteen miles away. It was there that Allan S. Clifton lived from January to De cember of 1946 as a member of the Australian occupying force.

Every Tuesday night, no matter what the weather, sixty men and women, young and old, gather in the auditorium of Walton High School in the Bronx and make music. Those nights are reserved for rehearsals. And then, once a month under the banner of the Bronx Symphony Orchestra, these sixty musicians give a formal concert before an invariably packed house of more than 1,500 persons.

Conant, president of Harvard, called upon the people of this country today to rededicate themselves to the great task of "moral reconstruction."

MIAMI, Feb. 18--Confidence that his country could succeed in the race to become self-sufficient was declared here today by Abba S. Eban, Israeli Ambassador to the United States, as more than 500 Jewish leaders pledged $10,150,000 to open the nation-wide campaign of the United Jewish Appeal.

Citations for bravery and exceptional police duty were awarded yesterday to 289 members of the Police Department. The list of award winners covers all cases acted upon by the Honor Committee since last Dec. 4.
Daily newspapers consumed slightly more newsprint in January than in the 1950 month, although there were four Sundays last month against five a year earlier.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 18--Colors vivid and fashions dashing share equally with colors pale and fashions demure in the combined spring collections of The Affiliated Fashionists--Agnes Barrett, Irene M. Bury, Addie Masters, Mabs, Marjorie Montgomery and Peggy Hunt.

Luebeck, the north German city famous for its marzipan, has shipped to this country for the first time in many years a quantity of those slightly bitter, almond-paste candies that Europeans like so well. And they come as Europeans evidently prefer them, in pieces shaped and colored to resemble about every food except candy.
Investors were active as the buyers of realty in Manhattan in deals reported over the week-end. The sales covered a wide area from the downtown section to Yorkville.

A record group of 590 candidates for appointment to the Coast Guard Academy from the New York area will start today a twoday competitive entrance examination at the Federal Building, 641 Washington Street.

A critical period of debate and decision lies just ahead on questions of New York City's finances. It involves not only the larger city budget which seems unavoidable because of inflationary costs, civil defense needs, rising debt service and newly opened hospitals but also the better pay for civil service employes and public school teachers which will add millions of dollars to the budget.

ALBANY, Feb. 18--A program of special state aid for school construction in suburban areas where building booms have swamped the school facilities had been approved tentatively today by a special committee headed by Lieut. Gov. Frank C. Moore.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18--A steering committee of the National Planning Association today proposed that the United States could best help backward countries to a democratic way of life by offering to them a balanced program of assistance in line with their needs and aspirations.

Contracts totaling about $450,000,000 were placed with American manufacturers in January by the New York Quartermaster Procurement Agency. This is announced for publication today by Brig. Gen. H.L. Peckham, who commands the purchasing installation.
The German Hungarians eliminated the Brookhattan-Galicia eleven, 4 to 3, in a re-play of their National Challenge Cup soccer match at Sterling Oval, the Bronx, yesterday.
PARIS, Feb. 5--Productivity has become the watchword of the Continent's economic salvation in the world crisis.

Prospects for larger American bituminous coal shipments to Europe have brightened as a result of latest requests for additional merchant-shipping vessel withdrawals from the mothball fleet, coal exporters asserted here yesterday.
LONDON, Feb. 19--Substantial gain in rubber shares was the feature of the London stock markets today. Otherwise there was a slight tendency toward dullness.

Consolidated gross earnings of $5,401,503 for the fiscal year ending Jan. 31, an increase of $551,450 over the previous year, were reported yesterday by Brown Bigelow, remembrance advertising concern.

With blossoms wreathing them, pressed against their crowns or filling their saucer--like brims, most of the Easter hats shown by Russeks yesterday at the Plaza Hotel had an enchanting flowery air.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 19--The South today has forty major research laboratories available for industrial research projects and Government research programs essential to the national defense, according to a report issued by the Southern Association of Science and Industry.

EIGHTH ARMY HEADQUARTERS, in Korea, Feb. 19--The Chinese Communist attack on Korea's central front has been checked and enemy troops are making a "very definite effort to disengage" along that vital sector of the line, it was announced today by Lieut. Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, commander of the Eighth Army.

All afternoon baseball games to be played by the New York Yankees this season at Yankee Stadium will be televised by both WABD and WPIX, Fourteen scheduled night games at the stadium will be televised by WPIX only, which also will carry the full home scnedule of the New York Giants.
Measures to reduce the hazards involved in trying to board subway trains in evening rush hours have been taken by Sidney H. Bingham, chairman of the Board of Transportation.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Feb. 19-- Canada offered $25,000,000 today toward the first year of the Colombo plan for the development of South and Southeast Asia as the fourteen-nation conference on the international six-year, $5,000,000,000 public works program drew near a close.

Sales volume of New York and Brooklyn department stores for the week ended Jan. 17 were 24 per cent higher than for the corresponding week of last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The influence of the port is felt so widely that its prosperity or lack of it affects the lives of the American people--not only on the Eastern Seaboard but throughout the nation.

PARIS, Feb. 19--The search for a permanent site for Supreme Headquarters, Allied Powers in Europe (Shape) ended today when General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's representatives accepted President Vincent Auriol's offer of 60 acres of an unused hunting preserve.
Housewives who are troubled over recent food price rises were found yesterday to be confused also about how to get some rollbacks through the Office of Price Stabilization.

LENINGRAD, Feb. 15--The Leningrad region's Communist party committee singles out for special praise this week four new works of the Leningrad theatre-- the operas. "The Family of Taras" and "The Young Guard," and the new ballets, "Flame of Paris" and "Youth."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 19 --Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Helen Paula Finke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour W. Finke, to Peter J. Schlesinger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emil Schlesinger of 90 Riverside Drive, New York. The wedding is planned for June 24.

Operations of the United States Robber Company last year resulted in the highest sales and earnings in its fifty-nine-year history, according to the annual report issued yesterday by Herbert E. Smith, chairman, and Harry E. Humphreys Jr., president.

Confidence in the ability of the paper and pulp industry to meet defense and civilian needs during 1951 was expressed by industry leaders yesterday as "Paper Week" conventions started full business sessions, most of which were closed.

Traffic "tickets" given out anywhere in the city are now "absolutely fix-proof," Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh asserted yesterday.

HOUSTON, Feb. 19 (U.P.)--The Professional Golfers Association tonight fined Jimmy Demaret $500 for jumping south of the border last week to play in the Mexican open while the Rio Grande Valley open was in progress at Harlingen.

Seattle, Wash., sold yesterday $25,850,000 of light and power revenue bonds due on March 1, 1956 to 1980, to a syndicate headed by Blair, Rollins Co., and Shields Co., on a bid of 100.78 for interest of 2 per cent, for an interest cost of 1.965 per cent.

Michael Maye, Salem Crescent performer, outpointed Anthony Zamppelli of the Catholic Youth Organization in the heavyweight open contest that provided the feature of the twenty-fifth annual Golden Gloves finals at Madison Square Garden last night. The program, staged by the News Welfare Association, attracted a crowd of 12.233.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19--Responding to widespread protests from builders, the National Production Authority today relaxed temporarily its ban on copper tubing for water systems in homes after March 1. The relaxation will permit many homes now under construction that otherwise could not have been completed to be finished on schedule.

ALBANY, Feb. 20 A state-wide legislative investigation of organized crime was proposed today by Senator Seymour Halpern, Queens Republican, to supplement the United States Senate crime investigation and the proposed inquiry of the alleged tie-up between crime and politics in New York City.
LONDON, Feb. 20 (AP) The Labor Government defeated a Conservative motion of censure by a vote of 302 to 295 tonight on the issue of its peanut-growing project in Africa.

Experiments have been made recently in this country and in Canada to capture the tang of apples in an essense that might be used to flavor a variety of sweets. Applegems, a Turkish paste type of confection is one of the first commercial products to become available as a result of this work.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 Eric Johnston, Economic Stabilization Administrator, committed himself firmly today to the idea of a wage stabilization board having representation from the public, industry and labor.

There can be no doubt that the New York City Ballet has a hit on its hands in its new "La Valse," which had its world premiere last night at the City Center. Nor can there be any doubt that George Balanchine, its choreographer, is an artist of enormous resources and unimpeachable integrity.
ROME, Feb. 20 (AP)--Communism is losing ground throughout Europe, the press office of the Italian Catholic Action reported today.

Stockholders of Warner Bros. Pictures, Inc., at their annual meeting yesterday in Wilmington, approved the reorganization plan, separating the theatre assets of Warner in the United States from its production and distribution assets,...

PARIS, Feb. 20--Manufacturers of the six countries involved in the Schuman plan for merging Europe's coal and steel demanded today that their interests should be safeguarded in the treaty project and that the plan should be so framed as to permit it to be modified in its practical operation.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 20 (AP) Yale, a leader in setting national collegiate sports policy in World War II, tonight disclosed it it was taking immediate action to tighten its athletic belt.

NEWARK, Feb. 20 A Hoboken meat processing company, its vice president and two soldiers were indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of defrauding the Government of $1,000,000 by conspiring to deliver inferior meats to the Army.

The board of trustees of Long Island University last night informed Ned Irish, Madison Square Garden basketball promoter, that the school was canceling all of its remaining basketball games, including those scheduled for the Garden.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Feb. 20 (AP) Buddy Scott of Dallas, a prizefighter, testified for the state today in the trial of two men charged with bribing boxers last November.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 George F. Richardson, Assistant Superintendent of Police in Philadelphia, denied today before the Senate Crime Investigating Committee that Harry Stromberg, alias Nig Rosen, ever gave him...

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 The National Production Authority announced today that it would curb the use of steel for passenger automobile production as well as for a variety of consumer durable goods by 20 per cent for the quarter beginning April 1.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20 The grain markets broke badly on the Board of Trade here today with general selling in evidence in wheat, corn and other grains, after announcement that the Government was drafting a program which, if adopted, would result in handling...

Government-owned forests must be opened up more liberally as a source for pulpwood, at least for duration of the national emergency, it was urged yesterday at a meeting of the American Pulpwood Association.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 20 (UP) United Nations Secretary General Trygve Lie warned today that despite the present armaments programs a great expansion of the world's economy was necessary to avoid disaster.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 21--A group of the country's farmers prepared today to tell the Federal Government that a better job of conservation is needed on public lands in the Western states.
GANDER, Nfld, Feb. 21--A twin-jet British bomber failed today in a race to beat the sun across the North Atlantic but landed with the fastest crossing in history--four hours and forty minutes.

ALBANY, Feb. 21--An increase in highway use taxes, to be collected exclusively from truck operators was proposed officially today as Governor Dewey's recordbreaking $938,940,000 budget received final legislative approval in the Senate.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 21--Proposals for revision of Federal tax rules applying on incomes from mining sources were foremost in topics of discussion by scientists, engineers and industrialists among more than 2,500 persons attending the 171st general meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers here today.

Acceptance of the tentative settlement reached Sunday night by negotiators of the Bethlehem Steel Company and the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C.I.O., was indicated yesterday as five of the eight yards involved finished voting.

Paul Jacobs, 20-year-old New York pianist who made his debut last night at Times Hall, proved to be a young man of individual tastes with an experimental approach to the instrument he already has mastered.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 21-- The deal for Jose Ferrer to leave the cast of "Twentieth Century" on Broadway and come to the coast to play Androcles in George Bernard Shaw's "Androcles and the Lion" at R.K.O. has been revived, on the basis of a verbal commitment Ferrer gave last year to Gabriel Pascal, producer of the film, it was learned today.
LONDON, Feb. 21--The Thirtyeighth Parallel in Korea still seemed today to lie athwart British-American policy in the Far East even more than Formosa.

Coming from behind on two occasions, the New York Rangers managed to earn a 2-to-2 tie with the Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden last night. A crowd of 12,263 fans witnessed the battle for third place and saw the status quo unchanged.
Detailed architectural plans for a new 1,250-bed Veterans Administration general hospital on a sixacre tract from Twenty-third to Twenty-fifth Streets at Avenue A were made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in the ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended on Feb. 14, the Federal Reserve Board announced today:

The marriage of Miss Naomi Celia Burton of 206 East Sixtysecond Street, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Claude Edward Cole-Hamilton Burton of Westham, Sussex, England, to Melville E. Stone of 30 East Seventieth Street, son of Mrs. Herbert E. Stone of 59 West...

Determined to carry on and erase the blot that the three confessed "dumpers," Al Roth, Ed Warner and Ed Roman, smeared over its name, the City College basketball team resumes action tonight at Madison Square Garden against Lafayette. Unlike Long Island University, which suspended all intercollegiate sports following the revelations that Sherman White, Al Bigos and Le Roy Smith had been guilty of "shaving scores," C.C.N.Y. will complete its 1951 schedule.

An insurance company yesterday afternoon withdrew its offer to provide $50,000 bail for Leiser Weitman, 31-year-old Austrian, who had been indicted on charges of smuggling $744,800 worth of high-quality diamonds into the United States.
ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 21-- American education does not prepare youth adequately to meet the challenge of present-day world issues, a panel of six high school students declared here today.

The forty-six-family apartment house at 514-18 East 138th Street, the Bronx, has been sold by Geisinger Rau, operators, to the S. F. Woodworking Corporation for cash above mortgages of $102,500. The property is assessed at $100,000. The building also contains four stores.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 21-- Britain and the United States proposed today a new mediation plan for ending the three-year-old struggle between India and Pakistan for control of the princely state of Kashmir.

David S. Fischman, president of United Dye and Chemical Corporation, has been elected a director of Lowell Adams Factors Corporation, it was announced Yesterday by Robert H. Bailey, chairman of Lowell Adams.

Acting to ease the strain on the money market resulting from the impact of heavy corporate tax payments, the United States Treasury next month will initiate a new collection procedure. Withdrawals of approximately $3,000,000,000, from banks over the nation will be affected.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--With foreign grain commitments a major consideration, the Government is setting up a priority system for the use of boxcars, now in far too short supply to meet export demands.
Frank C. Bals, former seventh deputy police commissioner, testified yesterday before the Brooklyn holdover grand jury investigating police tie-ups with organized gamblers.

OSLO, Norway, Feb. 21--A plan to hasten and expand Norway's defense and to achieve by the end of 1952 the goal originally set for the end of 1954 was presented to the Storting (Parliament) here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--The Department of Agriculture today spearheaded before the Interstate Commerce Commission the opposition of shippers generally to a request of the railroads for an immediate 6 per cent increase in freight rates.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP)-- The Senate ordered tonight that arrest warrants be issued for seventeen witnesses accused by Senate crime investigators of going into hiding to escape questioning.

ALBANY, Feb. 21--The State Commission on School Buildings, headed by Lieut, Gov. Frank C. Moore, recommended in its second report today that the proposed State Defense Council be empowered to assign priorities for the construction of school buildings.
Fair skies and mild temperatures were promised by the Weather Bureau for today's observance of the 219th anniversary of George Washington's birth.

A Pacific defense pact analogous to the North Atlantic Treaty became a definite possibility when Secretary Acheson confirmed at his press conference yesterday that informal talks on such a project are now under way between the United States and "friendly Governments."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--The Senate passed today, and sent back to the House with several amendments, a bill to set up an independent board with the mission of renegotiating future defense contracts to insure against excessive contractors' profits.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--The atmosphere of partisan, infra-partisan and world conflict which surrounds the President in this period of history, and which lately he has made more sulphurous by certain words and actions, vanishes in his private presence.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--The Office of Price Stabilization moved today to block the sale of new cars as "used" automobiles at inflated prices. It issued regulations, effective March 2, that would establish ceilings for used cars at levels set forth in January issues of trade "guide books" used by dealers to help them fix prices in normal times.

SPORTSMEN'S Show highlights: Many of the interesting personalities at this outdoor exposition are hidden from the public view or camouflaged by the displays that divert the visitor's attention from the individual.
AT SEA, Off the China Coast, Feb. 3--1 have just come out of China and now am sailing south from Tientsin. All in all I have been just a month in and around China.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--An accusation that perjury had been committed arose today as the Senate investigating subcommittee that has accused the Reconstruction Finance Corporation of making loans marked by political influence and favoritism opened public hearings designed to prove its findings.

Chelsea Warehouses, Inc., headed by Louis Schramm, has added another warehouse to its chain in the metropolitan area through the purchase of the building at 54 Broadway, Newark, N.J., from the Model Storage Warehouse Corporation.

Heavy demand for wastepaper --spurted in part by the defense program and the pulp shortage-- will result in record consumption this year by paper, paperboard and roofing materials mills, it was predicted yesterday at a convention session of the American Paper and Pulp Association.

BOSTON, Feb. 21--When the thirty-eighth annual show of the Eastern Dog Club began its twoday run today in the Mechanics Building, a lot of the interest attached to a boxer whose fame had spread before him. He was Dr. and Mrs. R.C. Harris' Champion Bang Away of Sirrah Crest, continuing the winter season's most spectacular campaign that included the best-in-show victories at Westminster, Hartford and New Haven.
The spring collection of designs by Adele Simpson was presented yesterday by De Pinna at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Another aid to paraplegics, a specially equipped hand-controlled 1951 Ford automobile, was presented yesterday to the Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation of the New York UniversityBellevue Medical Center by the Ford Motor Company.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21--Scattered liquidation in the grain markets in the early trading on the board of trade here today sent wheat at the low down 12 3/8 cents a bushel and corn 6 cents a bushel under the high marks of last week.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 21-- William R. Matthews, president of the construction company bearing his name, died today at the age of 76 after a long illness.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--The urgent necessity for more steelproducing ore in our national security program was the theme today as three of the country's defense authorities added their efforts to the Administration's allout drive for early Congressional action on the St. Lawrence seaway and power project.

Failure of the Government to clarify cotton pricing has caused deep concern in the primary cotton textile market. Suppliers in Worth Street said yesterday that the situation was more confused than at any time in the last twenty years as the result of continued shutdown of the cotton exchanges.

Rolled oats is one of the cheapest foods in terms of the nutrients it yields. A nickel, even if it will not buy a bus ride or a telephone call, will buy two cups of oats. One cup of this whole grain cereal, measured before cooking, costs only 2 cents. It supplies a family of four with 7 per cent of its daily requirement for protein, 10 per cent of its...

Applications of the New York City Housing Authority to construct the proposed $11,300,000 Howard Houses and $16,600,000 Sumner Houses in Brooklyn, both state-aided low-rent projects, were approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission. Site Called Compromise
Minimum wage standards for 75,000 workers in the state's amusement and recreation industry--ranging from bat boys to movie cashiers--have been ordered by the State Labor Department.
For 550 West Point cadets the Hayden Planetarium lit up its shimmering heavens yesterday to prove that a knowledge of the stars could be as useful to the foot soldier as to the sailor or airman.

Mrs. Samuel L.M. Barlow and Mrs. Morehead Patterson are cochairwomen of the committee of hostesses for the annual dinner of the Asia Institute, to be held March 1 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Patterson gave a tea yesterday afternoon in her home at 730 Park Avenue for Mrs. Barlow and members of the committee.

Fish, fowl and eggs--all fresh protein foods now readily available --may in many instances give the budget-conscious housewife the answer as to what to serve in place of high-cost meats. The comparative economy of these items is best demonstrated when the edible portion of each is determined, and then its cost per pound.
The sale of five dwellings in several communities in Westchester County has been reported by Rostenberg Associates, Inc., of White Plains, brokers.

DETROIT, Feb. 21--Children of pre-school age whose mothers have established in the home an atmosphere of warmth, democracy and encouragement of curiosity tend to attain emotional independence sooner than their playmates whose parents are autocratic, Dr. Glen Heathers of the Fels Research Institute at Antioch College reported here today.

The season's first presentation of the Balanchine--Stravinsky "Baiser de la Fee" by the New York City Ballet at the City Center last night found that basically charming work in the strongest form it has yet enjoyed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP)-- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced today that the Government's synthetic rubber plants were starting commercial production of a new type of general purpose rubber intended to stretch out the rubber supply substantially.

Net profit of the Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation for the fiscal year ended last November rose to $10,241,644 from $3,713,156 in the preceding fiscal year, Floyd B. Odlum, board chairman, reported yesterday.
SANFORD, Fla., Feb. 21--One of the chief reasons the Giants floundered so badly during the first half of the 1950 season was their inability to solve left-handed pitching.

LONDON, Feb. 21--Secretary of State Dean Acheson's recent suggestion that Spain should be more closely associated with the North Atlantic powers and make a contribution to Western Europe's defense was rebuffed by Britain's Labor Government today.
In a cash deal in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn the two-story building at 2105-09 Eighty-sixth Street, adjoining Twenty-first Avenue, has been purchased by Ralph Abrams from Selma Fromkin.

Electronic engineers as well as television viewers are awaiting with interest the start of television program transmissions by five stations from the new 222-foot steel tower atop the Empire State building.

Combined United Nations air and ground forces struck out against the enemy all along the sixty miles of the Central Korean front registering advances of up to 10,000 yards in the Hoengsong area. Other spearheads pushed forward as much as four miles in the WonjuChechon area against resistance that was characterized as light to moderate.

Communists are exploiting racial discrimination in the United States for propaganda purposes, Charles D. Jackson, president of the National Committee for a Free Europe, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting held in behalf of the United Negro College Fund's forthcoming campaign.

It is a long time since we have heard the melody of Irish speech in New York, and it would be a pleasure to salute "The King of Friday's Men," which opened at The Playhouse last evening. But Michael J. Molloy's play does not quite sing, and the performance does not quite get to the point of dancing and jigging. Without previous acquaintance with the script in performance, one cannot say...

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 21-- The appointment of Charles H. McGuire of the Maritime Administration staff to head the National Shipping Authority, the new counterpart of the World War II War Shipping Administration, was announced here today by Vice Admiral...

PHIL WRIGLEY of the Chicago Cubs once offered the sage observation: "Baseball is too much a sport to be a business and too much a business to be a sport." College athletic authorities would do well to ponder those words. Reluctant though they be to admit it, the description now applies unerringly to the entire intercollegiate athletic set-up.

The Massachusetts Housing Authority yesterday designated March 7 as the date for receiving bids on $9,251,000 of bonds on behalf of local housing authorities. The bonds will be due over forty years and will be a general obligation of the Commonwealth. The proceeds will be used to retire temporary-loan notes.
A fellow-craftsman, Going down in Fredericksburg in Too Virginia, sends us an advertisement clipped from The Providence Journal in
Carl Lindgren, formerly with Montgomery Ward, has been named purchasing agent of Interstate Department Stores, Inc.

Those photographs of shamefaced, grief-stricken college basketball players lined up for arraignment like common criminals will haunt our conscience for a long time. For the rest of us also stand before the bar of judgment for what has happened.

Jed Harris has signed contracts to sponsor and direct on Broadway early next fall a comedy called "A Piece of the Sun." Written by Edith Grafton and her husband, Samuel, former New York Post columnist, the work has held the interest of Mr. Harris for some time, but it wasn't until last week that he signed the necessary legal papers.
Two major retail groups urged yesterday prompt issuance of special margin-type price regulations to free their businesses from growing inequities of the general ceiling price freeze.

The German people are psychologically unable to accept the Western thesis that peace can be maintained through strength of arms, Pastor Martin Niemoeller, German church leader and former submarine captain in World War I, said here yesterday.

The stock market's downward course was arrested yesterday, although the influence of the Washington's Birthday holiday today invited considerable caution. It marked the first major turn of the week in the list's trend but the increases proved modest, while trading diminished to the smallest since last mid-November.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--Secretary of State Dean Acheson said today that the United States was very sympathetic toward the Colombo plan of British Commonwealth nations for the development of Southeast Asia but indicated that this country would not participate in any arrangement for financing the program.

A national policy for the draft deferment of active merchant seamen, to eliminate vessel delays and short-handed sailings, was urged yesterday by Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, C.I.O.

Archie Moore, 176 pounds, Toledo, Ohio, knocked out Jimmy Bivins, 180 , Cleveland, in the feature at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. The bout was scheduled for ten rounds, but Bivins could not come out for the tenth.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 21--The Yugoslav Army would go into action in the event of any of three well-defined cases of Soviet aggression in Europe, according to responsible sources who clarified today the precise meaning of Premier Marshal Tito's announcement last Friday.

Dr. John R. Dunning, Dean of Engineering at Columbia University and one of the country's leading nuclear physicists, declared yesterday that the production of tens of thousands of atomic bombs was "perfectly feasible and possible."

Directors of the Crucible Steel Company of America, in their first dividend action on the common stock since 1945, yesterday placed it on a stock dividend basis for 1951 and voted 2 per cent a share for the first quarter.

VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 21-- Manager Chuck Dressen, who for a great part of his baseball life has specialized in discerning the mechanical mistakes of pitchers, demonstrated in the second day in camp today that he has lost none of his keenness of perception.

ALBANY, Feb. 21--At the request of the State Controller, the Assembly today postponed for a week final approval of a constitutional amendment that would allow the use of state funds to supplement the pensions of retired teachers and civil service workers.

The only "conspiracy" inferable from the anti-trust complaint against seventeen investment banking houses is that the defendant bankers were bent on "cutting each other's throats," a defense lawyer asserted yesterday in Federal Court here.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Feb. 21 --Ben H. Atwell, retired publicity man, who represented many prominent theatrical figures, including Eleanora Duse, Al Jolson, Pavlowa and Mordkin, died today in San Laurel Hospital, where he had been a patient for a year. He was 74 years old.

PARIS, Feb. 21--The semi-official French News Agency reported tonight from Morocco that talks between French authorities and the nationalist-minded Sultan of Morocco had been broken off. The conclusion drawn here was that the political situation in the protectorate had reached its most critical point in years.
The case of the "basketball fix," involving star players of Long Island University and City College, went before the grand jury yesterday.

PARIS, Feb. 21--Wearing his well-known smile, General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower arrived here today, amid a minimum of fanfare and a maximum of security, to assume his duties as Supreme Commander of the North Atlantic Treaty powers' defense forces.

The extent and limits of the Communist world are outlined in a trade conference just opened in Moscow. For the first time China sits in with the Soviet satellites at a joint meeting. Eastern Germany is there, too, and this brings to eight the number of nations under the Soviet aegis.

Robert W. Wolcott, chairman of the Lukens Steel Company and head of the steel industry's scrap committee, called on the Government and industrial plants yesterday to help replenish ferrous scrap inventories, which he said were declining at an "alarming rate."
Safety exhibits and tests for motorists have attracted 11,000 persons in the last week and have disclosed that 20 per cent of the total, presumed to be drivers, suffer from faulty vision.

The Federal regulation imposing ceiling prices on used cars was commended yesterday by dealers in these vehicles in the New York metropolitan area. The general opinion was that the Office of Price Stabilization order had clarified a complicated situation.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 21--The costume look, so important in dresses and sportswear, also appears strongly in California coat and suit collections presented in the third day of press showings.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--High Army generals late today assured leaders in National Guard and Organized Reserve affairs that plans for the release from service of National Guardsmen called in the present emergency meant no diminution in the status or importance of Reserve organizations.
Fashions for spring and summer afternoons and evenings were the topic of a luncheon showing at the Pierre Hotel in the Cotillion Room yesterday. The author of the collection was Philip Hulitar.

CAPETOWN, Feb. 21--In the House of Assembly today Finance Minister Nicholas C. Havenga implied that despite setbacks as well as reluctance on the part of the International Monetary Fund he was determined to continue efforts to obtain a better price for South Africa's gold.

Manufacturers of automobiles, refrigerators, radios and other "consumer durables" will be compelled to get along, beginning with the March quarter, on reduced supplies of steel. Their allowances will be cut 20 per cent, or to 80 per cent of their consumption rate in the first half of 1950.
The Lords Commissioners of the Admiralty presented to Mayor Impellitteri a bell and a book yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 21--The United States Office of Education is held in "peonage" and is dominated by administration-appointed politicians, spokesmen for the nation's public schools charged here today.

The latest proof that the mass strength of communism in Western Europe is steadily weakening has come to us from Rome. A compilation, made there by the Italian Catholic Action and sent in an Associated Press dispatch, gives an impressive and heartening list of countries where the local Communists have lost party followers, members of parliament and trade union strength.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--The Union Pacific Railroad Company today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to make part of the record of a proceeding before it a radio address of Senator Edwin C. Johnson, Democrat of Colorado. The railroad asserted that the address was "intended for the purpose of intimidating and coercing the commissioners."

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 21 (AP)-- Avery Brundage, president of the United States Olympic Committee, announced today that a compromise settlement had been reached in the long dispute over selection of an American hockey team for the Olympics in Helsinki next year.
FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 21 --The West German Government ordered today an immediate moratorium on liberalized imports and announced an impending revision of its trade liberalization policy.

A RATHER crucial weapon in the struggle for our existence is the submarine. The Nazis made a near thing of drowning the free world's Atlantic shipping less than ten years ago. In a looming uproar someone might get the idea of stopping a submarine outside the three-mile limit and lobbing hell-bombs toward the shore.

NEWARK, Feb. 21--The inside of the banked rails of the temporary Pennsylvania Railroad's tracks at Woodbridge, scene of the Feb. 6 wreck in which eighty-four persons were killed, were fastened to each of the ties with one spike, in contrast to alleged standard...

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--President Truman pleaded today for an end of profiteering and partisanship in the mobilization effort, declaring high moral standards and solid national unity would contribute materially to the progress being made in the drive to prevent a third world war.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--The head of the United States bomber command testified today that all the ground forces now contemplated for Europe's defense would not be enough to check a Russian invasion.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 21--There was a mild surprise and a whopping surprise in the two divisions of the Everglades Handicap for three-year-olds at Hialeah today. Ken, owned by Mrs. E. Kendall Weil of Chicago, upon by ten lengths as an $11.40-for-$2--fourth choice, and then Gray Matter, carrying the navy blue and white of Hal Price Headley of Lexington, Ky., scored with a length and a half to spare as a $78.40 outsider.

The resignation of one of the twenty-seven members of the Fire Department who were questioned by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan about the alleged buying of promotions was disclosed last night in routine departmental orders.

City employes, confronted by a rising cost of living, are borrowing more money than ever before. A survey showed yesterday that New York's municipal workers were taking loans against their pension funds, borrowing from the Municipal Credit Union, and in many cases pledging their furniture, automobiles or salaries to obtain ready cash from commercial lenders.

Commodity futures on the local exchanges showed a mixed price movement yesterday in light trading. Copper and lead futures worked into higher territory, while rubber, tin, zinc, coffee, sugar and cottonseed oil declined.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Feb. 21-- Dissension within the new Vietnamese Cabinet resulted in the withdrawal of two members today, even before the new Bao Dai Government, formed last Sunday, could formally begin functioning. One of the Ministers who left the Cabinet was Nguyen Huu Tri, Governor of North Vietnam (Tongking), who was slated to occupy the key post of National Defense.
Irving Trust Company yesterday announced the election of Harold L. Nelson as an assistant secretary.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--The Congress of Industrial Organizations called today for adoption of a "pay-as-you-go" tax program that would produce an additional $16,000,000,000 to $18,000,000,000 annually without unduly burdening low-income groups.
Congress continued to debate this week the role of land power in United States military policy.

TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 22-- United Nations forces launched yesterday a wide offensive along the fifty-to-sixty-mile front in central Korea. To the west the Communists were digging in, preparing to hold the Han River line and the former Republican capital at Seoul.

PARIS, Feb. 21--The first Czechoslovak Bishop of the Roman Catholic Church to swear allegiance to the Communist Government in Prague is now ordaining priests who have been graduated from religious seminaries approved by the regime.
FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 21 --Military units of the People's Police in the Soviet Zone are being completely equipped with Russian tanks, field artillery, anti-tank weapons and anti-aircraft guns.

ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 21 (AP)-- Dick Chapman of Pinehurst, N.C., and his partner, Miss Peggy Kirk, surprised the international mixed two-ball golf tournament today by upsetting the defending co-champions, Miss Patty Berg and Earl Stewart, 1 up on the nineteenth hole.

BERLIN, Feb. 21--Under the chairmanship its Vice President, Pietro Nenni, the Communistsponsored "World Peace Council," opened a four-day session today in the Soviet sector with a series of speeches by delegates denouncing the United Nations and the United States.

Emphasizing the wide breach between the Electric Bond and Share Company and its former subsidiary, the American Power and Light Company, the latter asked the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday to hear several allegations against Electric Bond and Share.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21--Charles E. Wilson, Director of Defense Mobilization, told protesting labor leaders today he was waiting for them to nominate somebody he could appoint to his top staff, but the labor leaders bided their time for a "package" settlement of all their grievances.

During a bargaining session which began at noon yesterday and was still continuing late last night, the American Federation of Musicians and the major radio and television networks, negotiating for a new contract, agreed to extend their interim agreement, for the third time until Saturday midnight. If a new wage agreement is reached by then, it will be retroactive to Feb. 1, when the old contract expired.
MADRID, Feb. 21--An air of hostility toward Britain marks the current Spanish propaganda policy in distinction to a notable increase in friendliness toward the United States.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 21--The first penetration of the Far West by a Yankee ball club reached its climax here this afternoon in a typical frontier setting.

Donald McNeill of Searingtown, L.I., defending titleholder in the national indoor tennis championship, gained the quarter-final round last night with a 6-0, 6-0 victory over Ubert Vincent of New York at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

Mr. Currier and Mr. Ives, sketchboards ih hand, would have been more in harmony with the setting than the newspaper photographer who pictured yesterday the nineteenth century fire engine recently acquired by the Fire College museum in Long Island City, Queens.

Mayor Impellitteri's office announced yesterday that he would appear before the House Ways and Means Committee in Washington at 10 A.M. Monday to oppose the pending proposal to terminate the Federal tax exemption now enjoyed...

William MacHarg, author and creator of the "good hard-headed cop, O'Malley," hero of many stories published in Collier's and The Saturday Evening Post, died yesterday of a heart ailment in his home, Goin Lane, Alpine, N.J. His age was 78.

July 1 has been set as the date for putting into operation the Federal plan for over-all control of materials, Robert L. Niles, of the New York and New Jersey regional office of the National Production Authority, disclosed here yesterday.
Disaffection among Soviet Moslems, the second largest religious group in the Soviet Union, is troubling the Kremlin, informed sources in this country believe.

Miss Nancy Chaffee of Ventura, Calif., defending titleholder, defeated Miss Althea Gibson of New York last night to reach the semifinals of the national indoor tennis championships at the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue.
United Nations forces carried their new Korean offensive forward about twelve miles through heavy rains and patchy enemy resistance.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development announced today that it was sending an economic survey mission to Iraq this week-end to help that country draw up a long-range program of industrial development.

A 16-year-old girl, taking advantage of the holiday to picnic in Brooklyn's Prospect Park with three young cousins, recognized yesterday the body of a boy being removed from Swan Boat Lake as that of her brother who had disappeared a month ago.

OTTAWA, Feb. 22 (Canadian Press)--Steamship service between Canada, Australia and New Zealand will be resumed under a one-year subsidy paid by the governments of the three countries, Transport Minister Lionel Chevrier of Canada announced today.
Brisk sunshine added sparkle yesterday to official and informal observances of the 219th anniversary of George Washington's birth.

ROME, Feb. 23--At the end of a two-day debate the Christian Democratic Deputies decided this evening to give their support to the Government bill granting the Cabinet full powers in certain sectors of the economy with a view to speeding and facilitating Italian rearmament. The Christian Democratic support virtually insures the bill's approval by Parliament.

LONDON, Feb. 23--After five days of continuous negotiations, in which Labor Minister Aneurin Bevan took an active part at the last minute, a settlement was reached today, averting the threat of a protracted strike on the nation's nationalized railways.

LONDON, Feb. 23--Hopes for a settlement in the rail wage dispute--later realized--encouraged the stock markets today. Prices tended to rise though actual gains were mostly small.
Two large group exhibitions, one of paintings and the other of sculpture, should appeal to all tastes, for the former is conservative and the latter more or less experimental.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Feb. 23 (AP) --Representative Clarence Brown, Republican of Ohio, said tonight that the American economy could not long survive if President Truman's and Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder's tax recommendations became law.
It is heartening news that Senator Paul Douglas has gone into action behind the Federal Reserve System in the letter's controversy with the Treasury.

The Ohio Bell Telephone Company, a $419,000,000 subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, had a net income of $19,573,271 last year, a gain of $2,893,259 over the 1949 profit, according to the annual report issued yesterday by Randolph Eide, president.

M.A. Straub has been appointed sales manager of the Norge Heat division of Borg-Warner Corporation. He formerly was assistant sales manager in charge of sales promotion and advertising of the division.

Governor Dewey said yesterday that he was opposed to the Wherry Senate resolution that would admonish President Truman not to send additional American troops to Europe without the advance approval of Congress.
ROME, Feb. 23--Early construction of a 25,000-ton liner for the North Atlantic run was announced today by Alberto Simonini, Minister of the Merchant Marine.

Two hundred and sixty-three employer in the state's unemployment insurance claims bureau have lost their jobs as assistant interviewers, examiners and clerks since the beginning of the year, Edward Corsi, Industrial Commissioner, said yesterday.

Manufacturers and retailers of furniture on the Eastern Seaboard prepared yesterday to make an allout fight against imminent Government seizure of the New York Furniture Exchange, 206 Lexington Avenue.

DETROIT, Feb. 23--It is possible that children may develop schizophrenia, the most prevalent type of mental illness, as a defense against impulses to behave in a destructive way toward their parents or others close to them.

TOKYO, Feb. 23--With the mission of John Foster Dulles to Japan and the Pacific nations completed and with outlines of the treaty that the West will offer to the Japanese now fairly clear, thoughts of Japanese political parties are rapidly turning toward the question of Parliamentary ratification of a "separate" agreement excluding the Soviet Union and Communist China, according to well-informed persons close to the Government.

Mere alms-giving by Christians for the unconverted in foreign mission fields was condemned yesterday by the Rev. Frederick McGuire, executive secretary of the Roman Catholic Mission Secretariat in Washington. He addressed the senior executive board of the Catholic Daughters of America at the Statler Hotel.

Among the other pleasures of the Bronx this week-end, take particular note of the Equity Library performance of Bernard Shaw's "Major Barbara," which opened last evening at the DeWitt Clinton Community Center. It will be repeated tonight and tomorrow night at box-office tariffs of 60 and 90 cents.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23--A conference of all Senate Democrats decided today to bring the military manpower bill to the floor next week, with every indication the majority would support it in the form reported by the Armed Services Committee. Debate may start Tuesday.

AT SEA, Off the China Coast, Feb. 5--Communist China's main immediate grievance against the United States lies in its firm belief that Washington still is supplying Chiang Kai-shek with war material and dreams of helping him to reconquer the mainland and to become an American puppet pillaging his countrymen while conceding to Americans a dominant position in foreign trade and the exploitation of China's resources.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 23--Fabric interest runs high in today's showings of sportswear by California designers, with costume versatility taking a close second in interest.

For the first time in many sessions, Mr. Churchill succeeded in uniting both sides of the House of Commons by his protest against the choice of an American instead of a British admiral to head the combined fleets of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 23-- Reliable evidence that Russians in large numbers are being made aware of America's intensified global campaign of "truth-telling" in answer to the Kremlin's "Big Lie" was reported today by the State Department.

Manhattan and Georgetown are bracketed as co-favorites and Seton Hall, Army, Villanova and Cornell as close contenders in what shapes up as one of the liveliest team battles in the colorful seventy-fiveyear history of the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A., whose thirtieth annual indoor track and field championships will take bedlam-producing possession of Madison Square Garden this afternoon and tonight.

Fitzie Pruden realized the dream of the understudy making good in the role of the star at Madison Square Garden last night. Called in as a virtual last-minute substitute for a stablemate, Pruden handed Tony Janiro of Youngstown, Ohio, a decisive trouncing in the main bout of ten rounds, before a surprised crowd of 4,495 fans.

MOSCOW, Feb. 23--Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky, Deputy War Minister of the Soviet Union, warned today that the United States "doctrine of atomic war" could not prevail against the "invincible might" of the "military science created by the genius of Stalin."

The Air Material Command will extend its sub-contract "clinic" and display for another week beginning Monday at the Eastern Procurement District office, 67 Broad Street, it was announced yesterday. Six additional manu-...
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 23--To revive production of oil from old wells, the largest water flooding project in America's oil industry is to start within a few months at fields in southern Illinois.
Another packed house saw another first-rate performance by the New York City Ballet at the City Center last night.

Both the military and social outlook of the young members of the armed services can be enlarged through adequate community programs, speakers at a session of the Mideast Regional Conference of Community Chests and Councils indicated yesterday.

What is the score on Permanent Personal Registration as the Legislature prepares to go into its final three weeks? Our guess is that the professional politicians will again have their way, the reform will once more be buried in committee, and the voter will as usual be standing in line twice at his polling place in order to vote once.
The responsibility of the man in the pew for extending the teachings of his faith at a time of world crisis will be highlighted tomorrow in Presbyterian and Methodist churches throughout the country.

Liens for unpaid income taxes totaling $1,128,493.57 were filed yesterday by the Federal Government against Salvatore Tarto Sollazzo, 45-year-old Jewelry manufacturer and former convict accused of "fixing" college basketball games through wholesale bribery of key players.

When Walter S. Gifford was named Ambassador to Great Britain his post as chairman of the board of trustees of the Community Service Society was filled by Bayard F. Pope, formerly president of the century-old organization.
Frank Shields made his exit from the national indoor championship tennis singles last night.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 23--Testimony before a Senate Crime Investigating Committee hearing today indicated that a nation-wide betting system in this area conducted a business of more than $7,000,000 through Western Union facilities.

SPORTSMEN'S SHOW highlights. With the conservation agencies of so many states controlled by politics and directed by a politician, it was refreshing to meet Maine's new Commissioner of Inland Fisheries and Game, Roland Cobb. After spending a short time with Commissioner Cobb you begin to wonder why other states seem unable to find men of his caliber for a similar post.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 28 (UP)--Norman M. Tucker, general manager of the Industrial Development Bank of Turkey and former director of marketing of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, died at the American Hospital here today after being ill for ten days.

Defense loans, principally to metal and aircraft manufacturers, were an important influence in the further rise of $48,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural borrowings from New York banks Last week.
Hilde Somer, attractive, Viennaborn pianist, returned to Town Hall last night after a four-year absence.

The National Travelers Aid Association has opened talks in Columbia, S.C., to survey prospects for moving out families in the Savannah River area being cleared to make way for hydrogen bomb experiments and to move in workers, the association reported hers yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 23-- William McMillen, president of Eagle Lion Classics, who has been in Hollywood for the last two weeks, announced the conclusion of arrangements by his company today to distribute nine independent productions with budgets in excess of $500,000 and fifteen low-budget action pictures.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 23--The Saar issue, minor to the Western Allied powers but deeply important to the Germans, has arisen anew to plague the relations between the Bonn Government and the Western powers and delay progress toward closer integration of the two.

OSSINING, N.Y., Feb. 23--This village's Golden Age Club No. 1, cited by welfare organizations as the original old folks' social canteen of a public recreation commission, has attained such stature that it is setting a pattern for "sunset of life" groups in several states and Canada.

United Nations forces in the Central Korean sector repulsed several enemy counter-attacks and pushed forward relentlessly for the third straight day. Troops in the area east of Hoengsong advanced up to eight miles, seized Pyongchang and drove spearheads several miles beyond. To the southwest, other elements registered Gains of from two

An April prospect for Broadway is "Angels Kiss Me," a first play by Scott Michel, mystery story writer. The work will be produced by the author's sister, Trudi Michel, a newcomer to the New York stage, whose theatrical experience includes putting on variety shows on the so-called "borscht-circuit."

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 23--An overcapacity field of twenty horses has been entered in tomorrow's fourteenth running of the $50,000 added Widener Handicap at Hialeah. Unless there are two scratches, the management is going to be embarrassed, because at the starting point for mile-and-aquarter races here only eighteen quadrupeds can be accommodated in the starting gates.

LAKE SUCCESS, Feb. 23--The United Nations Trusteeship Council today approved an Argentine proposal that could open the way for Italy to gain full voting-membership in that major body of the world organization.

Strict enforcement of ceiling price regulations on new and used cars with drastic punishment for violators were promised yesterday by James G. Lyons, acting regional director of the Office of Price Stabilization.

TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 24-- United Nations forces plodded slowly forward yesterday through mud and swollen streams on the third day of their offensive in the Korean mountains. They registered general gains of two to three miles, while engineers, working round...

Nearly a thousand fighting men in the Korean war owe their lives to the "Dumbos" and "choppers" of the Third Air Rescue Squadron. Five pilots and crewmen of the planes, more commonly known as amphibians and helicopters, told about some of their rescues at the Astor Hotel yesterday.

Already approved by the House and with every prospect of speedy passage through the Senate is a bill intended to correct one weakness in the immigration provisions of last year's Internal Security (McCarran) Act.

A new long-term high ration between unfilled orders and shipments of machine tools was reported yesterday by the National Machine Tool Builders' Association. For the month of January, the trade organization reported, a three-year peak of 17.4 to 1 was shown by reports of unfilled orders compared with shipments for the entire industry.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23--Millard F. Caldwell, the Civil Defense Administrator, said today that the nation must organize its civil defense organization "from top to bottom" by the end of this year.

Fordham stepped up the pace in the Second half and finished strongly to defeat Manhattan, 59--49, in a spirited basketball game before 4,500 persons at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night. It was the seventh straight triumph for Johnny Bach's Rams, who now have a season's record of 19 and 6.

Miss Cynthia M. Cogswell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Cogswell of 141 East Seventysecond Street, and Good Ground, Southampton, L.I., was married to George Sim Johnston Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Johnston of Memphis, Tenn., yesterday afternoon in the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Peace by the Rev. Emil E. Molinelli.

Monte Proser reached an agreement yesterday with representatives of Actors Equity, Chorus Equity and the American Guild of Variety Artists whereby he may present a condensed version of "Billion Dollar Baby" at his new Cafe Theatre, with Jackie Gleason and Carol Bruce in the leading roles.

PARIS, Feb. 23--Premier Rene Pleven was obliged tonight to ask a vote of confidence from the National Assembly to avoid the immediate break-up of his Cabinet. Unless some compromise can be obtained on a reform of the French electoral system before this vote is taken Tuesday, a Cabinet crisis appears unavoidable.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 23--A military alliance between India and Nepal, the independent kingdom that partly intervenes between this country and Tibet, may be the outgrowth of joint activity by Indian and Nepalese troops against rebels in the strategic Himalayan state.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP)-- The United States District Court here has issued an order staying the effectiveness of a new securities plan for the Boston and Maine railroad.

Twenty thousand riders on the I.R.T.'s Queens line to Flushing were stranded during the rush hour last night by a failure in the line's power cables somewhere between Grand Central Station and the stop at Vernon Boulevard-Jackson Avenue, the first station in Queens.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23--The Office of Price Stabilization moved today to close a loophole in its general price-freeze order of last month. Through this loophole some producers and wholesalers have attempted to use isolated sales at exorbitant prices as ceiling levels for their entire lines.
HOUSTON, Feb. 23 (AP)--Ed Oliver, Seattle golf pro, celebrated his ninth wedding anniversary today by taking a one-stroke lead at the mid-way mark of the $10,000 Houston Open.

"The pleasant land of counterpane," which Robert Louis Stevenson remembered so fondly when he wrote "A Child's Garden of Verses," can be made just as pleasant today for a convalescing child as it was when Stevenson was a little boy. New records, books, toys and even decorations for the child's room can help the time pass quickly for one recovering from an illness.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 23--The three-man diplomatic team set up to search for a Far Eastern settlement has put out a "feeler" to Peiping for new direct talks between representatives of the United Nations and Communist China.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23--President Truman took a hand in the wage stabilization controversy today by arranging a conference at Blair House this evening. As a result it is expected that a wage policy will be issued by Monday.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 23 (UP)-- Senora Peron today proposed President Peron for re-election next year.

ALBANY, Feb. 23--New York City stated its case to the Legislature today for permission to raise the sales tax and levy other additional taxes to provide new revenues of $82,000,000 to take care of rising city costs and to continue the $250 pay increase for city employes during the fiscal year starting July 1.

When a mathematician enters the kitchen, it is time for home cooks to look for the nearest exit. At least that's what Japanese-born Masao Yoshitsu, who recently started a home delivery service of family dinners--Japanese, Chinese or American style--hopes will happen.

SANFORD, Fla., Feb. 23--The Giants' squad received a notable addition today when a strapping fellow invaded camp, donned a uniform and promptly started peppering the distant left field barrier of the local park with some prodigious drives.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company established new high records last year in assets, amount paid to policyholders and insurance in force, according to the report issued yesterday by Leroy A. Lincoln, chairman, and Charles G. Taylor Jr., president.
For thirty-three years Dr. C. Guyer Kelly, a Methodist missionary in North Africa, has been mixing the Bible and baseball to the benefit of both.

VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 23-- Rex Barney, with whom manager Chuck Dressen has been working ever since this camp opened last Tuesday, will get his baptism of fire tomorrow--but the firing won't be very heavy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23--The Senate subcommittee investigating alleged political influence and favoritism in operations of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation discovered today that copies of a ten-year accumulation of letters from members of Congress to the R.F.C. on behalf of prospective borrowers had been sent to President Truman at his request.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Feb. 23 --Denouncing "irresponsible" critics of American foreign policy, Philip C. Jessup, United States Ambassador at Large, declared here today that the "only alternative course to follow would be to start a war against the Soviet Union now."

A daughter was born to Dr. and Mrs. Melvin Moore of Brooklyn on Feb. 11 in Beth-El Hospital, Mrs. Moore is the former Miss Elaine Stacia Pohl, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Pohl of Brooklyn. The child, who will be named Abigail Sue, is a granddaughter also of Mr. and Mrs. Max Moore of Brooklyn.
Hopes of exporters and importers for special price regulations easing the squeeze of present general controls are unlikely to be more than partly fulfilled, informed trade sources said last week.

THIS twenty-year harvest of short stories by Rhys Davies, a London-dwelling Welshman now in his late forties, offers American readers much of the best work of a regional writer of skill, warmth and wit, and no sentimentality at all.

SAIGON, Indo-China, Feb. 24-- The new Vietnam Cabinet took under consideration today a request from Chief of State Bao Dai that ways and means be studied for organizing a consultative national assembly.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 24 (Reuters)--India and Pakistan reached agreement here tonight on the first full trade pact between the two countries since India devalued her currency in September, 1949.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 24--Michael V. DiSalle, the Federal Price Stabilizer, told members of the City Club today that his program of price controls, a month old tomorrow, had begun to slow down the rate of increase in the cost of living.

New York University's swimming team completed its season by defeating Georgetown, 54 to 21, but the Violet fencers bowed to unbeaten Navy, 20 to 7, yesterday. Both events were held in the Violets' Alumni gymnasium at University Heights.

The seventh annual Borden's home economics scholarship at Hunter College has been awarded to Eileen Anita Walsh of 236 Hillside Terrace, Staten Island, it was announced yesterday. The award of $300 is made to the home economics senior with the highest scholastic standing. Miss Walsh plans to teach home economics and will use the award toward graduate study.

Just one month ago tomorrow-- seven months after the outbreak of the Korean war--the U.S. imposed price and wage controls upon its economy. With this move the nation was squared away for an economic mobilization which will touch every American's daily life for years to come.
ROSELLE, N.J., Feb. 24--Mr. and Mrs. George E. Pepin have made known the engagement of their daughter, Mary A.H., to Robert J. Sippel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Sippel of near-by Roselle Park.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24--A Senate investigating subcommittee may turn over to the Department of Justice, for possible perjury action, the transcript of sworn testimony by top officials of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

Two courteous bandits, who nevertheless forced their victims to remove their trousers as a precautionary measure, escaped with more than $2,500 yesterday in an armed hold-up of a Brooklyn wholesale confectionery store.
HELL hath no fury like Brooklyn scorned, Noel Coward discovered some years back when, in "Middle East Diary," he let slip some ill-chosen words about Brooklyn boys in a Mediterranean hospital.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 24--Two of the six National Guard divisions on active duty were alerted today for training and service in Japan.

First indications of a possible serious recession soon at all trade levels of the television and refrigerator industry appeared last week. Retailers ceased all forward buying that they have been engaged in against future shortages and limited purchases to necessary fill-ins.

Bruno Walter took his turn on the podium of the N.B.C. Symphony in Carnegie Hall last evening. It was the first of two broadcast concerts he was scheduled to conduct in place of Arturo Toscanini, whose old knee injury forced him to cancel his final appearances of the season.

PARIS, Feb. 24 (AP)--A strike of Paris subway and bus workers was called today for Monday. Both Communist and non-Communist unions ordered the walkout to back up their demands for wage increases of 6,000 francs ($17).

The special three-man committee now investigating ship construction subsidies has decided that no major amendments are needed to the Merchant Marine Act of 1936 for the proper determination of such awards by the Government, it was learned yesterday.

The Alcoholic Beverage Industries Committee of the New York Heart Association will undertake a one-day city-wide drive on March 10 to raise $250,000 for the Heart Fund. The fund is seeking to raise $1,000,000.

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 24 (UP)-- The American Bowling Congress said today 5,194 teams would compete in the A.B.C. tournament beginning at St. Paul, Minn., April 7. The field is the seventh largest in the history of the tournament.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 24 (UP)-- Dr. Harry W. Rockwell, nationally known educator, will retire July 31 after having served as head of Buffalo State Teachers College for thirty-two years.

Potential roles for United States and European women in view of the threat of war were discussed yesterday by speakers at the sixtysecond annual luncheon of the Women's Press Club of New York City. Seven hundred persons attended the luncheon, which was held at the Statler Hotel.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 24 (AP)-- Quadruplets--two boys and two girls--were born today to the wife of a Baltimore steel worker who had been expecting twins. Several New Yorkers are among the seventy-six purchasers of homesites in the new Delray Gardens community at Delray Beach, Fla., where twelve all-year houses have been completed and contracts have been closed for twenty-two others.

LONDON, Feb. 24 (Reuters)-- Turkish soldiers wounded in Korea will get transfusions of "Turkish blood only," the Ankara radio reported.
