TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 26 (AP)-- Communique 806 of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur's headquarters, for period from 6 A.M. Sunday to 6 A.M. Monday, issued at 9:66 A.M. Monday (7:55 P.M. Sunday, Eastern standard time):

WASHINGTON, Feb. 251--President and Mrs. Truman attended a Constitution Hall event tonight opening the District of Columbia phase of the American Red Cross campaign to raise $85,000,000, the greatest amount sought in any year since World War II.

VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 25-- Manager Charley Dressen of the Dodgers was a very sick influenza victim tonight. Shortly before 8 o'clock the little skipper was running a temperature of nearly 102 degrees after remaining in bed since shortly after noon.

More "sermonizing, dramatizing and advertising about brotherhood" is done in February than in any other month, the Rev. Maurice A. Dawkins said in his sermon yesterday, but he asked if we have not become "split personalities--talking brotherly love and practicing brotherly hate."

IRON MOUNTAIN- KINGSFORD, Mich., Feb. 25--Powerdiving Arthur Tokle, 28-year-old Flying Norseman from Brooklyn, thrilled a turnout of 35,000, including Gov. G. Mennen Williams of Michigan, to lead a talent-loaded field of forty-eight today as the two-day Olympic skiing tryouts came to an end.

Secretary of Defense George C. Marshall will administer the loyalty oath to 700 volunteers in the medical emergency division of the city's civil defense organization at ceremonies tomorrow at 5 P.M. at 500 Park Avenue.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 25-- Acquisitions of three new story properties were announced this week-end by major studios.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 25 --The Communist program for Germany based on unity and neutrality has won so much support in Western Germany that its introduction at a four-power meeting, it is felt, would have a critical effect on relations between the Western powers and the Federal Republic.
PARIS, Feb. 25--Gen. Charles de Gaulle, in a speech at Bourges today, stressed the idea that Europe must be saved and pleaded with the French in the next elections to restore France's unity.

Rabbi Jonah B. Wise, who was 70 years old last week, was honored by 500 friends and colleagues last night at a birthday celebration in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. For a quarter century, Rabbi Wise has been the spiritual leader of the Central Synagogue.

A significant step in a general movement toward organizing the parent education field and raising it to the status of a profession was announced yesterday by Mrs. Mildred B. Beck, director of the Child Study Association of America, 132 East Seventy-fourth Street.

BOSTON, Feb. 25--The American construction industry set a record in 1950, and only a small portion of the huge building volume was direct defense work, according to the annual report of H.E. Foreman, managing director of the Associated General Contractors of America, Inc.

HONG KONG, Feb. 12--I have already written about the manifest honesty of purpose that the Chinese Communist Government displays in its internal administration and to which many foreigners living in the country bear witness.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 25--The forgotten man of the Yankee pitching staff is determined to make a strong bid for a starting role this year. His name is Fred Sanford from Salt Lake City, Utah.

Raya Garbousova, who is not one to stint either on quality or interest, treated her large audience to an exceptionally varied program last night in Town Holl. It was the Russian-born 'cellist's annual recital here; she played with the first-class assistance of David Stimer at the piano.
"Springtime Folly," the week's sole Broadway entry, will open at 8:30 this evening at the Golden.
The tight tourist class situation on the North Atlantic during the summer months will be alleviated by the addition of almost 850 extra berths this year, the Home Lines made known yesterday.

Members of the Committee on the Present Danger will be heard over the WOR-Mutual network in a series of Sunday night programs startinn on March 4. Dr. Vannevar Bush, director of the Carnegie Institution in Washington, the first speaker, will be heard from 9:30 to 9:45 P.M. His topic will be "The Atomic Bomb and the Defense of the United States."

Normal--seasonal reorders and fill-ills were noted in the wholesale markets here last week as most markets waited for a clarification of the current price situation, according to reports prepared especially for TxE NEw YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Few buyers were in town during the week.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25--Presidential powers to send United States ground troops to Europe would not be abridged under a resolution drawn up by two powerful Democratic Senate Committee chairmen.

PARIS, Feb. 25--German financial difficulties, which have been revealed here at the meeting of the European Payments Union, are causing concern among French monetary authorities. France is in fact one of the largest European creditors of the German republic.
William Talbert of New York regained the men's crown and Miss Nancy Chaffee of Ventura, Calif., retained the women's title yesterday in the national indoor tennis championships.
The recent increase of public interest in the problem of narcotic addiction and illicit sale inspires the hope that a more intelligent program of con trol and cure may not be far distant.

HONG KONG, Feb. 25--Two years back Yang Pei-yung (which is not his real name) was a newspaper man in the South China province of Kwangsi. But revolution, hard times and a new regime narrowed the market for reporters so he became--of all things-- a fortune teller.

Mr. and Mrs. James W. Maitland of New York and Lawrence, L.I., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Maitland's daughter, Miss Nancy Mellen, to Seton Ijams, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Horton Ijams, also of this city and Lawrence.

The proposal to increase the Federal tax on alcoholic beverages from $9 to $12 a gallon will increase illegal distilling, Erwin B. Hock, director of the Division of Alcoholic Beverage Control of New Jersey, declared last night.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 25-- The new trade agreement between India and Pakistan puts an end to commercial warfare waged by the two countries since September, 1949. On that date all sterling countries except Pakistan devalued their currencies.

HOUSTON, Tex., Feb. 25 (UP)-- Marty Furgol of Long Beach, Calif., who predicted yesterday while in second place that he would "take top money" in the Houston open golf tournament, did just that today with a 72-hole score of 277.

LONDON, Feb. 25--Now that the steel industry has been finally taken over by the state, the somewhat hectic activity in the stock markets has subsided and more normal trading conditions have been restored.

WITH THE UNITED STATES MARINES, in Korea, Feb. 24-- Pilots of the Army's "eggbeater fleet" responded today to an emergency call from the marines and came here with their helicopters to help evacuate the badly wounded.

TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 26--The Chinese and North Korean Communists launched counter-attacks along the Eastern and Central Korean fronts yesterday, holding the United Nations advance to small gains. The enemy resisted stubbornly from dug-in hill positions, backed with tank and artillery fire.

Steel mills and foundries in this country, facing a grave scrap supply situation, have enlisted the aid of the Government and the nation's industrial plants to help increase the slow of this vital raw material.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company had the greatest year in its history during 1950.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, Feb. 25-- With a record leap of 165 feet, Jacob Sorensen of the Norway ski club captured the annual Telemark Ski Club trophy tournament as some 11,500 baked in midsummer weather today at this 50-meter hill.

FLORAL PARK, L.I., Feb. 25--The operators of Radio Station WSHS do not have to depend on the Hooper spot check system to count their audience. They merely check the attendance records of more than sixty schools in Nassau, Suffolk and Westchester counties.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP)-- Dr. Robert L. Johnson, national chairman of the Citizens Committee for the Hoover Report, urged today "early and sweeping reorganization of the Veterans Administration from top to bottom."

Pedestrians from town and city as well as motorists of the metropolitan area went into "spring training" yesterday.

The committee on administrative reorganization of the Board of Higher Education has recommended that the post of chancellor or provost be created for the over-all administration of this city's four colleges, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Ordway Tead, board chairman.

PARIS, Feb. 25--A Soviet military mission of several hundred officers and technicians is reliably reported to be established in Czechoslovakia. The size of the mission --which has grown from an original small group to one that some sources estimate as large as 1,000 --cannot accurately be confirmed since it is spread around the country.

CLARK TOWNSHIP, N.J., Feb 25--Seven children narrowly escaped serious injury here today when a light plane, making a forced landing, struck and nearly demolished a wooden platform under which they were playing.

An American management consulting company will conduct a survey of the Belgian cotton textile industry beginning March 1, it was made known last week. The survey is being sponsored by the Economic Cooperation Administration and the Belgian Government through the Belgian Economic Mission now in Washington.

The Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation, leading designer and manufacturer of airplanes for the United States Navy, and also specializing in amphibious type aircraft for private and commercial use, last year achieved the highest earnings for any peacetime year on record.

THERE are 858 pages adn 430,000 words in James Jones' first novel, "From Here to Eternity."*. That's about five times as long as the average novel. But this block-buster of a book is about five times as interesting as the average novel. It is a powerful and brutally shocking story which will outrage many of its readers.

THE HAGUE, Feb. 25 (AP)--The latest available figures on the world tin position issued in its advance statistics by the International Tin Study Group estimated world mine production for December at 15,700 long tons, compared with 13,100 in November.
The spring suit season is on in the shops. Now more than ever both the home seamstress and the purchaser of a ready-made suit are keenly interested in the fabric.

New York, like the ancient city of Sodom, is "fundamentally rotten to the core," the Rev. Ira W. Langston, minister of the Park Avenue Christian Church, Park Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street, charged yesterday in his sermon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25--The refusal of a St. Louis betting commissioner to make a television appearance before the Senate Crime Investigating Committee in St. Louis yesterday drew spirited speculation today from constitutional lawyers on whether the defiant witness stood on solid legal ground.

Questioning of Mrs. Jeanne Sollazzo, wife of Salvatore T. Solazzo, 45-year-old jewelry manufacturer held in the "fixing" of ten college basketball games at Madison Square Garden, has been delayed by her illness.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP)-- Eric Johnston probably will sign into effect the 10 per cent "catchup" wage formula tomorrow or Tuesday "without very extensive changes," Government officials said today. It mould replace the present general wage freeze.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25--Meat supplies have been increasing as the result of consumer reluctance to buy at prices permitted by the government "freeze," a survey of three of the nation's largest metropolitan areas disclosed today.

Not at all content to see the visitors tie the score four times, the New York Rovers broke out with a four-goal onfall in the last period to beat the Johnstown (Pa.) Jets, 8--4, in the Eastern Hockey League feature at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

There is reason for satisfaction in the fact that India and Pakistan have reached a temporary trade agreement. WASHINGTON, Feb. 25--The reclamation and full utilization of our most precious sources of water, the great river basins, has been blueprinted in the third and last volume in the report of the President's Water Resources Policy Commission. The bound summary was forwarded to the White House today.

In 1930 the late Mrs. Kate Macy Ladd established the Josiah Macy Jr. Foundation as a memorial to her father. ALBANY, Feb. 26--A series of changes in the proposed amendments to the New York City Parking Authority Law were introduced tonight.

Steelman, assistant to President Truman, and members of the National (railway) Mediation Board conferred with the disputants for six hours.

SANFORD, Fla., Feb. 26--Regardless of how Leo Durocher's various minor experimentations make out, such as converting Whitey Lockman into a first baseman or switching Monty Irvin and Clint Hartung to the outfield, most observers are agreed the Giants' pennant hopes for 1951 rest largely with two pitchers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--The Truman Administration has received Ambassador at Large John Foster Dulles' report on his mission to Japan with extraordinary satisfaction and has author ized him to proceed with the completion of the Japanese peace treaty at the earliest possible date.

George Gainford, manager of Ray Robinson, middleweight champion, tossed a brickbat at the International Boxing Club yesterday when he announced that his charge would defend his title against Kid Marcel, French middleweight ruler, in Paris between May 14 and 20.

Motor travel across 125th Street was speeded yesterday by 30 per cent as the new progressive traffic signal lights went into operation. A series of spot tests by engineers of the Department of Traffic showed that the running time over the thirteen blocks of the installation--from First Avenue to Broadway-- averaged 7 minutes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio demanded today a Congressional veto power over the dispatch of any American ground troops to help in Europe's defense. He proposed other Congressional restrictions as well.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--The Constitution of the United States was amended tonight to forbid any President from being elected for more than two terms or from being elected more than once if he had served in excess of two years of his predecessor's term.

PARIS, Feb. 26--Efforts to break the deadlock in the French Cabinet over a method of reforming the electoral system in France failed today after discussions lasting several hours. Another meeting of the Ministers was called for tomorrow morning.
The preliminary annual statement of the Continental Can Company, Inc., yesterday snowed sales and earnings in 1950 were the highest in its history.

Gwilym A. Price, president of the oldest and second largest electrical equipment concern in the world, the $695,000,000 Westinghouse Electric Corporation, condemned what he described yesterday as "Government-as-usual" and said it was "about time we realized that we cannot afford [it] if we are to spend $40,000,000,000 or $50,000,000,000 a year for military needs."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--William E. Willett, a member of the board of directors of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, told the Senate Banking subcommittee investigating the loan agency today that it was "a bad board" and that he was "as bad as the rest."

HAMDEN, Conn., Feb. 26--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Arthur Flint of the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Keller, to George Clinton Jones 4th, son of Mrs. Jones 3d of New Haven and the late Mr. Jones.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--General of the Army Omar N. Bradley, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, assured the Armed Services Committee of the House of Representatives today that the Department of Defense had no intention of calling further National Guard divisions to active duty.
Approval of the proposed $16,500,000 La Guardia Houses in lower Manhattan to accommodate 1,000 families, or 3,900 persons, was voted yesterday by the City Planning Commission in executive session.

For the sixth consecutive year the M.A. Hanna Company, producer and marketer of anthracite coal and iron ore, realized a new high record in earnings, G.M. Humphrey, president, disclosed in the annual report released for publication today.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 26--Dr. Elmer L. Henderson of Louisville, Ky., president of the American Medical Association, declared here tonight that wider application of preventive medicine and hygiene to industry was an obligation of labor and management as well as of the medical profession.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--The Supreme Court upheld, 5 to 3, today a four-month jail sentence for contempt imposed on Mrs. Jane Rogers of Denver.
New York City has borrowed $60,000,000 on tax anticipation notes dated Feb. 26 and due on May 1 at an interest rate of 1 per cent, Controller Lazarus Joseph announced yesterday.
ROME, Feb. 26--Communist leader Palmiro Togliatti returned to Italy from Moscow this evening after an absence of ten weeks and resumed effective leadership of the Italian Communist movement.

ANGOLA, La., Feb. 26--Ten of the thirty-one convicts who had each slashed the tendon of one heel as a protest against alleged brutal treatment in the State Prison Farm here repeated their selfmutilation today on their other heels.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP)-- The St. Lawrence Seaway and power project would cost about $16,000,000 more to build now than in 1948, according to Maj. Gen. Lewis A. Pick, chief of Army Engineers.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26--The Government's wage-price freeze is not workable because of the provision regarding farm parity prices, E.M. Cushing, director of industrial relations for the United States Rubber Company, asserted today. He spoke in a panel discussion at the personnel conference of the American Management Association.

Temporary repairs to two lowpressure turbine shafts of the United States liner America are expected to be completed in time for the vessel to sail from Southampton late tonight or early tomorrow, the company announced here yesterday.

The Avco Manufacturing Corporation not only achieved the highest sales and earnings in its history last year, but more than tripled its net of the previous year, increasing sales by 87 per cent, Victor Emanuel, president, reported in the annual statement issued for publication today.

The $312,000,000 Radio Corporation of America rolled up in 1950 the largest profit in its thirty-twoyear history. After all expenses, net income amounted to $46,249,865. That was 84 per cent more than the $25,144,279 reported for 1949. Share earnings in the respective years were $3.10 and $1.58.

Buying in a few key issues such as Chrysler and American Telephone yesterday kept a wavering stock market in line. Day care centers here, the war baby among social agencies, are marking up new highs in attendance. Some 4,800 children, many of them war babies themselves, troop into the centers daily while mothers and fathers work. This is 200 more than could be admitted at the previous peak in 1947.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 26 (AP)-- Some 2,000 athletes from twentyone Pan-American nations and colonies took advantage of an unexpected extra day of practice to loosen up their muscles in midsummer sunshine. First competition in the Pan American Olympics now is scheduled for tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP)-- President Truman told his Congressional leaders today he would send Congress a message this week recommending increases in secondclass postal rates.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 26Jose Ferrer has posted a bond of $25,000 to protect the backers of "Twentieth Century" on Broadway, against possible loss as a consequence of his withdrawal from the cast to come to Hollywood for the role of Androcles in "Androcles and the Lion," it was learned today from R-K-O, the company which will make the picture.

ISLAND PARK, L.I, Feb. 26-- A 200-ton reinforced concrete box the height of a three-story building was lowered into a cradle of massive piles on the bottom of Reynolds Channel here today to serve as the outfall chamber for Nassau County's new $25,000,000 sewage treatment plant at Bay Park.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 26-- Reports that India had accepted unequivocally a nondevalued par valuation of the Pakistani rupee at 30 United States cents against 21 cents for the Indian rupee were confirmed today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--A twelve-country committee of the new International Materials Conference began discussions today on how to speed the flow of essential and critical materials among the several nations.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP)-- The Securities and Exchange Commission rejected jurisdiction today over the American Power and Light Company's proposed sale of Washington Water Power Company.

Pittsburgh Steel Company announced yesterday that its directors had declared dividends covering all arrearages on its 5 per cent Class A and 7 per cent Class B preferred stocks. Cautious but steady buying in all items except copper and aluminum giftware and a record attendance marked the opening yesterday of the winter New York Gift Show in the New Yorker and Statler Hotels. Retailers sought to place heavy orders for copper and aluminum items because production of giftware using the two metals soon will be ended by National Production Authority direction.

An educational campaign to enlist 500 women with social service backgrounds to acquaint parents with the narcotics menace among children was opened yesterday by the women's division of Youth United, a Brooklyn organization opposing juvenile delinquency.

ALBANY, Feb. 26--The eating habits of the snowy owl, a bird native to Arctic climes, were the subject of an hour-long debate today before the Legislative committees on conservation.

Nathan (Natie) Miller, a Long Island University basketball player of two seasons ago, was arrested late last night on a charge of having accepted bribes to lose or limit the margin of victory on two games played in Madison Square Garden in December, 1948.

The Mayor's Committee on Unity, which for some years has grappled with the problem of race relations in New York City, has done a useful job in inquiring into a series of fights in mid-January involving a few students at Franklin K. Lane High School in Brooklyn.

Harry Gross testified yesterday for the first time before Brooklyn's racket-investigating grand jury, but--whether the gambler detailed the operations of his police-protected bookmaking syndicate remained an official secret.

If American exporters do not succumb to fears or indifference in the face of new problems and dangers, there is no doubt that United States export volume can reach a value of $12,000,000,000 this year, members of the Export Advertising Association were told yesterday. This would be $2,000,000,000 or 20 per cent higher than in 1950.

The Senate Crime Investigating Committee will air crime and politics in six days of public hearings starting March 12 in the United States Courthouse, in Foley Square, Rudolph Halley, chief counsel, announced yesterday.

Another major business concern has leased office space in the twenty-one-story office building under construction at 260 Madison Avenue, on the westerly blockfront between Thirty-eighth and Thirtyninth Streets.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 26--Not much attention has been paid to a Mahmoud colt named Yildiz, owned by Mrs. Walter M. Jeffords, in the chatter about next Saturday's $50,000 Flamingo Stakes. Today at Hialeah Yildiz called a bit of attention to himself. He beat a couple of fairly prominent Flamingo nominees--and two other 3-year-olds--in a $5,000 race over the Flamingo route of a mile and a furlong.

The Hartford Fire Insurance Company and its affiliates, which write practically every form of insurance except life, passed the $300,000,000-mark in assets for the first time in its 140-year history. As of Dec. 31, last, the report disclosed yesterday, total assets ...

Lewis H. Brown, chairman of the board of Johns-Manville Corporation, died yesterday of a heart ailment at Delray Beach, Fla. His age was 57. He went to Florida from his home in Deer Park, Greenwich, Conn., a few days ago.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--The chance discovery of a celestial body tentatively believed to be a minor planet, was reported today by members of the United States Naval Observatory.
SOMEWHERE IN KOREA, Feb. 26--Troops of the South Korean Army supported by United States units got a bitter surprise today when Chinese Communist soldiers rose suddenly and recaptured a crest.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--President Truman ordered his chief advisers on anti-inflation strategy today to develop ways and means of curbing excessive bank lending without interfering with the Treasury's "easy money" policy of public debt management or support of the Government bond market by the Federal Reserve.

Today's arrivals, at the Fiftyfifth Street Playhouse, are "The Dance of Life," a dance film trilogy, and "Little Ballerina," a British-made dance drama. Margot Fonteyn, Martita Hunt and Yvonne Marsh head the cast of "Little Ballerina," a J. Arthur Rank presentation ...

The request of the United States Senate Crime Investigating Committee for a look at the payrolls of the New York State Legislature is based on a desire to inquire into the background of Alfred C. Muscio, an assistant research counsel to Senator Elmer F. Quinn, Democratic minority leader in the Legislature's upper house.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--Mayor Impellitteri warned Congress today that New York City would have to cut back, if not abandon, many essential public improvements if a Federal tax were imposed on state and municipal bond issues.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--The Federal Supreme Court denied today the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish a review of his fight against removal as rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn.

"THE people of Pompeii were lucky: they did not know beforehand." It is only a loquacious minor character speaking in Arthur Koestler's new novel, "The Age of Longing"; but he is speaking for his creator. Mr. Koestler's novel is both a bitter prophecy of doom and a melancholy lament for the lost hopes of European civilization.
AUBURN, Ala., Feb. 26 (AP)-- Ralph Jordan was named Auburn's football coach today. The former Auburn center has served as line coach at Georgia since October, 1946.

LONDON, Feb. 26--With a modicum of success, Prime Minister Attlee sought today to allay British misgivings about the selection of a United States Admiral as Supreme Commander of the Atlantic pact naval forces in the North Atlantic.
A large sketch of the new home of the Hospital for Special Surgery was unveiled yesterday in a lot between Seventy-first and Seventy-second Streets on East River Drive.
The continued boycott of highpriced meat by housewives in the metropolitan area has resulted in unemployment among union slaughterers and a decrease in retail prices.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--Opinions of wide significance in the field of labor relations were handed down by the Supreme Court today.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Feb. 26--A lightweight helicopter powered with two jet engines that weigh eleven pounds each and are replaceable in two or three minutes by the use of a screw driver, was reported to be ready for production today at the East Palo Alto plant of Hiller Helicopters.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--Officials in the State Department charged today that the Soviet Union had used "tricky" figures in replying to a British note of Feb. 17.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Tuesday, Feb. 27--Former Foreign Minister Vladimir Clementis has been arrested and has confessed to charges of espionage and conspiracy to overthrow the Government, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26--Oscar Collazo, a mild-appearing Puerto Rican Nationalist, went on trial for his life in Federal District Court here today charged with killing one White House guard and intending ...

CHICAGO, Feb. 26--Liquidation was on in the grain markets in the early trading on the Board of Trade here today, prices dropping to new lows on the current movement. March wheat showed 15 3/8 cents under the recent top at the extreme.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 26--Phillipe Baudet, French Ambassador to Belgrade, informed Marshal Tito this morning that if the Soviet satellite threat to Yugoslavia should become unmistakable,

The international trade fair idea has been successfully adapted to domestic hardware merchandising for the first time, it was revealed here yesterday by William G. Earnest, sales manager, Whitlock Corporation, 17 Warren Street. More than 1,740 hardware dealers from twelve eastern states attended a trade fair staged by this hardware wholesaling firm at the Commodore Hotel over the week-end.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 26--The West German Communist party is installing younger leaders at the state level to promote a drive against rearmament designed specially to enlist factory workers and the Social Democratic rank and file.

In one of the most active trading sessions in several months, sugar futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange continued to advance sharply yesterday in response to the absorbtion of a major portion of the Cuban free market quota last week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP)-- William M. Boyle Jr., chairman of the National Democratic Committee, said today that Clarence E. Hood of Meridian, Miss., had been relieved of his duties as acting Democratic National Committeeman for Mississippi.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 26--The semblance of a real parliamentary debate made its appearance for the first time at a session of a Communist Parliament when debate opened this afternoon in the Yugoslav National Assembly on the new criminal code.

Notre Dame's basketball team, which used to jam Madison Square Garden with fans and thrill them, did neither last night. The annual visit of the Fighting Irish was a total loss as N.Y.U., pulling its punches in the last ten minutes, coasted to a 87--72 victory over the slow-footed South Benders.
A 10 per cent increase in net sales and a rise of 138 per cent in backlog were reported in the annual statement of the Douglas Aircraft Company issued yesterday by Donald W. Douglas, president.

The major radio and television networks have offered a 10 per cent increase in minimum wages for staff musicians, but the American Federation of Musicians, with whom the companies are negotiating for a new contract, is demanding 20 per cent, it was learned yesterday.
CHICAGO, Feb. 28--The House of Delegates of the American Bar Association unanimously recommended today that bar associations expel from membership Communists and advocates of Marxism-Leninism.

UNION CITY, N.J., Feb. 26-- Plans to place under construction in New Jersey public housing to cost $100,000,000 by the end of the year, in addition to the $40,000,000 of low-rent construction under ...

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 26--A new Yankee third-base candidate was announced today by Manager Casey Stengel in Gil McDougald, 21-year-old San Franciscan. Stengel said he plans to play the youngster for an indefinite period at the corner heretofore monopolized by Bobby Brown and Billy Johnson.

VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 26-- Fresco Thompson, vice president in charge of Dodger farm operations, dropped in this afternoon from Caracas, Venezuela, with what "may be the answer" to Manager Chuck Dressen's query:

The West Side Association of Commerce, long a militant opponent of the proposed St. Lawrence Seaway, yesterday accused advocates of the waterway of inconsistencies in their arguments and uneconomic thinking.

The Office of Price Stabilization's primary objective is to encourage low-end merchandise, according to Joseph N. Kallick, director of the Consumer Soft Goods Division. The O.P.S., he said, will seek to avoid such mistakes as were made by the Office of Price Administration during World War II that made it impossible for manufacturers to produce their basic of low-end lines.
Far East Air Forces summary of Sunday operations issued at 1:15 P.M. Monday (11:15 P.M. Sunday, Eastern standard time):

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 26--Hundreds of employes of the newspaper La Prensa tonight notified President Juan D. Peron they intended to report to work tomorrow afternoon with a view to getting out the paper Wednesday morning.

ALBANY, Feb. 26--Republican legislative leaders, in conference with Governor Dewey, decided tonight to recommend pay increases for employes of the state to range from $300 to $1,000 a year, The net cost to the state would be $19,500,000 annually.

PARIS, Feb. 26--French officials said today that the threatening political crisis that gripped Morocco last week had been resolved following the Sultan's decision to accede to demands made upon him by Gen. Alphonse-Pierre Juin, French Resident General in the protectorate.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP)-- A Federal Power Commission attorney at a hearing here today called the proposed merger of Colorado Interstate Gas Company and the Canadian River Gas Company "the most extravagant, outrageous proposition I've ever heard of."

AFTER a series of astronomical calculations, an exami nation of the undersides of stones, and a check on the color of seaweed, the Nags Head fishing prophets have come forth with the prediction that the first channel bass will he taken off Oregon Inlet on or about March 23.

From United Nations sources comes the first tabulation of the casualties suffered by our allies in Korea. Australia, Canada, France, Greece, the Netherlands, New Zealand, the Philippines, Turkey, the United Kingdom and the Union of South Africa all report dead, wounded or missing men.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP)-- The Supreme Court today agreed to rule whether state "fair trade" laws may be applied to liquor stores and other retailers who never agreed to abide by minimum prices.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 27 (UP) Straight Clark of Pasadena, Calif., and Miss Beverly Baker of Santa Monica, Calif., each seeded second, advanced easily today in the first round of the Bermuda invitation tennis tournament.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 27 There wasn't much to write home about at Hialeah today. Seven of the nine races were claimers, and a sprint for maiden 3-year-old colts and geldings was just about the best item on the program.
Specialized price-control regulations issued yesterday for the nonfood retail field generally are fair and equitable, trade leaders here agreed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--Inflationary forces sufficient to produce a five-fold rise in prices could result from the failure to increase taxes promptly, according to a study by the staff of the Joint Congressional Committee on the Economic Report.

JERUSALEM, Feb. 27 Freed from his party's agreement with the Orthodox bloc by the fall of the Government coalition, Premier David Ben-Gurion has precipitated another bitter clash with Israel's religious leaders, both political and clerical.

SAN PEDRO, Calif., Feb. 27 (AP) Eighteen persons now doomed to die were selected today as volunteer guinea pigs in a research experiment that may produce a cure for the fatal disease muscular dystrophy.
HONG KONG, Feb. 27--The Chinese Communists are settling some old scores in their intensified drive against "obstinate unrepentant counter-revolutionaries."
The investigation of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation should consider the desirability of continuing the agency, the guaranty Trust Company of New York asserts.
The Long Island Rail Road asked the Public Service Commission yesterday for a permanent increase of 20 per cent in all commutation rates instead of the 32 per cent increase it had been seeking.
A young Negro athlete was credited yesterday with the capture of a thug who with a companion had tried to hold up a restaurant.

DIOGENES never would have bothered with the boxing business in his search for an honest man any more than a fellow would deliberately search through a haystack for a needle. But if he had made the try and if his patience had been inexhaustible he eventually would have met up with Jack Hurley.

Development of an operation to provide a new blood supply to the heart muscle in patients with discased coronary arteries was reported last night at a meeting of the New York Heart Association at the New York Academy of Medicine.
ALBANY, Feb. 27 Legislators were being subjected to mounting pressure from their constituents today to oppose the proposed weight-distance tax on heavy trucking, which has Administration backing.
Robert Casadesus, the pianist, began his recital last night in Carnegie Hall by playing with the mastery of true simplicity the Schubert dance pieces, the Laendler, Op. 121.

A special exhibition of distinguished eighteenth century furniture and decorations, a treat for the connoisseur and a guide for the would-be collector and student, opens today in the Brooklyn Museum, a timely display as the season for antiques shows begins.
ALBANY, Feb. 27 Trustees of the State University, in their third annual report to the Legislature, said today that state facilities for higher education had been greatly expanded last year.

At almost every legislative session for many years doctors and scientists have had to drop everything in order to fight anti-vivisection bills promoted at Albany by well-meaning but shortsighted sentimentalists. At this session they have something to fight for instead of against in the Metcalf-Hatch bill that would make it easier and less expensive for hospitals, medical colleges and other research laboratories to get animals for experimentation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--William H. Fedder, a Baltimore printer, testified under oath today that he had taken orders and pay for the distribution of campaign literature, under attack as scurrilous, from the headquarters of John M. Butler, Republican Senator elected in Maryland last fall.

A price regulation similar to that created by the Office of Price Administration in World War II would be acceptable to the dress industry if certain modifications were included, Erwin Feldman, director-counsel of the National Association of House Dress Manufacturers, declared yesterday.
A man over whose body one car of a subway train passed yesterday may live to tell the tale because of the fast work of an ambulance surgeon.
The proposed St. Lawrence Seaway project is the most serious threat to New York since this city became the nation's leading port more than a hundred years ago, Mayor Impellitteri declared yesterday.
NEWARK, Feb. 27 (AP) A 21year-old girl was sentenced to a year in jail today as one of Newark's "most vicious" dealers in narcotics.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 President Truman today proposed broad increases in postal rates which, with a fourth-class increase now being considered, would wipe out more than half of the Post Office Department's prospective deficit of $521,000,000.

Robert Schrade, who gave his second local recital last night at Town Hall, is a young pianist with a real flair for the keyboard, and when he got to his modern selections, his playing was clean, deft and very much alive.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 27--United States High Commissioner John J. McCloy "will arrive at a fair and reasonable solution," former Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson tonight told his German clients, who are opposing the present Allied decartelization law for German heavy industry. Mr. Patterson was to board a plane for New York later tonight.

As the Senate hearings on the question of sending additional American troops to Europe approach their end it becomes evident that they have already produced virtually unanimous agreement on the immediate issue which precipitated the whole discussion.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 Eric Johnston, Economic Stabilization Administrator, today approved the basic pay-rise regulation that was recommended by the Wage Stabilization Board's public and industry members, but directed the agency to liberalize it.

One thousand professors and other staff members of the four city colleges adopted a resolution at an "emergency rally" last night urging support for a pay increase bill offered by Assemblyman Lewis Olliffe.

VIENNA, Feb. 27 Two former Hungarian law officers who fled from Hungary to Salzburg have furnished what was described today by United States intelligence officials as an apparently authentic account of methods of drugging and torture used by Hungarian political police to extract a "confession" from Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, Primate of Hungary, more than two years ago.

Roundly lambasted by the critics, "Springtime Folly" was hurriedly taken off after last night's performance the second at the Golden, thereby attaining some kind of a distinction in equaling the shortest run of the season previously held by "Four Twelves Are 48."

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 A close Federal watch on United States' exports has prevented more than $155,000,000 of American goods from falling into Russian hands in the last three years, John C. Borton, assistant director of the Office of International Trade, said today. He spoke at the annual Foreign Trade Conference arranged by the Chicago Association of Commerce and the Export Managers Club of Chicago.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 27 One of the worst traffic bottlenecks in the east is developing at the northern terminus of the Saw Mill River Parkway in Mount Kisco, Westchester officials said today in planning a fight for $8,750,000 state improvements.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 The Legislative Military Law Committee has decided to omit any state appropriations for bomb shelter construction from the pending administration Civil Defense Bill unless Congress revises the law governing Federal grants for such construction.
ROME, Feb. 27 A large increase in Government spending is foreseen in the budget forecasts for the fiscal year, 1951-52, which were discussed and approved by the Cabinet today.

Announcement has been made here by Mr. and Mrs. Lewis B. Maytag of Colorado Springs of the engagement of their daughter, Catherine, to Gwynn Herndon Robinson of New York, son of Mrs. Corinne Herndon Robinson of Washington.

The young listeners are not the only ones who get a chance at the student matinees given at the Metropolitan Opera House under the auspices of the Metropolitan Opera Guild. Young singers also benefit from the performances by getting chances at big roles, and yesterday afternoon Jean Madeira, who joined the company two seasons ago, got her first opportunity to sing Azucena in "II Trovatore."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) Following is the text of President Truman's message to Congress today asking for higher postal rates:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 Yugoslavia needs up to $450,000,000 in aid over the next three years to meet her current economic crisis, informed officials reported today.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 27 Delegates of eighteen countries represented in the meetings here of the Economic and Social Council of the United Nations covered a good deal of the map of the world as charges of infringements of trade-union rights were leveled today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 President Truman wants to make a parachute jump from an airplane, he said today.

The stock market suffered yesterday its worst reversal in more than a week and, while activity tailed to expand sharply, prices melted with ease. For several sessions the list has evidenced signs of fatigue as indicated by the restricted volume. A possible "secondary, correction" has been the theme of most letters from brokers to customers.

ISLIP, L.I., Feb. 27--Retention of W. Kingsland Macy as Suffolk County Republican leader was urged today by a group of influential Republicans in a letter sent to members of the Suffolk County Republican Committee. The letter was designed to offset the drive by supporters of Governor Dewey to elect County Clerk R. Ford Hughes as leader in Mr. Macy's place.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 28 (AP)--General of the Army Douglas MacArthur's communique 808 covering operations from 6 A.M., Tuesday to 6 A.M., Wednesday (4 P.M., Monday to 4 P.M., Tuesday, Eastern standard time):

SANFORD, Fla., Feb. 27 With a broiling sun beating down upon a perspiring but extremely healthy band of athletes, the Giants today concluded the preliminary phase of their 1951 training campaign on what should have been a pleasing note.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) The Federal Power Commission authorized Algonquin Gas Transmission Company today to sell natural gas to local distributors in parts of Connecticut, Rhode Island, New Jersey and Massachusetts, including Boston.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27--American Bar Association leaders held today that there was no reason why lawyers should not take anti-Communist oaths. The decision was a victory for Texans over a group of Easterners attending the association's House of Delegates here.

BOSTON, Feb. 27 (AP) The Boston Maine Railroad today declared the first dividends on its new stock but payment must await settlement of a suit attacking the road's plan of modifying its stock structure.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 27--The Communist party in West Germany has offered to support a Social Democratic candidate in a special election to the Bundestag in the first example of the new policy line of the party.

VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 27 An agreement has been reached with the Caracas Club of the Venezuelan Winter League to provide nine players each year for that outfit, Walter O'Malley, president of the Dodgers, announced today at his first training camp press conference.

SACRAMENTO, Feb. 27 (UP)--Gov. Earl Warren, aligning himself with the "international wing" of the Republican party, said today that it was up to the military leaders to decided where American troops should be sent.

Further reductions in the price of choice meat cuts appeared in store for New York housewives as reports yesterday indicated increased efforts by wholesale and retail meat dealers to move their stocks in the face of continued consumer resistance to high prices.

Public distribution was made yesterday of $30,000,000 worth of common stock of Aluminium Ltd., in part compliance with an antitrust trial court order handed down in mid-January. The sale marked one of the largest secondary distributions of stock ever made by securities dealers.

An increasing life span and higher costs have made uneconomic the life-care contract of residents in homes for the aged, Miss Muriel W. Ashwell, president of St. Luke's Home for Aged Women, said yesterday at a forum of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies.

NEWARK, Feb. 27 The speed of the Broker, the commuter train in which eighty-four persons were killed at Woodbridge on Feb. 6, was "between 58 and 60 miles an hour" when the train was derailed, a Pennsylvania Railroad official testified here today.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 27 (AP) Curtis Stone won the 10,000meter run in the Pan-American Games today with a thrilling spurt in the stretch that defeated Argentina's Ricardo Bralo.

Under the title of "Course in Self-Preservation,"' Margaret Arlen has started on Channel 2 this week an admirable new television series for the housewife. The presentation is providing a thorough and detailed guide in the fundamentals of civilian defense with detailed instruction on how to care for injuries.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27--A special priority to enable factories, business establishments and public and private institutions to get materials needed for the maintenance, repair and operation of the plants at "peak efficiency," was granted today by the National Production Authority.

A sudden rush of activity on the part of the state Legislatures has added a new Amendment to the Constitution of the United States. This is the Twentysecond Amendment, which declares that after Mr. Truman (who is specifically exempted) no President shall be elected for more than two terms, or elected more than once if he has served in excess of two years of his predecessor's term.

Mayor Impellitteri is determined to protect the city's business men from paying any money to "five percenters" to get defense business, he declared yesterday at City Hall. He asserted that the city was prepared to "fight" to make certain that no intermediaries are necessary to insure fair allocation of short materials to manufacturers.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 27 --Edvard Kardelj, Foreign Minister, announced tonight in the National Assembly that the Yugoslav Government favored the proposed four-power conference because even a partial success would help preserve peace.
A special kind of supermarket with merchandise ranging from plows to powdered milk and textbooks on epidemiology, was set up yesterday in one of the Astor Hotel's banquet rooms.

Government evidence of "reciprocity" in the anti-trust trial of seventeen investment banking firms shows that if the defendant Stone Webster Securities Corporation was in any conspiracy it was with the non-defendant business of Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., Federal Judae Harold R. Medina was told here yesterday.

An observation by Asa Bushnell yesterday that, in his opinion, the finish between Don Gehrmann and Fred Wilt in last Saturday's Intercollegiate A.A.A.A, special mile was even closer than the disputed Wanamaker Mile of 1950 led to the previously undisclosed discovery that it was on a split decision that Don won his thirty-ninth straight race.

Dr. J. Gardner Hopkins, specialist in dermatology, who was professor of that subject at Columbia University from 1925 until his retirement in 1947, having served on the Columbia faculty for thirty-six years, died last night, presumably of a heart attack, at his office, 102 East Seventy-eighth Street. He was 68 years old. His residence was at 217 Haven Avenue.

Newspaper advertising will continue to be a "great force" for selling goods, it was said last night by H.T. Ewald, president of the Campbell-Ewald Company. He spoke at the agency's fortieth anniversary dinner in the Pierre Hotel. The company now has 350 employes, has billings in eight figures annually and has offices in six cities.

LET nature relax from the seasonal norm for a few days, sending the thermometer to May levels, and a number of un-natural humorists are certain to emerge like woodchucks from their winter burrows to try their bucolic wit on defenseless rod and gun editors.

"ON Feb. 7, 1837, God spoke to me and called me to His service." Like Joan of Arc, Florence Nightingale was convinced that she was chosen for a unique destiny. She wasn't yet 17 and the trouble was that she didn't know what God wanted her to do. It took her eight years to discover that it was to nurse the sick and eight years more to triumph over her family's...

PARIS, Feb. 27--In a statement announcing that the French Government would not reply to the Soviet note of Jan. 20 regarding the French-Soviet treaty, the Foreign Office today contended that the Soviet Union maintained some 5,000,000 men under arms.

A new high in net earnings of $18,767,554 on a record sales volume of $230,397,661 was reported yesterday in the 1950 statement of the Admiral Corporation, television, radio and appliance manufacturer.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Feb. 27 (AP) Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican of Michigan, has suffered a setback in his convalescence from a long illness that will delay his plans to return to Washington.
Many parties will be given at the twentieth annual Loyola luncheon, fashion show and card party for the benefit of the Jesuit Missions tomorrow in the Grand Ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Under the pressure of profit-taking and hedge-selling, sugar futures on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange declined yesterday in the largest single day's trading since the reopening of the market following World War II. For the previous several days sugar futures had recorded sharp gains in response to the sale of a large part of the Cuban free market quota.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Feb. 27 Western Germany's import embargo has created an atmosphere of disaster in the Netherlands, which fears disruption of her trade and dislocation of her internal economy with drastic effect on her farm population.

There is another avalanche starting in Central Europe. At the moment it is only a snowball, launched in Berlin with malice aforethought, but it will descend upon us soon tons and tons of it. There has been a five-day conference in Berlin of what was ironically labeled the "World Council of Peace." At its concluding session it announced the launching of one more campaign "to force peace" upon a supposedly reluctant world.
An investigation as to why it took an ambulance two hours to respond to an unconscious woman suffering a cerebral hemorrhage is being made by the Department of Hospitals, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 About 4,000,000 of the country's 61,500,000 civilian labor force will be in defense production by the end of the year. Ewan Clague, Commissioner of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor, predicted today.
The Third Avenue Transit Corporation operated at a loss of $3,450,598 last year. According to the annual report issued yesterday, that was $1,108,716 less than the $4,559,314 loss recorded for 1949.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 The Department of Justice announced today filing of an anti-trust action against the Insurance Board of Cleveland, Ohio. Attorney General McGrath said he had filed a civil suit in the Federal District Court at Cleveland charging a conspiracy among board members to monopolize the sale of fire insurance in Cuyahoga County, in which Cleveland and its suburban areas are located.

Plans for converting the fivestory limestone residence at 21 East Seventieth Street, near Madison Avenue, to business quarters and apartments were announced yesterday in connection with the purchase of the property by an industrial designer from Dr. Lena Halpern in a deal negotiated by Culver, Hollyday Co., brokers,...

A married couple from Hollywood were arrested in Brooklyn last night, accused of having attempted to extort $20,000 from a manufacturer on the threat of reporting him to authorities for an alleged evasion of income tax payments.

The City of New York has earned a pretty penny through the sale of cakes and candy, gum, nuts and soft drinks, reading material and sundry facilities in the subway system. Last year the total income from concessions was $4,764,176.

Plans have been completed by Miss Martha Talcott Blankarn, daughter of Marshall P. Blankarn of 187 East Sixty-fourth Street, and Rumson, N.J., and the late Mrs. Blankarn, for her marriage to Alexander Van Rensselaer Halsey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles D. Halsey of 125 East Seventy-second Street, and Rumson.
BERLIN, Feb. 27--The Soviet-type widely publicized five-year plan in Eastern Germany is currently encountering rough going.

ALBANY, Feb. 27 The Senate crime investigating committee completed the ground work today in its investigation of gambling in Republican-controlled Saratoga County. Peter C. Murray, a committee investigator, said he had collected about 100 pounds of records covering "personal affairs and business connections" of eighteen officials and other well-known figures. Most will be called to testify at an open hearing in New York City March 12, he asserted.

Moscow's latest note to Britain does not brighten the dim prospects of agreement among the Foreign Ministers when and if they meet. It refers to the Anglo-Soviet pact and is not part of the series of notes dealing with that meeting, but the chief concern of the British, as reflected in the press comments, is that the Government...

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 27 (Reuters) Members of the Czech Communist party, shaken by a purge that has resulted in the arrest of Dr. Vladimir Clementis and other top members, tonight faced the prospect of continued screening and examination.

LONDON, Feb. 27 Under attack from the Opposition for agreeing to the appointment of an American as supreme North Atlantic commander of Western Allied naval forces, the British Labor Government is now trying to regain the initiative.
The Brooklyn Dodgers baseball club yesterday entered into a television contract which, with options, will extend television rights beyond seven years to the Schaefer Brewing Company.

Final tally of voting by 18,000 workers employed in eight East Coast shipyards of the Bethlehem Steel Company yesterday showed overwhelming acceptance of the wage increase settlement reached on Feb. 18.

Plans for houses "designed from the inside out" are part of an exhibit that opens today in the gallery of the American Craftsmen's Educational Council at 32 East Fifty-second Street. Entitled "Good Home Design on a Limited Budget," the display is a one-man show of house plans and new furniture, all designed by Norman Cherner. It will be on view every day except Sunday through March 28.

Armco Steel Corporation is offering to its stockholders today warrants to subscribe to 819,737 shares of the company's new stock at $41 a share on the basis of one new share for each five shares held. The warrants will expire March 14.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27-Secretary of Defense George C. Marshall and General of the Army Omar N. Bradley, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, joined today in new appeals to Congress to authorize the draft of men at 18, instead of 18 as is provided in a bill pending before the House Armed Services Committee.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 General liquidation developed in the grain markets on the Board of Trade today with December wheat, corn and oats and November and January soybeans selling at new seasonal low prices.

Robert M. Catharine, president of the Dollar Savings Bank, and a member of the New York State Banking Board, publicly entered yesterday the current controversy between commercial and savings banks, over the latter's attempt to obtain broader branch banking powers.
LONDON, Feb. 27 There is an old saying that today's newspaper is only good for lighting tomorrow's fire.

The "overwhelming majority" of firemen are conducting themselves so well that the people of New York "will soon forget the black days we are living through now," Fire Commissioner George. P. Monaghan said yesterday.
ORMOND BEACH, Fla., Feb. 27 (AP) Shooting an even men's par 71, Miss Edean Anderson of Helena, Mont., today captured the medal in the twenty-second annual women's South Atlantic golf tournament.

The payroll of the General Motors Corporation reached an alltime high of $1,809,218,043 in 1950, and its employment of an average 465,239 salaried and hourly rated workers last year was a peacetime record and equal to the wartime peak year of 1944, according to an announcement yesterday by C.E. Wilson, president, and Alfred P. Cloan Jr., chairman.

Edwin B. Hinck has been named sales manager of the electronic parts division of Allen B. Du Mont Laboratories, Inc. He succeeds Maj. Harry Van Rensselaer, recently recalled to active duty with the Air Force.

A major management tool has been developed for both American and European factories which it is expected will enable many companies to maintain higher levels of output of both "guns and butter" manufacturing schedules. This was disclosed yesterday at a preview of research results by the Society for the Advancement of Management.
Underwriting syndicates will place on the market today $95,000,000 of new bonds of Consolidated Edison Company and New York and Tennessee Gas Transmission Company.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 President Truman displayed no concern today over ratification of the Twenty-second Constitutional Amendment, restricting a President to two elected terms.
The text of President Truman's address, broadcast from the White House last night to open the 1951 Red Cross appeal, follows:
HONG KONG, Feb. 27 (U.P) The Chinese Communist radio today reported the death of Dr. Chang Po-ling, a prominent educator whose students included Premier Chou En-lai. His age was 76.

The United States Government has leased another floor in 1790 Broadway for occupancy by the Department of State, bringing the number of floors occupied by the State Department in the building to four. The floor was leased by Edgar Ellinger, Inc., renting agent, through Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers.
Operations of the United Fruit Company in 1950 were the most successful of its fifty-one-year history, with record net earnings of $66,159,375 compared with $54,852,364 in 1949.

On Feb. 22 Senator Douglas of Illinois presented on the floor of the Senate a brilliant exposition of the issue of monetary policy and its relation to the present inflation of prices. At the outset he rejected the version that this controversy between the Treasury and the Federal Reserve was one of low versus high interest rates.

Police Commissioner Thomas F. Murphy will recommend restricting parking to one side of the street in congested residential areas where there is adequate garage or parking lot space to accommodate the displaced vehicles.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,243, compared with 1,460 last week and 1,211 in the corresponding week of last year, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 729 arrivals yesterday against 448 last Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 The Government asked a Federal jury of ten women and two men today for a verdict that would mean death in the electric chair for Oscar Collazo, Puerto Rican on trial for murder in the assassination attempt on President Truman Nov. 1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 The White House has turned the Railway Labor Act into a compulsory arbitration measure, David B. Robertson, president of the Brotherhood of Railroad Firemen and Enginemen, declared today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 The Senate investigation of alleged favoritism in lending operations of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation centered today upon a $9,540 mink coat.

The first American-designed collection ever offered by Callot Soeurs, a French fashion house with a New York branch, has a high degree of flattery and chic. Robert T. Stevenson is the American designer who has invaded the French house, at 42 East Fiftyseventh Street.

PARIS, Feb. 27--Premier Rene Pleven obtained a vote of confidence today on a measure to approve the discussion of the Government bill for the revision of the French electoral system but in such a way as to leave the Government in a hazardous situation.

German exporters of machine tools are offering equipment to Norwegian buyers at prices as low as one-third those of comparable American-made tools, it was disclosed here yesterday in an export statistical study prepared by the National Machine Tool Builders Association, a national trade organization.

LONDON, Wed., Feb. 28 (AP) Lloyd's annual summary of newlylaunched merchant ships, published today, shows 3,492,876 tons of merchant vessels of 100 tons or more were launched last year outside Iron Curtain countries.

WASHINGTON, Feb, 27 (AP) The Department of Agriculture announced today it will not extend price support loans on 1950-crop small grains beyond their original maturity dates. Often in the past, loans have been extended for long periods, particularly when prices were low and surpluses existed.

TRENTON, Feb. 27--Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll sharply disagreed today with the 6-3 decision of the United States Supreme Court invalidating the Wisconsin utility anti-strike law. New Jersey has a similar act.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 The Office of Price Stabilization applied "margin" ceilings today to the sale of more than 200,000 individual items on which Americans spend more than $30,000,000,000 annually. The order, effective today, limits the margin between what a retailer pays for an article and what he may charge his customers.

St. John's and Fordham will clash in an intracity battle at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory and Columbia will make its final home appearance against Brown in tonight's local college basketball attractions.

New arts bring new constitutional problems, and television is no exception. Some interesting issues are raised by the refusal of James J. Carroll, betting commissioner with something of a national reputation, to answer questions while the Senate Crime Investigating Committee hearing in St. Louis was being televised.

Squeezing an Easter bonnet plus an entire spring wardrobe out of a career girl's salary is done with finesse at Hearn's. At a preview of the fashion shows to be held at noon and 6 P.M. tomorrow, the press saw veil-caps for under $1 and straw hats for under $8.

Sixty amateur firefighters, who are among the 6,000 being trained for civil defense in New York fire stations, finished their fourth two-hour practice session with shiny red pumpers, hose wagons and hook and ladder trucks of Combination Company 49 on Welfare Island yesterday afternoon.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 27 Despite disagreement from Frank Capra, Paramount has called off the producer-director's projected religious film, "The Trial," which was to have been based on a story by Virginia Van Upp. The studio announced today that the picture had been abandoned because of the heavy expenditure necessary to produce it.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 27 Unimpeded by the police, thugs shot and killed one La Prensa employe, wounded four others and wrecked five of the newspaper's trucks this afternoon as workers, under what they believed was a guarantee of police protection, sought to go back to work to get out the independent daily for the first time in thirty-two days.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 28 United Nations troops again ground out small tactical gains along the Korean front yesterday, battling mud and stubborn, entrenched Communist rearguards as the allies' new "Operation Killer" offensive completed its first week.

Mayor Impellitteri issued a call yesterday to fifty-five organizations to meet with him on March 13 at City Hall to formulate a continuous and coordinated traffic safety education program in the interest of national defense.
A new manufacturing process that reduces both the cost and time required to make airplane propellers was announced yesterday by the propeller division of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation.

The highest volume of production, sales and earnings in its eighty-year history was achieved in 1950 by the B.F. Goodrich Company, one of the four largest manufacturers of rubber products in the nation.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 27 Capt. Ed Smith poured in 31 points to equal the season's high for Harvard's indoor athletic building as the Crimson basketball team upset Princeton, 64 59, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game tonight.

Floyd G. Layne, 22-year-old basketball star at City College, was taken from the campus at 3 P.M. yesterday by detectives of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's staff. Within an hour he admitted participation in the "point-fixing" of three games at Madison Square Garden this season.
BOSTON, Feb. 27 A 16 per cent increase in the nation's steel capacity by the end of 1953 was predicted today by Frank R. Creedon of the National Production Authority.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 27 The slaying of Benjamin (Bugsy) Siegel here in 1947 stemmed from a Nevada gambling casino row in which a number of New York personalities figured, Police Chief Clinton H. Anderson of Beverly Hills testified today before the Senate Crime Investigating Committee.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Feb. 23 A soup brown as chocolate, thick as a puree of peas, smelling strongly of sour rye bread, came to the table in a cone-shaped bowl with many apologies. The host was 26-year-old Gert Munch, reporter on Politiken, one of this city's nine daily newspapers.
Louis F. Budenz, former managing editor of The Daily Worker, testified in court yesterday that Rockwell Kent, artist, had been a Communist. Mr. Kent denied the charge.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 27 Both Yogi Berra and the Yankees were standing firm today in the salary squabble the catcher is having with the club.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP)--Following is the text of a letter today from Eric Johnston, Economic Stabilization Administrator, to Cyrus S. Ching, chairman of the Wage Stabilization Board, ordering the 10 per cent wage rise formula into effect:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, called on all Americans today to mount guard on the nation's internal security, but warned against "witch hunts."

Bids representing interest costs of 1.6728 per cent and 1.6821 per cent were the best offers received yesterday by Fort Worth, Tex., on issues of $6,800,000 of revenue and general obligation bonds. The high bids, submitted by syndicates...

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27 Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, said here tonight that the free-enterprise system was "a greater deterrent to world conflict and a more dependable guardian of peace than a United Nations organization will ever be."
GREENSBORO, N.C., Feb. 27 (AP) Dr. Henry Louis Smith, who President Wilson declared did more to end World War I than any other, died today at the age of 91.

A "campaign of truth" can sustain the United Nations until the day when by universal consent it becomes powerful enough to maintain the peace, Mrs. Anne O'Hare McCormick, member of the editorial board of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared yesterday.

President Truman and Secretary of Defense George C. Marshall appealed to the American people last night to give generous support to the Red Gross to help it carry the new burdens imposed on it by the national emergency.

Volume on the stock market is usually a good reflection of the degree of public participation. Francis I. du Pont Co., in analyzing the diminishing turnover, notes that "as against the demand for stocks shown just a few weeks ago the present apathy toward equities which exists while they remain near the top may be providing an important signal.

A new issue of $50,000,000 of twenty-five-year bonds of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development will be placed on the market today by a group of thirty-two banking agents headed by Chase National Bank, First Boston Corporation, C.J. Devine Co. and Salomon Brothers Hutzler. The bonds bear 3 per cent interest and are priced at 100. First Boston Corporation is handling the subscription books.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 Herbert Hoover asserted today that the Truman Administration's decision to send four more divisions to Europe was likely to lead to a hopeless land war with Russia and "the massacre" of American boys.

A morning drive in Central Park brought death yesterday to a 55year-old harness maker, when the horse drawing the phaeton in which he and two other men were riding bolted and raced along the West Drive. Morris Yorshis of 6 East Ninety-second Street, Brooklyn, was killed when he fell or jumped from the swaying vehicle, according to the police of the Central Park station.

LONDON, Feb. 27 A member of the Labor Government left London for Argentina today with the obvious intention of bringing back some beef for meat-hungry Britons and thereby relieving his party of a serious political embarrassment.

SOUTH LINCOLN, Mass., Feb. 27 Dr. and Mrs. Barry Bigelow have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Crawford, to Peter Anthony Bator, son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Bator of New York and Nonquit, Mass., formerly of Budapest, Hungary. The wedding will take place in April.

The latest priority rules issued by the National Production Authority make it possible for the first time for almost all industrial organizations to formulate plans for purchasing operating supplies, it is believed here. Leaders in purchasing systems so declared yesterday.

When wages, along with prices, were "frozen" a little over a month ago, it was made clear that this situation was to continue only until the Wage Stabilization Board had reached agreement on a policy for replacing the "freeze" with a more flexible "stabilization" program.
TOKYO, Friday, March 1--United States infantry and marines jumped off this morning in two attacks on the Communist lines on the rain-sodden Korean front.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 28 The Soviet Union yesterday notified the United Nations that it hoped Konstantin E. Zinchenko, former press chief of the Soviet Foreign Office, would be renamed as Assistant Secretary General in charge of Security Council affairs.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 The Interstate Commerce Commission took two steps today to spread out the freight car supply of the country.

Four students at New York University who tried unsuccessfully to be "caught" placing false bets on the Notre Dame-N.Y.U. basketball game at Madison Square Garden on Monday night returned to school with a negative impression of the efficiency of Garden policing methods.

The dearth of good music on the radio airwaves, which in the wake of television's growth has become increasingly pronounced, gave rise yesterday to a new campaign which merits the support of music lovers who want "to do something" about the situation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--The Office of Price Stabilization acted today to correct difficulties in the control of meat prices that have threatened to paralyze slaughtering operations in New York City. Spokesmen for the agency said it would not be "many days" until price ceilings were ordered on livestock.
Bert M. Knighton, who has been handling special projects of the Pepsi-Cola Company for the last year, has been named assistant to the president.
"March comes in like a lion, goes out like a lamb" is but one of eighteen quotations expressing the same sentiments about the capriciousness of this month included in the Home Book of Proverbs.

Another historic debate on the role which the United States should play in a world in which it has grown to a commanding position of leadership has come to an end with the completion of the Senate hearings on the dispatch of additional American troops to Europe.

Luncheon guests in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel were entertained for an hour yesterday by a Saks-34th Street millinery showing. Twenty original French hats and their copies were presented.

The Republic Steel Corporation, third largest member of the steel industry, announced that it will start construction immediately on a new seamless tube mill at its South Chicago Works. Production at the plant, which is to have a capacity of 150,000 tons annually, is scheduled to start in April, 1952.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--Gen. J. Lawton Collins, Chief of Staff of the Army, expressed the opinion to the House Armed Services Committee today that the armed forces of the United States would have to be expanded within six months beyond the combined total of 3,462,000 now contemplated.

The world's most expensive picture, Raphael's "Alba Madonna," which was purchased in 1931 by the late Andrew W. Mellon from the Soviet Government and is now in the National Gallery of Art in Washington, is declared by a recent Soviet publication to be still hanging in the Hermitage Museum in Leningrad.
E.I. du Pont de Nemours, Inc., has embarked on a long-range program for evaluating the comfort of apparel textiles, according to A.E. Buchanan Jr., assistant general manager of the rayon department.

Relationships between the Long Island Rail Road and the Pennsylvania Railroad, which formerly controlled it, were explored here yesterday in cross-examination of Long Island officials at a hearing before the Public Service Commission.

The Georgia-Pacific Plywood and Lumber Company last year achieved the highest sales and earnings in its twenty-four-year history, Owen R. Cheatham, president, informed stockholders in the annual report issued today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--The Senate crime investigating committee reported today that organized criminals operated in interstate commerce to an extent requiring continuous surveillance by some new Federal unit, which it said should have the additional job of coordinating all investigative activities of the national Government.

THE Pulitzer laurelers will do well to choose "His Eye Is on the Sparrow," by Ethel Waters, for their book-of-the-year club. It is already a Book-of-the-Month Club choice for March, and it will not be topped in that field. Miss Waters and Charles Samuels, who put it all down, present a magnificent autobiography, a revelation of squalor and splendor and fortitude and laughter.

The United Corporation, with investments of about $64,000,000, market value in the securities of fourteen utility companies, reported yesterday that its net income of $3,124,941 last year showed a gain profit of $494,950 over the profit of $2,629,991 in 1949.

LONDON, Feb. 28 The Labor Government acknowledged today that another of its projects to produce food from Africa had been a costly failure. After having lost 36,000,000 in a fruitless effort to grow peanuts in East Africa the Government had a sad tale to tell in the House of Commons about its efforts to rear poultry in Gambia colony, West Africa.

New York motorists respond more quickly to emergency and changing traffic conditions than drivers in other parts of the country do, according to results of nine days of safety tests ended here at noon yesterday. Safety exhibits and tests were conducted at the Port Authority Bus Terminal, Eighth Avenue and Forty-first Street; Grand Central
The 1950 annual report of the Graham-Paige Corporation, released to stockholders yesterday, shows a marked improvement in earnings over the previous year.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 John Foster Dulles, special assistant to the Secretary of State, predicted today that a Japanese peace treaty probably would be completed by the middle of this year.

Three top scientists in the development of the atom bomb and Lieut. Gen. Leslie R. Groves, retired wartime head of the bomb project, will testify for the Government in the espionage trial of three persons accused of transmitting atomic secrets to Russia in wartime.
Harry Gross testified yesterday for the second time before the special grand jury investigating organized gambling in Brooklyn and, again, all signs pointed to a talkative witness.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 Up to now confined to a hearing room, the investigation of the recent Maryland Senatorial election boiled over today to the Senate floor where one Republican called for "a halt to this whole silly business."

Two spurts by the Fordham basketball team failed to close sufficient ground and St. John's, speedier and more resourceful, recorded a 73-63 victory over the Rams before 5,000 at the Sixtyninth Regiment Armory last night. It was the twenty-first triumph in twenty-four starts for Frank McGuire's tournament-bound Redmen.
PARIS, Feb. 28--Premier Rene Pleven's Centrist coalition Cabinet broke up today without an adverse vote and the Premier handed the collective resignation of the members to President Vincent Auriol.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 The joint assault of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the New York State Federation of Labor against the Hughes-Brees bill to revise the unemployment insurance law was stepped up today as executive groups of both organizations held separate meetings here today.
VIENNA, Feb. 28 The Hungarian Government announced in Budapest today, that butter-fat, bacon and soap would be added to the list of rationed articles

LONDON, Feb. 28 The new bookkeeping account started on the stock markets here today with a further general rise in prices. The rubber shares were active and strong and most of the other commodity groups were firm.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Feb. 28 Although they have been forced to shoulder the burden of supporting an armed force of more than 600,000 men and although they have virtually abandoned their hope for independence, the natives of Formosa are generally satisfied with the Chinese Nationalist regime.
