The five-story building at 1398 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, containing five stores and fifty apartments, has been sold by the Ammek Realty Corporation to the Raymar Realty Corporation. Pearce, Mayer Greer were the brokers.

Anthony Tudor's ballet "Lady of the Camellias" had the first performance of what should prove to be a lengthy career last night at the City Center, where it was presented by the New York City Ballet, with Diana Adams and Hugh Laing in the central roles.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 Labor called a general walkout of its representatives at all mobilization agencies today. In a blistering attack on Charles E. Wilson, Director of Defense Mobilization, union leaders accused him of allowing "big business" to dominate the defense program.

The twenty-two-story National Association Building at 28 West Forty-fourth Street (running through to 25 West Forty-third Street) was virtually closed down tight for fifteen minutes yesterday as 2,000 employes in 150 concerns staged a civilian defense test against air attack.

Strong optimism for increased business in the drug-products field this year, despite potential shortages and other mobilization problems, was expressed at the opening yesterday of the semi-annual meeting of the Federal Wholesale Druggists Association.
MADRID, Feb. 28 A major black market scandal has been discovered in the Spanish meat syndicate and six important officials are under arrest, a reliable source revealed today.

Supplies of canned tuna that have been increasing steadily for several years reached a recordbreaking 8,500,000 pounds in 1950. Large quantities of this pack still are available; there's so much, in fact, that tuna figures prominently in the Department of Agriculture's list of plentiful foods for March.

New securities offered to the public by underwriters here in February consisted entirely of bonds. Forty-nine issues of bonds with a face value of $467,328,000 were marketed, compared with forty issues for $258,186,000 in the preceding month and fifty issues

Salvatore T. Sollazzo, the key "fixer" in the college basketball scandal, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on income tax fraud charges having nothing to do with his bets on "sure-thing" basketball games. The grand jury accused him of paying a 1944 Federal income tax of $12,356 on a supposed income of $28,740, when he should have paid $223,135 on a real income of $265,633 ...

Adults aren't the only ones concerned over the rising cost of living, judging from what was said yesterday at Junior High School 120, 1832 Madison Avenue. In a city-wide forum arranged by student councils of four boroughs,

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 J. Donald Kingsley, United Nations agent general for Korean reconstruction, just back from his first organizing trip to the Far East, today told the Women's National Press Club that the Korean landscape was the most devastated and its refugees were the most destitute in the history of modern warfare.

The New York House and School of Industry, after 100 years of service to women, is going coeducational. The plan was announced yesterday by Manton B. Metcalf Jr., president of Greenwich House, and Mrs. Francis T.P. Plimpton, president of the school, who said the two organizations were consolidating.

Since the outbreak of the Korean war, foreign countries have increasingly resorted to monetary and credit policy as an instrument of economic and financial control, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York says in its monthly Review, published today.

Plans are being advanced for the April 24 performance of "Make a Wish," starring Nanette Fabray, at the Winter Garden, which has been taken over that night for the benefit of Grosvenor Neighborhood House. Mrs. Lowell Wadmond, cochairman with Mrs. David Granger Jr. of the benefit committee,
Mrs. Ray Wilner Sundelson first woman general agent of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, died yesterday at her home, 444 Central Park West, after a long illness. Her age was 76.
An organization incorporated a year ago to aid war-blinded veterans was enjoined permanently yesterday from soliciting funds in New York State.

The Texas Gulf Sulphur Company, which showed record sales and earnings for 1950, disclosed in its annual report yesterday that maximum shipments to customers during the first quarter of 1951 will be on the basis of 80 per cent of annual maximum tonnage purchasable under terms of contracts.

To the surprise of Broadway, strenuous opposition has developed from the Shuberts, operators of sixteen houses playing stage attractions, to forestall Governor Dewey's approval of a measure to increase the premium on tickets sold by brokers from 75 cents to $1.

Enactment of rent control relaxation as proposed by State Rent Commissioner Joseph D. McGoldrick permitting landlords rent increases up to 15 per cent will bring on an "almost unmanageable" boom in apartment house refrigerators.

In the collection of exclusive ready-to-wear designs that Jay Thorpe exhibited yesterday emphasis on detail marked every cos tume, from the slim white ribbon knit with flag ornamentation that opened the showing to the lacetreated evening gown that closed it.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 28 Yogi Berra's salary siege with the Yankees ended today. The husky catcher from St. Louis' hill district, a week overdue in camp, closed one of the most stubborn contract squabbles of recent years by accepting a compromise agreement that will make

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 The Investors Syndicate of America, Inc., of Minneapolis, today applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission here for permission to register $306,000,000 of certificates. The organization sought registration of $22,000,000 of Series 10, $106,000,000 of Series 15, and $178,000,000 of Series 20 certificates.

ALBANY, Feb. 28?Except for a rise in the sales tax, all proposals to increase New York City's local taxing powers are dead, Senator Walter J. Mahoney, chairman of the Republican-controlled Finance Committee, said today.

The Eastern Golden Gloves championships were held at Madison Square Garden last night before 6,457 amateur boxing fans. This annual fixture, presented by the News Welfare Association, brought together the survivors of the various tournaments conducted in several sections of the East and in Puerto Rico.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 President Truman issued today an executive order defining the responsibilities of various government departments relating to domestic transportation, shipping and ship construction and air transportation in the mobilization program.

Julius Katchen, who played the piano at Town Hall last night, has just come back to this country after a two-year swing through Europe and the Near East. From all reports he made a big impression abroad, and was assigned to do recordings by one of the major British companies.

ROME, Feb. 28 (UP)--A lieutenant of Charles (Lucky) Luciano tonight branded as "plain bunk" the United States Senate Crime Investigating Committee's charge that Luciano umpired American underworld disputes.

Electoral reform seems a trivial reason for a French political crisis at a time when the Government needs to brace itself to carry through economic and military measures vitally important to the defense of the country.

FRANKFORT, Germany, Feb. 28--The Bundestag fulfilled today the Western Allies' request for legislation giving the displaced persons remaining in West Germany equal rights with the Germans in law, education, employment, social benefits, and freedom of movement.

BERLIN, Feb. 28 Leaders of the Public Service Trade Unions warned the West Berlin Administration tonight that a public service strike would be called Sunday unless their wage demands, rejected yesterday, were met.

BOSTON, Feb. 28 Funds have been made available for $2,400,000,000 in Army and Air Force construction through the 1951 fiscal year, Maj. Gen. Lewis A. Pick today told the thirty second annual convention of the Associated General Contractors of America.

The Fireman's Fund Insurance Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday the highest net premium writings in the history of the organization during 1950. They amounted to $119,936,000, compared with $117,232,000 in 1949. Consolidated net earnings, after

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange was on a smaller scale last month and although the total, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, dropped to 41,233,877 shares, compared with 70,180,730 shares in January it was the largest for a corresponding month in fourteen years, or since 1937.

Prices of commodity futures on the local exchanges were irregular yesterday in light trading. World sugar futures advanced, while the domestic contract declined. Lead advanced, but copper and tin moved into lower territory.

the holiday season, nor in the month or so following when there were still Christmas books to be read. Any one of these next few week-ends is as good a time as another for dusting the books. Naturally it could not be done during...
"In many ways a philanthropist foundation resembles an investment trust," says the New York Foundation in introducing a report which commemorates the fortieth year of its activity.
CHICAGO, Feb. 28 The United States must export goods, not dolars, to pay for imports needed in defense production, business men attending the annual World Trade Conference were told today.

The New York Foundation observed a milestone in its history of philanthropy yesterday with the issuance of a special forty-year report that showed it expended nearly $8,000,000 from 1910 through 1949 in the fields of medical science, social welfare and education.

A method that has made it possible for the first time to measure the mechanical efficiency of the human heart was described yesterday in a report before the New York Heart Association at the New York Academy of Medicine.

Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of City College since 1941, will retire next year upon reaching the compulsory retirement age, the Board of Higher Education announced yesterday. Dr. Wright will be 70 years old on Oct. 3 of this year and will officially retire on Aug. 31, 1952, upon the completion of the academic year.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 28 The employes of La Prensa, who were fired upon yesterday when they entered the newspaper's printing plant and who spent the night in a police station having their documents of identity "examined," were making tentative plans today to try to go back to work tomorrow.
LONDON, Feb. 28 Denmark, which provides Britain's breakfast most mornings, sent two ministers to London today to tell the British that she wants more goods and money for her butter, bacon and eggs.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Feb. 28-- Frank Erickson, New York bookmaker now serving a prison sentence, was indicted here today by a special Bergen County grand jury, charged with operating a widespread telephone-betting network.

VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 28 With nine more players checking in today the Dodger camp will burst into full activity tomorrow, but the athletes still will be minus the direction of their new manager, Chuck Dressen. Chuck's con dition has improved, but he remains hospitalized and his coaches, Cookie Lavagetto, Clyde Sukforth

ALBANY, Feb. 28 The Public Service Commission today authorized the Bee Line, Inc., which operates buses in Queens and Nassau Counties, to increase its fares for travel in more than two zones. The increases, which become effective tomorrow, vary from 2 to 4 cents.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 A group of nine organizations, representing shippers and shipbuilders, maritime labor and veterans, called upon President Truman today to oppose any "unwarranted expansion" of the Japanese shipping and shipbuilding industries.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 28 Champion 2-year-olds of the Hialeah meeting are the Marlboro Stud Farm's Jet Master and Mrs. Laura Birr's Blue Revoke. Today, in sprints over the three-furlong nursery course, they won the two divisions of the $10,000 added

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)-- The Senate Crime Committee said today the check cashier for "the mob" operating gambling casinos in northern New Jersey cashed checks totaling $5,000,000 in about six months.
An IND subway train in Brooklyn yesterday passed several feet over a man and a woman who had fallen to the tracks, but apparently hurt neither of them seriously.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--Gen. Lucius D. Clay, retired, told Congress today that within a year Europe could be made so strong that the world's peace would be reasonably safe.

WITH UNITED STATES MARINES, Korea, Feb. 28 General Mud has taken over the command in Korea, but for the chocolatestained, boot-squishing G.I. there is one big consolation, the Chinese Communist soldiers are even more mud-suffering.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 Permanent personal registration became a party issue today, as a New York City Democratic leader announced his support of the system and the State Republican Chairman said that his party's Executive Committee opposed it.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 General liquidation developed in grain markets in the early trading on the board of trade today with November and January soybeans breaking the permissible limit of 10 cents and showing little rallying power.

Talks toward settlement of the twelve-day woolen and worsted strike were being arranged last night after an exchange of telegrams between the American Woolen Company and the Textile Workers Union of America, C.I.O.

RARITAN TOWNSHIP, N. J., Feb. 28 A 25-year-old convict, being taken to state prison by auto this afternoon, slipped off a pair of handcuffs and then, using a home-made knife, stabbed a prison guard to death and slashed another during an attempted escape.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 28 (Reuters) Premier Marshal Tito said today that Yugoslavia would have "no special difficulty" in resisting a combined attack by the Soviet satellites on her borders, but that if they were joined by Russian "volunteers" it would be "another thing."
The most shocking revelation of the testimony before us is the extent of official corruption and connivance in facilitating and promoting organized crime.

Grants totaling $1,275,000 were made to the Social Science Research Council in the last twelve months to advance the development of personnel, methods and theories by which the social sciences "are to meet the multitude of demands being made from day to day," Pendleton Herring, council president, said in his annual report yesterday.

MOSCOW, Feb. 28 General price reductions of 10 and 15 per cent on food products, 20 per cent on furniture and china and 10 and 20 per cent on building materials and hardware were announced tonight by the Council of Ministers and the Central Committee of the Communist party.

The nation's gasoline stocks rose 2,272,000 barrels last week to a new peak of 136,870,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The previous high was on April 1, 1950, when they amounted to 135,586,000 barrels. On Feb. 25, last year, gasoline stocks were 133,888,000 barrels.
The State of California announced yesterday that it will take bids on April 4 on an issue of $50000,000 of school bonds. Dated May 1, 1951, the bonds will come due from 1953 to 1977.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) Farm product prices rose 4.29 per cent between mid-January and mid-February to a new record level, the Department of Agriculture reported today. The new price level is about 2 per cent above the previous record set in January of 1948.

LAHORE, Pakistan, Feb. 28--A motion by the Soviet Union to bar the Chinese Nationalist delegation from a conference of the United Nations Economic Commission on Asia and the Far East was defeated 8 to 5 at the opening session today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 An Amendment to the Constitution, a comparatively rare event in American history, can be the product of a national organization with great power in most of the states or of widespread public pressure strong enough to prevail despite the fact that it is unorganized.

Calls for emergency medical assistance made to operators of the New York Telephone Company will be connected directly with TRafalgar 9-1000, the Manhattan number of the Doctors Emergency Service of the New York County Medical Society, under an arrangement to go into effect today.

In Korea Wednesday, the attrition being wrought on Chinese Communist and North Korean forces by United Nations troops continued as assaults were mounted against enemy positions, despite overflowing streams and adverse weather conditions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve System announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended on Feb. 21:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) The Federal Reserve Board reported today that industrial production in February was down "slightly" from the post-war record level of January. The agency blamed the decline chiefly on the railroad and woolen mill strikes.
Henry W. (Harry) Armstrong, composer of the music of "Sweet Adeline," died yesterday in his home, 3942 Secor Avenue, the Bronx, after a long illness. His age was 71.

An investor has purchased from the Evelyn Holding Corporation the twelve-story apartment house on plot 63 by 102 feet at 68-70 East Eighty-sixth Street in a deal negotiated by Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers. Fully rented and containing thirty apartments, the house

Setting a new record for the court in its final home game, Columbia's high-riding basketball team defeated Brown, 93 55, last night for its twentieth consecutive victory of the season and its twenty-ninth since it last was beaten.

Unit and dollar sales of the American Tobacco Company, Inc., last year were higher than in 1949, but earnings declined as a result of higher tax rates, Paul M. Hahn, president, explained in the annual report to be issued to stockholders today.

LONDON, Feb. 28 From an official source, it was learned today that Britain had never proposed a British admiral for the supreme North Atlantic Treaty Organization command in the Atlantic. In fact, the Admiralty advised the British Government representatives to urge the appointment of an American.

The stock market floundered yesterday until the final hour when a faint buying movement lifted prices out of the doldrums. Public participation was still small and large operators, such as investment trusts and pension funds, showed little interest in the day's proceedings.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UP) The National Labor Relations Board today found a New York newspaper deliverers' union guilty of unfair labor practices and ordered it to make up any loss of pay fourteen nonunion men might have suffered because of discrimination against them, together with all state and Federal Social Security benefits.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 28 Executing a flanking movement that quickly enveloped the town from all sides, the Giants today took over the Sunshine City, long the spring training base of the world champion Yankees, and in no time at all made themselves at home in their new surroundings.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 28 (AP) Rafael Fortun of Cuba and Jaime Aparicio of Colombia, ran North American favorites into the ground today to upset the United States' hopes of dominating track events in the Pan-American Games.

ANGLERS and hunters like to plan their field excursions well in advance, possibly because of the delights of anticipation, and right now the major interest seems to be directed toward the outer banks of North Carolina, where the channel bass is king and the bluefish threatens his crown.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 28 Edward G. Miller Jr., United States Assistant Secretary of State, who is here for the inauguration of Uruguayan President Andres Martinez Trueba tomorrow, expressed deep concern this evening over the news from Buenos Aires of the attack on La Prensa workers.

An amendment to the State Defense Emergency Act is being prepared so that apprenticeship standards of training in New York State can be relaxed in the interest of national defense, the State Department of Labor reported yesterday.

City Councilman Stanley M. Isaacs, Manhattan RepublicanLiberal, announced yesterday that he would introduce in the Council tomorrow proposed local laws requiring city firemen to give thirty days' advance notice of intention to retire on pensions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 Government efforts to mediate the wage dispute between management and 1,000,000 nonoperating railroad employes were on the verge of collapse tonight after a long White House conference.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28--Senate investigation of how Mrs. Lauretta Young, a White House stenographer, got her $9,540 mink coat last September received the silent treatment at the Executive Office today.

Mayor Impellitteri issued a proclamation yesterday designating March as Red Cross Month and uring New Yorkers to oversubscribe the $6,500,000 quota that has been set for them in the organization's 1951 drive for $85,000,000.
The recently opened George S. Kaufman and Leueen MacGrath play, "The Small Hours," will terminate its Broadway engagement at the National Theatre after Saturday night's performance, the ...

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 A drive to limit the regular income tax rate on corporations to 50 per cent was taken to Congress today by representatives of separate business organizations testifying before the House Ways and Means Committee.

We are glad to note that both the Mayor and the Police Commissioner take cognizance on the same day of the necessity of doing something about the traffic accident and congestion problems, which go hand in hand.

Herman Chopak, president for twelve years and one of the founders of the Textile Distributors Institute, Inc., 469 Seventh Avenue, died Tuesday while on a vacation trip to Phoenix, Ariz. He was 58 years old.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 Col. Gerard W. Kelley, who commanded the Fighting Sixty-ninth through three Pacific Island invasions in World War II, has been promoted to brigadier general and made chief of staff of the New York National Guard.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb., 28 Mayor Bernard Samuel joined other city officials and shipping men today in protesting vehemently against seizure by the Marine Corps of Philadelphia's new $6,000,000 municipal pier.

The 135-man corps of the custodian's department of the Amer ican Museum of Natural History has come to a time of the year at which housekeepers the world over find themselves when a light dusting won't do any longer; the place needs a good turning-out.
The United Labor Policy Committee decided unanimously today that all labor representatives of our respective organizations serving on existing defense mobilization agencies shall resign immediately.
A newcomer to this country who had been keeping his savings in a little black box he found attached to a wall in his apartment decided yesterday that using a bank would be simpler in the long run.
PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 28 "An Evening in Paris" will be the theme of Princeton University's annual junior promenade, which will be held tomorrow evening in the Herbert Lowell Dillon Gymnasium.

The suppression of the great Argentine liberal newspaper, La Prensa, followed by the killing and wounding of its loyal employes on Tuesday, is one of the most outrageous events in recent hemispheric history.

EASTBOURNE, England, March 1--As a consequence of rearmament, and the shortage and high cost of raw materials, a recession in Britain's overseas trade in 1951 and an increase in the country's dollar deficit were forecast here tonight by Hugh Gaitskell, Chancellor of the Exchequer.

The board of directors of the Panama Railroad Company has been urged to make a thorough study of the operation of the Panama Line on the ground that the income of the steamship service is consistently decreasing and that the service may soon cease to be self-sustaining.

WASHINGTON, March 1 Carl G. Strandlund, president of the Lustron prefabricated housing enterprise at Columbus, Ohio, which went bankrupt after borrowing $37,500,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, swore ...
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 1 The Netherlands Government has agreed tentatively that the standing Dutch units should be places at the disposal of General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower.

Reporting on operations of the P. Lorillard Company for 1950, the annual statement of Herbert A. Kent, president, discloses that the tobacco firm plans to raise about $20,000,000 through the sale of debentures and common stock.

Net premuim writings of the Hanover Fire Insurance Company increased more than $2,000,000 in 1950, aggregating $22,688,427, against $20,660,327 in 1949, F. Elmer Sammons, president, reported yesterday.

TOKYO, Friday, March 2 United Nations forces struck hard yesterday at the Chinese and North Korean lines all along the Korean front in the heaviest fighting of this week and punched out gains of up to four miles in some sectors.

WASHINGTON, March 1 President Truman today requested Congress to provide $1,732,859,274 in supplemental appropriations and borrowing authority, the great bulk of it to be used to expand defense production and to operate the national civil defense system.

LONDON, March 1 Aggression from within in the form of a possible Communist uprising in Iran has Britain worried. The possibility has been discussed privately for some time. So has the question of what the West should do if there is no direct evidence of Soviet intervention.

Aaron Feld, a recently retired patrolman, was accused yesterday in Kings County Court of accepting $350 from one of Harry Gross' runners to overlook the man's bookmaking activities in the midtown garment area.
Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, C.I.O., got a green light yesterday from his international executive board to go ahead with plans to organize New York's policemen.
WASHINGTON, March 1 President Truman said in a message read tonight to the fourth annual Conference on Civil Liberties that he would continue to urge his civil rights program with all vigor.

PARIS, March 1 Former Premier Georges Bidault, chairman of the Popular Republican party, which was the first group to resign in the Pleven Cabinet split upon the proposed electoral law, was asked today by President Vincent Auriol to attempt to form a new French Government.

The marriage of Baroness SonjaMaria von Etthofen, daughter of Baroness Brigitte von EtthofenRavene of Gumden, Austria, and Baron Eduard-Karl von Etthofen of Schloss Strelzhof, Austria, to Berwick Bruce Lanier Jr., son of Mrs. Thorne Lanier of 200 East ...

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 1 "Country Girl," Clifford Odets' current Broadway play about the theatre, has been bought for the screen by Paramount at a price reportedly in the neighborhood of $150,000, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (UP) Illegal traffic in narcotics continued at a stepped-up rate in 1950 with peddlers even stooping to giving teen-agers free "shots" to start them on the road to addiction, the Federal Narcotics Bureau reported today.

The suite that Busoni made from orchestral parts of Mozart's little-known opera "Idomeneo" opened the program that Dimitri Mitropoulos gave with the Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra Society last night in Carnegie Hall.
In times of disaster and emergency one of the first organizations to turn out with money, supplies and trained personnel to aid those affected is the American Red Cross.

BUENOS AIRES, March 1 (AP) United States track and field forces scored a sweep of the 800meter run, finished 1 2 in the discus and won the pole vault easily today in the greatest single show of might of the Pan-American Games.
WASHINGTON, March 1 Turkey has invited the United States to consider associating itself with the British-French-Turkish treaty of mutual assistance.

THERE is time for just one more warm-up pitch and then we can leave the bullpen for the game itself, a look at ball players in the flesh instead of in print. So this Floridabound tourist will take a last fling by skimming through the Red Book, the statistical press information brochure that Earl Hilligan has assembled for the American League. It makes fascinating reading.

Chicago Sanitary District sold yesterday $9,900,000 of corporate purpose warrants payable out of 1951 tax collections. Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and associates bought the issue at 1 per cent interest ` plus $6,197.

The National Production Authority is making every effort to help small business which have been affected by shortages of basic supplies which have been funneled off to defense production, according to Bernard Fields, assistant general counsel of the agency.

Selected with great discrimination, the Rosette Pennington showing at the Plaza Hotel brought to its audience some of the best of American ready-made quality fashions yesterday. Represented were such designing houses as Trains-Norell, Ben Reig, Pattullo, Trigere and others.
WASHINGTON, March 1 President Truman said at his news conference today that Congressional debate might not help this country's relations with the rest of the world.

While sales of drug products since the first of this year indicate that despite some leveling off after price control started, waves of illness in many parts of the country have accelerated buying, an industry group meeting heard yesterday at the Statler Hotel.
Bob Murphy, the southpaw sailor from San Diego, Calif., and Harry Matthews of Seattle will meet in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight.
A work stoppage by drivers on nine Bronx bus lines of the Surface Transportation Corporation deprived thousands of passengers yesterday of service during the morning rush hour.

The good wishes of the entire American people will be extended to Uruguay, whose new President, Andres Martinez Trueba, was inaugurated yesterday. Uruguay is an example of Western democracy at its best; it has every important feature of democracy and it has political stability to boot.

ALBANY, March 1 Mayor Impellitteri's political fight with Carmine DeSapio, leader of Tammany Hall, and his treatment of James A. Roe, Queens Democratic leader, is jeopardizing chances for obtaining legislative approval of a rise in New York City's sales tax.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) Following is the text of a letter from President Truman to E. Raymond Wilson, chairman of the National Civil Liberties Clearing House:

NEW DELHI, India, March 1 Virtual Communist rule in defiance of the Government in parts of India's northeastern state of Assam, on the borders of Tibet, China and Burma, is reported in firsthand accounts from the state where police are now engaged in an intensive comb-out of terrorist nests.

A down-to-the-wire battle for the team title between Yale's defending squad and Army, 1948-49 winner, shapes up in the fourth annual Heptagonal indoor track and field championships, which will be decided at the Third Engineer Group Armory tonight after a matinee field event session at New Haven.

CHICAGO, March 1 General liquidation continued in grains and soybeans on the Board of Trade today with December wheat, corn and oats and November and January soybeans selling at new lows for the season, December corn at the inside being 4 cents a bushel under the anticipated Government loan, Chicago basis, on the 1951 crop.

Criticism of the court martial procedure for both white and Negro servicemen in the Far East was voiced yesterday by Thurgood Marshall, special counsel for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, at its headquarters at 20 West Fortieth Street.

MORRISVILLE, Pa., March 1--Construction of the United States Steel Corporation's $400,000,000 Fairless Works, the largest steel expansion project in the nation's history, began officially... cially at 2:32 P.M. today on a 3,800-acre site two miles south of here.

A group of artists and sculptors have unwittingly supplied the inspiration for a collection of china and porcelain lamps now on view at McCreery's. The designs have been taken from paintings and pieces of sculpture, reproductions of which are displayed with the lamps.

BONN, Germany, March 1--The North Atlantic powers are expected to have thirteen full divisions and six brigades of troops in Germany by late summer, when conditions will be most favorable to a Soviet attack in Western Europe.

Early last evening the Board of Estimate, after a long day of public hearings and in a defiant mood, disapproved the controversial $16,600,000 state-aided low-rent La Guardia Houses for lower Manhattan. A crowd of more than 200 opponents of the project cheered and shouted its approval.

The Board of Education voted unanimously yesterday to ask the city and state for $7,100,000 to provide an average of $780 in salary increases for its 32,000 regular teachers, effective April 1, and $28,400,000 to continue the rises in the 1951-52 budget.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (UP) A former official of an Indiana aeronautical "school" admitted today that he bought airplane engines from the Government for "educational purposes" for $10 each and sold them for an average of more than $1,300 apiece.

The building on lot 27 by 100 feet at 144 West Ninety-first Street has been sold by the estate of Mattie Demers to M.C. Berg, operator, in a deal negotiated by Earle Calhoun--Slawson Hobbs, brokers, who also arranged a new first mortgage loan of $30,000. Assessed at $48,000, the house was remodeled in 1940 into twenty apartments.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 1 (AP)--Jim Ferrier toured the Pasadena course in seven under par 64 today for the first-round lead in the $10,000 St. Petersburg open tournament.

MADRID, March 1--Cheered by crowds in the streets, Stanton Griffis rode in a gilded state coach to the Royal Palace here at noon today and presented his credentials to Generalissimo Francisco Franco as the United States Ambassador to Spain.
ALBANY, March 1 (AP)--The State University announced today adoption of a program to help overcome the shortage of elementary school teachers.
A tall, broad-shouldered Yankee, his bronzed complexion reflecting half a century of life under sail and steam, disclosed yesterday his desire to spend his remaining days on the beach.
WASHINGTON, March 1 Plans to speed the production of a new all-jet heavy bomber and to add a jet version of the B-36 to the weapons of the Strategic Air Command were disclosed today.

MOSCOW, March 1 In a brief, businesslike note of less than 100 words, the Soviet Union today agreed to a meeting of the deputies in Paris March 5 to draft an agenda for the proposed session of the foreign ministers.
WASHINGTON, March 1--The old dispute over taxation of cooperatives was revived today before the House Ways and Means Committee as witnesses presented opposing views on the question.

CAIRO, March 1 (AP) Emir Abd el Krim, leader of the bloody Riff revolt against France and Spain in the early Twenties, sent messages to all Arab capitals today demanding united Arab action for Moroccan independence from France.

CHICAGO, March 1--The television committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tomorrow will view a demonstration of phonevision for possible application to collegiate athletics, principally football.

WASHINGTON, March 1 The manager of John M. Butler's victorious Senate campaign in Maryland last fall conceded under oath today that certain contributions of large amounts had been spent without having been cleared through the campaign treasurer.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., March 1 School and village leaders reported today at Pleasantville's third annual community institute that they finally have a formula for obtaining adequate funds from taxpayers for improvement of the three public schools.

In the allocation of available materials and manpower, the railroads should be held just as vital to defense as plants producing arms, William T. Faricy, president of the Association of American Railroads, said yesterday.

Unless a last-minute hitch occurs, representatives of the United States, Britain, France and Soviet Russia will sit down together in the "Pink Palace" in Paris beginning Monday to examine whether they can agree on a mutually acceptable program for a new conference of the Big Four Foreign Ministers.
TODAY at 4 P.M. three folk tales, "The Flea," "The Frog" and "Three Fridays," will be told to boys and girls at the New York Public Library's Columbus Branch, 742 Tenth Avenue.
LONDON, March 1 Out of semi-retirement, enforced on him by illness, Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin appeared tonight before his constituents to declare that reports of his resignation were premature.

Federal authorities spent several hours yesterday in the offices of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan, going over the books of two jewelry concerns of which Salvatore T. Sollazzo, basketball "fixer," is believed to be the principal owner. The books were seized by Mr. Hogan a week ago.

Asked to comment on the "rebellion" of top union leaders against the administration of Charles E. Wilson, director of the Office of Defense Mobilization, President Truman assured news men yesterday that he had complete confidence in his mobilization chief.

The Army has agreed to rent from the city three additional Staten Island piers and 591,000 square feet of adjoining upland at an annual rental of $310,000. These berths, Piers 10, 13 and 14, will be operated in conjunction with Piers 11 and 12, which have been under lease to the Port of Embarkation since 1942.

ALBANY, March 1 Vigorous opposition to the New York Telephone Company's application for rate increases totaling $44,000,000 was registered by the Federal and New York City administrations today as the Public Service Commission opened its hearings.

BUENOS AIRES, March 1 The Time correspondent here, Frank Shea, and Life photographer, Leonard McCombe, were released today a few minutes past noon, after having been in police custody for almost thirty-six hours.

WASHINGTON, March 1 Erie Johnston, Economic Stabilization Administrator, modified the Government wage policy today to permit cost-of-living increases under "escalator" clauses signed before Jan. 25, the date of the wage freeze. The 10 per cent ceiling on general wage increases will not be a bar.

WASHINGTON, March 1 Oscar Collazo, Puerto Rican nationalist on trial for murder, admitted on the witness stand today that he had participated in the Nov. 1 shooting in front of Blair House but denied he had intended to kill President Truman, who was inside at the time.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 1 The Yugoslav Government has abolished controls over a wide variety of agricultural products and has ordered the restoration of free trading in these products on the basis of supply and demand.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) Following is the text of the revised wage stabilization regulation under which cost-of-living escalator clauses will be permitted:

WASHINGTON, March 1 George C. Marshall, Secretary of Defense, urged the House Armed Services Committee today to amend its bill so that men could be drafted at 18 instead of 18 years of age, as it now would provide.

ROME, March 1 Premier Alcide de Gasperi was confronted by a revolt of some of his own followers today, when a minor Government-sponsored bill squeezed through the Chamber of Deputies by a margin of only 253 votes to 237. Signor de Gasperi, feeling that he no longer enjoys his party's undidvided support, wished to resign immediately.

PHOEHIX, Ariz., March 1 The echo of long hits bouncing off distant fences and the spectacle of drives disappearing over the wall characterized the first day's workout for Casey Stengel's Yankee regulars today and brought a familiar atmosphere that had been missing.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) Industrial expansion in the Pacific Northwest got a hand from Secretary of the Interior Oscar L. Chapman today. He said he was prepared to approve plans for a new plant of the Aluminum Company of America in the Wenatchee, Wash., area.

WASHINGTON, March 1 President Truman paid a surprise visit to the Senate today to honor Vice President Alben W. Barkley, who will complete thirty-eight years of continuous service in Congress on Sunday.

Protests against threats of eviction and appeals for protection against higher rents have begun to pour into the offices of the Temporary State Housing Rent Commission from tenants who apparently have been thrown into confusion over the new controls effective on March 15.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 1 Lester De Witt Mallory, United States Minister and charge d'affaires in Buenos Aires, flew here today in an Embassy plane to give Assistant Secretary of State Miller a briefing on events in the Argentine capital relating to the closing of La Prensa.

Further progress, though small, was made yesterday by the stock market. Interest remained unimpressive, however, and gains generally held within a fractional range. The settlement of the wage controversy in the rail industry brought out some bidding for the ...

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 1 The Bundestag today overwhelmingly rejected the Justice Ministry's recommendation that the parliamentary immunity of Com munist party leader Max Reimann be restored and that legal proceedings against him be dropped.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 1 Andres Martinez Trueba today succeeded Luis Batlle Berres as President of Uruguay. The former head of the Central Bank took the oath before a joint session of Congress shortly before 4 P.M. Alfeo Brum was sworn in as Vice President a few minutes later. Both men will serve four years.

The RCA-Victor division of the Radio Corporation of America will reduce production of higher price television receivers beginning April 1, a company spokesman reported yesterday. He declined to disclose the extent of the cutback.

Grace of motion was the outstanding characteristic of the spring and summer custom-made collection that Bergdorf Goodman presented yesterday. There wasn't a rigid line or silhouette in the costumes created for all hours of the day.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 1 Governor John Davis Lodge appointed today a five-member committee to study "community adjustment problems" that might arise from the proposed construction of a $250,000,000 steel mill in the New London area.
WASHINGTON, March 1 C. Powell Minnigerode, director emeritus of the Corcoran Gallery of Art, died today at his home after a long illness. He was 74 years old.

BOSTON, March 1 A resolution adopted today by the thirtysecond annual convention of the Associated General Contractors of America, Inc., asked modification or delay in the Government order prohibiting further use of certain copper, brass and aluminum products in construction.

The Chrysler Corporation and its wherry-owned United States subsidiaries in 1950 established a new high in unit and dollar sales, but an increase of $42,000,000 in taxes reduced earnings from 1949 by $4,293,305.

MIAMI, Fla., March 1 Ode, owned by Mrs. Ivar Bryce's Mill River Stable, got the money in Hialeah's main event today after having finished in third place back of Gustave Ring's 4-5 entry of Jam Session and Lone Eagle.

In response to frantic complaints by victims of rheumatoid arthritis, rheumatic fever and several other serious diseases that it had become practically impossible to obtain cortisone for the relief of their suffering, Merck Co., sole producer of the vital chemical, ...
A light snowfall that started at 6:40 A.M. yesterday ended a twoday preview of spring. In most of the city, the snow melted as soon as it hit the ground.

With Seton Hall's acceptance yesterday, the field for the fourteenth annual national invitation basketball tournament was increased to eight teams. Four berths remain to be filled in the post-season fixture, which will get under way at Madison Square Garden a week from tomorrow.

CHICAGO, March 1 Carrol M. Shanks, president of the Prudential Life Insurance Company of America, formally announced here today the company's plan for a new thirty five story office building in Chicago. Cost of the project was estimated at $30,000,000.

A frightening picture of an underworld government, dominated by two major crime syndicates, and deported Lucky Luciano as absentee arbiter ruling from Italy, with all this and more waiting for an occasion to become the basis of a subversive movement capable of wrecking the nation, is drawn by the Senate Crime Investigating Committee in an interim report.

NEWARK, March 1 A temporary increase from 5 to 7 cents a zone in bus and trolley fares of the Public Service Coordinated Transport and the Public Service Interstate Transportation Company was authorized today by the Board of Public Utility Commissioners.

CHICAGO, March 1 The American Library Association's division of public libraries issued today its annual list of notable books of 1950. The forty titles selected are considered "genuinely meritorious in terms of literary excellence, factual correctness, sincerity and honesty of presentation and value and interest to readers."

LAHORE, Pakistan, March 1 A Soviet motion to exclude the South Korean and Vietnamese delegations from the United Nations Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East was voted out of order today as the commission's seventh conference went into its second day.

WASHINGTON, March 1 Three days of argument before the Interstate Commerce Commission on the railroads' petition for a 6 per cent freight rate increase ended today with a railroad security owner opposing the increase, and with the railroads announcing that ...
Despite a $7,875,000 larger tax bill, the International Business Machines Corporation last year turned in the highest earnings in its 39-year history.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 1 India told the United Nations Security Council today that she could make no more concessions in her dispute with Pakistan on Kashmir and turned down a new United States-British plan for mediation.
DALLAS, March 1 (UP) The co-pilot of a twin-engined airliner fell 4,000 feet to his death through a rear door of the plane today while twenty passengers slept.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 1 Mrs. John A. McCreery of Quiet Waters, Greenwich, and Nantucket, Mass., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Lalande, to John W. Keeshan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred G. Keeshan of Newtown.

Commuters on three divisions of the New York Central lines who were prevented from using their tickets during the "sick" strike of switchmen over the week-end of Feb. 2 to 6 will be entitled to collect cash refunds for their loss next Monday.

TRENTON, March 1 Clifford T. Shephard, 65-year-old resident of Irvington, N.J., who last June 14 received a full pardon from Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll after a fifteen-year fight to establish his innocence, will receive a minimum ...

EACH year the opening of the trout season, an event of traditional if not piscatorial importance, finds a lot of anglers with tackle in such bad condition that the big day has been robbed of much of its pleasure.

ALBANY, March 1 The Senate prepared today to vote Monday night on a controversial Republican bill to repeal the exemption from jury duty now available to any woman in the state who wishes not to serve.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) Following is the text of a White House statement today on President Truman's request for additional defense appropriations:
