SALT LAKE CITY, March 1 To curb the mounting costs of education, Gov. J. Bracken Lee vetoed today a legislative appropriation of $21,600,000 that would have allotted to the state's public schools $3,600 a year for each classroom unit. The budget for the last two years had allocated $3,300 for each unit.

Plans for a taxpayer on the plot 128 by 180 feet at the southeast corner of Main Street and Maple Avenue in Flushing, Queens, were disclosed in connection with the announcement of the purchase of the property by Henry A. Lanzner from F. Chauncey Whittelsey. The Halleran Agency and Milton Gunsberg were the brokers.

LONDON, March 1 The British do not really expect the Paris talks with the Soviet Union to lead directly to any settlement of differences between the East and West. Still they are glad these preliminary discussions are to be held.
TOKYO, Friday, March 2 (AP) Communique 810, issued by General of the Army MacArthur's Headquarters at 10 A.M., Friday (8 P.M., Thursday, Eastern standard time):
In a small town upstate the Friends of Music, as they call themselves, played a concert the other night.

WASHINGTON, March 1 With strong backing from the Economic Cooperation Administration, the European Marshall Plan Council has demanded representation on the Central Commodity Group being formed by the United States, Britain and France to end the "commodity scramble" that has inflated prices for scarce materials.

Although he has received aid from many different sources since his church was destroyed in a spectacular fire seven weeks ago, the Rev. Francis Del Vecchio was happiest about a check for $2,000 he received yesterday

PARIS, March 1 In a report accusing the Western German Government of "lack of diligence" in living up to its agreement to balance its trade, the managing board of the European Payments Union has told the Bonn regime that it will grant no further credits to cover Western Germany's deficit.

Leiser Weitman, 31-year-old Austrian, pleaded guilty yesterday before Judge Mortimer W. Byers in Brooklyn Federal Court to two counts in a three-count indictment charging him with smuggling $744,800 worth of high-quality diamonds into the country.

WASHINGTON, March 1 Manufacturers of new passenger cars will be permitted to raise their list prices by 3 per cent above Dec. 1, 1950, levels under a regulation issued tonight by the Office of Price Stabilization, effective tomorrow. Dealers will be permitted ...
Expanded training facilities for reserve officers and enlisted men and women are now operating in the New York metropolitan area.

PHILADELPHIA, March 1 The Philadelphia Fellowship Commission at a dinner tonight presented its 1951 awards to four men whose "artistic achievements have resulted in the improvement of intergroup understanding." Those honored were:

Miss M. Helena Zachos, Ph. D., who taught elocution, oratory and debating at Cooper Union from 1897 until her retirement in 1939, died Wednesday in her apartment in the Sevillia Hotel, 117 West Fifty-eighth Street, after a long illness. She would have been 95 years old next Monday.
John Morris Perry, senior member of the law firm of Rathbone, Perry, Kelley Drye, 70 Broadway, died yesterday or a heart attack in his apartment at 300 Park Avenue. His age was 84.
HONG KONG, March 1 Nineteen persons have been arrested in Tientsin on charges of espionage "under the camouflage of the Catholic Church" Ta Kung Pao reported here today.
WASHINGTON, March 1 In the week ended on Feb. 28, member bank reserves increased $132,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

PHILADELPHIA, March 1 The Philadelphia Fellowship Commission at a dinner tonight presented its 1951 awards to four men whose "artistic achievements have resulted in the improvement of intergroup understanding." Those honored were:

Miss M. Helena Zachos, Ph. D., who taught elocution, oratory and debating at Cooper Union from 1897 until her retirement in 1939, died Wednesday in her apartment in the Sevillia Hotel, 117 West Fifty-eighth Street, after a long illness. She would have been 95 years old next Monday.
John Morris Perry, senior member of the law firm of Rathbone, Perry, Kelley Drye, 70 Broadway, died yesterday or a heart attack in his apartment at 300 Park Avenue. His age was 84.
HONG KONG, March 1 Nineteen persons have been arrested in Tientsin on charges of espionage "under the camouflage of the Catholic Church" Ta Kung Pao reported here today.
Spanning six weeks during which three revivals will be presented at fortnightly intervals, the City Center's spring drama season will begin April 25 and extend through June 3.
WASHINGTON, March 1 If Charles E. Wilson is beginning to feel a sense of discouragement toward the vast task to which the President assigned him, that would be simple to comprehend.

A 1934 remark of a Kuhn, Loeb Co. partner, who said his firm did not want to "poach on the preserves" of another banking firm that is now a co-defendant in the Government's anti-trust suit, was aired in Federal Court yesterday.
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 1--Puerto Cabello, which is now receiving all ships originally destined for La Guayra, Venezuela's principal seaport, is in a critical state of congestion.

The Board of Estimate ratified yesterday the recent action of the City Council in passing local bills designed to block precipitate retirement of policemen called as grand jury witnesses and to penalize racial or religious discrimination in private housing projects built with financial aid from the city.

WASHINGTON, March 1 In one of the fastest negotiations on record in the railroad industry, the nation's carriers settled their dispute with 1,000,000 non-operating employes today with a rise of 12.5 cents an hour. These employes have been receiving an average of $1.48 an hour.
Prices of most commodity futures on the exchanges here drifted into lower territory yesterday in a reduced volume of trading. Only crude rubber and world sugar futures ended the day higher.

Although consumer resistance to costly meats continues, it has had little effect on week-end prices. The only meats that are cheaper are three cuts of veal and one of lamb; these are off 2 to 5 cents a pound. Luxury beef cuts, which declined a nickel a pound last Friday, are holding steady.

TRIESTE, March 1 Triestene leaders said today that the Italian Government had for some time been acquainted with the general outline of proposals for a modusvivendi with Yugoslavia that, in their opinion, not only would improve Italian-Yugoslav relations in this area but also afford a sound temporary solution of the Trieste problem acceptable to Belgrade.

LISBON, Portugal, March 1 Dr. Antonio de Oliveira Salazar, Portuguese dictator, warned the United States, Britain and France today against a temptation in a new Big Four conference to throw away present advantages for any kind of appeasement of the Soviet Union.
ST. PETERSBURG, March 1 Leo Durocher today came back to old St. Pete where, as a Yankee, he made his major league debut a quarter of a century ago, and he really gave the folks a show.

LONDON, March 1 General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower flew here today from Paris for discussions with the British Chiefs of Staff regarding the structure of three main posts in his Western European military command.

CHICAGO, March 1 Record sales lifted 1950 net income of Standard Oil Company of Indiana and subsidiaries to $123,581,477, or $8.09 a common share, from $102,668,228, or $6.72 a share, in 1949, Dr. Robert E. Wilson, chairman, announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, March 1 Baldwin-Lima Hamilton Corpora Continued on Page 39, Column 3 Continued From Page 35 tion reported today that it made a net profit of $3,671,930 last year on sales of $94,386,752, compared with earnings of $3,522,223 on sales of $119,002,443 in 1949.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 1 Dr. Edward S. Brackett, for thirty years one of New England's leading obstetricians and gynecologists, died here today in Jane Brown Hospital in his seventy-sixth year.
Plans for improved rush-hour express service on I.R.T. lines serving 200,000 residents of the upper Bronx were announced yesterday by the Board of Transportation.

Industrial buying of metals declined yesterday as Government cutbacks in civilian uses became effective, metal industry executives revealed. Declines ranged from as little as 10 per cent, compared with average sales in the first trading days of January and ...

Educational, medical and charitable institutions shared in $61,547,405 in a final distribution of the residuary estate of Edward S. Harkness, financier and philanthropist, it was disclosed yesterday in an accounting filed by Malcolm P. Aldrich, trustee.

William H. Draper Jr., trustee of the Long Island Rail Road, asserted last night that the agreement reached in Washington yesterday with the non-operating railroad employes would increase the bankrupt road's wage costs by $2,000,000 to $2,500,000 annually.
The welcome mat is out at New York City's hotels, but fewer patrons have been crossing it in recent weeks.
The 106th Bombardment, Wing (Light) of the New York Air National Guard was sworn into Federal service yesterday afternoon at Floyd Bennett Naval Air Station.
WASHINGTON, March 1--The United States, Britain and France will meet with the Soviet Union in Paris on Monday in a first step toward a possible Big Four foreign ministers conference at a later date.
CHICAGO, March 1 (AP) The New York Rangers moved into a third-place tie with idle Boston in the National Hockey League tonight by defeating the Chicago Black Hawks, 4 to 1, before 5,918 fans.

Maintaining their upward surge for the sixth successive week, loans to business by banks in this area rose $88,000,000 last week to a new high total of $6,747,000,000. The advance in the week ended on Wednesday brought the total expansion since the first of the year to $442,000,000, compared with only $15,000,000 in the same period of 1950.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 1 Manager Charley Dressen, still battling influenza in the hospital but keeping in close touch with training operations being directed by his coaches, today decided that the time was ripe for the first intra squad game.

Aided in part by more favorable weather, sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 19 per cent in February, compared with the corresponding month last year, according to the survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

IN his new novel, "The Age of Longing," Arthur Koestler suggests that the only hope for modern Europe would be the emergence of a new religion. In his new novel, "Round the Bend," Nevil Shute has written a parable about how such a religion might get started. But, to make his story plausible, Mr. Shute has laid it in the East, where religious feeling has always ...

WASHINGTON, March 2 In the wake of the settlement of the nonoperating railroad unions dispute the National Mediation Board speeded up conferences today seeking to adjust the two-year-old controversy affecting the "Big Four" railway brotherhoods, engineers, firemen, conductors and trainmen.

We congratulate the Board of Estimate on passing, by a vote of 12 to 1, the bills requiring policemen to give thirty-day notice of intention to retire before such retirement becomes effective. Due acknowledgment was given...

MILWAUKEE, March 2 Widespread construction of dams for hydroelectric power in this country was attacked today by Carl D. Shoemaker, conservation director of the National Wildlife Federation, at the group's annual convention here.
SIOUX CITY, Iowa, March 2 A twin-engined Mid-Continent airliner crashed and burned while landing at Municipal Airport in a snowstorm today, killing fifteen of the twenty-five persons aboard.

Paul R. Blaisdell, executive director of the National Committee on Traffic Safety, said recently that traffic accidents were on the rise because "fortyfive-mile-an-hour minds cope with our ninety-mile-an-hour vehicles and seventy-mile-an-hour roads."

In a hearing on the military training bill before the House Armed Services Committee, General Marshall declared that the drafted reservists called to duty in the Korean crisis cannot be released unless 18-year-olds are drafted.

First signs of successful Easter sales by department and similar stores were seen yesterday as trade observers estimated the volume for this week at 18 per cent above the corresponding week of last year.
The Distinguished Service Cross was added yesterday to other medals won by First Lieut. John R. Hardy in World War II and in the Korean war.

Mayor Impellitteri is negotiating with Carmine DeSapio, leader Tammany Hall, for support of the Mayor's proposal to increase the sales tax to 3 per cent, Walter Hoving, chairman of the Anti-Sales Tax Committee of New York City, charged yesterday.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 2 Dr. Thomas, Harvey Haines of 58 Tuxedo Road, a well-known psychologist and psychiatrist, died here today. His age was 79.

CHICAGO, March 2 The grain markets fluctuated in a nervous manner on the board of trade here today, several waves of scattered liquidation developing, but the recent sharp decline in prices brought in aggressive short-covering and the finish was about at the top, with wheat showing gains of to 1 cents a bushel.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 2 The central task of the West German Communist party is to turn the present passive anti-war feeling expressed in the popular phrase, "Without Me!" into "an active resistance movement against remilitarization."

Raymond Massey has completed his stage version of "Hanging Judge," a murder-will-out novel by Bruce Hamilton. On Monday, he will convey the manuscript to a New York typing service, whence the first script will go to Victor Samrock and William Fields of The Playwrights Company, who plan to produce it next season.

The New York Curb Exchange, second largest trading mart in the nation, had a net income of $64,085 last year. In 1949 there was a loss of $139,646. In his final report as president of the Exchange, Francis Adams Truslow said the institution was free of indebtedness and owns all of its properties free and clear.

JERSEY CITY, March 2--The offices here of Local 1247 of the International Longshoremen's Union, A. F. L., were bombed this afternoon in an intra-union fight for control of the local and the piers on which its membership is employed.
GENEVA, March 2 Western Europe's position in the coming struggle for raw materials is stronger than a lot of Europe's statesmen and some Washington officials seem to think.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 2 The marriage of Miss Patricia Louise Youngman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Vreeland Youngman, to John Hartwell Ames, son of Mrs. Alfrederick S. Ames and the late Mr. Ames, took place here this evening in St. Luke's Protestant Episcopal Church. The Rev. Marcus B. Hall, rector, performed the ceremony.

PARIS, March 2 General Eisenhower today began what is apparently a series of conferences on the role the United States Atlantic and Mediterranean fleets are to play in the defense plans of Western Europe.

ALBANY, March 2 The State Commission against Discrimination said today that its work should contribute materially to lessening "potential tension situations" that might otherwise disrupt defense production and national security.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 2 (AP) Miss Beverly Baker, ambidextrous youngster from Santa Monica, Calif., won the women's championship of the Bermuda invitation tennis tournament today by beating Miss Barbara Scofield of San Francisco, 9 7, 7 5.
In Korea Friday, United Nations forces progressively compelled enemy units to withdraw from strongly defended positions and forged gains of from one to two miles. Action was centered in the...

BRIGHAM CITY, Utah, March 2 As the first step in a longrange educational program promising an eventual solution to one cause of the much debated Navajo problem, 1288 tribal youngsters are currently achieving literacy at the Federal Government's year-old Intermountain Indian School on a 1,000-acre campus nearly 500 miles from their squalid reservation homes.

From the West Coast comes the intelligence that the third and fi nal role in Louis Verneuil's "See No Evil," in which Betty Garrett and Larry Parks will appear, will be played by Raymond Greenleaf, character actor at Columbia, who has been seen in such films as "All the King's Men" and "No Sad Songs for Me."

The Pennsylvania Railroad disclosed plans yesterday to install on its major passenger lines a $12,000,000 automatic train speed control system described by the railroad as "the most effective means of insuring maximum safety."

American Can Company completed arrangements yesterday for tha sale of $40,000,000 of twentyyear 2 per cent debentures. The financing was disclosed in the pamphlet report by the company which is celebrating its fiftieth anniversary and the fourth consecutive year of record production.
Five art exhibitions now at galleries in this city illustrate the diversity of twentieth-century painting.

A former corridor in the Metropolitan Museum of Art opens today as the institution's new print gallery with an exhibition of costume plates and water-colors reflecting the fashionable side of Parisian life at the turn of the century. "Found" space, the gallery takes the place of the regular print quarters, now under reconstruction.

ON THE CENTRAL FRONT, in Korea, March 1 Large-scale destruction in Korea, most of it resulting from the tremendous fire power of the planes and guns used against the Communist troops, is robbing the United Nations of some of the goodwill it had won with the Koreans.

New York's industrial facilities and manpower will be used to the utmost in the current rearmament program and mistakes of deficient government contract allocation of World War II will not be repeated if business and government leaders

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 2 Journalistic studies and actual jury service are being combined here by students of the Rutgers University School of Journalism. In Judge George R. Morrison's District Court students who once were restricted to detached note-taking now get right to the heart of things, as jury members.

WASHINGTON, March 2 Manufacturers of about 40,000 items containing rubber have until March 15 to adjust their production to the limitations placed upon their use of natural rubber by the National Production Authority last Monday. The order issued earlier in the week fixed the effective date for restrictions as March 1. The March 15 amendment was issued today.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (UP) The Chilean Embassy denied today that President Gabriel Gonzalez Videla had said recently that Chile would continue selling merchandise wherever she could obtain a fair price.

PARIS, March 2 Unable to frame a national union Cabinet or "even to reconstitute the majority that has just broken up," Georges Bidault today declined to continue his attempt to form a new French Ministry.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Feb. 26 The Agricultural Council, representing Danish farmers, was host yesterday to nine American food writers who are here for a week as guests of the Danish Government.

Mark A. Edison, vice president and treasurer of Edison Brothers Stores, Inc., St. Louis, national women's retail shoe chain, died in that city yesterday at his home after an illness of several months. His age was 55.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 2 A program to increase by onethird the world's largest helicopter plant was announced today by the Sikorsky Aircraft division of United Aircraft Corporation.

WASHINGTON, March 2 Roy Fruehauf, Detroit trailer manufacturer, swore before a Senate investigating subcommittee today that Joseph H. Rosenbaum, Washington attorney linked with charges of influence and favoritism in the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, had boasted to him that he had two R.F.C. directors Walter L. Dunham and William E. Willett "in his hip pocket."

WASHINGTON, March 2 With a laugh and a jest, Michael V. DiSalle, director of the Office of Price Stabilization, today dismissed reports that the agency was playing politics in the recruiting of personnel for its nation-wide organization.

AN encouraging note in the progress of pollution abate ment, a matter of real interest to all hunters and fishermen, was brought out yesterday at the opening of the National Wildlife Conference in Milwaukee.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP)-- Three employes of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, had roles in the election campaign that unseated Senator Millard E. Tydings, Democrat of Marylard, a witness related today.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) Drew Pearson columnist, sued Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, for $600,000 damages today, and Senator McCarthy and others for $3,000,000 or more.

Roman Catholic churchgoers will be asked tomorrow to make their annual contribution to the Bishop's Fund for the Victims of War. The yearly appeal is the only source of support for the Church's relief and resettlement projects in Europe and Asia. Its 1951 goal is $5,000,000.

BUENOS AIRES, March 2 (AP)-- Jim Fuchs of the United States and Rafael Fortun, Cuba's 30-year-old sprinter, became the first double champions in track events which highlighted the fourth day of the Pan-American Games today.

BOSTON, March 2 The New England Telephone and Telegraph Company reported tonight that earnings on total invested capital improved in 1950, but noted that they averaged only 4.81 per cent for the five post-war years.

WASHINGTON, March 2 The Bureau of Indian Affairs today refused comment on the charge of John Collier, its former Commissioner, that the right of the Pyramid Lake Paiute Indians in Nevada to employ legal counsel was being threatened. But it was pointed out...

EL CENTRO, Calif., March 2 A "flying squad" of the National Farm Labor Union, A.F.L., today forced the deportation of some 115 "wetback" Mexican farm laborers (illegal entrants) just as their presence in the United States, according to union officers, was being legitimized in an unlawful processing operation at the United States Immigration Service border office at Calexico, thirteen miles south of here.

Toys for children of all ages for the devotee of trains, for the historically minded, for doll collectors and for youngsters who just want something to play with are being assembled for exhibition on Monday at the National Antiques show at Madison Square Garden.

The Rev. Dr. Paul L. Buffa, founder of the Baptist Church of St. John the Baptist, 2409 Lorillard Place, the Bronx, and its pastor from 1919 to 1950, died Tuesday after an illness of several months. His age was 69.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 2 Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican-Liberal of New York, called tonight for a showdown in the Republican party "to decide whether modernism or ultra-con servatism will control the party machinery to pick the Presidential nominee in 1952." He spoke at the Harvard Law School Forum.

TRENTON, March 2 A pay increase of 11 cents an hour for 6,500 drivers and other workers of the Public Service bus companies in New Jersey was made effective immediately today by State Treasurer Walter T. Margetts Jr.

HONG KONG, March 2--Top Chinese Communist authorities in Kwangtung have issued a directive blasting away at overzealous political workers for "antagonizing the masses" and "playing into the hands of the enemy" by wrecking Buddhist temples and exposing Buddhist idols to ridicule.

FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., March 2 The Army signal Corps, which maintains its Signal Communications School and vast research and development laboratories here, will observe tomorrow the eightyeighth anniversary of its founding.

The college basketball scandal inquiry widened further yesterday with the arrest on bribery charges of a former Long Island University player, 26-year-old Louis Lipman, and the disclosure that four other suspects were being sought.

WASHINGTON, March 2 Military authorities estimated today that the cost of transporting and maintaining the four American divisions to be sent to Europe would be $248,000,000 more for the first year than if these units remained in the United States.

LONDON, March 2 The State Department has given orders for a new information program aimed at presenting the need for rearmament to the peoples of Western Europe. The program is designed to enlist popular support for the North Atlantic Treaty concept.
Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation is planning to sell an issue of 1,000,000 new shares of common stock to underwriters with a view to a public offering of the shares by the end of March.

THE chickens have odd ways of coming home to roost. The people who used to go roar ing around saving the Republic by calling everyone they didn't like a Fascist beast, and whatnot, now run temperatures when anyone intemperately paints them red.

BERLIN, March 2 There is no target in the Soviet Union that cannot be attacked by United States bombers, Lieut. Gen. Lauris Norstad, commander of the United States Air Forces in Europe, declared today.

PARIS, March 2 The Schuman plan seemed assured by a reported agreement in Bonn today postponing the problem of control over Ruhr coal. This development came after a maneuver of Ruhr industrialists had threatened to upset an understanding already reached between Western German authorities, United States officials and the French.

CASABLANCA, French Morocco March 2 (AP) About forty persons were arrested by French authorities yesterday in a flare-up between Arabs and Berbers at Ksiba, about 150 miles from here in the Atlas Mountains.

Don Gehrmann and Fred Wilt will present their weekly mile thriller to the appreciative Madison Square Garden railbirds for the last time this season tonight at the thirty-second annual New York Knights of Columbus games.
Evidence from state officials alleging bribery of at least two former clerks in the State Bureau of Motor Vehicles has been turned over to District Attorney Frank S. Hogan for investigation.
The Brazilian market for machine tools is expanding because of the continuing rapid growth of Brazilian industry, according to a research survey of the National Machine Tool Builders Association.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 2 Ray Hills Davenport of 328 West Jersey Street, a leader in the development of the modern railway tank car and for many years an executive of the American Car and Foundry Company in New York, died last night at the Elizabeth General Hospital after a brief illness. His age was 77.

PARIS, Feb. 28 On Oct. 23, 1949, Dr. Vladimir Clementis, Foreign Minister of Czechoslovakia, announced through his secretary that he was "not interested" in published reports that he was "scheduled to be interrogated on charges of 'deviationism'."

GROTON, Conn., March 2 A blunt and squat Navy ship without a name, almost grotesque in her hull lines, slid silently down the ways of the Electric Boat Company's yard here late this afternoon. Designated K-1, she is the nation's first modern submarine designed especially to hunt and kill enemy submarines.

LONDON, March 2 Rumors that Foreign Secretary Ernest Bevin had decided to resign were denied today by 10 Downing Street. The denial was occasioned by a report widely Circulated by a British news agency that the ailing Foreign Secretary had yielded to the demands from all political parties that he retire in favor of a younger and healthier spokesman for Britain.
The fashion for prints has taken a modern twist. Top designers along with fine artists have revolutionized printed silks, cottons and rayons.

A Yonkers television-cabinet manufacturer was temporarily enjoined yesterday in Federal Court from using electronic equipment for wood-welding because it emitted radio waves fouling Coast Guard and Army communications.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., March 2 Plans have been completed for the marriage of Miss Catherine Le Vaun Pendergast, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Scott H. Pendergast of Coniscliff, to John C. Bell 3d, son of Justice and Mrs. John C. Bell Jr. of Les Cloches, Wynnewood. The ceremony will be performed on April 28 at the home of the prospective brides parents.

TRENTON, March 2 A new effort to unscramble the claims of Representative Edward J. Hart and State Senator Edward J. O'Mara to be Democratic state chairman will be made Tuesday when they appear before Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons.

EASTBOURNE, England, March 2 Both because of rearmament and in spite of it Britain's export drive to dollar markets must be continued and raw materials must be found to sustain it. That point was repeatedly emphasized today by British, United States and Canadian authorities speaking to manufacturers and merchants of dollar exports at the second session of Britain's Dollar Convention.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Saturday, March 3 Basis for a "National Cabinet" was laid when a five-party agreement on a proposed program was announced early today. The agreement reflected a general desire for the widest possible coalition in view of the Netherlands' serious economic position and the international situation.

WASHINGTON, March 2 The United States Government will continue to urge the West German Federal Republic to rearm and join in the defense of Western Europe, despite the conference of the Big Four foreign ministers' deputies in Paris next week.

The twelve-story building containing three stores and sixty-four apartments at 21 East Tenth Street, northwest corner of University Place, has been sold by the Selbin Corporation to a syndicate of investors represented by Murray Rubenstein. L. J. Phillips Co. were the brokers in the sale for cash over mortgages amounting to about $427,000. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
Around the country these days farmers who are lucky enough to have an autumn hog or two on hand are busily finishing them off.

Colorful spring shoes will compete with the gay floral bonnets in this year's Easter parade. Soft spring "bouquet" shades in kidskin, bright colors in calf and creamy neutral tones in suede set off by the high gloss of black patent will bring flattery to the feet this season. The introduction of...

On March 5 the annual Newbery Award for "the most distinguished book for children" and the Caldecott Award for "the most distinguished picture book" will be presented. These awards remind us that every book written to be used by children is not a book for children.
LAKE SUCCESS, March 2 Bulgaria accused Yugoslavia today of joining Greece and Turkey in a plot to carry out air reconnaissance over Bulgarian territory.

TOKYO, Saturday, March 3 United States Marines on the central Korean front pushed yesterday into the ruined village of Hoengsong, Chinese Communist defense bastion in the mountains, which had been fiercely contested for the last week.

Oliver Colbentson is a talented young violinist. He gave his second local recital in Times Hall last night before a sizable and responsive audience. Despite a certain quality of restraint, he showed that he was a sensitive musician.
Prices of commodity futures on the exchanges here moved irregularly higher yesterday. Cocoa, coffee and tin developed the best strength.
A 17-year-old youth was stabbed fatally and his mother was slashed on the head in a fight in an apartment at 1063 Park Avenue last night. As a result, the police were looking for the woman's husband.

ROSELLE, Ill., March 2 (UP) Two gunmen locked twelve persons in a bank vault today, held a fiveyear-old girl hostage during the raid for their captives' good behavior, and fled in an auto with $2,000. The child was the daughter of a customer.
ARCADIA, Calif., March 2 (AP) Unsettled weather and the lack of an outstanding favorite may throw the $100,000 Santa Anita Handicap tomorrow into the widest open race in its fourteen runnings.

Private investment in new plants and equipment is going on at a faster rate than ever before, according to Thomas W.S. Davis, Assistant Secretary of Commerce. In the last five years such investment has amounted to $80,000,000,000, he said, and represents a great proportion of the American business man's profit.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 2 Prime Minister Robert G. Menzies told a conference of state premiers at Canberra today that he believed, after studying all the information available, that Australia had three years at the most in which to make herself ready for a national emergency.

WASHINGTON, March 2 A defense of the "emergency detention provisions" of the Internal Security Act of 1950 by Frank W. McCul loch, administrative assistant to Senator Paul Douglas, Democrat of Illinois, aroused heated floor discussion at the Fourth Annual Con ferences on Civil Liberties today.

Amendments to the New York City Parking Authority Law, now before the State Legislature, designed to strengthen the Authority and define more closely its powers, received the endorsement yesterday of the City Council. The Council tally was sixteen in favor, two against and two not voting.

WASHINGTON, March 2 Senator Kenneth S. Wherry of Nebraska, Republican floor leader of the Senate, proposed today that action on the pending military manpower bill be delayed until the chamber decided whether to permit further dispatch of United States ground forces to Europe. He also would defer...
Permanent license plates for automobiles are urged by the New York State Automobile Association as a saving of time and money to the state and motorist. While the revenues derived by the...

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 2 Chancellor Adenauer and Mr. McCloy agreed today on a formula postponing the coal-control problem and opening the way to West German acceptance of the Schuman plan if France also agrees.

Soviet and Communist propagandists throughout the world are now exploiting the recent price cuts in the U.S.S.R. as further evidence of the "superiority" of the Stalinist economic system over all others. Pravda set the line by...

Another safety innovation was introduced yesterday by the Department of Traffic when it installed foreign-language signs at "Coffin Corners," one of the most intricate and hazardous pedestrian crossings in Greenwich Village. Since 1947, two persons have been killed and fourteen injured there.

LONDON, March 2 The Labor Government suffered a technical defeat today when a motion criticizing its neglect to build up stocks of essential raw materials was carried by 167 to 163 votes in the House of Commons.
A sawdust trail or a mourner's bench has no place in the repertoire of the "new" evangelists, the Rev. Charles B. Templeton said yesterday.

CHICAGO, March 2 (UP) The National Collegiate A.A. Council today recommended a boycott, by its members of Madison Square Garden basketball games and intimated that in the future none of its tourney games would be scheduled at the New York arena.

ROME, March 2 The extreme left-wing press was jubilant today over the setback suffered by Premier Alcide de Gasperi in the Chamber of Deputies yesterday when a Government-sponsored bill was approved by a majority of only sixteen votes.

The National Retail Furniture Association yesterday asked the Office of Price Stabilization to amend a provision of Ceiling Price Regulaton 7, which controls retail prices by limiting store mark-ups. The association contends that the provision depresses furniture store margins to an "unbearable" extent.
The British Government has invited the Premier and the Foreign Minister of Italy to visit London this month. The invitation is not a mere...

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 2--Alberto Dodero, shipping leader, and one of South America's best-known personalities, died here tonight after having suffered a heart attack yesterday. He was 65 years old.
The extent to which the serious business of running the city government can get mixed up in extraneous political issues was never so well illustrated as in the current deadlock over New...

ALBANY, March 2 Dr. Herman E. Hilleboe, State Health Commissioner, endorsed the controversial Metcalf-Hatch bill today. The measure would permit the use of stray dogs and cats by medical schools and other medical research agencies for experiments.

"A Treasury of Kahlil Gibran," a selection from the writings of the Syrian symbolist poet and painter, has been scheduled for March 19 publication by The Citadel Press. The volume consists of translations from the Arabic manuscripts of Gibran by Anthony Rizcallah Ferries. Martin L. Wolf, editor of the volume, has written an introduction that throws new light on Gibran as a writer.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 2 The Senate Crime Investigating Committee announced today it would ask the Senate to hold two witnesses in contempt because of their refusal to testify. The committee opened a two-day hearing in this city.

MADRID, March 2 United States Ambassador Stanton Griffis promised the Spaniards today that he would give his full cooperation to efforts to relax the present stringent application of the Internal Security Act, which bars almost all Spaniards from the United States.

ALBANY, March 2 The state's pending civil defense bill was amended today to provide for state assistance to localities for the cost of shelters and other defense installations and for the care of persons needing emergency aid as the result of an enemy attack.

KEY WEST, March 2 President Truman arrived at his retreat here this afternoon for a stay of about twenty-three days and within fifteen minutes he had discarded his business suit for a sports outfit with a loud "tail-out shirt."

Further amendments to the Dewey administration's civil defense bill that would reduce the Governor's power of conscription and removal or suspension of local officials and relieve the cities of expenditures, now mandated by the measure, will be suggested by Democratic members of the Legislature as a result of a conference held yesterday in Gracie Mansion on the invitation of Mayor Impellitteri.

The City Council adopted yesterday a resolution asking the Legislature to pass a pending bill which would compel the city, upon application, to reimburse two elected officials for pay cuts made while they held elective office seventeen years ago.

ALBANY, March 2 A bill to provide for the speedy removal of bad security risks from public positions in the state when their continued employment might imperil the security or defense of the state or country was introduced in the Legislature today.

Plans are being advanced for the second annual dinner dance for the benefit of the production fund of the New York City Ballet Company to be held on April 3 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the Ballet Associates in America, Inc.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 2 Britain, France, Canada and Uruguay firmly supported democratic principles at today's meetings of the United Nations Economic and Social Council devoted to the study of world economy.

WASHINGTON, March 2 The Defense Transport Administration put the storage of grain at seaports under a permit system today. The system becomes effective tomorrow. The permits will be issued by the administration on recommendation of the Department of Agriculture. Applications should be addressed to the Director, Transportation and Warehousing Branch, Production and Marketing Administration, Department of Agriculture, Washington 25, D.C.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 2 Warner Brothers has signed Ray Milland to a three-picture contract, under which his first assignment will be the starring role in "A Baby for Midge," a domestic comedy which James Webb and Frank Davis have written from a magazine story by Webb.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 2 The Presidium of the Yugoslav National Assembly is planning to reactivate parliamentary clubs as part of the program of transforming the Assembly from a body of routine ratification into an institution where a reasonable amount of debate is to be tolerated.

BUENOS AIRES, March 2 Teofilo Gil, La Prensa photographer, who was sentenced yesterday to thirty days in jail, was released early this morning. It is understood that the order for his pardon was issued by the chief of Federal police. Gen. Arturo Bertollo.

BALTIMORE, March 5 (AP) The Baltimore City Council tonight asked the City School Board to bar Owen Lattimore from speaking at a school assembly.

JERSEY CITY, March 5 The hunt for the men responsible for the bombing Friday of headquarters of Local 1,247, International Longshoremen's Association, here,.... continued today as the police announced the arrest of two more material witnesses, bringing to sixteen the number of longshoremen being held in protective custody. No headway was indicated,....

Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany Hall, will be in Albany today and tomorrow, theoretically to attend two legislative dinners, but also to discuss with New York County members of the Legislature their attitude on Mayor Impellitteri's request for legislative permission to increase the city sales tax from 2 to 3 per cent.
Despite serious problems raised by the defense program, the toy industry expects to maintain a high level of production, key executives agreed generally yesterday on opening of the American Toy Fair.

Through the sale of Easter Seals the National Society for Crippled Children and Adults is endeavoring to raise additional funds to meet the increased cost of carrying out its three-point program of direct services, research and education. Through the years flexi-....
A garment cutter who allegedly substituted for one of Harry Gross' runners in an "accommodation" arrest said yesterday that Aaron Feld, a recently retired patrolman, cooperated in the arrangement.

Girl students in the Department of Home Economics at Hunter College looked through their best cookie recipes yesterday in preparation for baking pastries for four homesick G.I.'s in the front lines in Korea.

Vladimir Horowitz gave his first piano recital of the season last night in Carnegie Hall, packed with one of the brilliant and enthusiastic audiences which we remember to have greeted him in this city.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, March 2--Thirteen months have elapsed since the Greeks on this island voted to sever their ties with the British Empire and become an organic part of the Greek realm.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 5 Announcement has been made by the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. George Given Hollingshead of the engagement of their daughter, Jean, to Dr. James Alfred Lyon Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lyon of Pompton Plains.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 5 Commending the achievements of the State Institute of Applied Arts and Sciences here, the Westchester Board of Supervisors asked this afternoon for a one-year extension of the institute's life and protested against shifting any part of the cost to the county.

If former Mayor O'Dwyer's reported illness prevents him from appearing next week at the Senate Crime Investigating Committee's open hearings he may still be called to testify later before either the Senate Judiciary Committee or the Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee, Rudolph Halley, chief counsel of the crime committee, said yesterday.

MOSCOW, March 5 (AP) Pravda corrected itself today. The official newspaper of the Communist party said it had made an omission in an important article on rural reconstruction and improvements, written by a Politburo member, Nikita S. Khrushchev.
An underwriting syndicate headed by White, Weld Co. and Stone Webster Securities Corporation will offer to investors today a new issue of $27,500,000 par value of $2.55 dividend cumulative pre

ALBANY, March 5--The Moore Committee on Teacher Pay submitted to Governor Dewey today recommendations that virtually all minimum salary scales for teachers be increased by $500 and that all teachers be guaranteed a $100 cost-of-living bonus for the current school year.
The officers of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association have warned their 18,000 active members that unless dues are increased 50 per cent the organization "will have to close its doors by July 1."

LONDON, March 5--Heavy demand for rubber shares was the feature of an otherwise quiet session on the London stock market today. Rubber prices went ahead all day although actual rises were smaller than Friday's because of extensive profit-taking.
Representatives of tin producers in Bolivia denied here yesterday, in response to charges made in Washington on Sunday, that they were "gouging" the American taxpayers for their metal.

ALBANY, March 5 The Senate deferred action tonight on the Brydges-Ten Eyck bill to make jury service mandatory for women. Senator Arthur H. Wicks, Republican majority leader, declared later that the bill was "dead."

KALIMPONG, India, March 5 Communist China and the Government of Tibet were reported here today to have reached agreement under which, internal autonomy would be granted to the Himalayan state, while Peiping would control the defense and foreign affairs of the Dalai Lama's realm.

CAIRO, March 5 The Egyptian Government's grave concern over the "dangerous events" taking place in Morocco was expressed today in both housed of the Egyptian Parliament by Mohamed Salah el Din Pasha, Foreign Minister.

PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, Tuesday, March 6 An Italian film won the Grand Prize last night in the first International Film Festival here, but Gloria Swanson was honored for the best performance by an actress for her work in "Sunset Boulevard."

The adoption of sound policies by both the United States and Chile could end or reduce materially the present copper shortage, according to a statement made yesterday by C. Donald Dallas, chairman of Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., on his return from an extended South American trip.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., March 5 Master Sgt. Horst W. Tittel, a veteran of forty-three years of continuous military service, left stewart Air Force Base today to report for duty with the newly activated Central Air Defense Force headquarters at Kansas City, Mo.

Inroads made by trucking concerns in transporting import cargo from ship to railroad threaten to kill off lighterage business in the port entirely, possibly with disastrous results in time of national emergency.
Daily newspapers in the United States broke all records for circulation in 1950. At a rate of 54,877,000 copies a day for the year and with more than two people reading each copy, it is estimated...

PEARL RIVER, N.Y., March 5 This is a quiet little community about thirty miles by road from Times Square and right on the border of New York and New Jersey. At 4:19 P.M. all was peaceful.

The Union Bag and Paper Corporation in 1950 achieved the largest annual sales volume in its history and increased its earnings by $3,410,966, the preliminary annual report by Alexander Calder, president, informed stockholders today.

Ted Husing has resigned as announcer of the prize fights on Wednesday nights over the Columbia Broadcasting System's television network. Russ Hodges will take over the video commentary tomorrow night, when the feature

The Pennsylvania State Highway and Bridge Authority yesterday postponed for the second time its pending sale of $25,000,000 of serial revenue bonds. The new date for the sale was posted for April 11. The sale previously had been postponed from March 28 to
The General Motors Corporation wrote a new chapter in the financial history of private American enterprise last year.

The upsurge of interest in antiques that has been noticeable for months, closely resembling the collecting fever of the war years and those immediately after, was apparent yesterday at the National Antiques Show at Madison Square Garden.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 5 The West German Federal Republic must meet the fundamental tests of political democracy to win equality with the democratic nations, Benjamin J. Buttenwieser, Assistant United States High Commissioner for policy, declared today.

ALBANY, March 5 Mayor Impellitteri, speaking with the approval of all his associates on the Board of Estimate, told the Legislature tonight that New York City could not meet the mounting expenses it faced unless its taxing powers were broadened or it received more help from the state treasury.

LONDON, March 5 The United States Government has been advised that the appointment of an American to command the North Atlantic pact naval forces in the Mediterranean might engender farreaching political repercussions in Britain.
HENSINKI, Finland, March 5 The Finnish Communists have started an all-out campaign to capture the Finnish Federation of Labor at the trade union elections at the end of this month.

About half the treasures that were auctioned yesterday from the library of the late Lucius Wilmerding of New York were purchased by foreign collectors and dealers, In two sessions, day and evening, at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, American and European bidders fought to a draw over fine bindings and other rarities.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 5--President Truman called on Congress today to provide $97,500,000 immediately to complete the ring of radio transmitters being used by the Voice of America to pound our campaign of truth through Russia's Iron Curtain.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, March 5 (AP) Prof. Mogens Westergaard, prominent Danish geneticist, said today that permission to enter the United States had been denied to him because he formerly was a member of the Communist party.

PARIS, March 5 The Soviet Union proposed this afternoon that "immediate proceeding to the reduction of the armed forces of the four Powers the Soviet Union, the United States, Britain and France" be placed upon the agenda of the next session of the Council of Foreign Ministers.

TRENTON, March 5 Establishment of a medical school and a dental school at Rutgers University in New Brunswick was proposed today by a state study commission of doctors, dentists,.... educators, prominent citizens and legislators. They placed the over-all construction and equipment cost at $25,000,000.
BUENOS AIRES, March 5 Dr. Alberto Gainza Paz, publisher of the newspaper La Prensa, has been charged with violating Argentina's security law, it was announced tonight.

Retail merchants will suffer if the city sales tax is increased from 2 to 3 per cent, officials of four chambers of commerce here warned yesterday at a meeting in the office of Walter Hoving, chairman of the Anti-Sales Tax Committee of New York City.
WASHINGTON, March 5 The American South, termed twenty years ago the country's No. 1 economic problem, may be over the hump in economic development.

Although gross income of the Pure Oil Company was the largest in its thirty-seven-year history, consolidated net income for 1950 was exceeded by the record set in 1948.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 5 The United States called on the United Nations today to draw up with the greatest possible speed specific plans for preparing the organization to take quick military, political and economic action against any new aggression.

PHILADELPHIA, March 5--Dr. Paul R. Hawley, director of the American College of Surgeons, announced an agreement tonight among four major medical organizations to set up a joint commission on accreditation of hospitals.

NEW ORLEANS, March 5 (AP) A group of Protestant ministers testified today that a statue of a Roman Catholic saint erected on city property was offensive to them because of the American heritage "of the separation of church and state."

ST. LOUIS, March 5 The Most Rev. Peter W. Bartholme, Roman Catholic Coadjutor Bishop of St. Cloud, Minn., criticized today the recent Mid-Century White House Conference for Children and Youth as "under the control of men and women who had a pragmatic, materialistic and secular viewpoint of the child."
TRENTON, March 5 Two jurors were selected today at the opening of the retrial of six men charged with the 1948 hold-up murder of William Horner, 72year-old shopkeeper here.

PROVIDENCH, R.I., March 5 (UP) World lightweight champion Ike Williams of Trenton, N.J., won a split decision over Beau Jack of Atlanta, a former champion, in a ten-round nontitle bout before 3,679 fans at the Auditorium tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 5 The United States served notice on the Soviet Union today that it would push a general peace settlement for Japan, but would reject any one's right to veto it.

In addition to her mastery of detail and her handsome use of embroidery, lace and applique, Sally Milgrim injected a pleasing younger note in her collection of spring custom designs presented yesterday. They were supplemented by creations by Eulalie.

ALBANY, March 5 Republican legislative leaders were reported tonight as favoring the enactment of bills validating the McGoldrick rent plan and creating a watereddown version of the original Long Island Rail Road Authority. LONDON, March 5 Officials of the British Government and three British colonies met here today to consider the formation of a new federation in Central Africa, a proposal involving the very delicate issue of race relationships in the British Empire.
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 5--Manager Charley Dressen came out of the hospital long enough this morning to sit in a car in the sun and watch two teams of his Dodgers battle to a nine-inning, 5-5 tie.
WASHINGTON, March 5 The battle between powerful radio broadcasting systems over methods of color television will be reviewed by the Supreme Court under an order announced today.

A preliminary indictment accusing Salvatore T. Sollazzo, so-called sure-thing gambler, of fixing college basketball games will be returned in the next few days, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday.

Billy Rose, whose last Broadway show was "Concert Varieties" in 1945, acknowledged yesterday that he has an oral agreement with Ben Hecht and Charles MacArthur to produce their latest anti-Communist comedy, "The Big Lie." Casting already has started.

Fresh difficulties were encountered yesterday by the stock market after last week's modest recovery. The rails and steels dropped although buying in some issues near the close imparted a steadier tone to the list. Extreme losses ranged to 2 points but the composite rates reduction held at 0.96 point.

MIAMI, Fla., March 5 Philip Murray declared tonight that representatives of labor, agriculture and small business were entitled to a significant place on the policy and operating levels of the nation's defense mobilization agencies.

WASHINGTON, March 5 Two specialists from the National Production Authority's Office of Civilian Requirements have been sent around the country to make "spot" checks of threatened shortages of civilian goods and to survey any possible maldistribution of consumers' items.

WASHINGTON, March 5 Senator James E. Murray, Democrat of Montana and chairman of the Senate Committee on Labor and Public Welfare, was named before a Senate investigating subcommittee today as intercessor for a $1,000,000 Reconstruction Finance Corporation loan to a Miami Beach luxury hotel, the Sorrento, while his son, James A. Murray, a Washington attorney, was earning a $21,000 fee in this and allied cases.

ELIZABETH TAYLOR, the English novelist, not the movie actress, has a new book out this week, which should be good news to her small but growing and discriminating American body of readers. It is called "A Game of Hide-and-Seek"* and it is excellent of its kind; but its kind is peculiar.

A baker's dozen of table settings, representing twelve of the United Nations, went on display yesterday at Georg Jensen, Inc., as part of its Flower Show of the Nations. The field for the National invitation basketball tournament starting Saturday at Madison Square Garden reached eleven teams with the announcement yesterday that St. Bonaventure of Olean, N.Y., had accepted a bid to compete. One more team will be chosen.

The whirling light atop a police car that warns the speeder the law is on his trail may soon be adapted to airplanes. William S. Smoot, a project engineer for Capital Airlines, recently installed one of the "whirlers" atop an aircraft with good results.

WASHINGTON, March 5 The Erie Railroad today filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission a proposed plan of reorganization for the New Jersey and New York Railway Company, a subsidiary serving commuters in New Jersey and New York.

WASHINGTON, March 5 The Senate decided in effect today, in the first test vote in Congress on the military manpower bill, to lower the age of induction from the present 19 to 18. By a roll-call vote of 55 to 31, the Senate rejected an amendment that would have set the induction age at 18 .

WITH UNITED STATES SECOND DIVISION, Korea, March 5 Maj. Leonard (Chief) Lowry, descendant of the Cherokees, led a bayonet charge against a Communist-held hill and personally killed four fleeing machine gunners.

Elizabeth Yates and Katherine Milhous received yesterday gold seals representing the John Newbery Medal and the Caldecott Medal Awards. The awards are given annually by the Children's Library Associate, a section of the American Library Association, for the best contributions to juvenile literature.

NEW DELHI, India, March 5 In a letter to the Czechoslovak Government in Prague resigning his post as Ambassador to India, Dr. B.G. Kratochvil has accused the Communist regime of exploiting, robbing and betraying the Czechoslovak people.

THE latest item from the ammunition industry will be of interest to the scattergun enthusiasts, for the WinchesterWestern combine has finally licked the paper shotshell problem with an aluminum alloy case that has many advantages over the paper hull.

WASHINGTON, March 5 The Administration's foreign policy leader in Congress, Senator Tom Connally, Democrat of Texas, appealed today for Senate approval of the dispatch of American troops to Europe in advance of the prospective Big Four Conference.

ROME, March 5 Approximately 10,000 former Communist and left wing Socialist workers already have followed the two Communist "rebels," Valdo Magnani and Aldo Cucchi, and have turned against the two extreme left-wing parties, Ignazio Silone, the novelist, said today in a letter to the Rome afternoon independent newspaper Giornale d'Italia.
JERSEY CITY, March 5 Thomas P. (Buddy) Boyle, 23year-old political lieutenant of Mayor James V. Kenny, was killed early today at the height of a political argument in a downtown tavern here.
BUENOS AIRES, March 5(AP) The United States rang up two smashing triumphs in track and one in diving today, but saw its lofty baseball hopes shattered by Cuba in the Pan-American Games.

DALLAS, Tex., March 5--National Press Week of the Dallas fashion industry began yesterday when twenty-five visiting fashion editors from many parts of the country witnessed the first presentation of the city's Fashion Center at a breakfast showing. This is an innovation for the up-and-coming Texas fashion market, whose growth has been steady.

CHICAGO, March 5 The grain markets here showed a heavy undertone most of the day yesterday, with scattered liquidation developing in March corn and oats; both grains, as well as wheat, were down at one time around 2 cents from Saturday's finish.

Four four-story buildings containing stores and apartments at 717 to 723 Eighth Avenue have been sold by the Klatko Realty Corporation to an investing client of Walter Scott Co. represented by Reuben Lesser, attorney. Joseph P. Day, Inc., and Rhea Hirschkorn were the brokers.
CHICAGO, March 5 (AP) Civil defense planners in Illinois today disagreed with the Federal Government proposal to seize the railroads in a national emergency.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 5 The weather today was the nicest since the Yankees started training here, but it was a gloomy one for the club nevertheless.

WASHINGTON, March 5 An organized demand for a multibillion-dollar slash in Administration budget estimates for the fiscal year of 1952 gathered momentum today after a Pentagon spokesman had told Senators that defense outlays would be increased another $7,000,000,000 in the fiscal year 1953 to about $48,000,000,000.

PARIS, March 5 With the authorization of the Socialists' National Council, Guy Mollet, Minister of State in the recent Pleven Cabinet, agreed today to go before the French National Assembly tomorrow afternoon to seek its endorsement as Premier.
TAEGU, Korea, March 5 Definite gains against disease and famine among Korean refugees were reported for the first time yesterday by the United Nations civil assistance command.

Lilacs from Holland, mimosa from France, geraniums from New Jersey, roses from Pennsylvania and at least one amaryllis that had been grown on Forty-ninth Street in Manhattan were among the thousands of blossoms at Grand Central Palace where the International Flower Show opened at noon yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 5 Columbia has acquired screen rights to "From Here to Eternity," a new novel by James Jones about life at Schofield Barracks in Honolulu up until the Japanese bombing of Pearl Harbor in 1941. The studio reportedly paid $85,000 for the story an exceptionally high price, by current standards, for a novel. It is expected that Broderick Crawford will appear in the film adaptation of the work.

PARIS, March 7--Former Premier Henri Queuille was asked again today to seek to end the French Cabinet crisis. Having accepted the responsibility, he was working hard with party leaders tonight to induce them to agree to a compromise on the troublesome electoral reform issue. This time, he appeared to have better chances of success.

JERUSALEM, March 7 The legislation committee of the Knesset (Parliament) has tentatively decided that registration for the Israeli general election will be based on residence as of March 1, 1951. But registration will not start until the electoral law being prepared by the committee is completed, and it is now considered unlikely that elections can be held before July.

The flow of offerings into the market for Government securities in the wake of the announcement of the Treasury's pending conversion offer of 2 per cent bonds began to subside yesterday. As a result there was some improvement in prices throughout the list of Treasury obligations after two successive days of drastic declines.

SALT LAKE CITY, March 7--Twenty field and regional officials representing seven bureaus of the Department of Interior closed tonight two-day discussions reassessing plans for the vast Colorado River-Great Basin region in the light of the defense emergency.

Progress of the campaign continues to be satisfactory, with all three services Army, Navy and Air performing well their completely coordinated tactical missions. Designed to meet abnormal military inhibitions, our strategic plan, involving constant movement to keep the enemy off balance with a corresponding limitation upon his initiative, remains unaltered.

WASHINGTON, March 7 The International Monetary Fund sought today to clamp new restrictions on the international traffic in gold at premium prices that recently had been dramatized by arrests for attempted smuggling of the metal through New York and a boom in gold mining stocks.

Sol Schindel bought the ninestory and penthouse apartment building for forty-seven families on plot 75 by 100 feet at 262 West 107th Street from the Midboro Realty Corporation, Jacob Glass, president, in a deal negotiated by Paul P. Zinner, Inc., broker.

By the time 237 candidates had hurdled the last obstacle in the post gymnasium on Governors Island yesterday, a few wondered if they ever would get to the United States Military Academy. None, however, thought that he had made the wrong choice in wanting to go to West Point.
In a sharp reversal of its previous position, Nassau County yesterday came out in favor of some increase in passenger fares for the Long Island Rail Road.

The recent request of the Military Sea Transportation Service for the allocation of an additional twenty-one Government-owned Victory-type vessels to meet military requirements was approved yesterday by the Federal Maritime Board.

WASHINGTON, March 7 The Supreme Court will have passed judgment on four legalistic issues, but also have written the last or next-to-last chapter in a very celebrated case, when it makes known possibly next Monday-whether it will review the conviction of Alger Hiss for perjury by issuing a writ of certiorari.

Herbert Tichman, clarinetist, and his wife, Ruth Budnevich, a pianist, presented a program last night at Times Hall that featured contemporary works for the clarinet. The premiere of the evening was the first New York performance of the Clarinet Concerts, composed by Darius Milhaud originally for Benny Goodman.

With the opening of the New York racing season at Jamaica only twenty-six days away, the Metropolitan Jockey Club has some trouble on its hands. A city sewage pipe running under the racing strip has cracked. The repair job, which probably will be started today, is likely to take a couple of weeks and interfere with workouts.

TUCSON, Ariz., March 7 (AP) A. Perry Osborn, first vice president and trustee of the American Museum of Natural History, died last night at a local guest ranch twenty-four hours after he returned from a visit in San Francisco with his daughter. His age was 67.

The appointment of Vice Admiral Calvin Thornton Durgin, U.S.N., as president of the State University Maritime College at Fort Schuyler, the Bronx, was announced here yesterday by Dr. Alvin C. Eurich, president of the State University of New York.

WASHINGTON, March 7 The Senate Foreign Relations and Armed Services Committees approved in principle today the dispatch of American troops to Europe, without Congressional limitations, to serve in an international force to defend the West.

WASHINGTON, March 7 Organized labor's quarrel with the conduct of the defense program seemed likely today to become a drawn-out feud between the labor leaders and Charles E. Wilson, Director of Defense Mobilization.
Spring designs by Mollie Parnis for De Pinna were shown yesterday at a luncheon in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.
Stepping gingerly into the field of prognostication, more than a score of economists and business executives delivered speeches on as many subjects yesterday to an audience of about 700 analysts.

PARIS, March 7 Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, said at the Big Four deputies session this afternoon that his Government would be prepared to include the subject of Austria on the agenda for a proposed Council of Foreign Ministers meeting...

Rolling up a total of 83 points, Fordham won seven of ten first places to capture the team championship of the sixth annual Metropolitan College Swimming Association in New York University's John J. Quigley Memorial pool last night.
The New York Port of Embarkation, at Fifty-eighth Street in Brooklyn, is just completing a year's operation under the military unification program and it's thriving. Security considerations...
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 7 (UP) Dr. Henry Solon Graves, retired dean of the Yale forestry school and former chief of the United States Forestry Service,...
BUENOS AIRES, March 7 (AP) Employes of the Government-closed newspaper, La Prensa, asked President Juan Peron today to intervene personally to guarantee their right to work.
SINGAPORE, March 7 (AP) The price of Malayan tin skidded sharply today on news that the United States Government was suspending immediately all new purchases of tin for stockpiling.
F. Hugh Herbert's latest comedy, "The Moon Is Blue," will make its debut this evening at Henry Miller's Theatre. The curtain will rise at 8 o'clock.

Emil Bergen, a New York investor, was the successful bidder for the six-story apartment house containing forty-six suites at 14 Caryl Avenue, Yonkers, N.Y., in a recent auction at White Plains before Supreme Court Justice Frank H. Coyne. He was represented at the sale by Thomas S. Burke, Inc., Yonkers brokers.

Miss Judith Anne Dunnington, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Grey Dunnington of 812 Park Avenue, has completed plans for her marriage to Samuel Parkman Peabody of New York, son of the Right Rev. and Mrs. Malcolm Endicott Peabody of Syracuse, N.Y. The wedding will take place March 31 in St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, with a reception at the Colony Club.
The Government told a jury in Federal Court here yesterday that it would produce evidence that the three defendants in this nation's first atom bomb spy trial had conspired to steal and...

WASHINGTON, March 7 Walter L. Dunham, 69-year-old retired Detroit banker and a director of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, testified under oath today that he entered public office in 1949 unschooled in the Washington way of life and now con-. cluded that he had been "used" by friends in official matters that have led to Congressional investigation.

The nation's known reserves of crude oil and natural gas liquids at the close of last year were at a new peak of 29,536,061,000 barrels, according to a joint report issued yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute and the American Gas Association This represented an increase of 1,157,560,000 barrels over the 28,278,501,000 at the end of 1949.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 7 Israeli army units have been in action throughout the last fortyeight hours against large bands of armed Arabs numbering several hundred men who had crossed into Israeli territory from Jordan in the neighborhood of Hebron, it was announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission reported to Congress today that interlocking relationships among directors of the 1,000 largest United States manufacturing corporations evade the intent of the anti-trust laws and threaten free competition.

WASHINGTON, March 7 The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 28, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

The murder of Premier Ali Razmara of Iran is one of those acts of political madness which appear to punctuate our turbulent age with increasing frequency, but which continue to shock and arouse the civilized world, which can never tolerate government by assassination, no matter by whom attempted.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 7 Because of unfavorable test preview responses to "The Red Badge of Courage" in ordinary West Coast chain theatres, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has postponed release of the picture and will show it nationally in "art theatres" with a special booking and advertising policy.
Nat Kalech, formerly Western regional sales manager for Bymart, Inc., has been appointed general sales manager for Tintair, home hair coloring preparation.
