HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 9 (AP) Miss Beverly Baker of Santa Monica, Calif., won the women's singles in the Coral Beach Club invitation tennis tournament today, while Vic Seixas of Philadelphia and Straight Clark of Pasadena, Calif., advanced to the men's final.

THE cure for worrying about the state of the modern novel is to read more modern novels. The people who think the novel long since went to hell in a handbasket should fill a basket with this year's new books.
Edward C. Maguire resigned yesterday as director of the city's Division of Labor Relations and as Acting Commissioner of Commerce, effective next Thursday.

Even though he has to hustle out to Milwaukee tonight to renew his mile rivalry with Don Gehrmann, Fred Wilt did not spare the horses last night in his 1951 indoor farewell here. The 30-year-old F.B.I. man from the New York A.C. galloped two miles in 9:03.7 to provide the highlight of the fourth annual Pioneer Club games.

LONDON, March 9 A bill for the liberalization of Britain's divorce law was passed for the second time by the House of Commons today despite the Labor Government's attempt to sidetrack it and after its sponsor had sought to withdraw it.

A proposal for a city payroll tax as a substitute for any increase in the sales tax was put forward last night by Borough President Robert F. Wagner Jr. of Manhattan. He attacked the sales impost as "a vicious tax" upon those "least able to pay."
TOKYO, Saturday, March 10--The Chinese Communists pulled back yesterday on the central Korean front in what appeared to be a general withdrawal before the United Nations offensive.

PARIS, March 9 Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, warned the Western powers today that the Soviet Union could not accept any agenda for a proposed meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers that did not include explicit guarantees

The stock market struck a fairly even balance yesterday. Trading continued at a reduced pace and price changes were minor except in a few instances. Indicative of the lack of activity was the fact that the composite rate only rose 0.17 point on the day.
KEY WEST, Fla., March 9 Dr. Alan T. Waterman, technical director of the Office of Naval Research, has been selected by President Truman to be the first director of the National Science Foundation.

WESTERN stockmen who now graze their cattle on pub lic lands for a minute fee, often at the expense of wildlife and conservation, are not satisfied with the use of a public resource. They seek to control it, and have now drafted legislation to this purpose.

PANAMA, March 9--Former President Ricardo Adolfo de la Guardia was arrested early this morning by members of the secret police and held in a cell at headquarters until he was transferred to Santo Tomas Hospital this afternoon at his own request, it was reported.
SALT LAKE CITY, March 9 Utah's Legislature concluded a stormy sixty-day session early this morning, leaving economy-minded Gov. J. Bracken Lee at least temporary victor in a battle over school costs.
LONDON, March 9 Two men of similar background but of different temperament were involved tonight in the biggest Cabinet change since the Labor Government came to power in 1945.

TEHERAN, Iran, March 9 (AP) Fadayan Islam, fanatical secret Moslem terror society, threatened today to kill Shah Mohammed Pahlevi and other Government officals if the assassin of Premier Ali Razmara was not free in three days.
HARRISBURG, Pa., March 9 (AP) Gov. John S. Fine, other state officials, business and labor leaders have joined in a protest against the building of the proposed St. Lawrence Seaway.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 9 If there is one strategic plan with which the Giants' board of masterminds is in complete accord, it is that the club must break from the barrier at top speed this spring and keep going.

MELBOURNE, March 9 Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies has called a Cabinet meeting for Monday to consider the Government's course in respect to the Australian High Court's action in declaring invalid the Federal act outlawing the Communist party.

WASHINGTON, March 9(AP) The Food and Drug Administration said today it had seized a shipment of blackstrap molasses and health books, including the best-selling "Look Younger, Live Longer," as violating the pure food laws.

Inquiries among the big three automotive manufacturers and their advertising agencies here yesterday indicate that so far there have been no serious cuts in advertising schedules due to the huge volume of defense orders on all their books.

ALBANY, March 9 The WicksMailler bill to double the penalty for bribing participants in athletic contests, which has the backing of Governor Dewey, passed the Senate unanimously today and was sent to the Assembly.
MIAMI, Fla., March 9 Gil Hodges, the Dodgers' expert first baseman and still expectant father, put on his Brooklyn suit and worked out for the first time today under a blazing sun at Miami Stadium.

Conflicts between truck and rail interests throughout the country are "taking their toll of national security," H. W. Dodge, executive vice-president of Mack Trucks, Inc., said yesterday at a press luncheon at the Metropolitan Club.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 9 Linda Darnell, who is free under her new one-picture-a-year contract at Twentieth Century-Fox to take outside engagements, will play opposite Stephen McNally in Universal - International's "The Lady Pays Off," a comedy about a young school teacher who decides her life is too sheltered and takes up with a bid city gambler.

WASHINGTON, March 9 The Office of Price Stabilization ordered today a rollback in soap manufacturers' prices to December levels to effect a saving of one cent a bar in prices paid by consumers for soap and an estimated two cents a box for packaged soaps. Consumers, according to officials, spend an estimated $500,000,000 on soap.

There was reason to explore, in the usual Congressional processes, the proposal to make a grant of food grain to India. The exploration has taken place. The testimony has been heard. The imperative need has been established. It is time now for action before it is too late. Famine will not wait.

WASHINGTON, March 9 The Republican leaders of the House of Representatives will try to force the Administration, by law, to suspend all plans to send American troops to Europe until Congress as a whole has approved.

BELGRADE, March 9--The Yugoslav Foreign Ministry published today a 481-page White Book containing evidence of the Soviet bloc's aggressive activities against Yugoslavia in the last three years and a detailed analysis of military preparations by the Cominform armies.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 9 The Rev. George Sauvage, C.S.C., procurator general in Rome of the Roman Catholic Congregation of the Holy Cross for twenty-eight years, retiring because of ill health, died yesterday in the Community Infirmary at Notre Dame.

The McCarran Internal Security Act of 1950 will bar 100,000 otherwise eligible displaced persons from entering the United States, John W. Gibson, chairman of the United States. Displaced Persons Commission, said yesterday.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 9 Casey Stengel admitted today that he is going to miss Tommy Henrich around first base. Even the crippled version of the Massillon Macer who hobbled through the 1950 campaign before writing finis to an illustrious career as a Yankee would be a welcome addition to the regular squad.

NEWARK, March 9 There are 7,500,000 jobs in American industry and offices which can be transferred to mechanized operations within two to four years, Dr. Luther Gulick, authority on organization and management, said today at a conference on industrial engineering and industrial relations.

Mayor Impellitteri declared yesterday in his annual message to the City Council that his administration could cope with the rising cost of city government only through increased state aid and heavier local taxation.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (UP) Earl Browder, one-time leader of the Communist party, had no luck today in efforts to subpoena seven Senators and one former Senatorincluding Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin to testify at his contempt-of-Congress trial.
NEW DELHI, March 9 (AP)?--Japan's well-conditioned athletes outfought ten other nations today to move into first place again in the Asian games on the basis of unofficial scores.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 9 (AP) Sammy Snead and Jim Ferrier matched the competitive record for the Normandy Isle golf course today to a tie for the lead at the halfway point in the $10,000 Miami Beach open.
The Air Force brought into New York yesterday for the week-end a couple of striking examples of its glamour to publicize recruitment into that service. However, the examples, Cpl.

NEW ORLEANS, March 9 Charles Austin O'Niell, formerly for more than twenty-seven years Chief Justice of the Louisiana State Supreme Court, died early yesterday morning in his hotel room in New Orleans. His age was 81.

Dr. Henry Erying, dean of the University of Utah Graduate School, was honored by the American Chemical Society last night for fundamental studies explaining the mechanism of chemical reactions, the basis of all life.
The Celanese Corporation has under consideration the sale of new issues of securities totaling perhaps $200,000,000.

The most important news in the season's fifteenth performance of "Fledermaus" at the Metropolitan Opera last night was the appearance by Regina Resnik in the role of Rosalinda. This was the American soprano's first chance at the part, and she distinguished herself in it.

Hearings on the Long Island Rail Road's proposal for two new safety devices were postponed by the Public Service Commission yesterday to provide time for conferences between the road and the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, independent.

PHILADELPHIA, March 9 Alastair Bradley Martin of Glen Head, L.I., will defend his national amateur court tennis championship at the Racquet Club tomorrow against William E. Lingelbach of Philadelphia, runner-up a year ago.
Representative Jacob K. Javits warned last night against the Government's manner of dealing with our civil liberties and urged political action to safeguard American civil liberties.

WASHINGTON, March 9--Rapid extension of uniform traffic laws to reduce highway accident potentials created by the national emergency was urged today by Sidney J. Williams, assistant to the president of the National Safety Council. Apprehensions over international conditions have caused thousands of drivers to adopt reckless attitudes, he said.

Flower arrangements in competition and demonstrations have renewed interest in the International Flower Show at Grand Central Palace every day this week. Fresh table settings and arrangements will be made this morning and may be seen until the show closes at 10:30 P.M. tonight.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, March 9 Danish canned hams are "dollar earners." Denmark values them as a means of obtaining "hard currency," and in its shipments to the United States this Year hopes to exceed the 8,000,000 pounds it exported in 1950.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 9 (AP) Gen. Baron Alexander von Falkenhausen, 72 years old, Germany's wartime military commander of occupied Belgium, and Gen. Eggert Reeder, the civilian administrator, were sentenced today to twelve years' hard labor for war crimes.
WASHINGTON, March 9 Average primary market prices advanced 0.3 per cent in the week ended on March 6, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Mayor Impellitteri has been in office for a little over six months, and his annual message delivered yesterday to the City Council confines itself largely to making a report on that period.
Consolidated net sales of the Electric Storage Battery Company last year amounted to $91,734,046, second highest in its history, and 3 per cent over the $89,142,957 volume for 1949.

Miss Cecile Parker, daughter of King L. Parker of St. Louis and the late Mrs. d'Assern Parker of New York, was married to John A.H. Carver, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford N. Carver of Locust Valley, L.I., and Searsport, Me., yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest.

Cherry, lemon, huckleberry and strawberry pies covered with mountains of whipped cream were mashed into the grinning faces of three faculty members, student leaders, and two girls from a rival college yesterday afternoon as New York University staged its annual "Pie Fling."

TRENTON, March 9 Night sessions starting Monday were ordered by Superior Court Judge Ralph J. Smalley today as the retrial of six men accused of the 1948 hold-up murder of a shopkeeper here reached the end of the first week with only six jurors chosen of the fourteen needed.

Except for Brigham Young, North Carolina State and Arizona, which arrive today and tomorrow, all hands in the fourteenth annual National Invitation college basketball tournament, starting today at Madison Square Garden, were accounted for yesterday.

February dollar volume of local home furnishings credit stores decreased 1.4 per cent from the same month last year, chiefly because of the effects of Regulation W, according to James B. McMahon Jr., executive vice president of the Associated Furniture Dealers of New York. Compared with February, 1949, volume rose 8.4 per cent.
Tin prices declined sharply again yesterday in further reaction to the Government's recent decision to suspend stockpiling of the metal until prices should reach a more reasonable level.

Rex Layne with one right-hand explosion set up a knockout ending that provided one of the greatest boxing thrills of the local ring season. Opposing Bob Satterfield of Chicago in the star bout of ten rounds, the Lewiston, Utah, heavyweight scored an eight-round victory that came as a sudden surprise to the spectators at Madison Square Garden last night.

In its first change of ownership since 1885, the three-story private home at 357 East Sixty-second Street has been sold by hire. Ethel H. Remple to a buyer for occupancy in a deal negotiated by Pease Elliman, Inc., brokers.
The Government bond market's second day on a wholly free basis resulted yesterday in prices receding somewhat from the levels of Thursday.
Robert O. Bullard has been named manager of manufacturing of the tube division of the General Electric Company's electronics department.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 9 The Bethlehem Steel Corporation has released an option to take over the proposed $250,000,000 steel mill project in the New London-Waterford area. It did so after it had received an "unfavorable" evaluation report from a New York engireering firm.
Broadening of Government controls on importation of major strategic materials is near, it was hinted here yesterday by an official of the Office of Price Stabilization.

The Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C. I. O., has concluded new wage agreements with two more New York ship repair companies. Negotiations have been completed for the Todd Shipyards Corporation's two local yards and with Ira S. Bushey Sons, Inc.
The official Yugoslav accusation yesterday that the Soviet Union and its satellites are applying "military pressure" against her focuses attention again upon the threat to world peace in this area.

LONDON, March 9 The stock markets here continued dull today. The only real weakness, however, was in the commodity-share groups, especially the oil shares, which were depressed by the move in Iran to nationalize the AngloIranian Oil Company.

Ernie Hughes, the postman whose daily arrival is one of the few bright spots in the life of 6-year-old Robert Hiftline, made a special stop yesterday at the boy's home in Jasper, Mich. Mr. Hughes had 185 pieces of mail for Bobby.

TANGIER, March 9 Police served a summons today on Allal el Fassi, Istiqlal leader, to appear tomorrow before mixed international tribunal on charges of violating Article 10 of the basic Tangier statute. This article prohibits any agitation that might disturb the peace in other zones of Morocco or foreign countries.

WASHINGTON, March 9 The Securities and Exchange Commission authorized the Utah Power and Light Company, Salt Lake City, today to borrow through 1951 an aggregate of $12,000,000 from banks. The loans are to be made on 2 per cent promissory notes to be issued by the power company and payable on Dec. 15, next.
The late Dwight Deere Wiman's production of "Romeo and Juliet," starring Olivia de Havilland in her first Juliet, opens at the Broadhurst Theatre tonight at 8:30 o'clock.

Dr. Oscar Agnew Spier, who had practiced medicine here for fifty years, died after a heart attack Thursday night at his home, 1200 Fifth Avenue. He had spent the afternoon in his office at 1143 Fifth Avenue.

An emergency appendectomy prevented Frank S. O'Hara from personally receiving a scroll from Mayor Vincent R. Impellitteri yesterday at the luncheon session of the New York State Society of Real Estate Appraisers at the Hotel Astor.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 9 (AP) Jaroslav Drobny, veteran internationalist from Egypt, scored a stunning 6-0, 6-3, 6-4 upset over Dick Savitt of Orange, N.J., today in the semi-final round of the Egyptian tennis tournament.

Reopening of the cotton exchanges has been a signal for renewal of cotton textiles sales in the Worth Street area. The volume of sales, however, is somewhat restricted by two factors, textile men said. These are limitation of sales more than ninety days ahead and a cautious attitude on the part of buyers.

More than 100 church leaders will participate next month in a "strategy" conference on the relation of American Protestantism to President Truman's Point Four program for technical assistance to underdeveloped areas.
CLEVELAND, March 9 (AP) Two pole vaulters cleared 15 feet 1 inch tonight and Lenny Truex of Ohio State upset Don Gehrmann in the mile run at the Knights of Columbus' track meet.
Two deputy chief inspectors were among the twenty-five members of the Police Department who reported yesterday to the holdover grand jury in Brooklyn to receive financial questionnaires.

GENOA, Italy, Feb. 20 The administration of this city and the dock workers of its port, which not only is the second largest in the Mediterranean but of vital strategic importance for the defense of Italy, are under absolute Communist control.

WASHINGTON, March 9 The Senate, by a vote of 79 to 5, passed and sent to the House today the military manpower bill, including provisions to lower the draft age to 18 and to require service of twenty-four months.

The six-story apartment house for fifty-two families on plot 111 by 100 feet at 2084-86 Creston Avenue, northeast corner of 180th Street, the Bronx, was sold by the Parkcrest Realty Company to a client of Simon Panush, attorney.

ALBANY, March 9 Two moves were under way today to overcome the effects of yesterday's decision by the Court of Appeals in the Jockey Club case. The ruling outlawed licensing powers that the Jockey Club exercised in the field of racing with the consent of the State Racing Commission.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 9 (AP) Favored Penn State bounced back after a shaky start tonight to place five men in the semi-final round of the forty-seventh annual Eastern intercollegiate wrestling championships.

The national ratings of 1,300 student newspapers and magazines represented at the twenty-seventh annual convention of the Columbia Scholastic Press Association were announced yesterday, making the meeting's second day an exciting one for the 3,200 delegates.

WASHINGTON, March 9 Eric Johnston, Economic Stabilization Administrator, promised the country tonight that some prices would be rolled back, but warned that a general rollback order might wreck the economy.

MADRID, March 9 (UP) Lieut. Gen. Gonzalo Queipo de Llano, world famous as the "broadcasting general" during the Spanish civil war, died today in Seville, which he captured for the Nationalists by bluff with a handful of men. His age was 76.

RANGOON, Burma, March 9 Dr. Gordon Seagrave, American "Burma Surgeon" who was sentenced Jan. 17 to six years imprisonment for aiding rebel tribesmen, was freed today by the Burmese Court of Appeal after having served seven months in Rangoon's Central Jail.

DALLAS, March 8 The Dallas Fashion Market has a flavor all its own, as proven by the showings given the past week for visiting fashion editors who came from many parts of the country for the market's first Press Week.

BUENOS AIRES, March 10-- Recent events in Argentina, including the run-around given Edward G. Miller Jr., the United States Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, on his visit here, have again raised the question as to just how strong Gen. Juan Domingo Peron is.

Rare art objects donated by leading galleries, decorators and private collectors will be sold at auction at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue, on the night of April 10 for the benefit of the Play Schools Association.

BEGINNING next month, the American National Theatre and Academy will undertake the public phase of its cur rent fund-raising campaign designed to aid it in advancing the ideals for which the organization was established under a Congressional charter in 1935.

WILMINGTON, Del. March 10-- In the Westminister Presbyterian Church here this afternoon, Miss. Margaret Alice Milliken, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mahlon G. Milliken of Wilmington, was married to Ralph Warren Tyson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund H. Tyson of Lake Bluff, Ill.

PARIS, March 10--The Western powers revised today their draft for a proposed foreign ministers agenda and submitted a new version in the hopes it might facilitate an agreement at this somewhat stagnant deputies conference.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 10 --Big Jim Ferrier battled par, a stiff east wind and plenty of competitive pressure today to take a one-stroke lead in the $10,000 Miami Beach Open golf tournament.

MILLIS, Mass., March 10--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frank Ames Royce of Spring Meadows Farm of the engagement of their daughter, Janet, to Ensign Richard Waldo Conant, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Goldsmith Conant of Ridgewood, N.J.
A Hunter College junior has recently surprised psychology professors by developing a visual retention test for prospective art students.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 10 (AP) --Most of the juvenile racing stars of last season were listed today among the 122 nominations for the 1951 Kentucky derby.
These were some of the things President Truman did in Key West during last week--the first week of a projected twenty-three-day vacation:

The Soviet Union is trying to destroy the moral unity of the free world with "misleading" propaganda that the current world crisis is merely an "old-fashioned struggle for power" between her and this country, Ernest A. Gross, ...

The increasingly popular philosophy in this country that puts security ahead of opportunity to advance in a job is having a pronounced effect on the manpower problems of manufacturers' and wholesalers' selling organizations.
MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., March 10 (AP)--The mystery surrounding a set of big drills operating in a blueberry patch near here was solved today.
The current Senate investigation of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for the most part has revolved around five cases.
HONG KONG, March 10--Two kinds of China are projected in first-head reports arriving here from the mainland.

The Senate has taken an important forward step in its approval of the military manpower bill. It is significant that only five votes were cast in opposition on the final balloting. Our senior lawmakers are obviously convinced that we have no alternative but to make ourselves militarily strong, and they have acted accordingly.

AWINDBREAK is defined as "a clump of trees or shrubs serving to break the force of the wind; hence any pro tective shelter from the wind, as a fence or the like." In terms of practical usage, windbreaks are small, closely spaced groups of trees that are two to five rows wide.

NEW ENGLAND childhoods at the turn of the century continue to furnish the material for pleasant volumes of reminiscence.
Dr. Matford M. Mathews is in town, full of amazing bits of information about hooch, shooflies, widow's walks, mugwumps, and thousands of other Americanisms.
ROCHESTER--At the Dryden Theatre dedicatory ceremony held here recently a tribute was paid by Capt. Edward Steichen to the millions of amateurs who use their cameras to record simple expressions.

Sharp drops in retail sales of refrigerators and other appliances covered by the stiff credit terms of Regulation W will lead to substantial increases in sales of furnaces and other large home heating appliances.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (UP) --The Food and Drug Administration said today that blackstrap molasses would not do everything for the health that Gayelord Hauser's best-seller "Look Younger, Live Longer" said it would do.

HONG KONG, March 10--Dr. Stewart Allen, veteran director of a Canadian mission hospital at Chungking, and Calvin Bright, museum curator of the West China Union University at Chengtu, were reported today to have been arrested by Chinese Communist authorities in Szechwan Province.
CAIRO, March 10 (Reuters)-- Jefferson Caffery, United States Ambassador to Egypt, today visited Foreign Minister Mohamed Salah el Din Pasha and counseled "moderation" over events in Morocco.

A number of major advertisers, keenly interested in color television as a device for showing their wares to best advantage, are to see this week what the new development offers as a merchandising tool.

In the expansion of its cooperative housing development in the Bronx, the Amalgamated Housing Corporation completed a twelvestory and penthouse building containing 151 suites which will receive first occupants on March 19.

LONDON, March 10--The resignation of Ernest Bevin and the appointment of Herbert Morrison as Foreign Secretary implies no change in British foreign policy Prime Minister Attlee asserted today at a Labor party rally.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 10 (AP)--Although two of their top performers were left home, the Yale swimmers today registered their seventy-first consecutive dual meet victory today, submerging Harvard, 51--24.

This country is indebted to John W. Gibson, chairman of the Government's Displaced Persons Commission, for removing the obscurity from the question of the impact of the Internal Security Act of 1950 upon the flow of displaced persons to this country.
MIAMI, Fla., March 10--Major league owners were gathering here today ostensibly to find the answer to the question: Who will be the next commissioner of baseball?

An experiment in the field of nutrition, said to be the most comprehensive ever undertaken on an international, cooperative scale, is now in progress at the International Institute of Nutrition of Central America and Panama in Guatemala City.

TOKYO (by Wireless). AFTER six months of sweeping up and down the scorched, shell-pocked Korean peninsula, the opposing Communist and United Nations forces grapple in a war of thrust and parry. THE eightieth annual New England Spring Flower Show of the Massachusetts Horticultural Society will open today at 1 P.M. in Mechanics Building, Boston. Plants from many countries will occupy a total of six acres of space. The show will be open to the public until 10 P.M. today, and from 10 A.M. to 10 P.M. daily through Saturday.

THREE major movie companies are running a close race to acquire film rights to "Sad Sack," the be knighted G.I., whose gentlemanly ineptitude is depicted in George Baker's cartoon strips, which first appeared in the Army magazine "Yank."
OF painting, Andre Malraux writes: "When our con temporaries wish to ban poetry from painting, what is it they realty wish to ban? Painting...

FACING the dissolution of his Tory world with the same aplomb with which he has handled the details of its Victorian heydays, Humphrey Pakington has written a new novel that is a pinch of snuff to be taken just before guillotine-time.

A week ago the Secretary of the Treasury and the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board issued a joint statement to the effect that they had reached accord in the matter of reconciling their policies in the field of debt management and credit control.

SYRACUSE, March 10 (AP)--Religious cooperation on the Syracuse University campus received a mortal blow as a result of the Kirtley Mather incident, the Rev. Gannon F. Ryan, Roman Catholic chaplain at the university, said here this week.

WINTER travelers to the South are bound to notics that many trees are hung with long shreds of hoary gray. This drapery is a plant known as Spanish or Florida moss, long moss, tree moss or tree beard. Since it is light enough to be blown about by the wind, bunches may even hang from power lines.
LONDON, March 10--Control of the Mediterranean, a senior Allied officer remarked the other day, would be absolutely essential to the Western powers in the event of a war in Europe.

Louis Van Thielen, once an interior decorator in Chicago, visited THE NEW YORK TIMES office last week on his way back to his 1,300acre farm in the Belgian Congo, which he said is unusually free from the inter-racial strife that is increasing in many other parts of Africa.

Recommendations aimed at strengthening civil liberties and promoting closer inter-group relations in this country were offered yesterday at the closing sessions of a two-day conference on civil liberties held at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West Sixty-fourth Street.

A new colony of ranch style dwellings with three or four bedrooms and priced at $17,350 is being formally opened today in New Milford, N.J., by Joseph Raymond, builder. The development is off the Boulevard, four blocks east of River Road.
THE literary year, like that of the theatre, customarily be gins with the end of summer. "Gone With the Wind," to be sure, was published in August, but that was an exception.
WASHINGTON, March 10--The basic problem in Washington today is how to turn Uncle Sam, a good sprinter, into a marathon runner.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 10--The Government of the Union of South Africa has rejected the United Nations General Assembly's proposals for negotiation to improve the treatment of persons of Indian origin under the Union's racial segregation and discrimination policy.
TWO of Trans World Airlines' top overseas officials have predicted that the volume of international travel will be as great this year as last, "if not greater."

WASHINGTON. IF Presidents were judged only by their sense of the dramatic, by the impression they gave of consciously making history. Harry Truman would no doubt be assigned a niche somewhere between Calvin Coolidge and Rutherford B. Hayes.

WITH THE FIRST MARINES, in Korea, March 10--Snow and rain during the last ten days have turned Central Korea into a quagmire.

AMERICAN tourists entering Canada at a number of points last week found that progress had been made in cutting red tape at the border, Canadian customs and immigration inspections having been combined.

THE Scandinavian-American Foundation, of which Lith gow Osborne is president, has instituted a Music Center which, in the words of David Hall, its director, aims "to serve as an information and publicizing medium for Scandinavian music in America, and, as a secondary function, that of aiding Scandinavians, both abroad and visiting here in America, to obtain information with respect to American music and musicians."
The nation's cotton exchanges began operating last week under a specific price-ceiling order by the United States Government for the first time in history.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 10-- Miss. Alma Consuelo Munoz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Redman Munoz, was married in the First Congregational Church here tonight to Edward Ager Condit Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Condit of East Orange, formerly of Montclair.

CHICAGO, March 10 (UP)--A tall, well-dressed gunman killed one man and wounded three others today in a tavern shooting that the police said might have been intended to thwart the Senate Crime Investigating Committee's study of the policy racket.
DETECTIVE Champion Prescott detrains at Nantucket like Joseph's Vineyard for a rest.
The University of Miami's record in the national intercollegiate indoor polo championship is one which any school would be proud to own.

A continuing supply of funds for mortgage investments, and a stable mortgage market this year, "despite many confusing factors," was predicted by Jay I. Kislak, secretary of the J.I. Kislak Mortgage Corporation of Jersey City.

Department store sales last week were estimated at about 12 per cent above the 1950 week. The weather was good most of the week and spring apparel promotions drew good response. A successful Easter season was indicated.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 10 (AP)--Yale's basketball captain, Eddie McHugh, and his team-mate, Bob Harding, combined tonight in the final seconds for the needed two points as the Elis whipped Harvard, 72--70, in the season's finale for both teams.

THERE is good listening to be had from a new series of R.C.A. Victor 45 r.p.m. singles. Each of several popular singers has been chosen to represent a composer or lyric writer and has recorded a few of his favorite songs of yesteryear.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP)-- A Senate Internal Security subcommittee has started a far-reaching new search for Communists in the Government, including the armed forces.

OF the six productions put on so far it the Anta Playhouse series, three have been worth doing and have been done well--Judith Anderson in "The Tower Beyond Tragedy," Gloria Swanson and Jose Ferrer in "Twentieth Century" and now Barrie's "Mary Rose."

One of the most ambitious ventures in connection with Great Lakes shipping is rapidly taking form, and some large ocean-going vessels that have been "transplanted" from deep sea trades probably will be seen on the lakes this summer.

The campaign for Federal aid to education was renewed last week on two broad fronts--in Washington and in New York. In the capital Senator Lister Hill, Democrat of Alabama, long a vigorous advocate of Federal aid, warned the Senate that poor schools were impeding the defense effort.

THE conductor does his job by getting the hundred men of his orchestra to do theirs. He does not scrape a string instrument, blow into a woodwind or a brass or pound a percussion instrument. He just waves his hands and arms, flashes his eyes and gestures with his body. He should be seen, not heard, although a Toscanini sometimes cannot suppress his hoarse-voiced tones as they accompany the song of the orchestra.

For the first time in many years an apartment house has been built in Harlem for families in the neighborhood's higher-income group. The building, known as Ivey Terrace, is nearing completion at 17-19 Hamilton Terrace, near West 141st Street.

HOW does a European musician get launched in this country? If he or she has won the favor of a big-time manager, the chances are that a number of dates have been secured in advance, for local managers and orchestras will engage some unheard artists on the recommendation of impresarios they trust.

Motorola, Inc., television, radio and communications manufacturer, had a rise last year of 142 per cent in earnings and 116 per cent in sales over 1949, the annual report showed yesterday.

James C. The other music on the program was a suite arranged by d'Indy from Rameau's "Dardanus," two of the Debussy, "Nocturnes" and Albert Roussel's Third Symphony.

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregular yesterday and volume slackened. Final prices were at the ceiling for March and May, but July closed 10 points higher, while other months were 10 to 21 points lower than on Tuesday.

The Welfare Council of New York City has formed a committee for the armed forces. Carl M. Loeb Jr., a board member of the council at 44 East Twenty-third Street, will head the committee. Mayor Impellitteri will be honorary chairman.

BERLIN, March 14--Otto Grotewohl, Premier of East Germany, rejected today the proposal of Dr. Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of West Germany, for simultaneous elections throughout the country under Big Four supervision.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 14--A new jet engine, described as the most powerful and economical power plant of its type to be approved for mass production, was unveiled here today by the Allison Division of the General Motors Corporation.

CHICAGO, March 14--General liquidation developed in the grain markets on the Board of Trade today and closing trades were about at bottom, with professional sentiment bearish as the result of failure of rallies to be sustained.

The Departure of Agriculture's Suggestion that housewives make frequent use of the plentiful supply of dried beans refers to the familiar varieties. Such legumes as red kidney, pinto and Great Northern, all averaging 20 cents a pound are one of the most economical protein purchases now available.
William J. McCowan and Alexander A. Delle Cese, operators, bought the five-story apartment house on lot 38 by 100 feet at 436 East 141st Street, the Bronx, which is assessed at $33,000.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, March 14 (AP)--Britain today broadened the government of Malaya to include Malays, a Chinese and a Ceylonese in a Central Cabinet, previously manned by Europeans only.
North Atlantic passenger steamship officials are preparing to close the books on the most successful winter cruise season since before the war.

TRENTON, March 14--The jury in the retrial of six men accused of the 1948 killing of a Trenton shopkeeper was completed late this afternoon. A recess was taken until 9:30 A.M. Saturday, when state and defense attorneys will make opening statements. The first witness will not be called until Monday.

Comments on the status of the stock market by brokerage houses are somewhat veiled these days. Many would find it difficult to measure the significance of a real break-through should it occur. Some chartists think the market

ALBANY, March 14--The Assembly approved today a Democratic-sponsored bill that would strip the Chief Magistrate of New York City of power to remove court employes and vest it in the Board of City Magistrates.

WASHINGTON, March 14--The Air Force, short of second lieutenants, announced today that it would order to active duty all Air Force Reserve Officer Training Corps students graduating from college this year. These will total about 8,100.
Elegance and taste marked the spring and summer fur collection presented yesterday at Revillon Freres, 11 West Fifty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, March 14--The White House was "quite wrong" in giving the country the impression that the railway operating unions had walked out on an agreement intended to settle the 2-year wage dispute between the railroads and the unions, Senator Wayne Morse, Republican of Oregon, declared today.

ALBANY, March 14--The supplemental budget bill, with additional appropriations of $56,185,490 beyond the main budget bills approved last month, was passed by the Senate today and sent to the Assembly.
Judge Harold R. Medina asked Government counsel in the investment banking anti-trust trial yesterday to withdraw from the Government's complaint that part of the conspiracy charge allegedly

Mills of the American Woolen Company, closed by a strike for the last three weeks, will resume operation on Monday, it was learned yesterday. The shutdown during the strike made it impossible for the company to ship goods finished before the strike started. Shipments will be resumed on Monday, it was said.

ALBANY, March 14--The Senate approved today, 45 to 10, the bill designed to expedite the removal of public employes of doubtful loyalty or trustworthiness from "security" positions. The bill, approved by the Assembly yesterday, 115 to 28, now goes to the Governor.
CAMDEN, N.J., March 14--The R.C.A. Victor division of the Radio Corporation of America will begin a company-wide drive among rank-and-file employes tomorrow to conserve critical materials in

WASHINGTON, March 14--The railroads of the country received permission today from the Interstate Commerce Commission to increase freight rates on a temporary basis by an estimated $200,000,000 a year. Freight forwarders and water carriers also may increase their rates under the decision.

TOKYO, March 14--Japan is planning to send two missions-- one governmental and the other from the ranks of private business --to the United States to explore the possibilities of American aid and "economic cooperation" between the two nations after negotiation of a peace treaty.
GENEVA, March 14--United States policy, or at any rate United States practice, in stockpiling raw materials is causing increasing concern in Europe.

Signaling another climactic development in the Korean war, United Nations forces spearheaded by South Korean patrols have again entered the ancient capital of Seoul and the flag of the Korean Republic is again flying over the seat of the only legitimate Government in that country.

THE BOOK OF THE JAGUAR PRIEST: A Translation of the Book of Chilam Balam of Tizimin, with commentary by Maud Worcester Makemson (Henry Schuman, $3.50). An account of the legendary history, customs, prophecies and religion of the Maya Indians.
The city of Sacramento, Calif., sold yesterday $6,428,000 of municipal improvement bonds due on Jan. 1, 1952 to 1976, to the First National Bank of Chicago and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., on a

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 14-- The Soviet Union tried today to head off a United Nations inquiry into slave labor in Communist countries by proposing a worldwide investigation of working conditions, with special emphasis on the unemployment and workers in colonies.

ALBANY, March 14--Senate Republican leaders rejected flatly today a suggested compromise under which New York City would be given power to levy a payroll tax on employers at one-half of 1 per cent instead of the full 1 per cent requested.

WASHINGTON, March 14--The combined Senate Foreign Relations and Armed Services Committees appealed tonight for the early dispatch of American troops to Europe against the menace of a rising atomic bomb power in Russia.

WASHINGTON, March, 4 (AP)-- Following is the text of a letter from business and industry representatives to Eric Johnston, economic stabilizer, opposing a compromise proposal for the Wage Stabilization Board:
WASHINGTON, March 14 (U.P.) --The Senate approved a bill today to relax immigration barriers for otherwise qualified aliens who were involuntary members of totalitarian organizations.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14-- John Foster Dulles charged here tonight that the Soviet Union's refusal to resume discussion of a Japanese peace treaty was part of a 25-year-old Soviet plot to gain control of Asia by violence.

ALBANY, March 14--Former Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley is receiving $22,000 a year from the state, instead of the $16,000 previously announced, for his services as consultant to the Division of Veterans' Affairs.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 14-- President Truman announced today that he was making his own review of national water resources with the purpose of advancing the development of water control, irrigation and power projects both by executive action and new laws.
In the first change of ownership of the property in more than sixty years, two five-story apartment houses on plot 50 by 100 feet at 237-39 East Thirty-eighth Street

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 14--For a time this afternoon it looked as though the Giants, who flattened the Phillies in ten of their last eleven meetings in 1950, still held the winning combination over the National League champions.
Record gross operating income, refinery runs and refined products sales in 1950 marked the seventyfifth year of operations of the Continental Oil Company.

United States Government securities gave a good account of themselves yesterday. The market's fifth day on its own came to a close with fourteen of the Treasury's list of bonds and longer term notes showing price advances ranging from 1/32 of a point to 7/16 of a point.

WASHINGTON, March 14--The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended March 7:
TRENTON, March 14--A State Senate investigation was initiated tonight into the state police questioning of primary election candidates in Bergen County.

NEWARK, N.J., March 14-- The New Jersey Bell Telephone Company has taken 5,164 telephones out of service in the last ten years after receiving evidence that the instruments had been used for bookmaking purposes, William A. Hughes, president of the company, said tonight.

MANHASSET, L.I., March 14-- The engagement of Miss Mary Jean Pelkey to Randolph C. Blyth, son of Mrs. Arthur J. Blyth of Pensacola, Fla., and the late Mr. Blyth, has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Henry F. Pelkey. Plans have been made for a July wedding.
CHICAGO, March 14--Sales of electrical appliances would fall this year even if there were no metals restrictions to curtail output, Richard L. White, president

The liner Vulcania will go into drydock in Genoa today for repairs to steering gear, stern and superstructures damaged by exceptionally heavy seas during her last crossing from New York. She is expected to be out of service until April 22, when she will resume her normal Atlantic run.
Throughout yesterday morning a cloud of dark, heavy smoke trailed across Riverside Drive and over the Hudson River, marking an end to the Claremont Inn, a fabled landmark of the city's past.

Nearly as many conventions were held here last year as in 1939, when the World's Fair was an extra attraction, according to the annual report of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, Inc., issued yesterday. The bureau's activities have been increasingly successful over the last five years and promise a new peak for 1951, Bernard F. Gimbel, president and chairman, asserted.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 14 (AP)--Hampton Stable's Alerted, a cast off of Calumet Farm, captured the $5,000 Fountain of Youth Handicap at Gulfstream Park today.

The marriage of Miss Joan Lewin, daughter of Lieut, Col. George J. Lewin, U.S.A.F., and Mrs. Lewin of 1185 Park Avenue, to William L. Strauss 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Strauss of Woodmere, L.I., and New York, took place last night in the Garden of the Ambassador. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Judah Cahn.
Reserves of food, textiles, apparel and equippage for the armed forces are being kept within bounds by the Bureau of the Budget, Department of Defense and Military Committees of the House and Senate.

WASHINGTON, March 14--William H. White of Hyattsville, Md., an internationally known entomologist with the Department of Agriculture for thirty-seven years, died of a heart attack this morning while, on his way to work. He was with his brother, Richard O. White, when he was stricken. His age was 58.
WESTPORT, Conn., March 14-- George Hand Wright, dean of Westport artists, died last night at his home in Cross Highway. He was 78 years old.

Mrs. Ruth Prince Greenglass took the stand yesterday as the Government's fourth spy trial witness and corroborated in detail the story of wartime atomic espionage related earlier by her husband, David.

WASHINGTON, March 14-- Thomas B. McCabe, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, reminded all lending institutions today that "more drastic types of compulsory restraint" would be invoked by the Government unless the new voluntary plan of limiting credit to legitimate business purposes proved effective.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (U.P.)-- The Export-Import Bank plans to lend $30,000,000 to help finance a manganese mine in Brazil. This country no longer can get the strategic metal from Russia and manganese is now being imported principally from India and South Africa.

MIAMI, Fla., March 14--In one of their better played games, they Dodgers ran their winning streak to three games tonight as they otuscored the Reds, 3--2, under the Miami Stadium lights. All four of their games have been decided by one run, the opener a losing one to the Braves.

HONG KONG, March 14--The Peiping radio asserted tonight that four United States prisoners of war had been killed and fifteen wounded when their North Korea camp had come under a bombing and strafing attack in a raid by two American jets at 2:30 P.M. Feb. 19.

WASHINGTON, March 14--Exploratory talks with manufacturers concerning a proposed price regulation were opened here today by the Office of Price Stabilization. After an all-day conference, executives of the agency said that

In several of the finer restaurants here one of the popular luncheon dishes with men is hash. This indicates a masculine preference that may come as a surprise to many housewives who think of this dish as a kind of culinary last resort. Actually, a good hash has been held in high esteem by skilled cooks since Colonial times.

After playing "Springtime for Henry" for eighteen years throughout the rest of the country, Edward Everett Horton has finally brought it to New York, which adjoins America closely. He and three other actors opened in the Benn W.
COLUMBIA, S.C., March 14 (U.P.)--An anti-lynching bill making mob violence a capital crime passed its all-important second reading in the South Carolina House today.

Parke, Davis Co. showed net sales of $105,707,659 and net earnings of $17,864,830 for 1950, both the highest in the drug company's eighty-four-year history, according to the annual report for publication today.

WASHINGTON, March 14--Eric Johnston's month-long search for a formula to revive or replace the crippled Wage Stabilization Board apparently reached a dead-end today. The stabilization chief's indicated course is to wait and let natural economic pressures on labor and management do the job.

CHICAGO, March 14 (AP)--Johnny Bratton tonight won the National Boxing Association's version of the welterweight championship by defeating Charley Fusari in a blistering 15-round battle in the Chicago Stadium.

Presbyterian Hospital turned the clock back yesterday, the 100th birthday anniversary of the late Anna C. Maxwell. The observance was held in the residence hall of the hospital's school of nursing that bears her name.

BONN, Germany, March 14-- The West German Government handed to the Allied High Commission today a note that in effect demanded British approval of the implementation in Germany of the Schuman plan, already endorsed by the United States and France.

PARIS, March 14--In a brief and relatively constructive meeting of the foreign ministers' deputies today, Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko modified the Soviet Union's proposed... agenda draft. He said he was doing this in an effort to make it more acceptable to the Western powers.

The stock market was battered again yesterday by selling, of which a large part was concentrated in the last few minutes. Pressure was sufficiently intense in the concluding period to force the ticker tape behind actual floor

ALBANY, March 14--The Assembly passed and sent to Governor Dewey today the HughesBrees Unemployment Insurance Bill providing for increased benefits for jobless workers and lower payroll taxes for employers with stable employment records.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (U.P.) --The Defense Department reported a new Korean War casualty total today of 54,649, an increase of 2,201 over a week ago and the largest since mid-January.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (U.P.)-- Postmaster General Jesse M. Donaldson figures that his cutback of mail service to one-a-day home deliveries is saving the Government more than $80,000,000 a year.
Vernon Brooks, advertising director of the Scripps Howard newspapers, last night warmly defended present newspaper rates and the differentials between national and retail advertising.

WATERBURY, Conn., March 14 --Irving Hall Chase, industrialist, banker, civic and political leader, who was formerly president of the Waterbury Clock Company, died at his home here tonight at the age of 92.

William Perl, a 32-year-old Columbia University physics instructor and an outstanding specialist in aerodynamics, was arrested here last night by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on a sealed indictment charging perjury.

BARCELONA, Spain, March 14 --New trouble was believed looming here tonight as Spanish authorities ordered penalties against Barcelona workers who had carried out the first successful "general strike" during the Franco regime.

Speaking yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the women's committee of the United Negro College Fund, Dr. Peter Marshall Murray, a member of the house of delegates of the American Medical Association, said that of the nation's 176,000 doctors only 4,000, or 2 per cent, are Negroes, although Negroes comprise 8 per cent of the population.

At the close of yesterday's session of the Senate Crime Investigating Committee in the Federal Courthouse, Senator Estes Kefauver, its chairman, announced that the testimony of Frank Costello would be referred to the Department of Justice for possible indictment for perjury.

In celebration of the 2,000th anniversary of the city of Paris, the Cultural Division of the French Embassy, 934 Fifth Avenue, is opening an exhibition today illustrating the development and spirit of the beloved French capital.

The New York City Opera Company, which has slowly and steadily fixed a safe niche for itself in the town's musical life, opened its spring season last night, apparently unperturbed that its larger neighbor down on Thirty-ninth
The Ethical Culture Society of Long Island has contracted to purchase the former W.L. Wright residence on Hempstead Turnpike, between Cherry Valley Avenue and

The Skelly Oil Company reported in its thirty-first annual statement, issued today by William G. Skelly, president, a net income of $28,514,066 after all charges and taxes. This is equal to $1O.91 a share on 2,611,871 shares outstanding, and compares with the 1949 net of $26,186,500, or $10.02 a share.

Miss Denise Lawson-Johnston gave a tea yesterday afternoon in her home, 1088 Park Avenue, for a group of young women serving with her in behalf of the annual entertainment, known as Salute to Summer, to be held on May 25 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of Memorial Cancer Center.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 14 --The protection of the Fifth Amendment, which makes it impossible to force a witness to incriminate himslef, probably will be sought by eight Hollywood figures subpoenaed by the House UnAmerican Activities Committee, it was learned today from their attorney, Robert W. Kenny.

A proposal for conserving strategic petals by using "clad" steel has been put before the National Production Authority, the Munitions Board and the Atomic Energy Commission by the Lukens Steel Company.

The testimony of Frank Costello, gambler, before the Senate crime inquiry in this city is being turned over to the Department of Justice for possible perjury action, Chairman Kefauver said yesterday. Costello reluctantly disclosed he had up to $55,000 in cash at home and about $100,000 in the bank.

Poke-checking with a deftness that is seldom seen in current National Hockey League competition, the Toronto Maple Leafs subdued the New York Rangers, 3--1, at Madison Square Garden last night. The visitors tallied a goal a period and permitted the New Yorkers to score one late in the game.

Stocks of gasoline rose last week to a new peak for the third time in succession, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they amounted to 139,056,000 barrels, an increase of 847,000 over the 138,209,000 a week earlier. They were 135,284,000 barrels a year ago.
WASHINGTON, March 14--Re publicans and Southern Democrats combined today in the House of Representatives to reject consideration of the Administration's defense housing bill.

Regarded as definite threats to reach the last round, unseeded Dayton and Seton Hall will attempt to continue their giant-killing operations tonight in the National Invitation college basketball tournament semi-finals at Madison
PRINCETON, N.J., March 14-- Nobel Prize winners and other renowned figures in physics and mathematics attended an extraordinary luncheon gathering here today.
Marc Connelly's Pulitzer Prize comedy of two decades ago, "The Green Pastures," will be revived this evening at the Broadway Theatre. The curtain will rise at 8 o'clock.

ALBANY, March 14--The Fashion Institute of Technology and Design in New York City's Needle Trades High School would become one of the state's new community colleges under a bill approved unanimously by the Assembly today and sent to the Senate.
Fourteen hundred prime contracts for defense production work have been signed with manufacturers in the greater New York area by officials of the New York Ordnance District.

NEW DELHI, India, March 14-- Some idea of how the average Indian peasant lives is contained in a report released today by the Ministry of Labor on a survey of conditions in a typical village of Vandalur in Madras State.

ARTHUR KOESTLER has said that "The Burned Bramble,"* an impressive and eyeopening novel of European communism in the Nineteen Thirties, by Manes Sperber, is a work of exceptional depth and scope. It is all of that. Particularly since the scope is wide enough to make exceedingly timely reading for Americans today.

TOKYO, Thursday, March 15-- United Nations troops yesterday reoccupied Seoul. The old capital of the Korean Republic was abandoned without a fight by the Chinese and North Korean invaders now in full retreat all along the Korean front.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 14-- The international division of Stanford Research Institute will undertake an extensive industrial survey and analysis of Italy's mechanical industries, Dr. J. E. Hohson, director, announced today.

An Alaska moose squeaked by on a margin of a quarter of an inch to win first prize over another in the Third Annual North American Big Game Competition of the Boone and Crockett Club, which last night awarded its coveted medals and citations to hunters from all parts of the country.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., March 14--Sam A. Lewisohn, noted industrialist, who was one' of America's foremost collectors of modern art, died here of a heart attack last night. He was 66 years old. His wife, Mrs. Margaret Seligman Lewisohn, was at his bedside when he was stricken at the Biltmore Hotel cottage which they had occupied for several months.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 14-- President Truman declared today that this country and its allies would rearm to the utmost in the face of continuing threats of aggression, but he left the door wide open for any honest proposal for world disarmament.
New enamels and finishes are available for the special refurbishing jobs associated with spring housecleaning.

Senator Estes Kefauver was chosen yesterday as the recipient of the Newspaper Guild of New York's annual Page One Award in public affairs. At a luncheon in the Tavern on the Green restaurant, guild judges also selected award winners in several other fields.

An additional company is being formed by the Metropolitan Opera Association to present one opera-- the successful production of Johann Strauss' "Die Fledermaus." This unit will tour the United States, beginning in September, during the fall and winter of 19511952.

ALBANY, March 14--Seattle University, making its first appearance in the National Catholic Invitation tourney, staved off a last-minute rush by long of New Rochelle and gained the semifinals with a 69-67 victory.

Construction of a $3,500,000 garage for 1,200 cars at the Manhattan approach to the Queensboro Bridge is being considered by the Parking Authority, Arthur S. Hodgkiss, its general manager, said yesterday.

LONDON, March 14 (AP)--Lincoln Kilby is flying back to the United States tonight from a grass-roots survey of Britain with a suitcase full of notes and an idea that the world would improve if common men could be more influential in it.
WASHINGTON, March 14--A citizens advisory committee on education recommended today a national expenditure of $14,040,000,000 for a half million new classrooms in the next ten years.
TAMPA, Fla., March 14 (AP)-- The official baseball rules committee today voted to retain the balk rule and called for absolute enforcement in 1951.

Rudolf Bing, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, called together all the singers and conductors of the company for a private meeting yesterday and appealed to them, and through them, to their union, the American Guild of Musical Artists, to give the company priority in appearing in recordings of its productions.
WASHINGTON, March 14-- An enemy attack on New York would find the Coast Guard short-handed in protecting the harbor against vessels that might try to sneak in with atomic bombs and weapons.

WASHINGTON, March 14--Sean MacBride, Irish Minister for External Affairs, declared today that Ireland had refused a bid to join the North Atlantic pact because any Government that entered into a military alliance with Britain would be immediately "driven from office."
The United Nations ground offensive continued virtually unopposed Wednesday as enemy forces attempted tactical disengagement all across the Korean front.

LONDON, March 14--Britain today accused a second naturalized citizen of having acted as a paid secret agent of the Communist Czechoslovak Government in supplying reports to Prague on political exiles in London.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 14-- The Israell Government has decided to ask the United States for a grant in aid of $150,000,000 and a formal request is expected to be submitted to the State Department by Israel's Ambassador in Washington, Abba S. Eban, tomorrow or Friday.

The Sugar Act of 1948 has proved effective in stabilizing prices of sugar at fair levels for all branches of the industry, according to William H. Doherty, Washington representative of the Hawaiian Sugar Planters' Association.

Despite the Government's allocation and control order, tin futures on the Commodity Exchange continued to move forward yesterday. Final prices were 125 to 225 points, or 1 to 214 cents, up in total transactions of 130 tons.

BOLOGNA, Italy, Feb. 26--For the last four weeks the local leaders of the Italian Communist party have devoted themselves exclusively to the task of stemming the deviationist movement started by the sensational resignations, at the end of January, of the two Communist Deputies, Valdo Magnani and Aldo Cucchi.

PARIS, March 14--Former Premier Edouard Herriot, veteran Radical party leader, won a victory today when the executive committee of his group adopted a motion forbidding party members to adhere to the movement of Gen. Charles de Gaulle.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (U.P.) --Earl Browder, former Communist leader, was acquitted of Congressional contempt charges today when a Federal Judge agreed that he was within his rights in refusing to answer irrelevant questions of a Senate investigating subcommittee.

Less than forty years ago March 15 in American lives was just another day at the dead end of winter. Nobody filled out income tax returns, for there was no federal income tax on individuals in the land. Four or five states had individual income tax laws--in Virginia, in 1911, the tax raised the handsome total of about $128,000.
W. Alton Jones, president of the Cities Service Company, called for a moratorium on restrictive legislation during the emergency yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 14--Kentucky's vacant seat in the United States Senate will be filled soon by Representative Thomas R. Underwood, Democrat, according to trustworthy Washington sources who have discussed the matter with Gov. Lawrence W. Wetherby.

A sometimes amusing confusion of anthropology and love, of South Sea island folkways and straight hula-hula romance has been gaudily thrown together by Twentieth Century-Fox in a remake of Richard Walton Tulley's old play, "Bird of Paradise."

ALBANY, March 14 (AP)--The Legislature, which intends to legalize Horse race licensing procedures, probably will follow this emergency action by a detailed investigation of all racing laws and regulations.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 14--Actually, Wilmer Mizell doesn't live in Vinegar Bend at all. He hails from the thriving metropolis of Leakesville, Miss. (Pop. 1,500.) "But Vinegar Bend is where I gets mah mail," he drawled. "Shucks, that's all they got there, only a postoffice. They ain't got more'n 75 or 100 population."

PARIS, March 15 (Reuters)-- Canada overwhelmed the United States, 16--2, in the world ice hockey championships tonight to move into second place in Group A --one point behind Sweden--but with one game to play. The Americans remained in fifth place.

The Southern Pacific Company had a consolidated net income last year of $54,227,774 after charges and taxes, equal to $13.38 each on the 4,052,117 capital shares outstanding, according to the sixtyseventh annual report.

Although Richard B. Harrison has gone to his reward, "The Green Pastures" remains green, disarming and moving. William Marshall plays the Lawd in the beautiful new production which opened at the Broadway last evening.

ALBANY, March 15--Comicbook publishers were warned today by a legislative committee that unless immediate steps were taken to eliminate objectionable comics, the Legislature would attempt regulation in the field.
JERSEY CITY, March 15--Dr. Leon Banach, a physician who was prominent in Republican politics, died last night in the Berthold S. Pollak Hospital for Chest Diseases. He resided at 2778 Boulevard.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP)-- A special force of revenue agents is making an intensive investigation of tax returns by racketeers involving $57,000,000 in takes and penalties.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 15-- President Getulio Vargas, in his first message to Congress in his new term, today pledged Brazil to military and economic collaboration with the democratic nations, especially of the Western Hemisphere.

BUENOS AIRES, March 15-- Both houses of the Argentine Congress have been called into special session tomorrow to take up the matter of La Prensa, independent newspaper closed as the result of a boycott by the Government-dominated news venders' union since Jan. 26.

The Netherlands has solved its weekslong Cabinet crisis in a way that does credit to the country. The major parties have now agreed to support a new Administration with a program that is courageous and far-sighted.

WASHINGTON, March 15--John S. Wise Jr., one of a long line of lawyers and member of a family well known in Virginia history, died of a heart ailment early today at Bethesda Naval Hospital. His age was 75.

The Mayor's Committee on Unity paid tribute yesterday to Edward Lazansky, its former acting chairman, for "listinguished service" in furthering the committee's goal of obtaining better relations between raci-1 and religious groups in New York City.

WASHINGTON, March 15--The Senate probably will have Frank Costello arrested as soon as the Kefauver Committee requests such action to force his reappearance before the crime hearings in New York City.

Victor de Sabata made his first guest appearance of the season with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall. The qualities of his conducting which have been observed in the past were paramount.

A new opera from Italy, Luigi Dallapiccola's "The Prisoner," had its first performance in America at the Juilliard School last night. In the course of its fifty minutes it compresses much of the terror that has haunted countless thousands in the tyranny that our own age has learned to know so well.

A sales gain of more than $17,350,000 was made last year by the Borden Company through higher output of goods at lower selling prices, but earnings declined 8 per cent under the impact of heavier taxes.

MINEOLA, L.L., March 15--A I rift between Robert Moses and the Nassau County Transit Commission over the issue of whether the Long Island Rail Road should be placed under a public authority came out in the open here today with the announcement of Mr. Moses' resignation as adviser to the commission.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 15-- President Truman defended today his conduct as an office holder, praised his staff as honorable men and expressed the hope that in the perspective of history he would be remembered as an apostle of peace who had prevented World War III.

The toy rabbit clan and their barnyard friends, each one exhibiting its personality, are available in toy shops in a variety of sizes, poses and costumes.
The Navy sent out a special call yesterday for bandsmen, particularly clarinetists, oboists, flutists, saxophonists, and players on the French horn, piccolo and bassoon.

In a letter which may be read as an indirect appeal to both the Soviet Government and the Soviet peoples to join in efforts to build world peace, Secretary Acheson has endorsed a concurrent resolution now before Congress outlining anew the purposes of American foreign policy.

Mayor Impellitteri has ordered James J. Moran to quit his $15,000-a-year, life-tenure post as a Commissioner of the Board of Water Supply by noon today or face immediate suspension pending the filing of formal removal charges.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 21--When rain washed out the scheduled game between the Giants and Reds today, Owner Horace Stoneham and Manager Leo Durocher put their heads together with the idea of improving and tightening their battlefront for the 1951 pennant campaign.

WASHINGTON, March 21--A powerful Senate group, including the Democratic floor leader and Eastern Republicans, moved tonight to leave President Truman all but a free hand in sending American troops to Europe.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)-- Weapons for destroying enemy submarines--a top priority project of the Navy--now include new targetseeking torpedoes and special plane-launched rockets.

GRAND RAPIDS, March 21-- Howell H. Ridley, 52 years old, of Grand Rapids, former vice president of Blair Rollins Co., Chicago investment banking concern, admitted irregularities in handling securities for Blair Rollins clients, O. McMahon said today.

GENEVA, March 20--It is now common knowledge in diplomatic circles that both the British and French Governments are increasingly worried about the possibility that the United States might make a unilateral pledge to rearm Spain and privately promise to use its influence to gain for that country admission to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
The United Nations ground offensive in Korea continued Wednesday with our forward elements meeting only local hostile reaction.

PARIS, Thursday, March 22-- Increasing numbers of railway workers were idle today as the result of a call for a nation-wide rail strike for forty-eight hours beginning at midnight last night, issued by the Socialist Workers Force.

A weary band of Senate crime investigators left for Washington last evening after eight exciting days of open hearing here in the New York Federal Courthouse. They will resume at 10 A.M. today in the nation's capital.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 2l.--The Transport and Communications Commission decided today to give high priority to the problem of unification of maritime tonnage measurement.
WASHINGTON, March 21(AP)-- Announced United States combat casualties in Korea rose today to 55,814, an increase of 1,165 since last week.
The Los Angeles Department of Water and Power announced yesterday that it will receive bids May 15 on an issue of $10,000,000 of revenue bonds.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (UP) --The Government will begin rationing steel, copper and aluminum on July 1 under a controlled materials program aimed at assuring supplies of the metals for defense and essential civilian production, it was disclosed today.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 21--A formula for allocations under the United States "single aid" program will be worked out in negotiations starting next Tuesday between the Netherlands Government and United States officials.
Peter Phillis, store for a luncheonette in 1146 Madison Ave, through C. G. Nicholson--Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., broker.
With the city's water reserves at 99.5 per cent of capacity, the city wiped out yesterday the last of the water use restrictions imposed to bring about savings during the shortage of 1949-50.

The Tea Bureau,Inc.,announced a summer-long campaign yesterday in which Iceman's Ice and Sunkist Lemons will join with the $550,000 tea campaign to promote the beverage in which all three combine--iced tea.

BACK in the old days the only exercise a baseball player took during the winter offseason was to hoist a flagon of beer from a table to his lips. It didn't even develop the muscles of his hoisting arm and what it did to the rest of him was a caution.

Clarence Francis, chairman of the board of General Foods Corporation, yesterday committed that important segment of the food industry to a "bold" program of advertising, research, development and expansion of sales and the development of new products.

High school pupils of the nation are dropping out this spring at a much faster rate than a year ago. Expectation of draft, greater employment opportunities and increased student restlessness have brought about the downward trend.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, March 21 (AP)--American stars gained three berths in the men's singles semi-finals, one place in the women's singles final, and one position in the women's doubles final in the Alexandria international tennis tournament today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 21 --A Yankee specialty, the homerun, boomeranged the champions into their third straight defeat here today before 7,827 fans.

The nation's gasoline stocks increased last week 1,615,000 barrels to a new peak of 140,671,000, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A week earlier, they amounted to 139,056,000 barrels and they were 135,052,000 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, March 21-- Economy forces, after scoring a series of limited victories, sustained major setbacks in the House of Representatives today as a $2,918,827,000 appropriations bill was passed and sent to the Senate.

The Commerce and Industry Association of New York warned yesterday that any further cut in funds for the Bureau of Customs would have a drastic effect on New York, which handles a major share of the country's imports and the bulk of its passenger business.

WASHINGTON, March 21--Dr. John R. Steelman, assistant to President Truman, was "frozen out" in a proposal made today for settlement of the two-year-old dispute between the nation's railroads and the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen.

The Detroit Red Wings yielded the first goal in the National Hockey League game against the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night. That was all they permitted the Blue Shirts to tally. CHICAGO March 21--Trade in grain futures was unusually tight on the Board of Trade here today, with the markets showing an easy undertone, especially in the late trading when scattered liquidation developed in March wheat, corn and oats.

The danger of famine in India is approaching its critical stage. The most serious situation is in Bihar state, where winter crops have failed, but other areas are also threatened. The Indian Government is doing what it can, but is seriously limited by the basic food deficit in the country.

WASHINGTON, March 21--Eric Johnston, Economic Stabilization. Administrator, was reported today to be trying to arrange a conference of labor, management and public representatives as a prelude to setting up a new disputes board.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 21--A delegation of labor leaders charged here today that persons of the Jewish faith in the Soviet Union and its satellites were being subjected to "cultural and spiritual genocide."

The Sherman Anti-Trust Act is no umbrella to shield small business from the hazards of competition in a free and open market, Judge Harold R. Medina was told in Federal Court yesterday by Government counsel in a colloquy over the effect of public sealed bidding on the distribution of business among underwriters.

JESSELTON, North Borneo, March 21--This new British Crown Colony embracing 30,000 square miles of the northern panhandle of Borneo Island is slowly casting off all vestiges of control by the last of Britain's big empire-building chartered companies.

WASHINGTON, March 21-- Withdrawal by President Truman of his plan to reorganize the Reconstruction Finance Corporation pending Congressional consideration of broader reforms was advocated today at key points as Senators began study of the White House proposal.

Sales of J.P. Stevens Co., Inc., for the first six months of its current fiscal year probably will exceed those of a year ago, Robert T. Stevens, board chairman, told stockholders attending the annual meeting here yesterday.
