Relief for traffic congestion in mid-Manhattan received token Federal aid yesterday when a drive-up mailbox was installed in front of the General Post Office on Eighth Avenue between Thirty-first and Thirty-third Streets.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) --The Air Force appears to be devising ways at the Eniwetok proving ground for getting through enemy interception and pinpointing targets with atomic bombs.

KANSAS CITY, March 21 (AP)-- Brigham Young University, striving for basketball's double crown, sputtered to a 68-61 victory over San Jose State tonight after Kansas State had scored a 61-59 triumph over Arizona. The two games opened the western N.C. A.A. play-offs.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (UP) --The Senate Crime Investigating Committee announced today that James J. Carroll, St. Louis betting commissioner, would testify here tomorrow under "Costello" television rules.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 21 (AP)--C.V. Whitney's unpredictable Mr. Trouble took it upon himself to do a bit of fancy running at Gulfstream Park today and as a result the temperamental colt racked ug his first victory of the Florida season.

A single, independent agency for control of export trade will be set up in Washington if the recommendations of the International Development Advisory Board are carried out, according to August Maffry, vice president of the Irving Trust Company.

The defense of three American citizens charged with wartime atomic espionage for Soviet Russia opened at 3:45 o'clock yesterday afternoon with Julius Rosenberg, the most important defendant, denying the Government's charges against him.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 21-- President Truman received from General of the Army George C. Marshall, Secretary of Defense, today the news that our armed forces now exceeded 2,900,000 men and women, having doubled since the outbreak of the Korean aggression June 25.

WASHINGTON, March 21--The Soviet Union notified the United States today that it "refuses to consider" the return of 670 ships turned over to Russia by this Government under the lend-lease agreement in World War II.

Neither schools nor information mediums are meeting fully their obligations to students and the adult community in the presentation and trustworthy interpretation of current events, according to opinions expressed yesterday in The New York Times Youth Forum.

HONG KONG, March 21-- Twenty-one persons--six Europeans, one Japanese and fourteen Chinese--have been arrested by the public security bureau of Tientsin on charges of working for an alleged American "underground espionage organization" there.

A twenty-two-acre tract in the Bergen County Industrial Terminal in Teterboro, N.J., has been purchased by the Ford Motor Company for the construction of a service parts depot and sales offices for its Ford and LincolnMercury divisions.
Chuck Hunter of Cleveland gained the unanimous verdict over Jimmy Beau, 21-year-old New Canaan, Conn., fighter, in their tenround bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 21--One of the gravest dangers to the security of the Federal Republic and to the proper functioning of the Allied defense forces in an emergency is the presence of more than 5,000 trained Communist political agents in West Germany.

LAKE SUCCESS, March 21-- Britain and the United States today jointly submitted still another formula for settlement of the three-year-old dispute between India and Pakistan over the Princely State of Kashmir.

The National Academy of Design will open its 126th annual exhibition of oils, sculpture, watercolors and graphic work with a reception and preview tonight in the Academy Galleries, at which a long list of prizes and awards will be announced and presented.

Legislation is being sought to provide civilian benefits for crews who serve aboard Governmentowned vessels even though these men are considered to be employes of the Government, it was learned yesterday.

The merchant marine and the Navy made a friendly exchange of citations yesterday to cement their alliance as joint arms of national defense.

TRENTON, March 21--A cigar salesman whose car was parked in front of William Horner's secondhand furniture store when the elderly shopkeeper was murdered here three years ago testified today that he had seen two Negroes leave the place just before Mr. Horner's wife, Elizabeth, called for help.
The plan of an $18,000,000 housing project in the Bronx to be known as Bronxdale Houses was approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission at City Hall.

BOSTON, March 21 (UP)--Johnny Peirson fired an eighteen-foot shot into the Chicago net late in the final period tonight to give the Bruins a 6-to-5 victory and put them into the National Hockey League's Stanley Cup play-offs before 8,094 Boston Garden fans.

This community must thank the Senate Crime Investigating Committee for an entertaining, enlightening and disturbing week. The diverse parade of witnesses certainly proved that it takes all kinds to make a world and that we have most of them in New York City.
WASHINGTON, March 21--The formation of a political general staff to coordinate and direct United States policy in the Cold War is being seriously considered at the highest levels of the Government.

WASHINGTON, March 21--The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows the following principal charges for the week ended March 14, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The first concentrated citrus juices that do not require refrigeration will be introduced here by Clinton Foods, Inc., early next month. Double strength orange, grapefruit and a blend of the two juices are to be packaged under the brand name of "Tou-cans."

The American Fund for Israel Institutions held its tenth annual dinner-meeting and concert last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in honor of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra, which has just completed its first American tour.

The New York County Medical Society has made plans to go into television with what will be, provided all goes as foreseen, one of the greatest efforts to reach the American people that medicine has ever undertaken.

NEWARK, March 21--An electronically directed system of automatic control of the speed of locomotives was demonstrated today to three members of the Board of Public Utility Commissioners who have been investigating the Pennsylvania Railroad wreck at Woodbridge on Feb. 6.

ALBANY, March 21--The preliminary stage of development of New York'S State University was completed today with the signing by Governor Dewey of a bill establishing a permanent Board of Trustees for the 3-year-old institution.

Governor Dewey declined yesterday to comment on gambling in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., until his counsel had studied testimony about the subject already presented to the Senate Crime Investigating Committee.

The National City Bank of New York raised salaries 10 per cent yesterday in an "across the board" move covering all employes and staff members. The action is believed certain to be followed by similar salary adjustments by other large downtown banks.

MOSCOW, March 21--Pravda took occasion today to reiterate that at the basis of Soviet policy is the "desire for achievement of peaceful co-existence and business collaboration" of the Communist and capitalist systems.

ALBANY, March 21--Governor Dewey today signed into law a bill doubling the maximum prison sentence for persons who bribe or offer to bribe professional or amateur athletes to "throw" a sports contest.

Felicja Blumenthal, Polish pianist, gave her first New York recital last night in Town Hall. She was heard somewhat at a disadvantage because she had programmed works that were a little beyond her fingers.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 21-- The four-and-a-half-week session of the United Nations Economic and Social Council came to a close this afternoon with a final attack on the United States by the Soviet bloc regarding United States policy toward Spain.

When the transport Gen. G.M. Randall steams through the Golden Gate today into the harbor of San Francisco she will bring with her the first of the American dead to come back from Korean battlefields.

The semi-finals in the Eastern Regionals of the thirteenth annual National Collegiate A.A. basketball championship will send St. John's of Brooklyn (25-4) against Kentucky (29-2) and Illinois (20-3) against North Carolina. State (29-5) tonight at Madison Square Garden.

Theatrical Protective Union No. 1, the stagehands' organization, threatened to take "drastic action" yesterday against the League of New York Theatres for its alleged failure to live up to a recent agreement.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., March 21--An untrue, but widespread, report that the Red Cross has been charging soldiers in Korea for blood is seriously hampering the blood donor and fund-raising programs of the organization in Nassau County.

The University of Pennsylvania's football team is being shunned like the poison itch by other Ivy League colleges. The situation has brought forth bitterness and some unanswered questions within the group, which includes also Yale, Harvard, Princeton, Columbia, Cornell, Dartmouth and Brown Universities.

The military manpower bill-- universal military service and the modified draft--that will be considered by the House of Representatives after the Easter recess has become, in some major respects, a military abortion that may handicap rather than held national defense.

Support of the radio industry's case for color television, the allelectronic compatible type, was reiterated here last night by Robert C. Sprague, president of the Radio-Television Manufacturers Association.

"Festival of Opera," a transcribed weekly series featuring the orchestra and chorus of Radio Italiana, will make its debut over WOR Saturday afternoon from 1 to 3:30 o'clock with a performance of Rossini's "Barber of Seville."

TOKYO, Thursday, March 22-- United States tanks yesterday rolled into Chunchon, less than eight miles south of the Thirtyeighth Parallel. The city, once the big advance base of the Communist invaders, had been abandoned by the enemy and was occupied without a shot.

La Prensa has finally been taken over by the Argentine Government. The plant has been sealed, the books seized, the loyal employes dispersed and the publisher, Dr. Alberto Gainza Paz, to be jailed for contempt of Congress, cannot enter the building without the permission of a Congressional committee appointed to "intervene."

OTTAWA, March 21 (Canadian Press)--Railway freight rate increases on some hauls between Canada and the United States and other international traffic were authorized today by the Board of Transport Commissioners.

Total assets of New York State chartered banking institutions rose more than $1,000,000,000 last year to a total of $21,600,000,000 the highest figure ever registered on a consolidated balance sheet according to the year-end figures issued yesterday by William A Lyon, Superintendent of Banks.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 21 (AP)--"Dacron" is the new trademark adopted by E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. for its polyester fiber. The fiber originally was known by the laboratory designation of Fiber V and later given the trade-mark "Amilar."

A program for joint Government and industry cooperation in studying "chemicals-in-foods" problems was proposed yesterday. At the annual meeting of the Commercial Chemical Development Association at the Roosevelt Hotel, Isaac Fogg, president of the Atlas Powder Company, Wilmington, Del., said ...
GOSHEN, N.Y., March 21 (AP)-- Even trotting horses are going to have their hall of fame.
The question whether Gerardo Anastasia, younger brother of Albert Anastasia, is an American citizen was highly debatable yesterday in the Brooklyn Federal Building.

WASHINGTON, March 21-- Larry Parks, motion picture actor, admitted today that he once belonged to the Communist party but two other Hollywood players-- Howard Da Silva and Gale Sondergaard--refused to testify to possible Red activities on the ground that it might incriminate them.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)-- Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican of Michigan, said today the Communists had set up rigid new "loyalty" standards for Red agents assigned to infiltrate Federal agencies and America's defense plants.

Nelson A. Rockefeller, chairman of the International Development Advisory Board, said yesterday that economic cooperation with underdeveloped areas of foreign countries was a necessity at this time for the United States.

CHICAGO, March 21--With sales exceeding $2,500,000,000 and net income of $143,500,000, Sears, Roebuck Co. placed fifth in sales among American corporations in 1950 and among the top eight in profits. Sales and profits were the highest in the company's history.

John P. Crane, president of the Uniformed Firemen's Association, testified yesterday before the Senate Crime Investigating Committee, that he had given former Mayor William O'Dwyer $10,000 on the porch of the Gracie Mansion on Oct. 12, 1949, presumably for use in Mr. O'Dwyer's campaign for re-election.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, March 21 (AP)--The Foreign Ministry announced today United StatesDanish talks would begin here next week to decide how Greenland could best be defended.

NEW HAVEN, March 21 (AP)-- A noted Southern editor said today that the South "should be able to work out its interracial problem in a satisfactory manner if it is not "pushed too hard by well-intentioned ...

ALBANY, March 21--Governor Dewey vetoed today a bill that would have permitted the depositing of county funds in a bank of which the county treasurer was an officer or stockholder on the ground that it was "impractical and undesirable."

LONDON, March 21--Britain reaffirmed today her vital interest in the independence, integrity and security of Iran where martial law has been proclaimed because of disturbances accompanying a campaign to nationalize British oil interests there.

BUENOS AIRES, March 21--An order for the arrest of the publisher of La Prensa, Dr. Alberto Gainza Paz, was issued tonight by the joint Congressional committee that yesterday took over the independent newspaper's main building. Dr. Gainza Paz was charged with contempt of Congress and received a fifteen-day jail sentence.
WASHINGTON, March 21-- Frederick Vanderbilt Field, New York millionaire accused of Communist connections, was freed today of contempt-of-Congress charges by Federal Judge T. Alan Goldsborough.
ALBANY, March 21, (UP)--Six up-state winter resorts reported good skiing conditions today, according to the State Department of Commerce.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., had a net income of $128,216,683 last year after charges and taxes, equal to $4.03 a share, according to the company's pamphlet report for 1950. This compared with $98,329,305, or $3.09 a share, in 1949.
LONDON, March 21 (Reuters) --Canada tonight trounced the United States, 5--0, in the opener of a three-game international tournament for a new hockey trophy-- the Winston Churchill Cup.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)-- Following is the text of Secretary of State Dean Acheson's letter to Senator Tom Connally, Democrat of Texas, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, in support of a resolution expressing friendship to Russians and other peoples.
Tom Hamilton, chairman of the N.C.A.A. television steering committee, said here yesterday, The Associated Press reported, that he expected considerable live television of football games next fall.

Baked ham for Easter is as traditional as the lily or a gay new bonnet. It is regal fare at any time. But dressed up for Easter with garnishes of fruits, "flowers" or colored eggs--those unmistakable symbols of spring--it is a festive holiday dish.

Arturo Toscanini, who will be 84 years old on Sunday, has agreed to conduct the majority of the N.B.C. Symphony broadcast concerts for the 1951-52 season, the National Broadcasting Company announced yesterday.

RALPH INGERSOLL'S "Wine of Violence" is one of those quaint and old-fashioned, pre "From Here to Eternity" novels of Army life that people used to write before the appearance of James Jones' startling, sweeping, saturnine gripes of wrath.

Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, sent a letter yesterday to Senator Estes Kefauver, chairman of the Crime Investigating Committee, protesting that he and his organization had been treated unfairly in connection with testimony about conditions on the New York waterfront.

WASHINGTON, March 21--Secretary of State Dean Acheson, scanning recent developments in world affairs, found today that the Western position was stronger in both Europe and the Far East than it had been a year ago.

KARACHI, Pakistan, March 21 --Prime Minister Liaquat Ali Khan told Parliament today that the arrest of the chief of the general staff and others on March 9 had nipped a plot to bring Pakistan under a Communist government administered by a military dictatorship.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)-- A House subcommittee trying to ferret out tax evasions charted today an inquiry on whether big tax firms are able to exercise influence to protect clients from investigation.

Allen B. Du Mont Laboratories, Inc. will reduce production of television receivers and related electronic parts on Monday, Dr. Allen B. Du Mont, president, announced yesterday. He did not reveal the extent of the cutback but said the East Paterson, N.J., manufacturing plant would operate on a fourday, instead of a five-day week.

WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)-- Simon H. Rifkind of New York, former Federal district judge, expressed opposition today to a proposed revision of United States immigration laws on the ground it was "restrictive and racially discriminatory."

WASHINGTON, March 21-- Secretary of State Dean Acheson urged Congress today to pass a resolution declaring the friendship of the American people for those of the Soviet Union. Resolutions to this effect have been introduced in the Senate and the House of Representatives.
CHICAGO, March 21--Frank A. Chambers, head of the Chicago Department of Smoke Inspection and Abatement, died of a virus infection today in his home. He was 66 years old.

WASHINGTON, March 21-- Chairman Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, of the Senate Crime Investigating Committee said tonight the question of conflicting testimony by Ambassador William O'Dwyer and another witness would be brought to "a very quick conclusion."
The term of the special grand jury investigating organized gambling and police corruption in Brooklyn was extended yesterday by Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz is Kings County Court for another six months.

PARIS, March 21--The three Western deputies today declared "unacceptable" the proposal that Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko, their Soviet colleague, offered yesterday as a compromise for the agenda they have been trying now for nearly three weeks to prepare as the basis for a Council of Foreign Ministers conference.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 2 to 10 points lower yesterday on the new-crop months, while March, May and July were at the ceiling bid of 45.39 cents.

Albert Anastasia, the 47-year-old gangster who was described in testimony before the Senate crime committee open hearings as the official executioner for criminals operating in this area, hardly agreed with this description when he appeared before the committee in closed session last month.

MIAMI, March 21--A superlative six-inning pitching job by Chris Van Cuyk was nullified in two innings by Ray Moore tonight as the Phils hopped on the rookie righthander for all their runs in two innings to beat the Dodgers, 5--3.

Vito J. Guariglia, Ben Quarino and Marc A. Caccavo have sold the bathing establishment at Coney Island on West Thirty-sixth Street, between Surf Avenue and the Boardwalk, to Lenday Baths, Inc., represented by David Leavenworth, attorney.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (UP) --Senator Margaret Chase Smith, Republican of Maine, said today that "someone" has lied to the Senate subcommittee investigating the 1950 Maryland Senatorial campaign.

Emerging from a New York County grand jury room after testifying for two hours and forty minutes, Ambassador William O'Dwyer "flatly denied" yesterday he had received $10,000 incash from John P. Crane, president of the Uniformed Firemen's Association.

The district leaders of Tammany Hall turned off their television sets last evening, sadder but not much more informed. For eight days they had joined the rest of New York's adult population in viewing the Kefauver committee "show," but to them much of the information was stale.
WASHINGTON, March 21--Organized labor demanded today that Congress immediately consider a new Defense Production Act to replace the one expiring June 30.

Theodore Temple Knappen of Old Westbury, L.I., internationally known civil and hydraulic engineer, senior partner of the Knappen Tippetts Abbett Engineering Company, died Tuesday in New York, after a brief illness. His age was 50.

HONG KONG, March 21--Communist China and India have negotiated a barter agreement under which 50,000 tons of Chinese rice are to be exchanged for 16,500 bales of Indian gunnybags, the Peiping radio disclosed tonight.

Bernard Newman brought an air of daintiness and delicacy to his ready-to-wear designs shown yesterday at Bergdorf Goodman. A particularly skilled designer for the smaller woman, Mr. Newman scales his elegant little suits and flowing skirted chiffons perfectly for this type of figure.

WASHINGTON, March 21--A reorganization plan under which the Eastern Utilities Associates, Boston, would substitute a single operating-holding company for its present holding company system, was submitted to the Securities and Exchange Commission today ...

Michael Pressman, a "primitive" artist who began to paint pictures based on Bible stories and remembrances of his youth at the ages of 84, died yesterday at the home that he shared with his son, Dr. Benjamin J. Pressman, a dentist, at 215 East 164th Street, the Bronx. Mr. Pressman would have been 87 years old next month.

NEWARK, March 21--Twentyeight young artillerymen, on their last leave before going overseas, were finally airborne late tonight on their way back to their California camp after a mix-up in charter plane schedules that had delayed them more than twenty-four hours.

While such traditional Easter fare as ham, eggs and lamb are no higher this Friday than last, fresh produce is more costly, largely because of the brisk holiday demand.
ALBANY, March 22--Governor Dewey left the door wide open today for possible removal proceedings against New York City officials who have been identified as associates of underworld leaders.

WASHINGTON, March 22--Efforts by Senator James E. Murray, Democrat of Montana, to settle the two-year-old dispute between the railroads and the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen collapsed today when the carriers rejected a union proposal.

WASHINGTON, March 22--The Department of Defense moved today to decentralize the Munitions Board, top agency dealing with military production and construction requirements, and the stockpiling of critical war materials.

LONDON, March 22--George Bernard Shaw's will published today showed that although he was a Socialist in principle he was a very successful capitalist in practice. He accumulated more money than any other British writer in history, perhaps more than any other writer of any nationality.

WASHINGTON, March 22-- New credits of $288,700,000 were extended during the last six months of 1950, the Export-Import Bank of Washington disclosed in its eleventh semi-annual report to Congress today.

The Southern Railway and its affiliated companies reduced their funded debt, including equipment obligations, by $10,984,440 last year, according to the road's fiftyseventh annual report. At the year-end total funded debt of the system was $286,434,540.

ST. LOUIS, March 22--A Circuit Court grand jury gave up an effort today to link James J. Carroll and other "big wheels" with a recently raided handbook operation.

PARIS, March 22--A substantial wage increase for employes of both nationalized and private industries appeared certain tonight when the National Collective Bargaining Board, represent ing unions, employers and the Government, decided that the cost of living had risen 12.5 per cent since last August.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (UP) --The Defense Department said today it would begin meeting its manpower commitments to General of the Army Douglas MacArthur next month and simultaneously revealed that it hoped soon to discharge all Inactive Reservists.

CHICAGO, March 22--Closing out of March wheat, corn and oats contracts failed to have much effect today on the deferred months as the open interest was relatively small. March wheat finished cent higher, corn 7/8 cent higher and oats 1 to 1 cents lower.

The three unsalaried members of the City Parking Authority submitted their resignations yesterday to Mayor Impellitteri. The resignations are effective April 1 when the agency will be dis banded and its skeleton staff returned to other civil service posts.

WASHINGTON, March 22--The Government of Israel asked the United States today for $150,000,000 in grant-in-aid for the period of July 1, 1951, to June 30, 1952, Abba S. Eban, Israel's Ambassador to Washington announced.

LOS ANGELES, March 22 (AP)-- Judy Garland divorced Vincente Minnelli, movie director, today with testimony that he "secluded himself and wouldn't explain why he would be away and leave me alone so much."

An engrossing performance of Massenet's "Manon" was given by the New York City Opera Company last night in the City Center of Opera and Drama. This was the first performance of the work by this singularly intelligent and spirited company, and the only new production of its present season.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP)-- The State Department has advised Congress that travel of Soviet officials in this country will be restricted whenever it is evident that such action is in the over-all interest of the United States.
